This strategy, proven to be general, paves the way for designing efficient red/NIR phosphorescent materials through the DET mechanism, enabling their applications in molecular imaging and advanced high‚Äêtemperature encryption.

item.title: Photopolymer Resins from Sulfenyl Chloride Commodity Chemicals for Plastic Optics, Photopatterning and 3D‚ÄêPrinting
item.content:encoded:
From oil refining to high refractive index photopolymers for bulk plastic optics. The synthesis of a new photopolymer resin derived from inexpensive sulfur petrochemicals is reported affording a high‚Äêquality optical glass that is amenable to a wide range of photopolymerization‚Äêbased fabricated methods, including 3D Printing, for precision plastic optics and micropatterned arrays.
Abstract The development of a low‚Äêcost photopolymer resin to fabricate optical glass of high refractive index for plastic optics is reported. This new free radically polymerizable photopolymer resin, termed, disulfide methacrylate resin (DSMR) is synthesized by the direct addition of allyl methacrylate to a commodity sulfur petrochemical, sulfur monochloride (S2Cl2). The rapid rates of free radical photopolymerization confer significant advantages in preparing high‚Äêquality, bulk optical glass. The low‚Äêcost, optical glass produced from this photopolymer possesses a desirable combination of high refractive index (n¬†‚âà¬†1.57‚Äì1.59), low birefringence (Œîn¬†<¬†10‚àí4), high glass transition values (Tg¬†‚âà¬†100¬†¬∞C), along with optical transparency rivaling, or exceeding that of poly(methyl methacrylate) (PMMA) as indicated by very low optical absorption coefficients (Œ±¬†<¬†0.05¬†cm‚àí1 at 1310¬†nm) measured for thick glass DSMR photopolymer samples (diameter (D)¬†=¬†25¬†mm; thickness¬†=¬†1‚Äì30¬†mm). The versatile manufacturability of DSMR photopolymers for both molding and diamond turn machining methods is demonstrated to prepare precision optics and nano‚Äêmicropatterned arrays. Finally, large‚Äêscale 3D printing vat photopolymerization of DSMR using high‚Äêarea rapid printing digital light processing additive manufacturing is demonstrated.

item.title: Leveraging Strong Electric Field Gradients at Anapole Resonances for Enhanced Second Harmonic Generation from Molybdenum Disulfide Disks
item.content:encoded:
In this work, molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) disks supporting combined anapole scattering and Fabry‚ÄêPerot resonances with not just strong electric field enhancement but also enhanced field gradients for application in resonant enhancement of second harmonic generation (SHG) are designed, fabricated, and experimentally studied. Some of the highest enhancement numbers reported for the case of the widely used 2H‚Äêpolytype of MoS2 are reported.
Abstract Van der Waals layered materials are emerging as promising nanophotonic platforms for realizing linear and nonlinear optical devices. In particular, the high refractive indices of transition metal dichalcogenides, combined with their strong layer dependent optical properties offer interesting possibilities for designing photonic functionalities. In this study, the resonant enhancement of second harmonic generation (SHG) using molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) disks on a silicon substrate with an intermediate silicon dioxide (SiO2) layer is demonstrated. The resonant enhancement observed here is attributed to the combined interaction of the anapole scattering modes supported within the disk and Fabry‚ÄêPerot (FP) modes within the multilayer stack. For a fixed MoS2 disk dimensions, an optimized SiO2 layer thickness results in constructive interference between the anapole and FP modes, thereby enhancing the fundamental field within the disk. Utilizing this resonance mechanism, SHG enhancements as high as 160 and 85‚Äêtimes are experimentally demonstrated when compared with unpatterned multilayer and monolayer MoS2 flakes respectively. These are the highest reported enhancement values for the widely used 2H‚Äêpolytype MoS2. A significant enhancement in SHG is observed here for 2H‚ÄêMoS2 despite the alternating sheet dipoles canceling the far‚Äêfield emission owing to the strong electric field gradient setup within the disk at the anapole resonance.

item.title: Hofmeister Effect‚ÄêEnhanced, Nanoparticle‚ÄêShielded, Thermally Stable Hydrogels for Anti‚ÄêUV, Fast‚ÄêResponse, and All‚ÄêDay‚ÄêModulated Smart Windows
item.content:encoded:
Smart windows with anti‚ÄêUV, fast‚Äêresponse, and thermally stable characteristics for all‚Äêday modulation are crafted, demonstrating appealing stability and durability for practical building energy‚Äêsaving applications.
Abstract Thermochromic smart windows offer energy‚Äêsaving potential through temperature‚Äêresponsive optical transmittance adjustments, yet face challenges in achieving anti‚ÄêUV radiation, fast response, and high‚Äêtemperature stability characteristics for long‚Äêterm use. Herein, the rational design of Hofmeister effect‚Äêenhanced, nanoparticle‚Äêshielded composite hydrogels, composed of hydroxypropylmethylcellulose (HPMC), poly(N,N‚Äêdimethylacrylamide) (PDMAA), sodium sulfate, and polydopamine nanoparticles, for anti‚ÄêUV, fast‚Äêresponse, and all‚Äêday‚Äêmodulated smart windows is reported. Specifically, a three‚Äêdimensional network of PDMAA is created as the supporting skeleton, markedly enhancing the thermal stability of pristine HPMC hydrogels. Sodium sulfate induces a Hofmeister effect, lowering the lower critical solution temperature to 32 ¬∞C while accelerating phase transition rates fivefold (30 s vs. 150 s). Intriguingly, small‚Äêsized polydopamine nanoparticles simultaneously enable high luminous transmittance of 66.9% and outstanding anti‚ÄêUV capability. Additionally, the smart window showcases a high solar modulation (51.2%) and maintains a 10.2 ¬∞C temperature reduction versus a glass window during all‚Äêday modulation applications. The design strategy is effective, opening up new avenues for manufacturing fast‚Äêresponse and durable thermochromic smart windows for energy savings and emission reduction.

item.title: Point Defects Enhance Cross‚ÄêPlane Thermal Conductivity In Graphite
item.content:encoded:
Point defects typically reduce thermal conductivity (Œ∫) by scattering heat‚Äêcarrying phonons. However, introducing spiro interstitials through particle irradiation in graphite surprisingly increases cross‚Äêplane Œ∫ from 10.8 to 18.9 W¬†m¬†K‚àí1 at room temperature. The scanning transmission electron microscope and first‚Äêprinciples calculations reveal that these defects bridge graphene planes, increasing group velocity while reducing phonon‚Äêphonon scattering, thereby enhancing cross‚Äêplane Œ∫ of graphite.
Abstract Point defects typically reduce the thermal conductivity (Œ∫) of a crystal due to increased scattering of heat‚Äêcarrying phonons, a mechanism that is well understood and widely used to enhance or impede heat transfer in the material for different applications. Here an opposite effect is reported where the introduction of point defects in graphite with energetic particle irradiation increases its cross‚Äêplane Œ∫ by nearly a factor of two, from 10.8 to 18.9 W¬†m¬†K‚àí1 at room temperature. Integrated differential phase contrast imaging with scanning transmission electron microscopy revealed the creation of spiro interstitials in graphite by the irradiation. The enhancement in Œ∫ is attributed to a remarkable mechanism that works to the benefit of phonon propagation in both the harmonic and anharmonic terms: these spiro interstitial defects covalently bridge neighboring basal planes, simultaneously enhancing acoustic phonon group velocity and reducing phonon‚Äìphonon scattering in the graphite structure. The enhancement of Œ∫ reveals an unconventional role of lattice defects in heat conduction, i.e., easing the propagation of heat‚Äêcarrying phonons rather than impeding them in layered materials, inspiring their applications for thermal management in heavily radiative environments.

item.title: Redox‚ÄêActive Metal‚ÄêCovalent Organic Frameworks for Dendrite‚ÄêFree Lithium Metal Batteries
item.content:encoded:
Two MCOFs with dual‚Äêactive centers are designed as LMB separators to enable efficient Li plating/stripping. Synergistic effects between trinuclear copper clusters and electron‚Äêdonating diarylamine nitrogen create an electron‚Äêrich environment, regulating the local conjugated Li+ microenvironment. The designed Li symmetric cell exhibits excellent Li plating/stripping stability for over 1600 h at 0.5 mA cm‚àí2.
Abstract Lithium (Li) metal has gained attention as an anode material for lithium‚Äêmetal batteries (LMBs) owing to its low electrochemical potential, high specific capacity, and low density. However, the accumulation of Li dendrites and unstable solid electrolyte interphases, caused by sluggish Li+ migration and uneven Li deposition, limit practical LMB applications. This study presents the first report on redox‚Äêactive metal‚Äìcovalent organic frameworks (MCOFs) with dual‚Äêactive centers as functional separators for LMBs. These MCOFs facilitate homogeneous Li nucleation and accelerate Li+ ion transport. The synergistic effects of redox‚Äêactive diarylamine units and trinuclear copper clusters modulate local electron‚Äêcloud density, regulating microenvironment of Li+ ions and ensuring homogeneous Li nucleation. The MCOF‚Äêbased separator's well‚Äêdefined 1D channels in MCOF‚Äêbased separator enable uniform Li+ flux, and promote homogeneous Li deposition, resulting in high Li+ transference number of 0.93 and an ionic conductivity of 2.01 mS cm‚àí1 at room temperature. The Li|Cu cell demonstrates a low Li nucleation barrier of 16 mV, while the Li symmetric cell exhibits stable Li plating/stripping for over 1600 h at 0.5 mA cm‚àí2. When coupled with LiFePO4 cathodes, the assembled LMB exhibits stable capacity retention of ‚âà98%. This work paves the way for dendrite‚Äêfree Li metal anodes in high‚Äêperformance LMBs.

item.title: Inverse Oxide/Alloy‚ÄêStructured Nanozymes with NIR‚ÄêTriggered Enzymatic Cascade Regulation of ROS Homeostasis for Efficient Wound Healing
item.content:encoded:
An inverse oxide/alloy‚Äêstructured nanozyme, Co7Fe3/ZnO@C, is developed to achieve near‚Äêinfrared light‚Äêtriggered enzymatic cascade regulation. Under near‚Äêinfrared (NIR) irradiation, hot electrons are transferred from Co7Fe3 to ZnO, activating synchronized superoxide dismutase‚Äêlike, catalase‚Äêlike, peroxidase‚Äêlike, and hydroxyl radical antioxidant capacity‚Äêlike enzymatic activities. These cascaded activities enable spatiotemporal modulation of reactive oxygen species dynamics, synergistically integrating chemodynamic therapy, photodynamic therapy, and photothermal therapy to accelerate infected wound healing.
Abstract The precise spatiotemporal control of reactive oxygen species (ROS) generation and scavenging remains pivotal for infected wound healing. However, conventional nanozymes fail to adaptively regulate ROS dynamics across inflammatory and proliferative phases. A near‚Äêinfrared (NIR)‚Äêactivated inverse oxide/alloy‚Äêstructured nanozyme (Co7Fe3/ZnO@C) is developed, featuring enzymatic cascade activities to tune ROS homeostasis through synergistic chemodynamic (CDT), photodynamic (PDT), and photothermal (PTT) therapies. The nanozyme orchestrates a self‚Äêregulated cascade: peroxidase (POD)‚Äêlike activity initially generates bactericidal hydroxyl radicals in acidic wounds, while subsequent NIR triggers hot electron transfer from Co7Fe3 to ZnO, facilitating synchronized superoxide dismutase (SOD)‚Äêlike, catalase (CAT)‚Äêlike and hydroxyl radical antioxidant capacity (HORAC) activities to scavenge residual ROS. This cascaded network dynamically balances ROS production (POD) and scavenging (NIR‚Äêdriven SOD/CAT/HORAC), eradicating bacteria while resolving inflammation. In vitro/vivo studies have shown that the proposed method for maintaining ROS homeostasis can markedly enhance the rate of wound healing by the regulation of the inflammatory environment within the injured tissue and the facilitation of rapid re‚Äêepithelialization. This work provides an intelligent nanozyme platform that simulates the function of natural enzymes and constructs a cascade reaction strategy to balance the antibacterial and anti‚Äêinflammatory demands in the wound microenvironment.

item.title: Mitochondrion‚ÄêTargeted Type I Photodynamic Therapy for Agonist Independent cGAS‚ÄêSTING Activation
item.content:encoded:
This study presents the synthesis of mitochondrion‚Äêtargeted nanodrugs containing a BODIPY‚Äêderived type I photosensitizer and a dual nanozyme for light‚Äêcontrolled mitochondrial stress‚Äêinducing and agonist‚Äêindependent cGAS‚ÄêSTING pathway activation. Their tumor therapeutic ability, dual nanozyme activities, mitochondrion‚Äêtargeted cGAS‚ÄêSTING pathway activation, and intratumoral and systemic immunositimulation capacity underscore their potential as a paradigm for efficient photoimmunotherapy.
Abstract CGAS‚ÄêSTING agonists generally lead to hyperimmunity and systemic toxicity, hindering their immunotherapeutic outcomes. Herein, a mitochondrion‚Äêtargeted nanoagonist (termed HABH) containing boron dipyrromethene (BODIPY)‚Äêderived type I photosensitizer (BDP) and Au¬†nanoparticle‚Äêengineered hollow mesoporous silica (HMSN/AuNPs) has been fabricated for light‚Äêcontrolled mitochondrial stress‚Äêinducing and agonist‚Äêindependent cGAS‚ÄêSTING pathway activation. The HABH nanoagonist can actively target tumor tissues and release the mitochondrion‚Äêtargeted BDP. Under light illumination, BDP achieves type I photodynamic therapy (PDT) in mitochondria, generating massive hydroxyl radicals (‚Ä¢OH) and inducing mitochondrial stress in an oxygen‚Äêindependent manner, promoting the release of mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA). Simultaneously, the HMSN/AuNPs act as dual nanozymes to derive cascade reactions for ‚Ä¢OH production, elevating the intracellular oxidative state, and together with the BDP‚Äêinduced mitochondrial stress, finally evoking the cGAS‚ÄêSTING pathway and facilitating the release of type I interferon. In the orthotopic breast tumor models, the HABH nanoagonist achieved intratumoral and systemic immunoactivation for eradicating primary tumors and preventing metastasis tumors. Therefore, the constructed mitochondrion‚Äêtargeted nanoagonist enabled light‚Äêcontrolled and agonist‚Äêindependent cGAS‚ÄêSTING activation, providing a paradigm for photoimmunotherapy.

item.title: Ionic Liquid Induced Static and Dynamic Interface Double Shields for Long‚ÄêLifespan All‚ÄêTemperature Zn‚ÄêIon Batteries
item.content:encoded:
An ionic‚Äêliquid based wide‚Äêtemperature electrolyte inducing static and dynamic interface double shields of Zn anodes is developed for achieving highly stable Zn‚Äêion batteries with an operating temperature range of ‚âà‚àí40‚Äì60 ¬∞C.
Abstract Aqueous Zn‚Äêion batteries (ZIBs) have experienced substantial advancements recently, while the aqueous electrolytes exhibit limited thermal adaptability. The low‚Äêcost Zn(BF4)2 salt possesses potential low‚Äêtemperature application, while brings unsatisfied stability of Zn anodes. To address this challenge, an ionic liquid based eutectic electrolyte (ILEE) utilizing the Zn(BF4)2 presenting remarkable stability across a temperature range of ‚âà‚àí100‚Äì150 ¬∞C is developed, enabling ZIBs to operate in diverse thermal conditions. The inner Zn2+ solvation structure can be modulated to a BF4‚àí‚Äêrich state within the ILEE system, forming a static ZnF‚ÇÇ layer at the electrolyte‚ÄêZn anode interface, as evidenced by ab initial molecular dynamic simulations. Moreover, the positively charged EMIM+ can accumulate on the Zn anodes to form the secondary electrostatic dynamic shield that mitigates the uncontrollable Zn dendrites growth, enhancing the overall cycling life of Zn anodes to over 10 times compared with the pure Zn(BF4)2 system. When utilizing the ILEE as the electrolyte, PANI||Zn full cells demonstrate acceptable performances under the all‚Äêtemperature environments, especially presenting a long life of over 9500 cycles at a low temperature of ‚àí40 ¬∞C and 500 cycles at a high temperature of 60 ¬∞C. This special ILEE holds significant promise for future aqueous batteries in extreme environment.

item.title: Biplane Ion‚ÄêPairing Induced Supramolecular Assembly for High‚ÄêPerformance Uranium Detection
item.content:encoded:
A water‚Äêsoluble Pt(II) pincer complex probe is proposed to achieve the direct recognition of anionic [UO2(CO3)3]4‚àí using a new strategy where the overlapping of thick hydration shells drives an assembly. This hydration‚Äêshell‚Äêpromoted assembly endows the probe with excellent specificity, a rapid response, and high sensitivity (14.89¬†fg). This study paves the way for exploring new approaches for the direct detection of highly hydrated ions.
Abstract It is still challenging to directly recognize the anionic species [UO2(CO3)3]4‚àí, the dominant species in the environment (82%‚Äê93%), using current optical probes because of the adverse effects of its thick hydration shell on binding interactions. In this study, a water‚Äêsoluble Pt(II) methylated terpyridine complex ([Pt(CH3‚Äêtpy)NCO]+) supramolecular probe is designed to directly target [UO2(CO3)3]4‚àí by a new strategy of thick hydration shell overlapping arrangement. The optical response demonstrates excellent selectivity among ‚âà30 investigated interfering substances, along with rapid response (‚âà15¬†s), high sensitivity (64.1¬†nm) and dual‚Äêsignals. It is confirmed both experimentally and theoretically that the superior detection performance is attributed to the formation of a unique supramolecular structure featuring biplane‚Äêlike building block, bicolumnar stacking and water‚Äêbridged anionic networks, via the overlap of thick hydration shells of aligned [UO2(CO3)3]4‚àí to boost a superentropic driving force, and the distinguishable dual‚Äêsignals arises from the emergence of four types of Pt‚ÄêPt interactions, generating low‚Äêenergy metal‚Äêto‚Äêmetal charge transfer adsorption/emission. In addition, a [Pt(CH3‚Äêtpy)NCO]+‚Äêbased hydrogel platform is constructed for detecting both anionic and cationic uranium, with a detection limit of 14.89¬†fg. This work unlocks not only a way to directly detect [UO2(CO3)3]4‚àí, but also a new idea for sensing ions with extreme thick hydration layers.

item.title: Incorporating Ordered Indium Sites into Rhodium for Ultra‚ÄêLow Potential Electrocatalytic Conversion of Ethylene Glycol to Glycolic Acid
item.content:encoded:
Incorporating ordered oxyphilic In sites into Rh to form RhIn intermetallic compounds (IMCs) facilitates the ultra‚Äêlow‚Äêpotential electrooxidation of ethylene glycol into the high‚Äêvalue chemical, glycolic acid. The synthesized RhIn IMCs¬†also exhibit outstanding electrocatalytic performance for the hydrogen evolution reaction. Using RhIn¬†IMCs as bifunctional catalysts, a two‚Äêelectrode system is established for ethylene glycol electrooxidation coupled with hydrogen production.
Abstract The upcycling of polyethylene terephthalate (PET)‚Äêderived ethylene glycol (EG) to glycolic acid (GA, a biodegradable polymer monomer) via electrocatalysis not only produces valuable chemicals but also mitigates plastic pollution. However, the current reports for electrooxidation of EG‚Äêto‚ÄêGA usually operate at reaction potentials of >1.0 V vs reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE), much higher than the theoretical potential (0.065 V vs RHE), resulting in substantial energy wastage. Herein, body‚Äêcentered cubic RhIn intermetallic compounds (IMCs) anchored on carbon support (denoted as RhIn/C) are synthesized, which shows excellent performance for the EG‚Äêto‚ÄêGA with an onset potential of only 0.35 V vs RHE, lower than the values reported in current literature. The catalyst also possesses satisfactory GA selectivity (85% at 0.65 V vs RHE). Experimental results combined with density functional theory calculations demonstrate that RhIn IMCs enhance the adsorption of EG and OH‚àí, facilitating the generation of reactive oxygen species and thereby improving catalytic performance. RhIn/C also exhibits excellent electrocatalytic performance for hydrogen evolution reaction, ensuring that it can be used as a bifunctional catalyst in the two‚Äêelectrode system for EG electrooxidation coupled with hydrogen production. This work opens new avenues for reducing the energy consumption of electrocatalytic upcycling of PET‚Äêderived EG and clean energy production.

item.title: 3D Molecular‚ÄêReconstructed Disordered Precursor Toward Highly Stable Porous Ramie Carbon
item.content:encoded:
3D disordered ramie precursors (DRPs) with high mechanical strength and high density are achieved via the molecular reconstruction method. As a demonstration, this highly stable porous ramie carbon‚Äêbased supercapacitor delivers a prominent energy density of 28.11 Wh kg‚àí1 and a high‚Äêpower density of 47.94 kW kg‚àí1 simultaneously, evidently higher than commercial YP‚Äê50F (12.67 Wh kg‚àí1 and 40.86 kW kg‚àí1).
Abstract Biomass porous carbon possesses broad application prospects in the field of energy storage. However, soft biomass materials with high cellulose content and orders structure usually represent low mechanical strength, which leads to unstable pore structure of prepared porous carbon and even prone to collapse, thus reducing the quality and stability of carbon. Herein, a simple molecular reconstruction method is proposed to effectively re‚Äêconstruct 3D disordered ramie precursors (DRPs) by regulating the chemical interaction of hydrogen bonds. Benefiting from high mechanical strength and high density of DRPs, the highly stable porous ramie carbon (PRC) can display a higher specific surface area of 2404.36 m2 g‚àí1 than that of ordinary ramie carbon (2142.25 m2 g‚àí1). Moreover, this PRC‚Äêbased supercapacitor delivers a high specific capacitance of 39.35 F g‚àí1 at 1 A g‚àí1 and an excellent capacity retention rate of 89.5% at 40 A g‚àí1 in 1 M Et4NBF4/AN. Attractively, the evolution process of ion adsorption during the charge‚Äìdischarge process has been uncovered by using in situ electrochemical infrared spectroscopy, confirming the excellent structural stability of PRC. This work provides new insights into preparing biomass precursors with high strength derived from soft biomass materials, greatly promoting the application of soft biomass materials in commercial activated carbon.

item.title: Hierarchical‚ÄêStructured RGO@EGaIn Composites as Advanced Self‚ÄêHealing Anode for Room‚ÄêTemperature Liquid Metal Battery
item.content:encoded:
GO naturally adsorbs onto the surface of LMPs via electrostatic interactions, self‚Äêassembles into a core‚Äìshell structure, and subsequently reduces to RGO in an acidic solution. The presence of RGO in the hierarchical structural composites significantly improves the electrode‚Äêelectrolyte interface, suppressing and accommodating the irregular deformation of LMPs during the electrochemical reaction process and promoting the formation of a stable SEI film.
Abstract Gallium‚Äêbased liquid metal (LM) has emerged as a promising candidate anode material for lithium‚Äêion batteries (LIBs), exhibiting high theoretical capacity, excellent electrode kinetics, and unique self‚Äêhealing ability. However, the liquid‚Äêsolid‚Äêliquid transition during the electrochemical reactions can disrupt the solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) and damage the structural integrity, ultimately limiting the cycling stability. Here, hierarchical‚Äêstructured reduced graphene oxide coated eutectic gallium‚Äêindium liquid metal particles (RGO@EGaIn LMPs) are synthesized using a facile self‚Äêassembly strategy. The customized RGO@EGaIn electrode demonstrated impressive performance in both half‚Äêcell and full‚Äêcell configurations for LIBs. The morphological and phase transitions of RGO@EGaIn LMPs during the lithiation/delithiation processes are uncovered by real‚Äêtime in situ transmission electron microscopy tests. It is clarified that the presence of RGO in the hierarchical structure buffers the volume expansion of LMPs from ‚âà160% to 125% and provides a fast pathway for the rapid transfer of ions and electrons during the electrochemical reaction, which effectively enhances the electrochemical performance of the electrode. This work introduces a straightforward and effective method for preparing high‚Äêperformance room‚Äêtemperature liquid metal electrodes, representing a significant step forward toward the commercial application of liquid metal batteries.

item.title: Strain‚ÄêInduced Decoupling Drives Gold‚ÄêAssisted Exfoliation of Large‚ÄêArea Monolayer 2D Crystals
item.content:encoded:
Au substrate induces a strain in the adhered bottommost MoS2 layer. The strain weakens the coupling at the first MoS2‚ÄêMoS2 interface, making it the weakest point in the system, therefore MoS2 crystal preferentially cleaves at this interface, facilitating the selective exfoliation of large‚Äêarea monolayers with size comparable to that of the parent crystal.
Abstract Gold‚Äêassisted exfoliation (GAE) is a groundbreaking mechanical exfoliation technique that produces centimeter‚Äêscale single‚Äêcrystal monolayers of 2D materials. Such large, high‚Äêquality films offer unparalleled advantages over the micron‚Äêsized flakes typically produced by conventional exfoliation techniques, significantly accelerating the research and technological advancements in the field of 2D materials. Despite its wide applications, the fundamental mechanism of GAE remains poorly understood. In this study, using MoS‚ÇÇ on Au as a model system, ultra‚Äêlow frequency Raman spectroscopy is employed to elucidate how the interlayer interactions within MoS2 crystals are impacted by the gold substrate. The results reveal that the coupling at the first MoS2‚ÄêMoS2 interface between the adhered layer on the gold substrate and the adjacent layer is substantially weakened, with the binding force being reduced to nearly zero. This renders the first interface the weakest point in the system, thereby the crystal preferentially cleaves at this junction, generating large‚Äêarea monolayers with sizes comparable to the parent crystal. Biaxial strain in the adhered layer, induced by the gold substrate, is identified as the driving factor for the decoupling effect. The strain‚Äêinduced decoupling effect is established as the primary mechanism of GAE, which can also play a significant role in general mechanical exfoliations.

item.title: ‚ÄúWater‚ÄêIn‚ÄêOil‚Äù Electrolyte Enabled by Microphase Separation Regulation for Highly Reversible Zinc Metal Anode
item.content:encoded:
A microphase separated ‚Äúwater‚Äêin‚Äêoil‚Äù (W/O) electrolyte is proposed to simultaneously regulate the water molecules in both electrolyte bulk and electrode interface. Benefiting from the directed movement and reversible demulsification of micelles under the electric field, the as‚Äêdeveloped zinc metal batteries using W/O electrolyte exhibits extended cyclability, improve interface dynamics and negligible H2 evolution.
Abstract The sustained hydrogen evolution and zinc (Zn) dendrite growth greatly impede the practical application of low‚Äêcost aqueous Zn metal batteries (ZMBs). Herein, for the first time, a microphase separation strategy is proposed to construct a ‚Ä≥water‚Äêin‚Äêoil (W/O) electrolyte to endow durable ZMBs. As validated by theoretical modeling and experimental characterizations, the unique reverse micelle structure within the electrolyte not only disrupts water hydrogen bonding and efficiently inhibits the water consumption at Zn anode, but also undergoes directed movement and reversible demulsification under electric field, thus enhancing the anode desolvation kinetics and inhibiting the interfacial side reactions. Owing to the simultaneous regulation of water molecules in both electrolyte bulk and anode interface, this W/O electrolyte achieves a high Zn plating/stripping Coulombic efficiency of 99.76% over 6000 cycles, and maintains an extend lifespan in Zn||V10O24¬∑12H2O (VOH) cells with negligible hydrogen evolution and dendrite formation. These key findings are expected to promote the electrolyte engineering toward reversible ZMBs.

item.title: Kinetically Dormant Ni‚ÄêRich Layered Cathode During High‚ÄêVoltage Operation
item.content:encoded:
Ni‚Äêrich layered cathode remains thermodynamically reversible but undergoes dramatic kinetic degradation at high voltage, leading to the commonly observed capacity loss that in fact can be recovered under kinetic‚Äêfree conditions. Such kinetic dormant behavior highly synchronizes with the lattice strain evolution stemming from layered/rock‚Äêsalt structural heterogeneity during charge.
Abstract The degradation of Ni‚Äêrich cathodes during long‚Äêterm operation at high voltage has garnered significant attention from both academia and industry. Despite many post‚Äêmortem qualitative structural analyses, precise quantification of their individual and coupling contributions to the overall capacity degradation remains challenging. Here, by leveraging multiscale synchrotron X‚Äêray probes, electron microscopy, and post‚Äêgalvanostatic intermittent titration technique, the thermodynamically irreversible and kinetically reversible capacity loss is successfully deconvoluted in a polycrystalline LiNi0.83Mn0.1Co0.07O2 cathode during long‚Äêterm charge/discharge cycling in full cell configuration. Contradicting the dramatic capacity loss, the layered structure remains highly alive even after 1000 cycles at 4.6 V while undergoing a three‚Äêorder of magnitude reduction in the mass transfer kinetics, leading to almost fully recoverable capacity under kinetic‚Äêfree conditions. Such kinetic dormant behavior after cycling is not simply ascribed to poor chemical diffusion by reconstructed cathode surface but highly synchronizes with the lattice strain evolution stemming from the structural heterogeneity between deeply delithiated layered and degraded rock‚Äêsalt phases at high voltage. These findings deepen the degradation mechanism of high‚Äêvoltage cathodes to achieve long‚Äêcycling and fast‚Äêcharging performance.

item.title: In‚ÄêSensor Computing with Visual‚ÄêTactile Perception Enabled by Mechano‚ÄêOptical Artificial Synapse
item.content:encoded:
A mechano‚Äêoptical artificial synapse that enables in‚Äêsensor computing with visual‚Äêtactile perception is achieved by integrating photostimulated luminescence with self‚Äêrecoverable mechanoluminescence materials. The multimodal artificial synapse demonstrates an individual and synergistic plasticity in a remotely accessible manner and enables neuromorphic pattern recognition and materials identification. This work paves the way to construct flexible in‚Äêsensor computing systems with crossmodal integration and recognition.
Abstract In‚Äêsensor computing paradigm holds the promise of realizing rapid and low‚Äêpower signal processing. Constructing crossmodal in‚Äêsensor computing systems to emulate human sensory and recognition capabilities has been a persistent pursuit for developing humanoid robotics. Here, an artificial mechano‚Äêoptical synapse is reported to implement in‚Äêsensor dynamic computing with visual‚Äêtactile perception. By employing mechanoluminescence (ML) material, direct conversion of the mechanical signals into light emission is achieved and the light is transported to an adjacent photostimulated luminescence (PSL) layer without pre‚Äê and post‚Äêirradiation. The PSL layer acts as a photon reservoir as well as a processing unit for achieving in‚Äêmemory computing. The approach based on ML coupled with PSL material is different from traditional circuit‚Äìconstrained methods, enabling remote operation and easy accessibility. Individual and synergistic plasticity are elaborately investigated under force and light pulses, including paired‚Äêpulse facilitation, learning behavior, and short‚Äêterm and long‚Äêterm memory. A multisensory neural network is built for processing the obtained handwritten patterns with a tablet consisting of the device, achieving a recognition accuracy of up to 92.5%. Moreover, material identification has been explored based on visual‚Äêtactile sensing, with an accuracy rate of 98.6%. This work provides a promising strategy to construct in‚Äêsensor computing systems with crossmodal integration and recognition.

item.title: Non‚ÄêHermitian Boundary in a Surface Selective Reconstructed Magnetic Weyl Semimetal
item.content:encoded:
This study is the first to propose that the surface reconstruction of a Weyl semimetal creates a Hermitian bulk‚Äênon‚ÄêHermitian boundary system. The non‚ÄêHermitian effects arising from the surface reconstruction are manifested by the emergence of non‚Äêtopological surface Fermi arcs (NTSFAs) and the broadening of both topological surface Fermi arcs (SFAs) and NTSFAs. These effects are demonstrated through angle‚Äêresolved photoemission spectroscopy (ARPES) measurements in a surface‚Äêreconstructed Weyl semimetal NdAlSi.
Abstract Non‚ÄêHermitian physics, studying systems described by non‚ÄêHermitian Hamiltonians, reveals unique phenomena not present in Hermitian systems. Unlike Hermitian systems, non‚ÄêHermitian systems have complex eigenvalues, making their effects less directly observable. Recently, significant efforts have been devoted to incorporating the non‚ÄêHermitian effects into condensed matter physics. However, progress is hindered by the absence of a viable experimental approach. Here, the discovery of the surface‚Äêselectively spontaneous reconstructed Weyl semimetal NdAlSi provides a feasible experimental platform for studying non‚ÄêHermitian physics. Utilizing angle‚Äêresolved photoemission spectroscopy (ARPES) measurements, surface‚Äêprojected density functional theory (DFT) calculations, and scanning tunneling microscopy (STM) measurements, it is demonstrated that surface reconstruction in NdAlSi alters surface Fermi arc (SFA) connectivity and generates new isolated non‚Äêtopological SFAs (NTSFAs) by introducing non‚ÄêHermitian terms. The surface‚Äêselective spontaneous reconstructed Weyl semimetal NdAlSi can be viewed as a Hermitian bulk ‚Äì non‚ÄêHermitian boundary system. The isolated non‚Äêtopological SFAs on the reconstructed surface act as a loss mechanism and open boundary condition (OBC) for the topological electrons and bulk states, serving as non‚ÄêHermitian boundary states. This discovery provides a good experimental platform for exploring new physical phenomena and potential applications based on boundary non‚ÄêHermitian effects, extending beyond purely mathematical concepts. Furthermore, it provides important enlightenment for constructing topological photonic crystals with surface reconstruction and studying their topological¬†properties.

item.title: Rolling the Dice with Light Competition: Introducing a True Random Number Generator Powered by Photo‚ÄêInduced Polarity Current
item.content:encoded:
This work introduces the ALTRNG, utilizing a BPPD to generate random bits via unpredictable¬†arc discharge illumination. Validated by 15 NIST tests, ALTRNG produces highly random bit streams. With a 2‚Äêkbps readout circuit, it enables wireless random number transmission, offering potential for secure password systems and artificial X‚Äêray imaging.
Abstract The pursuit of hardware‚Äêbased security solutions has highlighted the true random number generator (TRNG). Various physical phenomena, from noise generation to quantum physics complexities, have been explored for random number generation. The arc discharge light‚Äêinduced TRNG (ALTRNG) is introduced, featuring wavelength‚Äêdependent photocurrent generation and arc discharge irradiation. A bipolar photo‚Äêresponsive photodetector (BPPD) differentiates ‚Äú1‚Äù and ‚Äú0‚Äù states, producing highly random bits validated by the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) 15 tests. The BPPD's response to deep‚Äêultraviolet (DUV) and blue light enables distinct photocurrent generation under arc discharge illumination. The ALTRNG generates true random signals, yielding bit streams with unpredictability, uniform distribution, and stability. With a readout circuit achieving 2‚Äêkbps, wireless random number transmission is demonstrated, highlighting potential for secure password systems and artificial X‚Äêray image generation.

item.title: A Supramolecular Nanoengine Generates Nanomechanical Force on Demand for Precise Cytosolic Delivery of Anti‚ÄêmiRNAs and Synergistic TNBC Therapy
item.content:encoded:
A carrier‚Äêfree supramolecular nanoengine (AMGA) is developed, which significantly enhances the cytosolic delivery of anti‚ÄêmiRNAs without requiring light irradiation for precise targeting and synergistic chemo‚Äêgene therapy of triple‚Äênegative breast cancer both in vitro and in vivo. AMGA can specifically generate nanomechanical force to promote the endo/lysosome escape of anti‚ÄêmiRNAs, simultaneously downregulating miRNA‚Äê21 and miRNA‚Äê10b, and release the chemotherapeutic drug gemcitabine.
Abstract Although anti‚ÄêmicroRNA (miRNA) is capable of silencing target miRNA and regulating multiple mRNAs in diverse signaling pathways, RNA medicines still encounter numerous challenges, especially in terms of poor delivery, inefficient endo/lysosomal escape, and suboptimal treatment. Herein, we have developed a carrier‚Äêfree supramolecular nanoengine, AMGA (anti‚ÄêmiRNA/GEM2‚ÄêAzo), which significantly enhances the cytosolic delivery of anti‚ÄêmiRNA without requiring light irradiation, thereby facilitating precise targeting and synergistic chemo‚Äêgene therapy for triple‚Äênegative breast cancer (TNBC). AMGA can be rapidly internalized by cancer cells and specifically generate nanomechanical force to promote the efficient escape of anti‚ÄêmiRNAs from the endo/lysosome to the cytoplasm, simultaneously downregulating miR‚Äê21 and miR‚Äê10b. In comparison to Lipofectamine 2000, AMGA demonstrated superior efficacy in inhibiting the proliferation, migration, and invasion of cancer cells. Significantly, AMGA exhibited profound antitumor and gene silencing effects in an orthotopic human TNBC mouse model. This novel supramolecular nanoengine presents a promising strategy for cytosolic delivery of anti‚ÄêmiRNAs.

item.title: Colossal Electromechanical Response in Antiferroelectric‚Äêbased Nanoscale Multilayers
item.content:encoded:
The careful design of interfaces in PbHfO3‚Äê and PbHf1‚ÄêxTixO3‚Äêbased multilayer heterostructures results in electromechanical strain ‚âà4.8% for films as thin as 120 nm. Such studies can significantly advance the understanding about electromechanically‚Äêactive thin films which can surpass the detrimental effects of substrate‚Äêinduced clamping to demonstrate strain values and be implemented in real‚Äêworld applications.
Abstract The pursuit of smaller, energy‚Äêefficient devices drives the exploration of electromechanically active thin films (<1 ¬µm) to enable micro‚Äê and nano‚Äêelectromechanical systems. While the electromechanical response of such films is limited by substrate‚Äêinduced mechanical clamping, large electromechanical responses in antiferroelectric and multilayer thin‚Äêfilm heterostructures have garnered interest. Here, multilayer thin‚Äêfilm heterostructures based on antiferroelectric PbHfO3 and ferroelectric PbHf1‚ÄêxTixO3 overcome substrate clamping to produce electromechanical strains >4.5%. By varying the chemistry of the PbHf1‚ÄêxTixO3 layer (x = 0.3‚Äê0.6) it is possible to alter the threshold field for the antiferroelectric‚Äêto‚Äêferroelectric phase transition, reducing the field required to induce the onset of large electromechanical response. Furthermore, varying the interface density (from 0.008 to 3.1 nm‚àí1) enhances the electrical‚Äêbreakdown field by >450%. Attaining the electromechanical strains does not necessitate creating a new material with unprecedented piezoelectric coefficients, but developing heterostructures capable of withstanding large fields, thus addressing traditional limitations of thin‚Äêfilm piezoelectrics.

item.title: Enhancing the Performance of Fluorinated Graphdiyne Moisture Cells via Hard Acid‚ÄêBase Coordination of Aluminum Ions
item.content:encoded:
This work presents a groundbreaking MEG method, highlighting the application of fluorinated graphdiyne in novel moisture cells. A unique Al ion‚ÄêF coordination mechanism is introduced, significantly enhancing ion migration and conductivity. Coupled with the FGDY's macroporous structure, the FGDY Al‚Äêion moisture cell achieves outstanding performance metrics.
Abstract Moisture‚Äêenabled electric generators (MEGs) are emerging as a transformative energy technology, capable of directly converting ambient moisture into electrical energy without producing pollutants or harmful emissions. However, the widespread application of MEGs is hindered by challenges such as intermittent output and low current densities, which limit power density and prevent large‚Äêscale integration. Here, a novel moisture cell based on Al ion‚ÄêF coordination‚Äîspecifically, a fluorinated graphdiyne (FGDY) Al‚Äêion moisture cell (FGDY AlMC) is introduced. This new moisture cell achieves an exceptionally high mass‚Äêspecific power density of 371.36¬†¬µW¬†g‚àí¬π, stable output (0.65 V for 15 h), and broad applicability across varying humid environments. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations reveal that the large‚Äêpore molecular structure of FGDY significantly reduces the diffusion barriers for Al ions compared to other 2D carbon materials. Furthermore, the F atoms as ‚Äúhard base‚Äù on FGDY effectively coordinate with ‚Äúhard acid‚Äù Al ions, enhancing ionic conductivity, accelerating ion migration, and promoting the generation of a higher number of mobile cations. These combined advantages lead to a marked improvement in the performance of the FGDY AlMC. These findings position Al ion coordinated FGDY as a highly promising candidate for the development of high‚Äêperformance MEG active materials.

item.title: De‚ÄêNovo Design of Actively Spinning and Gyrating Spherical Micro‚ÄêVesicles
item.content:encoded:
Engineered lipid vesicles, powered by enzyme‚Äêdriven symmetry breaking and transient lipid ordering, demonstrate rotational and translational motion. This innovative approach presents exciting possibilities for biomedical applications, particularly in targeted drug delivery.
Abstract Self‚Äêpropelled lipid‚Äêbased artificial cells that can achieve controlled rotation and directed translation present significant potential for biomedical applications, yet their engineering poses considerable challenges. Lipid vesicles synthesized via solution‚Äêbased methods naturally adopt isotropic spherical shapes. Active motion of these spherical objects requires symmetry breaking and rigidity. In this study, giant vesicles are employed as chassis, utilizing enzymes that undergo cyclic, non‚Äêreciprocal conformational changes as power sources. Weak, transient protein‚Äêprotein interactions induce lipid ordering leading to rigidity and spontaneous symmetry breaking. Upon activation of enzyme reactions, these spherical vesicles demonstrate a variety of motion patterns, from pure spinning to 3D spiral trajectories. From experiments and simulations, it is demonstrated how such motion enables the vesicles to cross complex barriers. By utilizing biocompatible and scalable materials, The methodology establishes a solid framework for the design of such self‚Äêpropelled systems. The work paves the way for advancements in biomedical and environmental technologies such as targeted drug delivery and active matter research.

item.title: CuPt Alloy Enabling the Tandem Catalysis for Reduction of HCOOH and NO3‚àí to Urea at High Current Density
item.content:encoded:
Electrocatalytic liquid HCOOH and NO3‚àí synthesis of urea with high Faraday efficiency at high current density is successfully achieved by synthesizing the Cu4Pt tandem catalyst loaded on copper foam. The doped Pt sites can enrich liquid HCOOH reactants, promote HCOOH intermolecular dehydration, and form a large number of *CO key intermediates to lay the foundation for subsequent C‚îÄN coupling.
Abstract The formation of urea by electrocatalytic reduction of C1‚Äêreactants and NO3‚àí is an attractive way to store renewable electricity, close the carbon cycle, and eliminate nitrate contaminants from wastewater. Involving insufficient supply of C1 reactants and multiple electron transfers makes the reaction difficult to achieve high Faraday efficiency and high yield at high current density. Here, a urea synthesis approach is presented via electrocatalytic reductive coupling between liquid HCOOH and NO3‚àí on copper foam (CF) loaded Cu4Pt catalyst with optimized ratios. A urea yield of 40.08 mg h‚àí1 cm‚àí2 is achieved with FE up to 58.1% at a current density of ‚àí502.3 mA cm‚àí2, superior to the productivity of previously reported catalysts. No degradation is observed over 120‚Äêh continuous operation at such a high yield rate. The highly efficient activity of Cu4Pt/CF can be attributed to the synergetic effect between Pt and Cu sites via tandem catalysis, in which the doped Pt sites enrich liquid HCOOH reactants, promote HCOOH intermolecular dehydration, and form and adsorb large amounts of *CO key intermediates. The Cu sites can generate large quantities of the key intermediate *NH2. The Cu4Pt/CF adsorbed intermediates *CO and *NH2 are the basis for subsequent thermodynamic spontaneous C‚îÄN coupling.

item.title: An Opto‚ÄêIontronic Cholesteric Liquid Crystalline Retina for Multimodal Circularly Polarized Neuromorphic Vision
item.content:encoded:
An opto‚Äêiontronic cholesteric liquid crystalline (i‚ÄêCLC) film is developed that is both electrically and photonically active, serving as the dielectric in phototransistors. The well‚Äêdefined cholesteric structure and broadly tunable pitches of the i‚ÄêCLC film enable it to detect CPL across a broad spectrum, with an unprecedentedly high dissymmetry factor (gph = 1.33) at low operating voltages (< 5¬†V).
Abstract Circularly polarized light (CPL) is fundamental to phase‚Äêcontrolled imaging, quantum optics, and optical computing. Conventional CPL detection, relying on polarizers and quarter‚Äêwave plates, complicates device design and reduces sensitivity. Among emerging CPL detectors, organic field‚Äêeffect transistors (OFET) with helical organic semiconductors are highly promising due to their compact structures but suffer tedious synthesis, low dissymmetric factors (gph <¬†0.1), and high operating voltages (> 50¬†V). To address these issues, an opto‚Äêiontronic cholesteric liquid crystalline (i‚ÄêCLC) film is developed that is both electrically and photonically active, serving as the dielectric in phototransistors. The well‚Äêdefined cholesteric structure and broadly tunable pitches of the i‚ÄêCLC film enable it to detect CPL with an excellent ‚Äúhandedness‚Äù selectivity across a broad spectrum. Moreover, its ionic nature provides a high capacitance (up to 580¬†nF cm‚àí2 @20¬†Hz). The resulting flexible CPL detectors achieve an unprecedentedly high dissymmetry factor (gph = 1.33) at low operating voltages (< 5¬†V), showcasing significant potential in optical communication and data encryption. Furthermore, leveraging high gph, they can perform in‚Äêsensor computing for highly accurate semantic segmentation using fused multimodal visual inputs (e.g., circularly polarized and ordinary light), achieving an accuracy of 75.73% and a mean intersection over the union of 0.3982, surpassing the performance of non‚ÄêCPL photodetectors. Additionally, it optimizes power consumption by a factor of 102 compared to most conventional visual processing systems, offering a groundbreaking hardware solution for high‚Äêperformance neuromorphic CPL vision.

item.title: A Soft Nonpolar‚ÄêSoluble Two‚ÄêDimensional Perovskite for General Construction of Mixed‚ÄêDimensional Heterojunctions
item.content:encoded:
A nonpolar soluble 2D perovskite, noted as TPA2PbI4, is developed to construct controllable mixed‚Äêdimensional perovskite heterojunctions without solid reactions with the initial 3D perovskite films. This strategy improves both the performance of small‚Äêarea perovskite solar cells and large‚Äêarea perovskite modules, promoting 30¬†cm √ó 30¬†cm FAPbI3 perovskite submodules to achieve a certified efficiency of 22.06%.
Abstract Constructing mixed‚Äêdimensional heterojunctions through ion exchange between functional organic ammonium halides and the already‚Äêdeposited bulk 3D perovskite films is a widely adopted strategy to effectively passivate and stabilize perovskite solar cells (PSCs). Such process poses challenges in precisely controlling the composition and distribution of the heterojunctions across the film, in particular for large‚Äêarea applications. Here, a soft 2D perovskite based on tetrapheptyl‚Äêammonium iodide (TPAI), noted as TPA2PbI4 is reported. It is the first‚Äêreported nonpolar readily soluble 2D perovskite, leading to highly compact and oriented perovskite layers. In addition, this nonpolar soluble TPA2PbI4 is beneficial to universally construct thickness‚Äêcontrollable mixed‚Äêdimensional perovskite heterojunctions to suppress the non‚Äêradiative recombination and promote charge‚Äêcarrier transfer on all the FA‚Äê, MA‚Äê and CsPbI3 PSCs. Such a unique strategy is also suitable for upscaling fabrication, demonstrated by 30¬†cm √ó 30¬†cm FAPbI3 perovskite submodules with a certified efficiency of 22.06%.

item.title: Mixed Electrolyte Enabling Ultrafast Mass Transport and Compatibility with Polypropylene Separator for Stable and Low‚ÄêCost Aluminum Ion Battery
item.content:encoded:
A mixed electrolyte (IL‚ÄêFB (1:5)) for aluminum ion batteries is synthesized by incorporating fluorobenzene into ionic liquid electrolyte. The IL‚ÄêFB (1:5) promotes mass transport, enabling cycling for 7500 h under high current density and capacity (8 mA cm‚àí2, 8 mAh cm‚àí2). IL‚ÄêFB (1:5) also exhibits significantly improved wetting ability with the polypropylene separator, guaranteeing 60% reduction in the cost of the AIB.
Abstract The energy industry has taken notice of aluminum ion batteries (AIB) for their low cost, high safety, and high capacity. However, using the ionic liquid electrolyte results in the uneven Al electrodeposition and the reliance on expensive glass fiber separators, due to the sluggish mass transport and low wettability for the polypropylene separator. Herein, a mixed electrolyte is introduced by incorporating the co‚Äêsolvent fluorobenzene into the traditional AlCl3/1‚Äêethyl‚Äê3‚Äêmethylimidazolium chloride ionic liquid, in which the fluorobenzene (FB) mitigates electrostatic interactions between ions and facilitates the ion diffusion. The optimization principle for the mixed electrolyte is proposed based on maximizing the mass transportation, as indicated by the limiting current density. The optimized mixed electrolyte IL‚ÄêFB (1:5) offers the highest limiting current density of 12¬†mA cm‚àí2, highly reversible plate/stripe of Al, and thus stable cycling for 7500 h with the high current density and capacity (8 mA cm‚àí2, 8 mAh cm‚àí2). Furthermore, IL‚ÄêFB (1:5) also shows enhanced wettability for the polypropylene separator. The AIB with the polypropylene separator, exhibiting 60% decrease in cost, is achieved for the first time by using IL‚ÄêFB (1:5), presenting a crucial step toward the initial practical application.

item.title: Homo‚ÄêHetero Double Junction Coupling Weakens Exciton Effects to Enhance Selective Photocatalytic O2 Activation on Carbon Nitride
item.content:encoded:
Through the homo‚Äêhetero double‚Äêjunction coupling strategy, the directional electron‚Äìhole migration is precisely regulated, and the exciton effect is substantially weakened. Under the strong built‚Äêin electric field, the FO/HCCN surface exhibits typical charge‚Äêcarrier behavior, which achieves ‚âà100% selective generation of ¬∑O2‚àí from O2.
Abstract Exciton effects caused by the inherent dielectric confinement in the 2D material carbon nitride (CN) severely limit the transfer of photogenerated carriers and the selective generation of free radicals. Herein, a homo‚Äêhetero double junction coupling strategy is reported to address these challenges. Ternary homojunction carbon nitride (HCCN) functionalized with cyano and cyanamide groups is constructed with a built‚Äêin electric field that efficiently separates the electron‚Äìhole into different structural units, thereby reducing reverse charge recombination and weakening exciton effects. The introduction of Œ±‚ÄêFe2O3 (FO) subsequently constructs the homo‚Äêhetero double junction catalyst FO/HCCN with a built‚Äêin electric field 127 times stronger than HCCN, which promotes the directional migration of carriers after exciton dissociation and achieves ‚âà100% selective generation of ¬∑O2‚àí from O2. These results suggest that FO/HCCN achieves 99.6% removal of tetracycline within 20¬†min, with a degradation rate 12 and 46 times higher than FO/CN and HCCN, respectively. In addition, the system shows excellent stability and cyclability in real‚Äêlife light experiments and trace organic contaminant removal. This homo‚Äêhetero double junction coupling strategy opens up new avenues in weakening exciton effects and precisely controlling the generation of free radicals.

item.title: Kinetics Manipulation Enabled by Solubility Control Toward 19% Organic Solar Cells via Compatible Air Coating
item.content:encoded:
A twisted guest acceptor BTP‚Äê4Cl is introduced to fine‚Äêtune the solubility of host components to address the excessive aggregation issue in blade‚Äêcoated processing. It is found that the twisted molecular conformation profited in inducing longer intermolecular distance and dispersing molecular distribution in the solvent. Simultaneously, the guest acceptor positively influenced the crystalization kinetics by providing nuclei seeding sites. Finally, a fine phase separation is achieved in the open‚Äêair blade‚Äêcoated organic solar cells with a state‚Äêof‚Äêthe‚Äêart power conversion efficiency of 19.67%.
Abstract Blade coating is a promising tool for upscaling organic solar cells (OSCs). However, the performances of blade‚Äêcoated OSCs still lag behind their spin‚Äêcoated counterparts, limiting their competitive edge towards commercialization. One of the main reasons is that controlling the film aggregation kinetics and morphology becomes challenging during the transition from spin coating to blade coating, especially when using high boiling point solvents, which can result in excessive aggregation. Therefore, a deeper understanding and appraisal of film formation kinetics influenced by coating methods is crucial. In this work, it is demonstrated that ink solubility tuning by incorporating a twisted third component (BTP‚Äê4Cl) can induce rapid crystallization behavior and promote fine phase separation between the donor polymer (PM6) and the acceptor (BTP‚ÄêeC9) in blade coating. As a result, a high power conversion efficiency (PCE) of 19.67% is obtained in OSCs (0.04 cm2), one of the state‚Äêof‚Äêthe‚Äêart efficiencies among the reported blade‚Äêcoated OSCs (19.76% for the spin‚Äêcoated devices). In addition, it is found that the inhibited phase aggregation contributes to enhancing the light stability of the device. This strategy offered novel insights into the effectiveness of solubility‚Äêtuning approaches for achieving highly efficient and stable OSCs under open‚Äêair coating conditions.

item.title: Development of Ternary Hydrogel Electrolytes for Superior Gel Thermocells: Exceptional Anti‚ÄêDrying, Anti‚ÄêFreezing, and Mechanical Robustness
item.content:encoded:
A flexible wearable ternary gel thermocell (TGTC) by integrating a thermosensitive crystallizing agent, and supporting electrolyte into a natural nanocellulose hydrogel matrix is designed and constructed, which exhibits a remarkable thermopower, an optimized effective ionic conductivity, anti‚Äêdrying, freezing resistance, and mechanical robustness. This work provides a versatile strategy for developing TGTC, contributing to advancements in low‚Äêgrade energy harvesting and wearable electronics for the Internet of Things era.
Abstract Gel thermocells (GTCs) provide a safe, facile, and scalable solution for harvesting waste heat to power ubiquitous electronics. However, achieving a harmonious integration of high power density, wide‚Äêtemperature‚Äêrange stability, and mechanical robustness in GTCs remains a significant challenge. In this work, a novel ternary gel thermocell (TGTC) is proposed and fabricated by integrating ferro/ferricyanide (Fe(CN)63‚àí/4‚àí) redox couples, thermosensitive crystallizing agents guanidinium chloride (GdmCl), and supporting electrolytes lithium chloride (LiCl) into natural nanocellulose hydrogels to enhance overall performance. GdmCl selectively induces Fe(CN)64‚àí crystallization, increasing the concentration difference of redox pairs, resulting in improving thermopower and significantly increased fiber friction, while LiCl rapidly balances charges through electromigration promoting efficient ion transport and reconstructing hydrogen bond networks, contributing to an excellent output power density and the capture of water molecules, which are further elucidated by simulations, achieving synchronous enhancement of anti‚Äêdrying, anti‚Äêfreezing and mechanical properties. Consequently, the TGTC achieves a remarkable thermopower of 3.42¬†mV K‚àí1, a maximum power density of 2.8¬†mW m‚àí2 K‚àí2, multiple continuous stable cycles at ‚àí20¬†¬∞C, and an impressive strength of 3.06¬†MPa. Notably, this study elucidates the design principles and underlying mechanisms of ternary gel electrolytes, offering a practical strategy for advancing GTC technology.

item.title: A Universal Solution for Direct Regeneration of Spent Lithium Iron Phosphate
item.content:encoded:
Design criteria for a lithiation solution that enables spontaneous lithiation under ambient conditions for the direct regeneration of spent LiFePO4 are proposed. Using machine learning (ML), the redox potentials of various solution systems are identified and revealed a critical relationship: the lower the redox potential, the more effective the lithiation of degraded LiFePO4 materials.
Abstract Lithiation reactions driven by chemical potential offer a promising avenue for directly regenerating degraded lithium iron phosphate (LFP). However, the choice of solution system significantly influences the lithium supplementation where improper selection may result in poor lithium recovery or extremely slow kinetics. Herein, it is identified that the most critical factor affecting solution repair effectiveness is the redox potential of the anions in the solution, which determines whether spent LFP (SLFP) can undergo spontaneous lithiation under ambient conditions. Then, machine learning (ML) is used for prediction and screening of huge potential solution systems, and finally a general strategy is proposed: creating a low redox potential solution system that incorporates anions with either low redox potential or moderate redox potential at high concentrations. As a demonstration, the regenerated LFP by ascorbic acid and LiOH solution systems exhibits a high discharge capacity of 144 mAh g‚àí1 at 1 C, retaining 96% of its capacity after 500 cycles at 5 C. This work establishes an important criteria for designing solution systems to restore degraded LFP, marking a significant advancement in the direct regeneration of cathode materials from spent lithium‚Äêion batteries (LIBs).

item.title: 17.68% Efficiency Nonhalogenated Solvent‚ÄêProcessed Organic Solar Cell Modules Driven by Seed Crystal Strategy
item.content:encoded:
The TOC illustration depicts asymmetric BDTF‚ÄêCA2O seed crystals (left) harnessing low nucleation barrier and strong crystallinity to facilitate PM6 crystallization. The module's J‚ÄìV curve (right) highlights the transition from small‚Äêarea cells to industrial‚Äêscale modules, emphasizing the seed crystal strategy's role in achieving uniform morphology and record efficiencies.
Abstract Organic solar cells now surpass 20% efficiency in small‚Äêarea devices, but the use of chloroform as a solvent poses industrial scalability challenges because of its limited ability of uniform film formation and toxicity. High‚Äêboiling, non‚Äêhalogenated solvents are being studied as alternatives, but their low solubility and slow evaporation complicate crystallization process. Here, the study introduces a seed crystal strategy by incorporating oligo (ethylene glycol)‚Äêmodified small‚Äêmolecule donors to optimize the nucleation and crystallization. The asymmetric BDTF‚ÄêCA2O molecule, which combines the strong crystallinity of rodanine group and the low nucleation barrier of oligo (ethylene glycol) chain, significantly promotes the crystallization of the polymer donor PM6. Moreover, BDTF‚ÄêCA2O effectively suppresses excessive phase separation, and optimizes vertical distribution, resulting in enhanced exciton extraction, balanced carrier transport, and reduced recombination losses. Small‚Äêarea toluene‚Äêprocessed devices achieve a power conversion efficiency of 19.67%. In the realm of large‚Äêarea organic solar cell modules, this strategy leads to a record active area efficiency of 17.68% and aperture area efficiency of 16.80% (certified at 16.26%), which is the highest reported for organic solar cell modules >10 cm2 to date. These achievements highlight the potential of the seed crystal strategy for large‚Äêscale production of efficient, large‚Äêarea organic solar cell modules.

item.title: Biomimetic Design of Breathable 2D Photothermal Fabric with Three‚ÄêLayered Structure for Efficient Four‚ÄêPlane Evaporation of Seawater
item.content:encoded:
Inspired by leaf structure and the transpiration process, a breathable 2D photothermal fabric with a three‚Äêlayer structure for efficient four‚Äêplane evaporation of seawater is developed. The fabric evaporator achieves faster evaporation rates (2.6 kg m‚àí2 h‚àí1) under sunlight (1.0 kW m‚àí2), outperforming single‚Äêplane (1.6 kg m‚àí2 h‚àí1) and double‚Äêplane (1.9 kg m‚àí2 h‚àí1) evaporations.
Abstract 2D photothermal membranes have demonstrated numerous advantages in solar desalination due to their flexibility, scalability, and low cost. However, their practical applications are limited by the restricted evaporation area and obstructed vapor channels. A biomimetic design of the breathable 2D photothermal fabric is reported, which is composed of two carbon‚Äênanotube‚Äêhydrogel‚Äêcoated polyester (PET) fabrics separated by fiber pillars, with the upper fabric layer having a hole array as stomatal channels. This fabric shows high solar‚Äêabsorption efficiency (96.1%) and decreased water‚Äêevaporation enthalpy (1664.6 kJ kg‚àí1). The hanging fabric as a heliotropic evaporator exhibits four‚Äêplane evaporation feature and achieves a high evaporation rate of 2.6 kg m‚àí2 h‚àí1 under sunlight (1.0 kW m‚àí2) illumination, better than the traditional floated model (single‚Äêplane, 1.6 kg m‚àí2 h‚àí1). The evaporation rate can be further enhanced to 4.2 kg m‚àí2 h‚àí1 upon introducing adscititious airflow (2 m s‚àí1). Simultaneously, the heliotropic‚Äêhanging design allows the dropping of concentrated brine, avoiding solid‚Äêsalt‚Äêcrystallization.

item.title: Regulating Interface Engineering by Helmholtz Plane Reconstructed Achieves Highly Reversible Zinc Metal Anodes
item.content:encoded:
The synergistic regulation strategy is proposed by introducing a small amount of Pyridine oxide (PNO). The preferentially adsorbed PNO constitutes a protective layer in the Inner Helmholtz Plane and inhibits the activity of water within the Outer Helmholtz plane via customizing solvation sheath. That's blocking the direct contact of active water and the anode, leading to highly reversible aqueous zinc metal batteries.
Abstract The rampant dendrite growth and notorious parasitic reactions significantly compromise the stability of zinc anodes in aqueous zinc metal batteries, presenting substantial for their practical applications. Herein, this work proposes a synergistic strategy that reconstructs the Helmholtz plane to precisely regulate the interface chemistry between the anode and the electrolyte. Experimental investigations and theoretical calculations demonstrate that even a small amount of pyridine oxide (PNO) additive effectively alters the coordination environment and reorganizes the solvation sheath in the Outer Helmholtz Plane (OHP). Simultaneously, PNO molecules preferentially adsorbed on the anode surface, displacing active water from the Inner Helmholtz Plane (IHP). Through synergistic regulation in both the OHP and IHP, zinc ions achieve compact and dense deposition along the Zn (002) crystal plane, while parasitic reactions catalyzed by active water are effectively suppressed. Consequently, the symmetric cell incorporating the PNO additive demonstrates stable cycling performance, maintaining more than 2300¬†h at 1¬†mA¬†cm‚àí2 and sustaining over 400¬†h even at a high depth of discharge of 85%. Furthermore, the Zn||AQ cell retains 80% of its capacity after 3000 cycles and exhibits outstanding cycling stability even under the high active material mass loading (22¬†mg¬†cm‚àí2) using the modified electrolyte.

item.title: Conjugated Coordination Polymer Aerogels with Increased Accessibility of Well‚ÄêDefined Single‚ÄêAtom Metal Sites as a New Paradigm of Electrocatalysts
item.content:encoded:
A facile and general strategy is developed to prepare conjugated coordination polymer aerogels (denoted as M‚ÄêCCPA, M = Ni, Cu, Zn, etc.) that can markedly increase the accessibility of their well‚Äêdefined single‚Äêatom metal sites within their hierarchically porous structures with mesopores and nanopores, which can provide a wide space for the design of high‚Äêperformance catalysts toward various energy‚Äêconversion systems.
Abstract Developing high‚Äêperformance single‚Äêatom catalysts (SACs) with maximum metal utilization efficiency is of significance, which presents enormous potentials to be extensively applied. It is desired yet challenging to elaborately tailor the coordination structures of active sites in SACs and simultaneously enable sufficient accessibility of these active sites to reactants. Here, a facile and general strategy to prepare conjugated coordination polymer aerogels (CCPA) with porous architectures that can markedly increase the accessibility of their elaborately‚Äêtailored active sites, which as a new electrocatalyst paradigm can fully present both the structural advantages of SACs and aerogel materials, is reported. Taking nickel (Ni) as an example, Ni‚Äêbased CCPA (Ni‚ÄêCCPA) and its counterpart Ni‚ÄêCCP with non‚Äêaerogel feature are studied as a proof‚Äêof‚Äêconcept case. Electrochemical measurements show that, relative to Ni‚ÄêCCP, Ni‚ÄêCCPA exhibits appreciably higher performance toward alkaline oxygen evolution reaction (OER). Both the experimental results and theoretical simulations unravel that the improved OER performance of Ni‚ÄêCCPA arises from the accelerated OH‚àí diffusion within its porous architecture and enhanced OH‚àí concentration near its highly exposed active sites at its high‚Äêcurvature surfaces with localized electric fields. Importantly, as evidenced by the Cu‚ÄêCCPA and Zn‚ÄêCCPA examples, such strategy can be promisingly applied to prepare high‚Äêperformance CCPA targeted toward various catalytic reactions and beyond.

item.title: Electrosynthesis of Urea on High‚ÄêDensity Ga‚îÄY Dual‚ÄêAtom Catalyst via Cross‚ÄêTuning
item.content:encoded:
Electrochemically converting carbon dioxide and nitrate into urea via the C‚ÄìN coupling route offers a sustainable alternative to the traditional industrial urea production technology. Herein, a high‚Äêdensity Ga‚ÄìY dual‚Äêatom catalyst supported on N, P‚Äêco‚Äêdoped carbon substrate is developed for urea electrosynthesis. Experiments and theories reveal that strong cross‚Äêsynergizing coupling between Ga‚ÄêY sites contributed to improving the electrosynthesis performance of urea.
Abstract Electrochemically converting carbon dioxide (CO2) and nitrate (NO3‚àí) into urea via the C‚îÄN coupling route offers a sustainable alternative to the traditional industrial urea production technology, but it is still limited by poor yield rate, low Faradaic efficiency, and insufficient coupling kinetics. Herein, a high‚Äêdensity Ga‚îÄY dual‚Äêatom catalyst is developed with loading up to 14.1 wt.% of Ga and Y supported on N, P‚Äêco‚Äêdoped carbon substrate (Ga/Y‚ÄêCNP) for urea electrosynthesis. The catalyst facilitates efficient C‚îÄN coupling through co‚Äêreduction of CO2 and NO3‚àí, resulting in a high urea yield rate of 41.9 mmol h‚àí1 g‚àí1 and a Faradaic efficiency of 22.1% at ‚àí1.4 V versus the reversible hydrogen electrode. In situ spectroscopy and theoretical calculations¬†reveal that the superior performance is attributed to the cross‚Äêtuning between adjacent pair Ga‚îÄY sites, which can mutually optimize their electronic states for facilitating CO2 reduction to *CO at Ga sites and promoting NO3‚àí conversion to hydroxylamine (*NH2OH) at Y sites, followed by spontaneous coupling of *CO and *NH2OH intermediates at Ga‚îÄY sites to form C‚îÄN bonds. This work offers a pioneering strategy to manipulate C‚îÄN coupling pathways by cross‚Äêtuning active sites to produce high‚Äêvalue‚Äêadded chemicals.

item.title: High‚ÄêEntropy 1T‚ÄêPhase Quantum Sheets of Transition‚ÄêMetal Disulfides
item.content:encoded:
An efficient high‚Äêentropy strategy is developed to produce 1T‚Äêphase quantum sheets of transition‚Äêmetal disulfides based on controllable introduction of multiple metal atoms with large size differences to retard the sliding of basal plane. The key is the topological conversion of in‚Äêplane ordered carbide laminates (i‚ÄêMAX) compatible with multiple atoms to high‚Äêstrained high‚Äêentropy transition‚Äêmetal disulfides with 1T phase, which facilely triggers the fracture into 1T‚Äêphase quantum sheets during the exfoliation process. The resultant 1T‚Äêphase disulfide quantum sheets show high electrocatalytic activities for lithium polysulfides, achieving good electrochemical properties in lithium‚Äêsulfur batteries.
Abstract Quantum sheets of transition‚Äêmetal dichalcogenides (TMDs) are promising nanomaterials owing to the combination of both 2D nanosheets and quantum dots with distinctive properties. However, the quantum sheets usually possess semiconducting behavior associated with 2H phase, it remains challenging to produce 1T‚Äêphase quantum sheets due to the easy sliding of the basal plane susceptible to the small lateral sizes. Here, an efficient high‚Äêentropy strategy is developed to produce 1T‚Äêphase quantum sheets of transition‚Äêmetal disulfides based on controllable introduction of multiple metal atoms with large size differences to retard the sliding of basal plane. The key is the topological conversion of in‚Äêplane ordered carbide laminates (i‚ÄêMAX) compatible with multiple atoms to high‚Äêentropy transition‚Äêmetal disulfides with high strains and 1T phase, which facilely triggers the fracture into 1T‚Äêphase quantum sheets with average size of 4.5 nm and thickness of 0.7 nm during the exfoliation process. Thus, the 1T‚Äêphase disulfide quantum sheets show high electrocatalytic activities for lithium polysulfides, achieving a good rate performance of 744 mAh g‚àí1 at 5 C and a long cycle stability in lithium‚Äêsulfur batteries.

item.title: Reduction of Nonradiative Recombination at Perovskite/C60 Interface in Inverted Perovskite Solar Cells
item.content:encoded:
By adopting a bimolecular synergistic passivation strategy, it is feasible to achieve micro‚Äê and nano‚Äêstructural modulation of the perovskite surface, thereby passivating surface defects, regulating interface energy levels, and enhancing the interface electric field. This approach maximizes the reduction of nonradiative recombination at the perovskite/C60 interface and demonstrates universal applicability across perovskite/C60 interfaces with different bandgaps.
Abstract Although p‚Äêi‚Äên type inverted perovskite solar cells (PSCs) achieve excellent photoelectric efficiencies, the nonradiative recombination at the perovskite/C60 interface is still the key factor affecting the overall efficiency of p‚Äêi‚Äên PSCs. Herein, a synergistic passivation strategy (meta‚Äêfluoro‚Äêphenylethylammonium iodide and piperazine iodide) is developed to modify the perovskite/C60 interface in p‚Äêi‚Äên PSCs. This strategy facilitates in situ reconstruction of the perovskite film to obtain a smooth and flat perovskite surface. Furthermore, the two molecules work synergistically to passivate surface defects, adjust the interface energy levels, and bolster the interface electric field, all of which reduce the nonradiative recombination losses at the perovskite/C60 interface. The optimal PSCs adopting this strategy achieve a power conversion efficiency of 25.85%. (certified value of 25.22%). After operating at the maximum power point for 1000 h, the 95% initial efficiency can be maintained. Furthermore, this process is universally applicable and scalable.

item.title: Minimizing Buried Interface Energy Losses with Post‚ÄêAssembled Chelating Molecular Bridges for High‚ÄêPerformance and Stable Inverted Perovskite Solar Cells
item.content:encoded:
The chelating molecule (CB‚ÄêPA) serves as both a top‚Äêinterface molecular bridge and a void‚Äêfiller to improve the buried interface quality and promote carrier extraction, leading to a high efficiency of 25.27% and superior stability for inverted MA‚Äêfree perovskite solar cells.
Abstract Self‚Äêassembled monolayers (SAMs) as hole‚Äêcollecting materials have made remarkable progress in inverted perovskite solar cells (PSCs). However, the incomplete coverage of SAMs and the non‚Äêintimate interface contact between perovskite/SAMs usually cause inferior interface characteristics and significant energy losses at the heterojunction interface. Herein, a post‚Äêassembled chelating molecular bridge strategy using 5‚Äê(9H‚Äêcarbazol‚Äê9‚Äêyl)isophthalicacid (CB‚ÄêPA) is developed to modify the perovskite/SAMs buried interface. It is found that CB‚ÄêPA can be chemically coupled with MeO‚Äê2PACz through œÄ‚ÄìœÄ stacking between carbazole groups, and chelate with perovskite by forming double C‚ïêO¬∑¬∑¬∑Pb bonds, thus constructing a bridge‚Äêconnected interface to promote carrier extraction. Simultaneously, the post‚Äêassembled CB‚ÄêPA can fill the voids of MeO‚Äê2PACz to form dense hybrid SAMs, resulting in uniform surface potential and improved interface contact. Moreover, CB‚ÄêPA treatment also tends to induce the oriented crystallization of perovskite films, passivate interface defects, and release lattice stress at the buried interface. Consequently, the CB‚ÄêPA‚Äêbased inverted PSCs achieve a champion efficiency of 25.27% with superior operational stability, retaining ‚âà94% of their initial efficiency after maximum power point (MPP) tracking (65¬†¬∞C) for 1000 h with ISOS‚ÄêL‚Äê2I protocol. This work provides an innovative strategy to address the buried interface challenges for high‚Äêperformance inverted PSCs.

item.title: Crack‚ÄêResistant and Self‚ÄêHealable Passive Radiative Cooling Silicone Compounds
item.content:encoded:
This study investigates the impact of crack damage on passive radiative cooling and introduces a self‚Äêhealing, crack‚Äêresistant radiative cooling silicone/boron nitride compound, developed through the synthesis of a dynamic and crack‚Äêresistant polymer/dielectric hydrogen bond network. This approach makes the material self‚Äêheal cracks from micrometers to millimeters wide and can prevent further crack propagation under stress through crack blunting and deflection.
Abstract Crack damage and expansion are prevalent issues in outdoor materials, which absorb or transmit sunlight to damaged areas, substantially impairing the functionality of passive radiative cooling systems. Herein, a silicone/dielectric radiative cooling compound is introduced that is both self‚Äêhealing and crack‚Äêresistant, developed through the synthesis of a dynamic and crack‚Äêresistant polymer/dielectric hydrogen bond network. This network incorporates boron nitride dielectrics, which serve as sunlight scatterers and hydrogen bond acceptors, with customized silicone polymer featuring high atmospheric window emissive chain segments and UV‚Äìvis‚ÄêNIR transparent hydrogen bond moieties. When cracks form, the polymer's chain mobility allows the hydrogen bond moieties in boron nitride and silicone to re‚Äêassociate, realizing self‚Äêhealing of cracks from micrometers to millimeters wide and restoring cooling performance to ‚âà100%. The combination of rigid boron nitride and sacrificial hydrogen bonds in polymer also enhances the materials‚Äô fracture energy to 865%, effectively preventing further crack propagation under stress through autonomous crack blunting and deflection. These remarkable characteristics make this radiative cooling compound highly suited for increasingly complex, dynamic, and prolonged outdoor application environments.

item.title: Strong and Tough Water‚ÄêTolerant Conductive Eutectogels with Phase‚ÄêSeparated Hydrophilic/Hydrophobic Dual Ionic Channels
item.content:encoded:
An eutectogel (PSDIC‚Äêgel) with exceptional integrative properties is successfully developed by blending hydrophilic/hydrophobic polymerizable deep eutectic solvents, in which spontaneously forming dual ionic channels through in situ polymerization‚Äêinduced phase separation. The transparent PSDIC‚Äêgel exhibits remarkable tensile strength, high toughness, excellent ionic conductivity, improved water tolerance, and rapid room temperature self‚Äêhealing ability, thus, has wide application prospects in wearable electronics.
Abstract Eutectogels are emerging as the next‚Äêgeneration stretchable electronics due to their superior ionic conductivity, non‚Äêvolatility, and cost‚Äêeffectiveness. Nevertheless, most eutectogels suffer from weak mechanical strength and toughness and pronounced hygroscopicity. Herein, a strategy is proposed to fabricate phase‚Äêseparated eutectogels with dual ionic channels (PSDIC‚Äêgel), which exhibit exceptional integrative properties, especially water resistance. By blending hydrophilic/hydrophobic polymerizable deep eutectic solvents, dual ionic channels spontaneously form via polymerization‚Äêinduced phase separation. The hydrophilic poly(acrylic acid) (PAA) phase containing Li+‚Äêchannels, rich in hydrogen bonding and ion‚Äêdipole interactions, provides mechanical strength and conductivity. The hydrophobic poly(hexafluorobutyl acrylate) (PHFBA) phase incorporating cholinium cation (Ch+) channels enhances toughness, conductivity, and water resistance. Adjusting the phase ratio yields a microphase‚Äêseparated transparent eutectogel with high tensile strength (6.03¬†MPa), toughness (16.18¬†MJ¬†m‚àí3), excellent ionic conductivity (1.6 √ó 10‚àí3 S¬†m‚àí1), strong substrate adhesion, and rapid room‚Äêtemperature self‚Äêhealing. Solid‚Äêstate NMR reveals the conductive mechanism and the phase‚Äêseparated structure featuring dual ionic channels in PSDIC‚Äêgels, advancing the understanding of complex ionic interactions at the atomic level. The PSDIC‚Äêgel enables a flexible triboelectric nanogenerator for accurate real‚Äêtime self‚Äêpowered human motion sensing.
