This work advances eutectogel design through structure‚Äêproperty engineering, offering a universal strategy to reconcile mechanical robustness, environmental suitability, and ionic conductivity for wearable electronics.

item.title: Highly Bright Pure Room Temperature Phosphorescence for Circularly Polarized Organic Hyperafterglow
item.content:encoded:
An efficient strategy is proposed for achieving highly bright and narrowband organic hyperafterglow by isolating conjugated energy donor with circularly polarized luminescence and energy acceptor with multi‚Äêresonance effect into a rigid host. Efficient energy and chirality transfers afford multi‚Äêcolor hyperafterglow with photoluminescence efficiency of‚âà90%, full‚Äêwidth at half maxima of 31‚Äì39 nm, lifetime of 120‚Äì770 ms, and luminescent dissymmetry of‚âà10‚àí3.
Abstract Pure room‚Äêtemperature phosphorescence (pRTP) promises great advantages in both exciton utilization and lifetime manipulation over existing organic luminophores for a variety of emerging applications, but the low brightness, low efficiency, and low color purity constrain the afterglow luminescence significantly. Here, a promising approach to design highly bright, efficient, and narrowband pRTP with long‚Äêlifetime for organic hyperafterglow is proposed by isolating a conjugated energy donor with circularly polarized (CP) luminescence and energy acceptor with multi‚Äêresonance effect into a rigid host. It is shown that the aggregation of chiral P‚Äêcontaining binaphthyl promotes the generation of CP‚ÄêpRTP and afterglow with high brightness up to ‚âà50¬†cd m‚àí2, while the simultaneous energy transfer and chirality transfer afford multi‚Äêcolor organic hyperafterglow with photoluminescence efficiency of ‚âà90%, full‚Äêwidth at half maxima of 31‚Äì39¬†nm, lifetime of 120‚Äì770¬†ms, and luminescent dissymmetry of ‚âà10‚àí3. Also, excellent stability capable of resisting quenching effects of oxygen, organic solvents, and aqueous solutions of strong acids and bases are observed. With these advantages, applications of chirality information encryption, afterglow grayscale imaging, and 3D high‚Äêresolution afterglow models are realized, promoting significantly the fundamental understandings on the modulation of organic afterglow brightness and construction of high‚Äêperformance pRTP materials with advanced photophysical properties and applications.

item.title: Benchmarking Corrosion with Anionic Polarity Index for Stable and Fast Aqueous Batteries Even in Low‚ÄêConcentration Electrolyte
item.content:encoded:
Since the water‚Äêinduced corrosion in aqueous electrolytes, including spontaneous chemical and electrochemical hydrogen evolution corrosion, will have a very adverse impact on the lifespan and rate performance of aqueous batteries. Through theoretical simulation, a strategy of anionic polarity index is proposed to resist corrosion by manipulating interfacial and solvated water simultaneously, thus realizing stable and fast Zn aqueous batteries.
Abstract Despite aqueous electrolyte endowing batteries with the merits of safe operation, low‚Äêcost fabrication, and high ionic conductivity, water‚Äêinduced corrosion, including spontaneous chemical and electrochemical hydrogen evolution corrosion, adversely affects lifespan and rate capability. There is still a lack of selection criteria for benchmarking corrosion behavior qualitatively. Through theoretical simulation, an anionic polarity index (API) tactic is proposed to resist corrosion by manipulating interfacial and solvated water concomitantly, thus realizing stable and fast Zn aqueous batteries (ZABs). As proof of concept, a low‚Äêcost zinc salt of 0.5 m zinc bis(4‚Äêhydroxybenzenesulphonate) (Zn(HBS)2) with low‚ÄêAPI anion is prioritized. Combined in situ spectroscopic and electrochemical analyses reveal that, even in a low‚Äêconcentration electrolyte, the low‚ÄêAPI anion reduces interfacial water in the inner Helmholtz plane, shielding the chemical water dissociation. Meanwhile, their entering into the solvation sheath of Zn2+ lowers the solvent‚Äêseparated ion pair, suppressing the electrochemical corrosion. The elaborated API‚Äêscreened zinc salt endows fast plating kinetics of 50 mA cm‚àí2 (119.1 mV polarization), high coulombic efficiency of 99.8%, dendrite‚Äêfree cycling over 1600 h, and prolonged lifespan over 5000 cycles for the Zn‚ÄêV cell. The results provide new metrics that can benchmark the success of ZABs for large‚Äêscale energy storage.

item.title: Molecular Weight Engineering Modulates Lignin‚ÄêMetal Supramolecular Framework to Construct Carbon‚ÄêCoated CoRu Alloy for Effective Overall Water Splitting
item.content:encoded:
CoRu‚Äêbased alloy catalysts are synthesized via a Lignin‚ÄêMetal supramolecular framework by molecular weight engineering. Lignin with low molecular weight formed graphitic carbon layers with high defect density, resulting in excellent activity but limited stability. While lignin with high molecular weight produced amorphous carbon layers that enhanced durability. In‚Äêsitu Raman and DFT indicate that defect density controls electron transport and intermediate adsorption.
Abstract To overcome the challenges of low catalytic activity and instability, a molecular weight engineering strategy coupled with oxidative ammonolysis is developed to synthesize CoRu‚Äêbased alloy catalysts with distinct morphologies and properties from biorefinery lignin. This approach effectively modulates intrinsic active sites and exposes unsaturated nitrogen‚Äêoxygen structures, thereby tailoring the morphology and defect structure of the carbon layers in the catalysts. The as‚Äêsynthesized CoRu alloy catalysts from lignin precursors with varying molecular weights are designated as CoRu@OALC‚ÄêEtOAC, CoRu@OALC‚ÄêEtOH, and CoRu@OALC‚ÄêResidual. CoRu@OALC‚ÄêEtOAC, featuring a defect‚Äêrich graphitic carbon‚Äêcoated CoRu alloy structure, exhibited exceptional overall water‚Äêsplitting performance (1.48 V at 10 mA¬†cm‚àí2), significantly surpassing Pt/C || Ru/C (1.58 V at 10 mA¬†cm‚àí2). In contrast, CoRu@OALC‚ÄêResidual, with its amorphous carbon‚Äêcoated CoRu alloy structure, demonstrated remarkable stability (350 h at 100 mA¬†cm‚àí2), vastly outperforming Pt/C || Ru/C (6 h at 100 mA¬†cm‚àí2). In‚Äêsitu Raman spectroscopy and DFT calculations revealed that the defect‚Äêrich carbon layers effectively adsorb *H intermediates, accelerating the catalytic process. This strong adsorption also induces carbon layer rearrangement, leading to its dissolution of the carbon layer and oxidation of CoRu metal particles. This strategy provides a universal method for biomass‚Äêderived catalysts, establishing a direct relationship between molecular weight, catalyst morphology, and electrocatalytic performance.

item.title: Targeted High‚ÄêResolution 3D Imaging of Tumor Vasculatures at Different Stages Using Far‚ÄêRed AIE Nanoparticles Compatible with Tissue Clearing
item.content:encoded:
This study presents an imaging technology for precise mapping and analysis of lung tumor vasculature at different stages using HA@TANP, a supramolecular assembly of far‚Äêred fluorescence nanoparticles with aggregation‚Äêinduced emission (AIE), compatible with tissue optical clearing (TOC). The advanced imaging technique reveals significant insights into tumor vascular dynamics, offering valuable implications for cancer diagnosis and therapy.
Abstract The occurrence and progression of blood vessels plays a pivotal role in different stages of tumor development, while current imaging techniques exhibit limited sensitivity to capture the dynamic changes of vasculature at different tumor stages. This drawback hinders the comprehensive understanding of the tumor microenvironment, thereby impeding the development of efficacious therapeutic strategies. Herein, a high‚Äêresolution three‚Äêdimensional (3D) imaging technology is developed for mapping and analyzing vasculatures at different tumor stages using HA@TANP, a supramolecular assembly of far‚Äêred fluorescence nanoparticles with aggregation‚Äêinduced emission (AIE), compatible with tissue clearing. The hyaluronic acid (HA) in HA@TANP specifically targets CD44 antigen of tumor vasculature, while the acrylic acid in HA@TANP is applied for temperature‚Äêinduced polymerization to ensure the covalent attachment of AIE fluorophores. Additionally, tissue optical clearing technology boosts light penetration and imaging resolution in dense tumor tissues. This strategy allows for the quantitative analyses of vascular diameter, length, and straightness and their correlation with various responses to treatments. The findings contribute to a more comprehensive understanding of distinct tumor vascular stages, providing valuable insights for enhanced cancer diagnosis and therapies from a tumor vascular‚Äêtargeted perspective.

item.title: Bio‚ÄêBased Multicompartment Photonic Pigments: Unlocking Non‚ÄêIridescent Pure RGB Structural Colors for Versatile Chromatic Engineering
item.content:encoded:
This research presents a novel class of multicompartment photonic pigments derived from vegetable oils, leveraging biodegradable bottlebrush block copolymers to effectively mitigate Ostwald ripening in complex emulsion systems. Through the development of an innovative structural model, non‚Äêiridescent pure red hues are achieved in photonic glass, enabling unprecedented versatility in chromatic engineering via an RGB three‚Äêprimary color mixing strategy.
Abstract Non‚Äêiridescent photonic glass pigments of block copolymers show great potential for sustainable structural coloration. However, the ability to create accurate RGB color mixtures for real‚Äêworld applications is limited by the prevalent use of non‚Äêdegradable, fossil oil‚Äêderived components and the difficulty in achieving pure red hues. This work presents an alternative strategy for achieving more sustainable structural coloration by fabricating composite photonic pigments through controlled self‚Äêassembly of water, vegetable oil, and biodegradable bottlebrush block copolymers (BBCPs) in a complex emulsion system. The obtained photonic balls feature unprecedented multicompartment structures characterized by a short‚Äêrange ordered assembly of water nanodroplets stabilized by the BBCPs, along with oil droplets stabilized by these nanodroplets, which substantially enhances resistance to Ostwald ripening. Furthermore, a new structural model is introduced to eliminate disordered scattering, successfully creating a pure red structural color and overcoming a long‚Äêstanding limitation in versatile chromatic engineering.

item.title: Single‚ÄêAtom Enables Reverse Hydrogen Spillover for High‚ÄêPerformance Protonic Ceramic Fuel Cells
item.content:encoded:
A novel single‚Äêatom Ru anchor on BaCe0.125Fe0.875O3‚àíŒ¥ (BCF) perovskite, develope via a scalable solid‚Äêstate approach, forms a distinctive 4‚Äêcoordinate Ru‚ÄìO‚ÄìFe configuration that induces reverse hydrogen spillover and promotes proton‚Äêinvolved oxygen reduction. The optimized 2Ru‚ÄêBCF (2 wt.% Ru) cathode based fuel cell delivers an excellent peak power density of 1.78 W cm‚àí2 at 700¬†¬∞C with stable operation for 200 h.
Abstract Protonic ceramic fuel cells (PCFCs) offer a promising avenue for sustainable energy conversion, however, their commercial potential is hindered by sluggish proton‚Äêinvolved oxygen reduction reaction (P‚ÄêORR) kinetics and inadequate durability of cathode materials. Here, a novel single‚Äêatom Ru anchor on BaCe0.125Fe0.875O3‚àíŒ¥ (BCF) perovskite, synthesized by a facile and scalable solid‚Äêstate approach, as a potential cathode for PCFCs is reported. Theoretical and experimental analyses demonstrate that the single‚Äêatom Ru on BCF, characterized by a unique 4‚Äêcoordinate Ru‚ÄêO‚ÄêFe configuration, not only induces reverse hydrogen spillover but also acts as an active site for P‚ÄêORR. The application of the optimized 2Ru‚ÄêBCF (2 wt.% Ru) cathode in a single cell delivers an exceptional peak power density of 1.78 W cm‚àí2 at 700¬†¬∞C, along with excellent operational stability over 200 h. These findings provide new insights into single‚Äêatom engineering, advancing the commercial viability of PCFCs.

item.title: Universal Prophylactic Antitumor Vaccination Using Stem Cell Membrane‚ÄêCoated Nanoparticles
item.content:encoded:
Induced pluripotent stem cell membrane is coated onto adjuvant‚Äêloaded nanoparticle cores to create a universal cancer vaccine. The formulation utilizes oncofetal antigens present on the cell membrane to elicit broadly protective immune responses in vivo. The enhanced immunity generated by the nanovaccine enables robust prophylactic efficacy against multiple murine tumor models.
Abstract Cancer vaccines are a promising immunotherapeutic modality that function by training the immune system to recognize and destroy malignant cells. As tumor‚Äêspecific and tumor‚Äêassociated antigens generally cannot be identified until after a tumor has already been established, these vaccines must be applied therapeutically when strong immunosuppressive mechanisms are already in place. Building upon previous work using cell membrane coating nanotechnology, the development of a broad‚Äêspectrum prophylactic cancer nanovaccine that consists of induced pluripotent stem cell (iPSC) membrane coated around an adjuvant‚Äêloaded nanoparticle core is shown. The resulting nanostructure is capable of presenting iPSC‚Äêderived oncofetal antigens, which are oftentimes re‚Äêexpressed on cancer cells but lowly present on normal adult tissues. When administered in vivo, the iPSC membrane‚Äêcoated nanoparticles are highly immunostimulatory and elicit strong antitumor immunity that can successfully inhibit the growth of multiple tumor types, including five different murine tumor models and in a bilaterial heterogeneous tumor model. Overall, this work demonstrates an effective approach for engineering iPSC‚Äêbased nanovaccines that can be applied broadly to prevent cancer before it occurs.

item.title: Molecular Design of Dimeric Acceptor Enables Binary Organic Solar Cells with 19.78% Efficiency and Enhanced Stability
item.content:encoded:
By optimizing building blocks and linking modes, a dimeric acceptor, named DY‚ÄêFL, is innovatively designed and synthesized. Benefiting from the efficient molecular design strategy, DY‚ÄêFL‚Äêbased binary OSCs rendered an efficiency of 19.78%. Importantly, DY‚ÄêFL‚Äêbased devices showcased significantly enhanced photo/thermal stability in comparison to small molecule acceptor‚Äêbased OSCs.
Abstract The development of organic solar cells (OSCs) with high efficiency and stability is highly desirable to facilitate its commercial applications. Although dimeric acceptors with distinctive advantages have been widely studied, high‚Äêperformance binary OSCs based on such molecules have rarely been achieved. In this work, a new dimeric acceptor (DY‚ÄêFL) is constructed by simultaneously optimizing the linking sites and units, as well as the building blocks. Thanks to the effective molecular design, DY‚ÄêFL provides improved molecular stacking for fibrous morphology with favorable exciton/charge dynamics. Consequently, DY‚ÄêFL‚Äêbased binary OSCs render a superior power conversion efficiency (PCE) of 19.78%, representing a record‚Äêbreaking efficiency for binary OSCs based on dimeric acceptors. Importantly, DY‚ÄêFL‚Äêbased devices display significantly enhanced operational stability under external stimuli such as light and heat, in comparison to their small molecule acceptor (Y‚ÄêF)‚Äêbased counterpart. These findings highlight the significance of building blocks and linking modes, providing insight into the effective molecular design strategy of dimeric acceptors for state‚Äêof‚Äêthe‚Äêart OSCs.

item.title: Monomolecule Coupled to Oxygen‚ÄêDoped Carbon for Efficient Electrocatalytic Hydrogen Peroxide Production
item.content:encoded:
Cobalt phthalocyanine molecule‚Äêmodified oxygen‚Äêdoped carbon catalyst achieves superior oxygen reduction with two‚Äêelectron selectivity of 99% and hydrogen peroxide yield of 10.4 mol¬∑g‚àí1¬∑h‚àí1. The modulation of the electronic structure of active sites through œÄ‚ÄêœÄ stacking‚Äêmediated oxygen doping optimizes the interaction between active sites and intermediate *OOH.
Abstract The electrocatalytic production of hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) is an ideal alternative for the industrial anthraquinone process because of environmental friendliness and energy efficiency, depending on the activity and selectivity of catalysts. Carbon‚Äêbased materials possess prospects as candidate catalysts for the production of H2O2. Herein, cedar‚Äêderived monolithic carbon catalysts modified with coupling oxygen doping and phthalocyanine molecules are synthesized. Cobalt phthalocyanine (CoPc)¬†molecules are introduced onto the carbon surface to construct monomolecular active sites via œÄ‚ÄêœÄ stacking. The electronic structure of CoPc is modulated by oxygen doping on carbon substrates, mediated by monomolecular œÄ‚ÄêœÄ stacking. A synergistic effect optimally modulated the interaction between CoPc and key intermediate to H2O2. The energy barrier for oxygen reduction is reduced to optimize the selectivity to H2O2. CoPc@OCW provided up to 99% selectivity to H2O2 at 0.7¬†V versus RHE. In a three‚Äêphase flow cell, CoPc@OCW achieved an H2O2 yield up to 10.4 mol¬∑g‚àí1¬∑h‚àí1 at 0.2¬†V versus RHE with stable running for 24 h. The advantages of carbon‚Äêbased catalysts including the adjustable chemical structure depending on œÄ‚ÄêœÄ stacking and electronic structure of carbon atoms through oxygen doping improved the catalytic performances in the production of H2O2. This proof‚Äêto‚Äêconcept research demonstrates the potential application of carbon‚Äêbased molecular catalysts for electrochemical synthesis.

item.title: Industrial‚Äêcurrent Ammonia Synthesis by Polarized Cuprous Cyanamide Coupled to Valorization of Glycerol at 4,000 mA cm‚àí2
item.content:encoded:
This work presents a membrane electrode assembly (MEA) system featuring Cu2NCN as an efficient nitrate reduction (NO3RR) electrocatalyst, coupled with glycerol oxidation for low‚Äêvoltage, industrial‚Äêlevel NH3 production. Achieving 4000 mA cm‚àí2 at 2.52 V with sustained stability at 1000 mA cm‚àí2 over 100 h, the system offers 83% Faradaic efficiency, with theoretical insights on NO‚ÇÉ* adsorption and O‚ÄìN bond cleavage.
Abstract The electrocatalytic nitrate reduction (NO3RR) holds significance in both NH3 synthesis and nitrate contamination remediation. However, achieving industrial‚Äêscale current and high stability in membrane electrode assembly (MEA) electrolyzer remains challenging due to inherent high full‚Äêcell voltage for sluggish NO3RR and water oxidation. Here, Cu2NCN with positive surface electrostatic potential VS(r) is applied as highly efficient NO3RR electrocatalysts to achieve industrial‚Äêcurrent and low‚Äêvoltage stable NH3 production in MEA electrolyzer with coupled anodic glycerol oxidation. This paired electro‚Äêrefinery (PER) system reaches 4000 mA cm‚àí2 at 2.52 V and remains stable at industrial‚Äêlevel 1000 mA cm‚àí2 for 100 h with the NH3 production rate of 97000 ¬µgNH3 h‚àí1 cm‚àí2 and a Faradaic efficiency of 83%. Theoretical calculations elucidate that the asymmetric and electron‚Äêwithdrawing [N‚àíC‚â°N] units enhance polarization and VS(r), promoting robust and asymmetric adsorption of NO3* on Cu2NCN to facilitate O‚àíN bond dissociation. A comprehensive techno‚Äêeconomic analysis demonstrates the profitability and commercial viability of this coupled system. Our work opens a new avenue and marks a significant advancement in MEA systems for industrial NH3 synthesis.

item.title: Lithiophilic‚ÄêGradient, Li+ Supplementary Interphase Design for Lean Lithium Metal Batteries
item.content:encoded:
High energy/power density batteries have become an urgent need for the electric vehicle and consumer electronics markets. In this work, Cheng et¬†al. develop an lean lithium metal batteries (LLMB) prototype with lithiophilic‚Äêgradient, layer‚Äêstacked interfacial design and self‚Äêsupplementary Li sources for bare Cu foil. It provides a new perspective for the optimization strategy for next generation lithium metal batteries (LMBs).
Abstract The practicability of anode‚Äêless/free lithiummetal batteries (LMBs) is impeded by unregulated dendrite formation on thedeposition substrate. Herein, this study presents a lithiophilic‚Äêgradient, layer‚Äêstacked interfacial design for the lean lithium metal battery (LLMB) model. Engineered via a facile wet‚Äêchemistry approach, the high entropy metalphosphide (HEMP) particles with tunable lithiophilic species are dispersedwithin reduced graphene oxide (RGO). Moreover, a poly (vinylidene fluoride co‚Äêhexafluoropropylenepolymer) (PVDF‚ÄêHFP), blended with molten Li at the tailorable amounts, forms aLi supplementary top layer through a layer‚Äêtransfer printing technique. Theintegrated layer (HEMP@RGO‚ÄêMTL@PH) not only regulates the dendrite‚Äêfree lithiumdeposition towards the Cu substrate up to 10 mAh cm‚àí2, but also maintains robust cyclability of the symmetric cell at 5 mA cm‚àí2 even under 83% depth of discharge. As pairing the modified Cu foil with the LiNi0.8Mn0.1Co0.1O2 cathode (NCM811, 16.9 mg cm‚àí2, double sided, N/P ratio of 0.21) in the 200 mAh pouch cell, achieves gravimetric energy densities of 414.7 Wh kg‚àí1, power output of 977.1 W kg‚àí1, as well as highly reversible phasic evolutionmonitored in operando. This gradient interfacial strategy can promotethe commercialization of energy/power‚Äêdense energy storage solutions.

item.title: Toward Intrinsically Stretchable OLEDs with High Efficiency
item.content:encoded:
This perspective provides a systematic discussion on the challenges and solutions in designing materials for intrinsically stretchable organic light‚Äêemitting diodes (ISOLEDs). It also highlights prospective challenges and offers insights into the development of highly efficient and stable ISOLEDs for practical applications.
Abstract Wearable electronics require stretchable displays that can withstand large and repeated mechanical deformation without failure. Intrinsically stretchable organic light‚Äêemitting diodes (ISOLEDs) that operate under DC voltage provide promising candidates for wearable display applications. However, the lack of sophisticated stretchable materials and processing techniques suitable for ISOLEDs results in a significant deficit in the efficiency of state‚Äêof‚Äêthe‚Äêart ISOLEDs compared to industrial standards. The design of stretchable conducting and semiconducting materials poses a significant challenge because of trade‚Äêoff relationships between stretchability and properties such as conductivity and charge carrier mobility. To increase the efficiency of ISOLEDs to meet industrial standards, strategies to overcome these trade‚Äêoffs must be developed. This perspective discusses recent progress and challenges in designing stretchable electrodes, light‚Äêemitting materials, transport materials, and potential applications of ISOLEDs. It¬†provides a useful guide in this field to develop efficient ISOLEDs for system‚Äêlevel integration.

item.title: Efficient Blue Perovskite LEDs via Bottom‚ÄêUp Charge Manipulation for Solution‚ÄêProcessed Active‚ÄêMatrix Displays
item.content:encoded:
A bottom‚Äêup collaborative charge manipulation strategy is developed to minimize the interfacial charge loss in blue perovskite light‚Äêemitting diodes, leading to stable blue electroluminescence and an external quantum efficiency of 25.87%. Solution‚Äêprocessed active‚Äêmatrix display with clear and uniform patterning is achieved by integrating with thin‚Äêfilm transistor circuits.
Abstract Perovskite light‚Äêemitting diodes (PeLEDs) are emerging as strong candidates for next‚Äêgeneration displays due to their outstanding optoelectronic properties, solution processability, and cost‚Äêeffectiveness. However, the development of highly efficient blue PeLEDs remains a significant challenge. Here, a bottom‚Äêup strategy is introduced for precise charge manipulation in blue perovskites to enhance radiative recombination efficiency. By employing 1,3‚Äêbis(N‚Äêcarbazolyl)benzene as an inserted hole transport layer, improved hole injection efficiency is achieved while effectively suppressing reverse electron transport and exciton quenching. Additionally, a fluorinated ester additive is incorporated to control perovskite crystallization, facilitating the formation of well‚Äêaligned reduced‚Äêdimensional phases to reduce nonradiative recombination losses. The resulting blue PeLEDs exhibit a record‚Äêbreaking external quantum efficiency of 25.87%, the highest reported for one‚Äêstep‚Äêprepared blue perovskite films. Furthermore, integration with thin‚Äêfilm transistor circuits enables solution‚Äêprocessed active‚Äêmatrix perovskite displays with sharp and uniform patterning. This work provides a comprehensive pathway for advancing blue PeLEDs toward high‚Äêperformance display applications.

item.title: Advanced GeTe‚ÄêBased Thermoelectrics: Charting the Path from Performance Optimization to Devices
item.content:encoded:
GeTe, as a classical thermoelectric material, has realized a significant leap in thermoelectric performance and conversion efficiency, stemming from its great intrinsic potential. This review presents an exceptional scientific summary of GeTe thermoelectrics from enhancing performance to device advancements, starting from the unique aspect of GeTe's drawbacks and features.
Abstract Thermoelectric (TE) materials can interconvert electricity into heat, rendering them versatile for refrigeration and power generation. GeTe as a distinguished TE material has attracted considerable focus owing to its excellent TE performance. Herein, the milestones of research progress on GeTe are reviewed. The intrinsic potentials of GeTe are elaborated, mainly focusing on crystal structure, band structure and microstructures. The path of GeTe‚Äêbased thermoelectrics from performance optimization to the devices is attempted to chart, referring to its shortcomings and characteristics. Primarily, optimization of the synthesis process is implemented to inhibit the generation of Ge precipitates and phonon migration. Furthermore, the thermoelectric performance of GeTe is enhanced through its features, including phase transition, multiple valence bands, and various microstructures via doping and alloying. Subsequently, the advancements of GeTe thermoelectric devices are presented from the aspect of device integration. Eventually, the prospect and challenges for the future direction of GeTe‚Äêbased materials are proposed, offering a roadmap to inject vitality into further developments.

item.title: Molecular Reconstruction for the High‚ÄêPerformance Recycled Fluororubbers
item.content:encoded:
A molecular reconstruction strategy is proposed to upcycle waste fluororubber into chemically awakenable and high‚Äêperformance ATLF‚ÄêBoc through three reactions: controlled oxidative degradation, fluorination addition and decarboxylation amination. This strategy solved the problem of difficult recovery of waste fluororubber, realized the upgrading and recycling of waste fluororubber. Furthermore, an epoxy curing system is constructed to achieve control of ATLF performance.
Abstract To address the challenges associated with the difficult recycling of fluorinated specialty materials and the subpar performance of recycled products, a molecular reconstruction strategy of oxidative degradation, fluorination addition is reported, and end‚Äêgroup transformation, which upcycled waste fluororubber into high‚Äêperformance, chemically awakenable amino‚Äêterminated low‚Äêmolecular‚Äêweight fluoropolymer (ATLF‚ÄêBoc). Leveraging the chemical properties of the vinylidene fluoride structure in the waste fluororubber, carboxyl‚Äêterminated low‚Äêmolecular‚Äêweight fluoropolymer (CTLF) with controlled molecular weight and end‚Äêgroup content are synthesized. Further, the whole chain is structurally strengthened at the molecular scale to achieve higher fluorine content and thermal stability, and saturated carboxyl‚Äêterminated low‚Äêmolecular‚Äêweight fluoropolymer (SCTLF) is synthesized. Subsequently, to balance high reactivity and stable storage, high‚Äêperformance ATLF‚ÄêBoc is synthesized, realizing the upcycling of waste fluororubber. After upcycling, the awakened ATLF exhibits a high fluorine content (66.95%), and the cured ATLF shows the regulation of surface hydrophilicity and hydrophobicity (between 43¬∞ and 114¬∞), a high tensile strength of 13.3¬†MPa, an excellent thermal stability (T10% = 359¬†¬∞C). In this study, a novel solution for the upcycling of waste fluororubbers for fabricating functional materials is offered, which is of great significance in the field of fluorinated specialty materials.

item.title: Flexible Tunable‚ÄêPlasticity Synaptic Transistors for Mimicking Dynamic Cognition and Reservoir Computing
item.content:encoded:
A flexible tunable‚Äêplasticity synaptic transistor (TST) is developed using indium gallium zinc oxide as a channel and a hybrid polyimide and Al2O3 layer as dielectric. The TST exhibits a transition from short‚Äêterm plasticity to long‚Äêterm plasticity by adjusting stimulus amplitude. It also enables neural networks with 94.1% recognition and 4‚Äêbit reservoir computing, laying the foundation for intelligent and efficient computing systems.
Abstract Inspired by biological systems, neuromorphic computing can process extensive data and complex tasks more efficiently than traditional architectures. Artificial synaptic devices, serving as fundamental components in neuromorphic computing, needto closely mimic synaptic characteristics and construct neural network computing systems. However, most existing multifunctional synapse devices are structurally complex and lack tunability, making them unsuitable for building smarter computing systems. In this work, a flexible tunable‚Äêplasticity synaptic transistor (TST) is realized with memory modulation and neuromorphic computing capabilities by using indium gallium zinc oxide as channel and a hybrid layer of polyimide and Al2O3 as dielectric. The TST exhibits a novel transition from short‚Äêterm plasticity to long‚Äêterm one by adjusting stimulus amplitude, mirroring dynamic human memory and forgetting behaviors across various scenarios. A neural network system with low non‚Äêlinearity and a wide range of conductance variations is constructed, and it demonstrates a 94.1% recognition rate on classical datasets. A reservoir computing system for 4‚Äêbit coding is also developed, which significantly reduces computational complexity and network size without sacrificing recognition accuracy. The devices and the system work as the foundation of more intelligent and more efficient computing systems.

item.title: Phototunable Rayleigh 3D Soft Self‚ÄêOscillator Enabling Versatile Biomimetic Tubular Peristaltic Pumping
item.content:encoded:
Leveraging biomechanical strategy based on two direction‚Äêand‚Äêdimension‚Äêtubular instabilities: postbuckling and snapping, it has created a phototunable Rayleigh 3D soft self‚Äêoscillator with direction/dimension/symmetry tunable self‚Äêoscillating deformations, which allow for controllable manipulation of spatiotemporal 3D motions of local tubular walls to achieve high‚ÄêDOF, multimodal, autonomous biomimetic tubular peristaltic pumping that can adapt to transporting a variety of matter.
Abstract Living tubular organs can spatiotemporally and cyclically deform their muscular walls to implement adaptable and sustainable peristaltic pumping applicable to broad matter, achieved via asymmetric and non‚Äêequilibrium self‚Äêoscillating deformations of muscular walls. However, man‚Äêmade tubular soft actuators have been limited to pumping a few simple matters, because of their reciprocal and monotonic wall motions that cannot break time‚Äêreversal symmetry and system equilibrium to gain adaptable and sustainable pumping. Here, a phototunable Rayleigh 3D soft self‚Äêoscillator (PR3DSSO) capable of multimodal, nonreciprocal, self‚Äêsustainable wall deformations is presented. PR3DSSO's design leverages two direction‚Äêand‚Äêdimension‚Äêphototunable tubular instabilities: snapping and postbuckling. The post‚Äêbuckling instability can generate local‚Äêwall origami which cannot only fold local walls into multimodal shape‚Äêmode waves, but also break wall‚Äêmotion symmetry; snapping instabilities help break equilibrium in wall motions to initiate autonomous wall motions. These phototunable‚Äêinstabilities‚Äêdriven wall deformations unprecedentedly create Rayleigh‚Äêlike 3D wall motions, which allow for versatile biomimetic tubular peristaltic pumping adapt to broad matter. Our PR3DSSO would spur creative life‚Äêlike active‚Äêmaterial designs and novel pumping functions.

item.title: Buried Interface Regulation with a Supramolecular Assembled Template Enables High‚ÄêPerformance Perovskite Solar Cells for Minimizing the VOC Deficit
item.content:encoded:
Self‚Äêassembled amphiphilic phosphonate‚Äêbased supramolecule functions as a perovskite crystallization‚Äêdriven template at SnO2/perovskite buried interface, which induces a highly preferred (100) orientation toward out‚Äêof‚Äêplane direction, facilitates carrier extraction and transfer, passivates the intrinsic defects, and achieves a promising efficiency of 25.34%, with a maximum VOC of 1.23 V, corresponding to the lowest reported 0.306 V deficit.
Abstract Despite the rapid development of perovskite solar cells (PSCs) in the past decade, the open‚Äêcircuit voltage (VOC) of PSCs still lags behind the theoretical Shockley‚ÄìQueisser limit. Energy‚Äêlevel mismatch and unwanted nonradiative recombination at key interfaces are the main factors detrimental to VOC. Herein, a perovskite crystallization‚Äêdriven template is constructed at the SnO2/perovskite buried interface through a self‚Äêassembled amphiphilic phosphonate derivative. The highly oriented supramolecular template grows from an evolutionary selection growth via solid‚Äìsolid phase transition. This strategy induces perovskite crystallization into a highly preferred (100) orientation toward out‚Äêof‚Äêplane direction and facilitated carrier extraction and transfer due to the elimination of energy barrier. This self‚Äêassembly process positively passivates the intrinsic surface defects at the SnO2/perovskite interface through the functionalized moieties, a marked contrast to the passive effect achieved via incidental contacts in conventional passivation methods. As a result, PSCs with buried interface modification exhibit a promising PCE of 25.34%, with a maximum VOC of 1.23¬†V, corresponding to a mere 0.306¬†V deficit (for perovskite bandgap of 1.536¬†eV), reaching 97.2% of the theoretical VOC limit. This strategy spontaneously improves the long‚Äêterm operational stability of PSCs under thermal and moisture stress (ISOS‚ÄêL‚Äê3: MPP, 65 ¬∞C, 50% RH, T92 lifetime exceeding 1200¬†h).

item.title: Optical Synaptic Devices with Multiple Encryption Features Based on SERS‚ÄêRevealed Charge‚ÄêTransfer Mechanism
item.content:encoded:
A hybrid R6G/InSe structure is designed, and the charge transfer mechanism within this structure is validated using SERS. This structure effectively emulates biological synapses, comprising a presynaptic membrane (R6G photosensitive layer), synaptic cleft (R6G/InSe interface), and postsynaptic membrane (InSe sensing layer). The charge transfer process in this structure closely mirrors the neurotransmitter transfer across the synaptic cleft. Surface treatment techniques are employed to regulate the charge transfer process, enabling multiple on‚Äêchip encryption anti‚Äêcounterfeiting applications to be developed.
Abstract 2D optical synaptic devices with atomic‚Äêscale thickness show potential for building highly integrated tunable artificial visual neural networks. However, their atomic‚Äêscale thickness also leads to weak light absorption, limiting device photoresponse. Here, a high‚Äêperformance optical synaptic device based on a Rhodamine 6G (R6G)/InSe hybrid structure is proposed, achieving a remarkable 328.9% enhancement in photoresponse compared to InSe devices. Using surface‚Äêenhanced Raman spectroscopy (SERS) as a nondestructive probing technique, it is demonstrated that light‚Äêinduced charge transfer between R6G and InSe is the key mechanism enabling the device's high performance. Furthermore, introducing a self‚Äêlimited oxide layer on the InSe surface provides additional evidence for the charge transfer process. This charge‚Äêtransfer‚Äêbased device effectively mimics the neurotransmitter transmission process in biological synapses, showing unique potential in applications such as image preprocessing and decoding within artificial neural networks. In addition, through surface treatment techniques, precise control over the charge transfer process is achieved, enabling the design of a multiple encryption‚Äêbased anti‚Äêcounterfeiting array and highlighting their value in on‚Äêchip anti‚Äêcounterfeiting. By employing a spectrally noninvasive method to probe charge transfer, this study elucidates the critical role of charge transfer in optical synaptic devices and opens novel application pathways.

item.title: Manipulating the Assembly and Architecture of Fibrillar Silk
item.content:encoded:
In this study, advanced in situ AFM, PiFM, and Cryo‚ÄêEM are leveraged to realize in situ observations of nucleation, growth, and degradation of silk nanofibrils. A clear picture of the assembly and structural evolution of regenerated silk nanofibrils is defined and demonstrates a novel strategy for manipulating their structure and properties, which emerges from the understanding of their structure and assembly.
Abstract Silk is a unique and exceptionally strong biological material. However, no synthetic method has yet come close to replicating the properties of natural silk. This shortfall is attributed to an insufficient understanding of both silk nanofibril structure and the mechanism of formation. Here in situ atomic force microscopy (AFM) and photo‚Äêinduced force microscopy (PiFM) is utilized to investigate the formation process and define the basic structural paradigm of individual silk nanofibrils. By visualizing the multistage process of silk nanofibril formation, the importance of conformational transformations along the assembly pathway is revealed. Unfolded silk structures initially accumulate into amorphous clusters, which then evolve into crystal nuclei via conformational transformation into Œ≤‚Äêcrystallites. Nanofibril elongation then occurs through the attachment of silk molecules at a single end of the nanofibril tip; this is facilitated through the formation of a new amorphous cluster that then repeats the aforementioned conformational transformation. However, enzymatic digestion of the amorphous regions leads to direct, rapid elongation of Œ≤‚Äêcrystalline fibers. These findings imply that the energy landscape is characterized by shallow minima associated with intermediate states, which can be eliminated by introducing Œ≤‚Äêcrystallites, and motivate research into the directed modification of the silk assembly pathway to select for features beneficial to specific applications.

item.title: Fast Encapsulation of Microbes into Dissolvable Hydrogel Beads Enables High‚ÄêThroughput Microbial Single‚ÄêCell RNA Sequencing of Clinical Microbiome Samples
item.content:encoded:
This work develops smGel‚Äêseq, a high‚Äêthroughput microbial single‚Äêcell RNA sequencing method characterized by low microbial¬†input, minimal loss, reduced bias, and high sample compatibility using dissolvable hydrogel beads. smGel‚Äêseq achieves the first microbial single‚Äêcell RNA sequencing in a clinical sputum microbiome sample and found different subpopulations, one of which may be critical for antibiotic resistance and virulence.
Abstract Microbial single‚Äêcell RNA‚Äêseq (mscRNA‚Äêseq) can achieve resolution at the cellular level, enhancing the understanding of microbial communities. However, current high‚Äêthroughput mscRNA‚Äêseq methods are limited by multiple centrifugation steps, which can lead to microbial loss and bias. smGel‚Äêseq is reported, a high‚Äêthroughput single‚Äêmicrobe RNA sequencing method for clinical microbiome samples that employs hydrogel beads to encapsulate individual microbes to reduce microbial loss and input requirements. In this method, a novel microchannel array device is implemented for encapsulating single microbe in dissolvable hydrogel beads (smDHBs), along with an optimized automated microfluidic platform to co‚Äêencapsulate barcoded beads and smDHBs, enabling high‚Äêthroughput barcoding of individual microbes. smGel‚Äêseq significantly increases the microbial recovery rate in a gut microbiome sample from 8.8% to 91.8%. Furthermore, this method successfully processes clinical microbiome samples with microbial inputs 20 times lower than those required by previous methods. Notably, smGel‚Äêseq enables the first mscRNA‚Äêseq in a clinical sputum microbiome sample, revealing a specific microbial subpopulation that may play a key role in environmental adaptability, antibiotic resistance, and pathogenicity. These results highlight the compatibility of smGel‚Äêseq with clinical microbiome samples and demonstrate its potential for widespread application in diverse clinical and research settings.

item.title: Stimulus‚ÄêResponsive Emission via Dynamic Triplet Energy Transfer in Organic Room‚ÄêTemperature Phosphorescence Glass
item.content:encoded:
A facile strategy is proposed based on host‚Äêguest doping to achieve stimulus‚Äêresponsive, color‚Äêtunable, and time‚Äêdependent organic afterglow glasses by dynamic triplet energy transfer processes. Impressively, the phosphorescence resonance energy tranfer and Dexter‚Äêtype triplet‚Äêto‚Äêtriplet energy transfer mechanisms are revealed by fs‚ÄêTA spectra. The potential applications of these organic glasses in advanced anti‚Äêcounterfeiting, dynamic data encryption, as well as large‚Äêarea and flexible afterglow display are demonstrated.
Abstract Dynamic organic room‚Äêtemperature phosphorescence (RTP) glasses with color tunability offer significant potential for practical applications due to their high transparency and excellent machinability. In this study, organic glasses with efficient and dynamic RTP properties are used as triplet donors, combined with commercially available chromophores as singlet/triplet acceptors, to successfully fabricate a series of host‚Äêguest doping glasses with color‚Äêtunable organic afterglow and dynamic responses to external stimuli. The energy transfer mechanisms, including triplet‚Äêto‚Äêsinglet phosphorescence resonance energy transfer and Dexter‚Äêtype triplet‚Äêto‚Äêtriplet energy transfer, are confirmed using state‚Äêof‚Äêthe‚Äêart femtosecond time‚Äêresolved transient absorption spectroscopy. These organic glasses demonstrate excellent transparency, good machinability, and dynamic responsiveness to external stimuli. The study highlights their potential applications in large‚Äêarea afterglow glass fabrication, dynamic data encryption, and flexible afterglow displays. This work not only provides a simple design principle for developing novel organic glass materials with color tunability and dynamic responses but also promotes the potential applications of organic RTP materials in dynamic information encryption and flexible optoelectronics.

item.title: Polymer‚ÄêHalogen Pockets Steering *CO Adsorption Configurations for Highly Selective CO2 Electroreduction
item.content:encoded:
The design and synthesis of copper nanoparticles encaged in polymer‚Äêhalogen pockets for selective CO2 reduction are presented. As a direct outcome, the strategy achieves selective conversion of ethylene and ethanol, ‚âà48.3 ¬± 1.3% selectivity for ethanol, and 60.3 ¬± 2.1% for ethylene.
Abstract The selective CO2 electroreduction (CO2R) toward specific C2 products represents a critical challenge for practical applicability, requiring precise control over *CO intermediates. Herein, a ‚Äúpolymer‚Äêhalogen‚Äù pocketed Cu catalyst is proposed, wherein the adjustable concentration of Iodide ion (I‚àí) within the pocket enables continuous modulation of *CO adsorption configurations on the Cu, thereby enabling tailored CO2R toward ethylene or ethanol production. A perfluorosulfonic acid (PFSA)‚Äêmodified CuI catalyst is constructed, where I‚àí is in situ leaching from CuI and subsequently confined by PFSA as an anion shielding layer to form polymer‚Äêhalogen pockets. By tuning the thickness of PFSA shell, the amount of I‚àí in the pocket can be controlled. The surface‚Äêenhanced in situ Raman spectroscopy demonstrates that the coverage of *CO intermediates on Cu surface increases and tends to adsorb at low coordination Cu sites in catalyst granule for dimerization reaction as the I‚àí concentration in the pocket increases. Furthermore, the coordination environment exhibits distinct product selectivity. *CO at medium‚Äêcoordinated sites favor ethanol production, while those at low‚Äêcoordinated sites are conducive to ethylene formation. This strategy enables wide modulation of ethylene‚Äêto‚Äêethanol ratios from 0.65 to 3.96, achieving peak Faradaic efficiencies (FE) of 60.3 ¬±¬†2.1% for ethylene and 48.3 ¬±¬†1.3% for ethanol.

item.title: Modulating Coalescence Timing of Liquid Marbles via Wettability Adaptation
item.content:encoded:
The design of nanoparticles embedded with wettability adaptation allows the modulation of coalescence timing of liquid marbles on solid surfaces with ‚âà1 min resolutions without requiring external interventions. It enables droplet‚Äêbased cascade chemical reaction and Janus liquid/gas marble formation. Overall, it opens new possibilities in droplet/bubble science.
Abstract Droplet coalescence is ubiquitous in nature, and its regulation is significant in industrial processes and biomedical applications. While bare droplets suddenly coalesce in contact, the droplets covered with liquid‚Äêrepellent particles to form ‚Äúliquid marbles (LMs)‚Äù are not. Previously, the external stimuli‚Äêresponsive breakage of the particle layer enables the regulation of the coalescence timing. However, preprogramming the coalescence timing of droplets without stimuli is challenging. In this work, LMs that break the particle layer in preprogrammed time are reported. The particles have a core wettable site and are tethered with a low‚Äêwettability flexible molecular chain, which gradually increases wettability with time. The time‚Äêdependent wettability variation is observed because of the differences in the adaptation of the molecular chain; thus, it is repeatedly available, and its speed is controllable by chain length. The formed LMs expose bare droplet surfaces in preprogrammed timing, which enables the modulation of coalescence timing from 2 to 45 min without relying on external stimuli. Moreover, the additivity of the particles enables the fine‚Äêtuning of the coalescence time with ‚âà1¬†min resolutions. Further, the contact of several LMs with different adaptation times enables cascade droplet coalescence, opening a new route for droplet manipulation.

item.title: Mechanically Enhanced, Environmentally Stable, and Bioinspired Charge‚ÄêGradient Hydrogel Membranes for Efficient Ion Gradient Power Generation and Linear Self‚ÄêPowered Sensing
item.content:encoded:
In the presence of an ion gradient, the constructed charge gradients in the ultrathin ion‚Äêselective hydrogel membranes of hydrogel solid‚Äêstate electric organ accelerate ion transport while mitigating ion concentration polarization, achieving high electrical output performance. More interestingly, the prepared device can still be applied as a linear self‚Äêpowered pressure sensor after the ion gradient is completely dissipated.
Abstract The soft hydrogel power source is an interesting example of generating electricity from clean energy. However, ion‚Äêselective hydrogel membranes in the systems are often limited by low ion selectivity, high membrane resistance, insufficient mass transfer, and ion concentration polarization, resulting in a generally low power output. Inspired by the unique structure of the electric ray's electric organ, a vertically stacked hydrogel artificial electric organ is proposed, aiming to increase the output current to a greater extent. By constructing the charge gradient in ultrathin ion‚Äêselective hydrogel membranes, ion transport is accelerated while mitigating the ion concentration polarization. A single hydrogel artificial electric organ achieves high outputs of ‚âà290¬†mV and ‚âà1.46¬†mA cm‚àí2 with rechargeability, surpassing similar devices. Density functional theory further reveals that the energy barrier of ion transport in charge‚Äêgradient membranes is lower than that in nongradient membranes. More impressively, the device can still be applied as a linear self‚Äêpowered pressure sensor for monitoring human activities after the ion gradient is completely dissipated. This study elucidates the key role of the structure and design of ion‚Äêselective membranes in the artificial gel power generation system, providing new insights into the further development and multifunctional application of flexible gel power source.

item.title: Pressure Induced Molecular‚ÄêArrangement and Charge‚ÄêDensity Perturbance in Doped Polymer for Intelligent Motion and Vocal Recognitions
item.content:encoded:
The sidechain doped polymer is investigated to have great potential for pressure detection due to the advantages including molecular rearrangement and charge‚Äêdensity perturbance induced by micro‚Äêmechanical deformation. This sensor displayed low‚Äêpressure detection limit of 0.7¬†Pa as well as a rapid response time of 18.8¬†ms, enabling multi‚Äêmode motion analysis and intelligent vocal recognitions.
Abstract Conjugated polymers (CPs) show great potential for pressure detection due to the amorphous polymer packing, but a lack of clarity regarding sensing mechanisms hampers the development of further applications. Herein, a sacrificial template‚Äêfull solution method with both rough surface and high conductivity is described that can be applied to sandwich‚Äêstructured resistive pressure sensors. Transient absorption measurements demonstrate the significant increase of carrier lifetime (from 1.44 to 2.54¬†ns) induced by pressure, which directly evidenced the superior sensing mechanism of sidechain doped conjugated polymer. This sensor displayed low‚Äêpressure detection limit of 0.7¬†Pa as well as a rapid response time of 18.8¬†ms, enabling multi‚Äêmode motion analysis including wrist pulse, swallowing, finger bending, grabbing, and typing. Additionally, an intelligent vocal recognition system with convolutional neural networks is used which can achieve >96% classification accuracy across diverse vocal profiles. This general approach is anticipated and enables a new direction for the development of pressure sensors.

item.title: Electric‚ÄêField Regulation of Adhesion/De‚ÄêAdhesion/Release Capacity of Transparent and Electrochromic Adhesive
item.content:encoded:
A conductive hydrogel with surface adhesion and electric field‚Äêtriggered de‚Äêadhesion and release is fabricated from thioctic acid and L‚Äêarginine. The non‚Äêcovalent intermolecular attractions not only endow the hydrogel with useful bulk‚Äêstate properties and strong adhesion but also generate electric responsiveness for on‚Äêdemand de‚Äêadhesion and release.
Abstract Removing adhesive nondestructively and intact from the adhered surface is a difficult challenge for advanced adhesive materials. Compared with the commonly used thermal or chemical release, the controlled adhesive release via electric‚Äêfield offers practical application advantages. However, a noninvasive release mode such as this has not been available for the de‚Äêbonding of supramolecular adhesives that originate from small organic molecules. Herein, a conductive hydrogel with surface adhesion and electric field‚Äêtriggered de‚Äêadhesion and release is fabricated from thioctic acid (TA) and L‚Äêarginine (LA). The non‚Äêcovalent intermolecular attractions of poly[TA‚ÄêLA], especially its electrostatic interactions, not only endow it with useful bulk‚Äêstate properties and strong adhesion (up to 363.3¬†kPa) but also generate electric responsiveness for on‚Äêdemand de‚Äêadhesion and release. The poly[TA‚ÄêLA] adhesive layer can be easily released within a short time (<60 s) under a mild voltage (5‚âà10¬†V). After a combined experimental and theoretical investigation, It is concluded that the adhesive‚Äêlayer morphological and mechanical changes, activated by a weak current (1.1‚âà3.2¬†mA), are responsible for the adhesion failure, which takes place primarily at the anode. Importantly, rapid electric release of poly[TA‚ÄêLA] is applicable at low temperatures (5 V, 60 s, ‚àí40¬†¬∞C) or underwater (5 V, 60 s, 25¬†¬∞C).

item.title: Magnetically Switchable Adhesive Millirobots for Universal Manipulation in both Air and Water
item.content:encoded:
This study presents a series of millirobots with magnetically switchable adhesion, enabled by soft, double‚Äêreentrant micropillar arrays with side liquid‚Äêrepellency. These millirobots can universally manipulate a wide range of targets in both air and water. Beyond transportation, they are capable of performing various complex tasks, such as circuit repair, precision assembly, and high‚Äêspeed actuation in amphibious environments.
Abstract Magnetic soft robots with multimodal locomotion have demonstrated significant potential for target manipulation tasks in hard‚Äêto‚Äêreach spaces in recent years. Achieving universal manipulation between robots and their targets requires a nondestructive and easily switchable interaction with broad applicability across diverse targets. However, establishing versatile and dynamic interactions between diverse targets and robotic systems remains a significant challenge. Herein, a series of magnetic millirobots capable of universal target manipulation with magnetically switchable adhesion is reported. Through two‚Äêphoton lithography‚Äêassisted molding, magnetic soft double‚Äêreentrant micropillar arrays with liquid repellency are fabricated on the robots. These micropillar arrays can serve as switchable adhesion units for the millirobots to effectively manipulate targets of various geometries (0D, 1D, 2D, and 3D) in both air and water. As proof‚Äêof‚Äêconcept demonstrations, these adhesive robots can perform various complex tasks, including circuit repair, mini‚Äêturbine assembly, and high‚Äêspeed underwater rotation of the turbine machine. This work may offer a versatile approach to magnetic manipulation of non‚Äêmagnetic objects through amphibious adhesion, emerging as a new paradigm in robotic manipulation.

item.title: Multifunctional Spinel Structure for Efficient Direct Recycling of Spent Layered Cathodes into Fast‚ÄêCharging Materials
item.content:encoded:
A channel‚Äêassisted regeneration strategy that utilizes waste spinel cathode materials to construct fast lithium‚Äêion replenishment channels on the surface of spent LiNi0.5Co0.2Mn0.3O2 materials is proposed. This surface reconstruction not only facilitates efficient material regeneration but also effectively mitigates lattice expansion and side reactions under fast‚Äêcharging conditions, thereby optimizing the comprehensive electrochemical performance of the regenerated materials.
Abstract Direct recycling is increasingly recognized as a promising solution to alleviate the burgeoning contradiction between the growing demand for lithium‚Äêion batteries (LIBs) and amidst resource shortages. A critical challenge in this process is achieving efficient lithium compensation, which is vital for replenishing lost elements and promoting the reconstruction of degraded structures. Herein, inspired by the concept of ‚Äúrecycle waste with waste,‚Äù a channel‚Äêassisted regeneration strategy is proposed that utilizes waste spinel materials to reconstruct the surface of the spent layered cathode, clearing blocked channels and transforming them into a 3D¬†structure that facilitates rapid lithium‚Äêion transmission. This approach enhances the efficient replenishment of exogenous lithium salts into the particle lattice and prevents intrinsic thermal decomposition during heat treatment due to element deficiencies. The presence of the 3D ion channels can also improve the fast‚Äêcharging performance of the regenerated cathode material, achieving a capacity retention rate of 87.9% after 500 cycles at 10¬†C. Additionally, its overall electrochemical performance significantly outperforms that of commercial materials. This work addresses critical challenges in the direct solid‚Äêphase regeneration of cathode materials and offers valuable insights for optimizing next‚Äêgeneration LIB recycling technologies.

item.title: Self‚ÄêOxygenating PROTAC Microneedle for Spatiotemporally‚ÄêConfined Protein Degradation and Enhanced Glioblastoma Therapy
item.content:encoded:
Self‚Äêoxygenating PROTAC microneedle (MN)¬†is engineered to circumvent the blood‚Äêbrain‚Äêbarrier (BBB) and achieve spatiotemporally‚Äêconfined bromodomain and extraterminal protein 4 (BRD4) protein degradation. PPT7 NPs are swiftly released for rapid cellular uptake, confining the region of photodynamic therapy (PDT) and ARV771 production upon 671 nm laser irradiation. BM NPs are continuously released for generating oxygen (O2) to alleviate tumor hypoxia. This PROTAC‚Äêdelivered MN significantly inhibits¬†tumor growth in both subcutaneous and orthotopic GBM tumor models.
Abstract Glioblastoma (GBM) is the most aggressive subtype of primary brain tumors, which marginally respond¬†to standard chemotherapy due to the blood‚Äêbrain barrier (BBB) and the low tumor specificity of the therapeutics. Herein, a double‚Äêlayered microneedle (MN) patch is rationally engineered by integrating acid and light dual‚Äêactivatable PROteolysis TArgeting Chimera (PROTAC) nanoparticles and self‚Äêoxygenating BSA‚ÄêMnO2 (BM) nanoparticles for GBM treatment. The MN is administrated at the tumor site to locally deliver the PROTAC prodrug and BM nanoparticles. The PROTAC nanoparticles are rapidly released from the outer layer of the MN and specifically activated in the acidic intracellular environment of tumor cells. Subsequently, near‚Äêinfrared light activates the photosensitizer to produce singlet oxygen (1O2) through photodynamic therapy (PDT), thereby triggering spatiotemporally‚Äêtunable degradation of bromodomain and extraterminal protein 4 (BRD4). The BM nanoparticles, in the inner layer of the MN, serve as an oxygen supply station, and counteracts tumor hypoxia by converting hydrogen peroxide¬†(H2O2) into oxygen (O2), thus promoting PDT and PROTAC activation. This PROTAC prodrug‚Äêintegrated MN significantly inhibits tumor growth in both subcutaneous and orthotopic GBM tumor models. This study describes the first spatiotemporally‚Äêtunable protein degradation strategy for highly efficient GBM therapy, potentially advancing precise therapy of other kinds of refractory brain tumors.

item.title: Photo‚ÄêResponsive H2S Composite System Regulates the Nerve Regeneration Microenvironment Through Multiple Pathways
item.content:encoded:
This article designs and prepares a photo‚Äêresponsive H2S composite nerve transplantation conduit using electrospinning technology and drug delivery system, combining aligned structure, RGD peptide, H2S, and Zn‚ÄêCA MOFs. This system can not only achieve artificially controlled H2S release, but also slowly release Zn2+, achieving the joint regulation of Zn2+ and H2S in the nerve regeneration microenvironment.
Abstract After injury, the imbalance of the regeneration microenvironment caused by inflammation, oxidative stress, insufficient neurovascularization, and inadequate energy supply affects nerve regeneration. Drug‚Äêdelivery nerve conduits play a role in repairing the regenerative microenvironment. However, traditional drugs often fail to cross the blood‚Äênerve barrier and lack multifunctionality, limiting the effectiveness of conduit therapy. Therefore, it is necessary to construct a multifunctional conduit that regulate the regeneration microenvironment timely and effectively. Herein, a photo‚Äêresponsive hydrogen sulfide (H2S) composite nerve conduit, artificially controlled H2S release, is developed. A new structure of zinc‚Äêcitric acid organic metal framework (Zn‚ÄêCA MOFs) is utilized to improve its drug loading rate, achieving the joint regulation of the nerve regeneration microenvironment by H2S and Zn2+. In addition, RGD modification of polyester amide (P(CL‚ÄêMMD‚ÄêMAC)‚ÄêRGD)) combined with aligned structure is used to improve the performance of the conduit. Relevant results demonstrate that H2S and Zn2+ can regulate inflammatory response and oxidative stress and promote mitochondrial function recovery and angiogenesis. Furthermore, the aligned structure can promote cell adhesion and guide cell directed migration. Overall, this study provides a method of combining gas neurotransmitters with ions to improve the nerve regeneration microenvironment, accelerate nerve regeneration, and restore motor function.

item.title: Red, Green and Blue Liquid‚ÄêFilm Lasers Based on Colloidal Quantum‚ÄêDots
item.content:encoded:
Colloidal quantum dots (QDs) in liquid films achieve breakthrough vertical‚Äêcavity surface‚Äêemitting lasers across red, green, and blue spectra. By leveraging entropic ligands for ultrahigh solubility and integrating microfluidic cooling, this work overcomes thermal quenching, enabling stable lasing at MHz repetition rates. The platform unlocks customizable, solution‚Äêprocessed lasers for tunable wavelengths and diverse applications.
Abstract Colloidal quantum dots (cQD) are heralded for their tunable bandgaps, solution‚Äêprocessibility, and cost‚Äêeffectiveness, making them ideal candidates for lasing applications. However, previous cQD lasing demonstrations have largely depended on close‚Äêpacked solid‚Äêstate films, which are deemed essential to counteract the rapid decay of material gain. In this study, a novel approach is introduced utilizing ‚Äúentropic ligands and solvent‚Äù to enhance the solubility of cQDs in solution. By achieving the necessary critical volume fraction for lasing, this strategy leads to the groundbreaking development of the first liquid‚Äêstate vertical‚Äêcavity surface‚Äêemitting lasers (VCSELs) based on cQDs across the blue and green spectrum, encompassing diverse material systems such as CdSe‚Äêbased and InP‚Äêbased cQDs. Furthermore, by integrating the liquid‚Äêstate VCSEL with a microfluidic channel, it is demonstrated that heat dissipation during intense excitation is pivotal for cQD lasing likely across various excitation modes‚Äîwhether pulsed or continuous‚Äêwave, optically or electrically‚Äêpumped‚Äîand different media, including liquid and solid states. The research will lay the foundation for a new era of liquid‚Äêstate cQD lasers for specific occasions, distinguished by their customizable and largely‚Äêvariable wavelengths, compact form factors, diverse materials basis, and dependable performance.

item.title: M√∂bius Solvation Structure for Zinc‚ÄêIon Batteries
item.content:encoded:
Herein, in a bold departure from convention, the Ouzo effect is pioneeringly utilized to design surfactant‚Äêfree microemulsion electrolyte (SFMEE), creating the first application of water‚Äêin‚Äêoil type M√∂bius polarity topological solvation in zinc‚Äêion batteries. This approach enables dual regulation of both the solvent environment and the solvation structure, thereby enhancing battery performance.
Abstract Zinc‚Äêion batteries (ZIBs) have promising prospects in energy storage field, but the water molecules in aqueous electrolytes significantly compromise the stability of the anode and cathode interfaces and hinder the low‚Äêtemperature performance. Herein, water‚Äêin‚Äêoil type M√∂bius polarity topological solvation composed of oil, water, and amphiphilic salt are first‚Äêever pioneered, forming the surfactant‚Äêfree microemulsion electrolyte (SFMEE). This water‚Äêin‚Äêoil type M√∂bius solvation structure, characterized by its distinct inner and outer layers and a polarity inversion feature, successfully connects the non‚Äêpolar phase with the polar phase, eliminating the need for surfactants to reduce costs and system complexity. The amphiphilic anion of salt creates a polarity singularity and stabilizes the polarity‚Äêreversed encapsulation. The outer oil layer disrupts the cohesive polarity network of water and constructs a polarity‚Äêreversed cage to restrict water. A series of SFMEE combinations are investigated and then directly applied to ZIBs, confirming excellent universality and durability of this design. The Zn||NVO (NaV‚ÇÉO‚Çà¬∑1.5H‚ÇÇO) cells using SFMEE can stably cycle for 4000 cycles with a capacity of 125 mAh g‚àí1 and 86.8% capacity retention. This discovery of M√∂bius solvation structure unlock unprecedented levels of electrolyte design and illuminate the development of next‚Äêgeneration high‚Äêperformance energy storage systems.

item.title: Proton‚ÄêMediated Topological Interlayer Shift in 2D Covalent Organic Frameworks for Efficient Photocatalysis
item.content:encoded:
Present work demonstrates an efficient proton‚Äêmediation strategy for precise regulation of interlayer shift of 2D D‚ÄêA COFs for facilitated charge transfer and exciton dissociation in photocatalytic water reduction. The structure with eclipsed AA stacking delivers an improved hydrogen evolution rate up to 171.2 mmol¬†g‚àí1h‚àí1, setting a new benchmark in photocatalysis employing 2D COFs. These findings highlight the significance of addressing the topology‚Äêgoverned charge transfer dynamics in COFs for efficient solar energy conversion.
Abstract The interlayer carriers dynamics are of significance in optoelectronic applications of 2D donor‚Äêacceptor (D‚ÄêA) covalent organic frameworks (COFs), while are challenged by the delicate control over the inherently variable and sensitive interlayer interaction. Present work demonstrates an efficient proton‚Äêmediation strategy that allows for the precise regulation of interlayer shift of 2D D‚ÄêA COFs for facilitated charge transfer and exciton dissociation. Exemplified by three imine‚Äêlinked D‚ÄêA COFs (IMDA), mild proton‚Äêmediation generates an eclipsed AA stacking (IMDA‚ÄêAA) featuring in‚Äêplane D‚ÄêA pairs and fully overlapping D‚ÄêA œÄ‚Äêconjugations, while excessive proton‚Äêmediation disrupts these conjugations, resulting in a slipped AA stacking (IMDA‚ÄêSAA) with out‚Äêof‚Äêplane D‚ÄêA pairs. Further analysis reveals that the interlayer topology of eclipsed AA stacking of IMDA favors for the synergistically optimized charge transfer dynamics, including enhanced intralayer charge transport with reduced exciton binding energy, and boosted interlayer exciton dissociation. IMDA‚ÄêAA COF delivers an improved hydrogen evolution rate up to 171.2¬†mmol¬†g‚àí1h‚àí1 under visible light illumination in the presence of 1.5 wt.% Pt co‚Äêcatalysts, which is as far as is known the highest value among the reports of 2D COFs based photocatalysis. Present work will provide an important avenue of addressing the topology‚Äêgoverned charge transfer dynamics within COFs for solar energy conversion.

item.title: A Salidroside‚ÄêBased Radiosensitizer Regulates the Nrf2/ROS Pathway for X‚ÄêRay Activated Synergistic Cancer Precise Therapy
item.content:encoded:
A novel radiosensitizer integrating traditional Chinese medicine compound salidroside, Cu2+, and ‚Ä¢OH activated FL molecules is developed, which achieves enhanced radiosensitization effect and promotes CDT efficacy monitored by NIR‚ÄêII FL imaging. Salidroside blocks cells in the G2/M phase with the highest radiosensitivity and amplifies ROS levels, which provides sufficient chemical fuel for Cu+‚Äêmediated CDT to generate more ‚Ä¢OH.
Abstract The hypoxic microenvironment and radioresistance of tumor cells, as well as the delay in efficacy evaluation, significantly limit the effect of clinical radiotherapy. Therefore, developing effective radiosensitizers with monitoring of tumor response is of great significance for precise radiotherapy. Herein, a novel radiosensitizer (term as: SCuFs) is developed, consisting of traditional Chinese medicine (TCM) compounds salidroside, Cu2+, and hydroxyl radical (‚Ä¢OH) activated second near‚Äêinfrared window fluorescence (NIR‚ÄêII FL) molecules, which make the radiosensitization effect and boosted chemodynamic therapy (CDT) efficacy. The overexpressed glutathione in the tumor induces the SCuFs dissociation, allowing deep penetration of the drug to the whole tumor region. After X‚Äêray irradiation, salidroside inhibits the Nuclear factor erythroid 2‚Äêlike 2 (Nrf2)protein expression and blocks cells in the G2/M phase with the highest radiosensitivity, which amplifies the reactive oxygen species (ROS) generation to exacerbate DNA damage, thus achieving radiosensitization. Meanwhile, the upregulated ROS provides sufficient chemical fuel for Cu+‚Äêmediated CDT to produce more ‚Ä¢OH. NIR‚ÄêII FL imaging can monitor the ‚Ä¢OH changes during the therapy process, confirming the radiosensitization effect and CDT process related to ‚Ä¢OH. This study not only achieves effective radiosensitization and cascaded ROS‚Äêmediated CDT efficacy, but also provides a useful tool for monitoring therapeutic efficacy, showing great prospects for clinical application.

item.title: Hyper‚ÄêCrosslinking to Customize Ultrathin‚ÄêWall Closed Pores in Pitch‚ÄêDerived Carbon for Sodium‚ÄêIon Batteries
item.content:encoded:
This work introduces an innovative hyper‚Äêcrosslinking strategy to molecularly reconstruct pitch and precisely tailor the closed‚Äêpore structure of derived carbon. This strategy enables the structure transition from graphitic soft carbon to highly disordered carbon with abundant closed‚Äêpore featuring appropriate pore sizes (2¬†nm) and ultrathin pore walls (1‚Äì2 layers). This work advances the development of low‚Äêcost and high‚Äêperformance carbon materials.
Abstract Pitch is a highly preferable and cost‚Äêeffective precursor of carbon materials. Nevertheless, its direct pyrolysis typically yields highly graphitized soft carbon, posing challenges to the modulation of closed‚Äêpore architecture, due to intense intermolecular œÄ‚ÄìœÄ interactions. This results in a negligible plateau capacity and sluggish diffusion kinetics in sodium‚Äêion batteries (SIBs). In this study, an innovative hyper‚Äêcrosslinking strategy is proposed to reconstruct pitch molecularly and precisely tailor the closed‚Äêpore structure of the derived carbon. The crosslinker intertwined the pitch units, transforming the linear molecules into 3D porous polymers. Structurally, these 3D cavities tactfully reserved space for forming closed‚Äêpore cores, with the single‚Äêlayer pitch network skeleton transforming into ultrathin pore walls upon carbonization. This strategy enabled the disruption of intense œÄ‚ÄìœÄ interactions and, therefore, inhibited structural ordering, facilitating a structure transition from graphitic soft carbon to highly‚Äêdisordered carbon with abundant closed pores featuring appropriate pore sizes (2¬†nm) and ultrathin pore walls (1‚Äì2 layers). The optimal sample delivered a high capacity of 370¬†mAh¬†g‚àí1 at 30¬†mA¬†g‚àí1, as well as a rate capability that surpassed those of most previously reported pitch‚Äêderived carbons. Hyper‚Äêcrosslinking has advanced the development of low‚Äêcost and high‚Äêperformance carbon materials for large‚Äêscale energy storage.

item.title: Integrating Ethereal Molecular Backbones into the Ester Solvent with High Solubility of Nitrate for High‚ÄêVoltage Li Metal Batteries
item.content:encoded:
By integrating the ethereal backbones into ester solvents and designing new organic nitrates, the high solubility of nitrate salt into the ester electrolyte is successfully achieved. The electrolyte containing new organic nitrate and designed ester solvent exhibits excellent cycle stability for Li||LiNi0.8Co0.1Mn0.1O2 (NCM811) batteries. Consequently, 1 Ah Li||NCM811 pouch cell showcases excellent cycle stability over 150 times.
Abstract The high‚Äêenergy‚Äêdensity Li metal batteries require high‚Äêvoltage cathode, low negative/positive capacity (N/P) ratio and lean electrolyte. Despite the all‚Äêfluorinated electrolytes with severe corrosion, the development of ester electrolytes is stagnant due to the incompatibility of ester solvent with Li metal anode. Hence, various electrolyte additives have been developed. Among them, LiNO3 is considered as the most effective electrolyte additive for improving the reversibility of Li deposition. Unfortunately, their solubility into the ester solvent is extremely low. This investigation suggests that the strong ionic bonds in LiNO3 and the low solvation energy of ester solvent are the main triggers for the insolubility of LiNO3 in the ester electrolyte. Hence, a new organic nitrate salt (N‚Äêpropyl‚ÄêN‚Äêmethylpyrrolidinium nitrate (Py13NO3)) with large organic cations and a new liner ester solvent (dipropyleneglycol methyl ether acetate (DPGMEA)) is designed, which integrates the ethereal molecular backbones into the ester solvent. Consequently, the electrolyte containing 1.2¬†m lithium bis(fluorosulfonyl)imide (LiFSI), 0.3¬†m Py13NO3 and 0.1¬†m lithium disfluorophosphate (LiPO2F2) in fluoroethylene carbonate (FEC):DPGMEA (2:8) showcases excellent electrochemical performance in high‚Äêvoltage Li metal batteries. Eventually, the ‚Äú1 Ah level‚Äù Li||LiNi0.8Co0.1Mn0.1O2 (NCM811) pouch cell (N/P ratio ‚âà1.2; electrolyte/capacity (E/C) ratio ‚âà2.5¬†g Ah‚àí1) exhibits excellent cycle life over 150 times in the designed electrolyte.

item.title: Polymer Microarray with Tailored Morphologies through Condensed Droplet Polymerization for High‚ÄêResolution Optical Imaging Applications
item.content:encoded:
This Study introduces condensed droplet polymerization (CDP) technology, enabling the fabrication of polymeric micro‚Äê and nano‚Äêdome arrays (PDAs) with tunable geometric properties. By manipulating polymerization kinetics, CDP allows for the rapid manufacturing of PDAs with specific sizes, radii of curvature, and surface densities. The research explores the optical properties of PDAs as nanolenses, enhancing high‚Äêresolution optical imaging capabilities.
Abstract Nature‚Äêinspired functional surfaces with micro‚Äê and nanoscale features have garnered interest for potential applications in optics, imaging, and sensing. Traditional fabrication methods, such as lithography and self‚Äêassembly, face limitations in versatility, scalability, and morphology control. This study introduces an innovative technology, condensed droplet polymerization (CDP), for fabricating polymeric micro‚Äê and nano‚Äêdome arrays (PDAs) with readily tunable geometric properties‚Äîa challenging feat for conventional methods. The CDP process leverages free‚Äêradical polymerization in condensed monomer droplets, allowing rapid production of PDAs with targeted sizes, radii of curvature, and surface densities by manipulating a key synthesis parameter: the temperature of a filament array that activates initiators. This work systematically unravels its effects on polymerization kinetics, viscoelastic properties of the polymerizing droplets, and geometric characteristics of the PDAs. Utilizing in situ digital microscope, this work reveals the morphological evolution of the PDAs during the process. The resulting PDAs exhibit distinct optical properties, including magnification that enables high‚Äêresolution imaging beyond the diffraction limit of conventional microscopes. This work demonstrates the ability to magnify and focus light, enhancing imaging of subwavelength structures and biological specimens. This work advances the understanding of polymerization mechanisms in nano‚Äêsized reactors (i.e., droplets) and paves the way for developing compact optical imaging and sensing technologies.

item.title: Customized Multifunctional Additive Regulates 1.67 eV‚ÄêWide‚ÄêBandgap Perovskite Crystallization for Four‚ÄêTerminal Perovskite/Silicon Tandem Solar Cells
item.content:encoded:
A doping strategy of incorporating Bis(trifluoroacetoxy)iodo)benzene (BTFIB) additive in 1.67 eV WBG perovskite precursor has been proposed to passivate uncoordinated lead ions and iodide vacancies and retard the crystallization of perovskite. Finally, BTFIB‚Äêbased perovskite solar cells yielded a champion efficiency of 23.05% (certified 22.21%) and enabled a four‚Äêterminal perovskite/Si tandem cell with a PCE of 31.20% and excellent long‚Äêterm stability.
Abstract Wide‚Äêbandgap (WBG) perovskite solar cells (PSCs, Eg >¬†1.6¬†eV), serving as the top cell in perovskite/silicon tandem solar cells (PSTSCs), play an indispensable role in absorbing high energy photons and increasing overall efficiency. However, WBG PSCs often suffer from severe light‚Äêinduced phase segregation and significant non‚Äêradiative recombination losses due to uncontrolled rapid crystallization. Here, polyfluoride molecular additives are designed and incorporated via (diacetoxyiodo)benzene into WBG perovskite, to regulate crystallization process of perovskite films and thereby reduce defects. (Bis(trifluoroacetoxy)iodo)benzene (BTFIB) can passivate uncoordinated lead ions and iodide vacancies, thereby inhibiting phase separation caused by iodide migration and reducing non‚Äêradiative recombination loss during charge transport. Moreover, the introduction of BTFIB can effectively moderate the film formation process and confer excellent hydrophobic properties to the films. Consequently, BTFIB‚Äêbased 1.67 eV‚ÄêWBG perovskite devices yield a champion efficiency of 23.05% (certified efficiency of 22.21%), enabling a 31.20% efficiency in four‚Äêterminal PSTSCs, along with excellent open‚Äêcircuit voltage of 1.246¬†V and fill factor of 85.34%. After 2500¬†h of aging in a glovebox, the device retained 80% of its initial efficiency.

item.title: Asymmetric Self‚ÄêAssembly of Colloidal Superstructures in Nested Transient Emulsion Aerosols
item.content:encoded:
A novel nested transient emulsion aerosol system is presented for the asymmetric self‚Äêassembly of colloidal nanoparticles into superstructures with anisotropic morphologies. These nested transient emulsion aerosols break the spherical symmetry associated with conventional emulsion droplets, enabling the production of anisotropic superstructures with potential applications previously considered unattainable.
Abstract Emulsions are versatile and robust platforms for colloidal self‚Äêassembly, but their ability to create complex and functional superstructures is hindered by the inherent symmetry of droplets. Here the creation of an aerosol of nested transient emulsion droplets with inherent asymmetry is reported, achieved by converging beams of water and 1‚Äêbutanol mists. Self‚Äêassembly of nanoparticles occurs within such emulsion droplets as driven by the rapid two‚Äêphase interface diffusion, producing anisotropic superstructures. A unique hollowing process is observed due to the asymmetric diffusion of solvents, akin to the Kirkendall effect. This novel assembly platform offers several advantages, including asymmetric self‚Äêassembly in air, surfactant‚Äêfree operation, and tunable droplet size.
