LACH/PNA disrupts tumor matrix and modulates cancer‚Äêassociated fibroblasts, thus facilitating its heat/mass transfer in tumors. Meanwhile, LACH/PNA demonstrates specific cytotoxicity on hepatoma cells and is further intensified by thermal treatment.
Abstract Thermal ablation (TA) is widely used for clinical treatment of various cancers. However, TA often struggles to efficiently kill tumor cells without injuring adjacent normal tissues/cells, leading to thermo‚Äêmediated tumor relapse and metastasis, owing to the immunosuppressive microenvironment surrounding residual tumor cells. In this study, a temperature‚Äêsensitive ionic liquid composed of lipoic acid and choline (LACH/PNA) is developed as a multifunctional TA sensitizer to suppress tumor metastasis induced by incomplete microwave ablation. LACH/PNA exhibits a high diffusion coefficient by disrupting the tumor matrix and modulating cancer‚Äêassociated fibroblasts, thereby facilitating heat and mass transfer in tumors. LACH/PNA demonstrates greater cytotoxicity toward hepatoma cells than on normal hepatocytes with this effect further intensified by thermal treatment. These findings highlight LACH/PNA as a promising multifunctional sensitizer for clinical chemoablation‚Äêmicrowave ablation synergy.

item.title: Friction Memory Ionogels With Hysteretic Sticky‚ÄêSlippery Transition via Thermolocking the Metastable state
item.content:encoded:
Owing to the kinetic differences between the evolution of the condensed structure in the bulk and the adsorption of droplets on the surface, on‚Äêdemand friction memory is achieved without persistent stimulus.
Abstract Many biological organisms possess adaptive friction states and display hysteretic friction recovery, allowing them to achieve specific friction memory after environment change. However, current artificial materials have limitations in maintaining on‚Äêdemand friction states upon withdrawal of external triggers due to their strong dependence on external stimulus. Here, thermally induced phase separation ionogels with friction memory are reported. The kinetic difference between the evolution of bulk condensed structure and the adsorption of surface droplets after removing external stimulus delayed the recovery of friction state transition from slippery to sticky, thus achieving responsive friction memory. In addition, the metastable intermediate state generated during phase separation could be locked through vitrification, resulting in three distinct friction states determined by the synergy of stiffness and surface properties, including sticky state (coefficient of friction of 1.8), medium state (0.3‚Äì0.5) and slippery state (0.03‚Äì0.07). As a proof‚Äêof‚Äêconcept, smart devices with diverse surface friction performance are engineered to realize various functions, including recognition of thermal range for target objects, de‚Äêicing, and movement manipulation. These results provide new insights for expanding the applications of ionogels in state‚Äêof‚Äêthe‚Äêart soft robotics and haptic engineering, offering fresh perspectives for further development of these fields.

item.title: Advanced 3D Food Printing with Simultaneous Cooking and Generative AI Design
item.content:encoded:
An in‚Äêsitu heating solution for 3D food printing is developed by incorporating noncontact graphene heaters as cooking sources during the printing process. This technique ensures food quality control and reduces microbial contamination. The AI‚Äêgenerated 3D food shape design allows users to create digital models using text input without prior computational skills.
Abstract 3D food printing is an indispensable technology for emerging food technologies. However, conventional nonconcurrent postprocessing methods limit the final food quality, including the unappealing nature of food ink modification, imperfections in retaining the desired food shape, and the risk of microbial contamination. Here, an artificial intelligence (AI)‚Äêenhanced solution is developed to achieve extrusion‚Äêbased printing with simultaneous infrared heating, enabling in‚Äêline and rapid cooking of complex starch‚Äêbased food. Noncontact graphene heaters as cooking sources present outstanding food quality control with microbial studies, microstructure analysis, and heat transfer simulation models. This integrative 3D food printing method with AI‚Äêenhanced food pattern generation and in‚Äêsitu cooking significantly expands the applications for customized food creation. It paves the way for the broader adoption of heating‚Äêbased 3D printing of functional materials.

item.title: Printing Multi‚ÄêLayered Functional Devices Using One Stamp with Programmable Surface Energy
item.content:encoded:
Multi‚Äêlayered printed electronics are generally fabricated by overprinting with multiple stamps. Herein, a novel printing approach is introduced by modifying stamp with patterned surface energy. This enables the fabrication of multiple functional layers using only one stamp. Using this method, the fabrication of flexible light‚Äêemitting devices and high‚Äêdenstiy transistor array are demonstrated (with over 17,900 transistors on an 8‚Äêinch wafer).
Abstract Beyond its role in cultural communication, printing technology has emerged as one of the most important approaches to distributing and patterning functional materials for advanced manufacturing. In a printing process, a stamp is employed to transfer functional inks to a target surface, generating a specific pattern that exactly replicates the stamp. Through precise manipulation of different inkdrops, herein, a ‚Äúone stamp, diverse patterns‚Äù printing strategy is developed and achieves deposition of varied patterns utilizing a single stamp. This stamp features patterned surface energy, achieved through regioselective energy injection treatment of an ultralow surface energy solid. It is revealed that inks with different surface tensions¬†can selectively exhibit Cassie or Wenzel state on the stamp to generate diverse ink distributions, which enables the printing of distinct patterns on target surfaces. Leveraging this approach, flexible light‚Äêemitting devices and high‚Äêdensity transistor array are successfully printed using single stamps. These findings advance the understanding of finely tuning and patterning surface energy for precise liquid manipulation and offer a leap forward in efficient and versatile printing methodology that will boost the innovative integration of functional materials in a simplified manner.

item.title: Nanoporous Ag Microparticles with Tailorable and Noncontaminated Nanopores for SERS Sensing Applications
item.content:encoded:
Nanoporous silver microparticles with noncontaminated surfaces have promising applications in surface‚Äêenhanced Raman scattering sensing fields. A method is developed to transform the electrodeposited Ag7O8NO3 microparticles into nanoporous Ag microparticles at room temperature within minutes without using organic ligands. The size of the interconnected nanopores can be controlled from less than 20 nm to more than 110 nm.
Abstract Nanoporous metallic microarchitectures with noncontaminated surfaces hold significant promise in catalytic and sensing fields. Fabrication of nanoporous metal microparticles without using any organic ligands remains a significant challenge. Here, a green synthesis strategy is presented inspired by dealloying mechanisms. Ag7O8NO3 microparticles are first electrodeposited. Subsequent chemical reduction process selectively removes nitrogen and oxygen species from the Ag7O8NO3 microparticles while preserving the original morphology, giving rise to the formation of nanoporous Ag microparticles without using organic agents under room temperature within several minutes. Based on the ion diffusion limited growth mechanism, a quantitative correlation is established between the opening size of the nanopores and the concentration of the reductive agents, allowing to rationally prepare nanopores with opening size ranging from <¬†20¬†nm to >¬†110¬†nm. The ultraclean surface of the nanoporous Ag microparticles guarantees a clean surface‚Äêenhanced Raman spectroscopy (SERS) background. Reliable and sensitive SERS detection of proteins by unfolding the protein structure is further demonstrated to expose the otherwise concealed parts to the nanoporous Ag microparticles. A simple but powerful approach is developed to design ultraclean nanoporous metallic microarchitectures with promising applications in those fields requiring clean surfaces, such as in SERS sensing and catalytic fields.

item.title: Plasma Membrane Targeted Photodynamic Nanoagonist to Potentiate Immune Checkpoint Blockade Therapy by Initiating Tumor Cell Pyroptosis and Depleting Infiltrating B Cells
item.content:encoded:
A plasma membrane targeted photodynamic nanoagonist called PMTPN is designed to target tumor tissues and anchor on plasma membrane, aiming to initiate tumor cell pyroptosis and deplete infiltrating B cells. Consequently, PMTPN promotes DCs maturation and CTLs infiltration, while decreasing Tregs, greatly reversing the immunosuppressive tumor microenvironment to potentiate immune checkpoint blockade therapy for primary and distant tumor eradication.
Abstract Immune checkpoint blockade (ICB) therapy has achieved remarkable benefits in the treatment of malignant tumors, but the clinical response rates are unsatisfied due to the low tumor immunogenicity and the abundant immunosuppressive cells. Herein, a plasma membrane targeted photodynamic nanoagonist (designated as PMTPN) is developed to potentiate ICB therapy by initiating tumor cell pyroptosis and depleting infiltrating B cells. PMTPN is composed of a rationally designed chimeric peptide sequence loaded with Bruton's tyrosine kinase inhibitor (Ibrutinib). Notably, PMTPN is capable of sequentially targeting tumor and tumor cell membrane to trigger immunogenic pyroptosis and cause overwhelming release of cytokines, promoting dendritic cells maturation, and cytotoxic T lymphocytes (CTLs) activation. Meanwhile, PMTPN can also deplete infiltrating B cells and reduce the secretion of interleukin‚Äê10 to decrease immunosuppressive regulatory T cells and enhance CTLs infiltration. Beneficially, the synergistic immune modulating characteristics of PMTPN potentiate ICB therapy to simultaneously eliminate primary and distant tumors. This study offers a promising strategy to elevate the immunotherapeutic response rate in consideration of the complex immunosuppressive factors.

item.title: 2D Metastable‚ÄêPhase Hafnium Oxide Triggers Hydrogen Spillover for Boosting Hydrogen Production
item.content:encoded:
Hydrogen spillover is a widespread interfacial phenomenon involving the migration of equivalent amounts of H atoms from metal to support. The design of the substrate is crucial for triggering hydrogen spillover. Metastable‚Äêphase hexagonal phase hafnium oxide substrate can trigger efficient hydrogen spillover after loading ruthenium, yet the same phenomenon is forbidden on the stable phase monoclinic phase hafnium oxide substrate.
Abstract Hydrogen (H) manipulation plays a significantly important role in many important applications, in which the occurrence of hydrogen spillover generally shows substrate‚Äêdependent behavior. It therefore remains an open question about how to trigger the hydrogen spillover on the substrates that are generally hydrogen spillover forbidden. Here a new metastable‚Äêphase 2D edge‚Äêsharing oxide: six‚Äêhexagonal phase‚Äêhafnium oxide (Hex‚ÄêHfO2, space group: P63mc (186)) with the coordination number of six is demonstrated, which serves as an ideal platform for activating efficient hydrogen spillover after loading Ru nanoclusters (Ru/Hex‚ÄêHfO2). For a stark comparison, the hydrogen spillover is strongly forbidden when using stable monoclinic phase HfO2 (M‚ÄêHfO2, space group: P21/c (14), coordination number: seven) as the substrate. When applied in an acidic hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), Ru/Hex‚ÄêHfO2 exhibits a low overpotential of 8¬†mV at 10¬†mA cm‚àí2 and a high Ru utilization activity of 14.37 A mgRu‚àí1 at 30¬†mV. Detailed mechanism reveals the positive H adsorption free energy on Hex‚ÄêHfO2, indicating that H is more likely to spillover on Hex‚ÄêHfO2. Furthermore, the strong interaction between Ru and Hex‚ÄêHfO2 optimizes the desorption of hydrogen intermediate, thus facilitating the surface H spillover. The discovery provides new guidance for developing metastable‚Äêphase oxide substrates for advanced catalysis.

item.title: One‚ÄêStep Symbiosis of Bimetallic Peroxides Nanoparticles to Induce Ferroptosis/Cuproptosis and Activate cGAS‚ÄêSTING Pathway for Enhanced Tumor Immunotherapy
item.content:encoded:
The designed zinc‚Äêcopper bimetallic peroxides nanoparticles, which are synthesized through a one‚Äêstep symbiotic method by co‚Äêhydrolysis of metal acetates, can release Zn2+, Cu2+, and H2O2 in TME to induce ferroptosis/cuproptosis and activate cGAS‚ÄêSTING pathway. Therefore, anti‚Äêtumor adaptive and innate immunotherapy can be simultaneously promoted to effectively inhibit tumor growth and metastasis with assistance of immune checkpoint inhibitor.
Abstract To improve the efficiency and application prospects of metal peroxides in tumor therapy, the synthesis of bimetallic peroxides via simple yet effective approaches will be highly significant. In this work, hyaluronic acid modified zinc‚Äêcopper bimetallic peroxides (ZCPO@HA) nanoparticles are synthesized through a one‚Äêstep symbiotic method by co‚Äêhydrolysis of zinc acetate and copper acetate in weakly alkaline solution, followed by modification with sodium hyaluronate. Upon decomposition in the tumor microenvironment, ZCPO@HA nanoparticles can generate a considerable content of hydroxyl radical (¬∑OH) by Fenton‚Äêlike reaction between Cu2+ and self‚Äêcompensating hydrogen peroxide, while downregulating the expression of glutathione peroxidase 4 to induce ferroptosis. The abundant release of Cu2+ leads to the aggregation of dihydrolipoamide S‚Äêacetyltransferase and the reduction of iron‚Äêsulfur cluster proteins, causing cuproptosis. The immunogenic cell death of tumor cells releases abundant damage associated molecular patterns, effectively activating the adaptive immune response. Zn2+ and ¬∑OH cause mitochondrial damage, leading to the release of a substantial amount of mitochondrial DNA. This subsequently activates the cyclic guanosine monophosphate‚Äêadenosine monophosphate synthase‚Äêstimulator of interferon genes (cGAS‚ÄêSTING) pathway, enhancing the innate immune response. In conclusion, it synthesizes a new type of bimetallic peroxides by one‚Äêstep symbiosis for activating anti‚Äêtumor immunotherapy combined with immune checkpoint inhibitor.

item.title: Low‚ÄêTemperature Pyrolysis: A Universal Route to High‚ÄêLoading Single‚ÄêAtom Catalysts for Fuel Cells
item.content:encoded:
This work develops a molten salt strategy for synthesizing single‚Äêatom catalysts at 450¬†¬∞C via LiCl/KCl‚Äêmediated Fe2+/Zn2+ exchange on nitrogen‚Äêdoped carbon substrates. By stabilizing Fe2+ ions and suppressing the Fe‚Äêoxide nanoparticle formation‚Äîa common limitation in conventional high‚Äêtemperature pyrolysis‚Äîit achieves a 3.9 wt.% Fe loading of atomically dispersed Fe‚ÄêN4 sites, delivering superior H2‚ÄîO2 fuel cell performance.
Abstract High‚Äêtemperature pyrolysis (HTP, ‚â•900¬†¬∞C) is a widely used method for synthesizing single‚Äêatom catalysts (SACs). However, the high operational temperatures required for HTP pose significant challenges in achieving high single‚Äêatom loading, primarily due to the Ostwald ripening effect. In this work, a low‚Äêtemperature trans‚Äêmetalation synthesis approach is developed which involves the exchange of cation between transition metal ions (M = Fe, Co, Cu, Ni, Mn, etc) and Zn2+ ions on a nitrogen‚Äêdoped carbon (NC) matrix within a molten salt medium. This strategy effectively avoids phase transformations and enables the direct formation of high mass loading (3.7‚Äì4.7 wt.%) of atomically dispersed M‚ÄêN4 sites. Both experimental and theoretical analyses confirm that this cation‚Äêexchange occurs at a lower temperature threshold of 450¬†¬∞C, significantly reducing the energy barriers for SACs synthesis. Furthermore, the synthesized catalyst with atomically dispersed Fe sites demonstrate excellent performance toward oxygen reduction reaction and fuel cell with a peak power density of 1.12 W‚Äâcm‚àí2 in an H2‚îÄO2 fuel cell at 1.0¬†bar and 80¬†¬∞C.

item.title: Carbon Dot‚ÄêLinked Hydrogel for TAMs Transform: Spatiotemporal Manipulation to Reshape Tumor Microenvironment
item.content:encoded:
The CDs crosslinked egg white hydrogel loaded with lipopolysaccharide (LPS) and CA170 (TTF‚ÄêL‚ÄêC) can realize spatiotemporal tumor‚Äêassociated macrophages (TAMs) transformation from multi‚Äêlevel dimensions, including spatial recruitment, cell phenotype reprogramming, and immune checkpoint molecule blockade. Finally, at the in vivo level, TTF‚ÄêL‚ÄêC can stimulate anti‚Äêtumor immunity through tumor microenvironment (TME) remodeling and reduce tumor recurrence with satisfactory biosafety.
Abstract As one of the most crucial immune cells in the tumor microenvironment (TME), regulating tumor‚Äêassociated macrophages (TAMs) is vital for enhancing antitumor immunity. Here, an injectable carbon dots (CDs)‚Äêlinked egg white hydrogel was developed, termed TAMs Transform Factory (TTF‚ÄêL‚ÄêC), to spatiotemporally manipulate TAMs. The fabricated CDs significantly promoted macrophage migration. Notably, TTF‚ÄêL‚ÄêC achieved macrophage spatial enrichment through CDs‚Äêinduced directional recruitment with molecular Ctnnd1 upregulation. Subsequently, the recruited macrophages were locoregionally reprogrammed within TTF‚ÄêL‚ÄêC, as well as blocking the upregulated PD‚ÄêL1. Finally, through multi‚Äêstage regulation at spatial, cellular, and molecular levels, TTF‚ÄêL‚ÄêC released immune‚Äêactivated M1 macrophages to the tumor site as it degraded. Moreover, TTF‚ÄêL‚ÄêC promoted dendritic cell (DCs) maturation and further boosted T cell activation, thereby reshaping the tumor‚Äêsuppressive TME. Through peritumoral injection, TTF‚ÄêL‚ÄêC enhanced tumor immunotherapy in both subcutaneous and recurrent 4T1 tumor models with satisfactory biosafety. Therefore, TTF‚ÄêL‚ÄêC is proposed to become a safe and powerful platform for various biomedical applications.

item.title: High‚ÄêPerformance Carbon Capture with Fluorine‚ÄêTailored Carbon Molecular Sieve Membranes
item.content:encoded:
A high‚Äêperformance carbon capture using fluorine‚Äêtailored carbon molecular sieve (CMS) membranes is developed. By incorporating bent terphenyl monomers and both aliphatic/aromatic trifluoromethyl groups into the polymer precursor, the derived CMS membranes achieve exceptional CO‚ÇÇ permeability of 47,190 Barrer and CO2/N2 selectivity of 28.3, maintaining 36,204 Barrer permeability and 35.3 selectivity under flue gas conditions.
Abstract Increasing energy consumption and climate change present an urgent global challenge to achieve carbon neutrality, with CO2 capture as a top priority. Among various carbon capture technologies, CO2 membrane separation stands out for its simplicity and energy efficiency in applications including gas purification and industrial gas recovery. Herein, a series of fluorine‚Äêtailored porous carbon molecular sieve (CMS) membranes derived from precisely designed precursors, achieving a well‚Äêbalanced high permeability and selectivity for CO2 separation are developed. Incorporating bent terphenyl monomers and both aliphatic/aromatic trifluoromethyl groups disrupted dense chain packing and promoted pore formation with enhanced permeability and selectivity for CO2 separation. The TFM‚Äê550 membrane, derived from a fluorinated stretched polymer backbone precursor, exhibits exceptional performance with a CO2 permeability of 47¬†190¬†¬±¬†3204 Barrer and a CO2/N2 selectivity of 28.3¬†¬±¬†5.7, while TFM‚Äê800 presented a higher selectivity of 71.8¬†¬±¬†11.5, surpassing the 2019 upper bound. Furthermore, under flue gas conditions (CO2/O2/N2 = 1/1/4 in molar ratio), the CMS membrane demonstrate high CO2 permeability of 36,204¬†¬±¬†2,235 Barrer and outstanding CO2/N2 selectivity of 35.3¬†¬±¬†1.8. The results here highlight the effectiveness of fluorine tailoring and the potential of fluorinated CMS membranes for sustainable industrial carbon capture applications.

item.title: Interlayer Expanded MXene Film Cathodes with Rich Defects for Flexible 2‚ÄêElectron Oxalate‚ÄêBased Li‚ÄìCO2 Batteries: A New Path to Enhanced Energy Efficiency and Durability
item.content:encoded:
A defect‚Äêrich, interlayer‚Äêexpanded MXene (Ex‚ÄêTi3C2Tx‚Äê3) film cathode, with abundant uncoordinated titanium atoms, stabilizes the bi‚Äêelectron pathway in Li‚ÄìCO2 batteries, improving energy efficiency and durability. Its extended interlayer spacing and mesoporous structure enhance ion and CO2 transport, and the surface functionalization suppresses interfacial oxidation and maintains integrity. The battery achieves low polarization (0.39 V), high capacity (3452.33 ¬µAh cm‚àí2), and long life (>1660 h). The foldable Ex‚ÄêTi3C2Tx‚Äê3 cathode enables flexible Li‚ÄìCO2 batteries, offering potential in wearable electronics.
Abstract Aprotic Li‚ÄìCO2 batteries have garnered significant attention owing to their high theoretical energy density and potential in zero‚Äêcarbon technology. However, their practical application remains hindered by sluggish CO2 reduction/evolution reaction (CRR/CER) kinetics and limited flexibility. While 2D graphene‚Äêlike materials are commonly employed to settle these issues, their four‚Äêelectron pathway limits efficiency and reversibility. Herein, a defect‚Äêrich, interlayer‚Äêexpanded Ti3C2Tx (Ex‚ÄêTi3C2Tx) film cathode is presented for flexible Li‚ÄìCO2 batteries. The extended interlayer space, reduced ‚îÄOH groups, and additional uncoordinated titanium atoms of Ex‚ÄêTi3C2Tx enable abundant catalytic active sites, enhance ion and CO2 transport, and these surface functionalizations suppress interfacial oxidation. Notably, Ex‚ÄêTi3C2Tx stabilizes the bi‚Äêelectron product Li2C2O4 via Ti3+/Ti2+ coupling bridges, effectively preventing disproportionation into Li2CO3, thereby significantly improving CRR/CER reversibility and lowering overpotential. Benefiting from these properties, Li‚ÄìCO2 batteries with Ex‚ÄêTi3C2Tx deliver a remarkable discharge capacity of 3452.33 ¬µAh cm‚àí2, a low polarization potential of 0.39¬†V, an energy efficiency exceeding 88.9%, and an ultra‚Äêlong cycling life (>1600 h). Furthermore, the belt‚Äêshaped flexible battery exhibits excellent flexibility and stable electrochemical performance under deformation highlighting its potential in wearable electronics. This work underscores the critical role of MXene‚Äêbased materials in bi‚Äêelectron electrocatalytic mechanisms, providing insights for advancing reversible Li‚ÄìCO2 batteries and flexible energy storage technologies.

item.title: Advanced Air Electrodes for Reversible Protonic Ceramic Electrochemical Cells: A Comprehensive Review
item.content:encoded:
Reversible protonic ceramic electrochemical cells (R‚ÄêPCECs) face challenges from sluggish and unstable oxygen reduction and evolution reactions in the air electrode. This review discusses recent progress in triple‚Äêconducting air electrodes, emphasizing mechanisms, performance factors, and design strategies, offering guidance for creating efficient and stable air electrode materials for R‚ÄêPCECs.
Abstract Reversible protonic ceramic electrochemical cells (R‚ÄêPCECs) have great potential for efficient and clean power generation, energy storage, and sustainable synthesis of high‚Äêvalue chemicals. However, the sluggish and unstable kinetics of the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) in the air electrode hinder the R‚ÄêPCEC development. Durable H+/e‚àí/O2‚àí triple‚Äêconducting air electrode materials are promising for enhancing reaction kinetics and improving catalytical stability. This review synthesizes the recent progress in triple‚Äêconducting air electrodes, focusing on their working mechanisms, including electrode kinetics, lattice and its defect structure in oxides, and the generation and transport processes of H+, O2‚àí, and e‚àí. It also examines the required physicochemical properties and their influencing factors. By synthesizing and critically analyzing the latest theoretical frameworks, advanced materials, and regulation strategies, this review outlines the challenges and prospects shaping the future of R‚ÄêPCEC technology and air electrode development. Based on these theories and multiple strategies about the bulk triple conducting properties and surface chemical states, this review provides practical guidance for the rational design and development of efficient and stable air electrode materials for R‚ÄêPCECs and related electrocatalytic materials.

item.title: Suppression of Charge Recombination Induced by Solid Additive Assisting Organic Solar Cells with Efficiency over 20%
item.content:encoded:
The work highlights the strong morphological optimization capacity of the solid additive DIDOB and elucidates its impact on molecular packing to suppress both bimolecular and geminate recombination in OSCs. As a result, DIDOB not only demonstrates universality in various non‚Äêfullerene‚Äêbased OSCs but also achieves an impressive efficiency of 20.11% with a remarkable fill factor of 81.8% in the D18:PM6:L8‚ÄêBO‚Äêbased device.
Abstract A volatile solid additive strategy, which can effectively optimize the morphology of the photoactive layer with an ideal domain size and purity, has emerged as a promising approach to improve the photovoltaic performance of organic solar cells (OSCs). However, the precise role of solid additives in modulating charge and exciton dynamics, especially the recombination process, remains not fully understand. In this study, a solid additive, 1,4‚Äêdiiodo‚Äê2,5‚Äêdimethoxybenzene (DIDOB), is developed to improve the photovoltaic performance of OSCs and conduct a comprehensive investigation into its effect on the charge recombination process. As a result, the PM6:L8‚ÄêBO‚ÄêX‚Äêbased binary OSC processed with DIDOB achieves an excellent efficiency of 19.75% with a remarkable fill factor of 81.9%, owing to the optimal fiber network morphology, tighter and ordered molecular packing, as well as the suppression of both bimolecular and geminate recombination. Notably, the DIDOB exhibits broad universality as an additive in other non‚Äêfullerene acceptor‚Äêbased OSCs. Impressively, the D18:PM6:L8‚ÄêBO‚Äêbased ternary device processed with DIDOB yielded an excellent efficiency of 20.11% (certified as 20.03%). This work highlights the effect of the solid additive on the charge recombination process within active layer and provides insights for the further development of OSCs.

item.title: Decoupling Strategy of Metasurface to Realize Independent Sensing and Wave Manipulations at the Same Time
item.content:encoded:
In this article, a decoupling strategy of metasurface to realize independent sensing and wave manipulations at the same time is proposed. By allocating the reflectivity of all meta‚Äêatoms across the space‚Äêtime dimensions, it is possible to realize arbitrary manipulation of electromagnetic waves while simultaneously sensing the wireless environment by the metasurface without integrating any sensors. An adaptive STCDM system is constructed and measured, showing excellent performances of sensing and wave manipulations in wireless communication scenarios.
Abstract In recent years, integrating electromagnetic (EM) sensing and wave manipulation has become crucial for future wireless developments, significantly enhancing the application performance by acquiring complex environmental information and optimizing the distribution of EM resources. Metasurface offers unprecedented control over sensing and wave manipulation, yet a conflict arises in achieving both simultaneously. To solve the problem, a decoupling strategy is proposed to simultaneously realize sensing and wave manipulation using a space‚Äêtime‚Äêcoding digital metasurface (STCDM) without integrating any sensors. A space‚Äêtime‚Äêcoding matrix is constructed by allocating the reflectivity of all meta‚Äê atoms across the space‚Äêtime dimensions, enabling arbitrary manipulation of EM waves while simultaneously acquiring the sensing information at the incident frequency from metasurface. Excellent accuracy of direction‚Äêof‚Äêarrival estimation and wave manipulation confirms the decoupling method. An adaptive STCDM system is built up to validate the strategy in wireless communications. The measured results show that the adaptive STCDM enables independent sensing and wireless communications at the same time for targets located at different positions without integrating any sensors. The proposed method may find potential applications in wireless communication, radar, and Internet of Things systems.

item.title: Nonlinear Optical Properties of 0D Chiral Hybrid Bismuth Iodides
item.content:encoded:
Optically stable lead‚Äêfree 0D chiral (R/S‚Äêmethyl‚Äêbenzyl‚Äêamine)‚Äêbismuth‚Äêiodide crystals showcase promising second and third‚Äêorder nonlinear optical properties. The chiral compounds show significant circularly polarized second harmonic generation. The achiral counterpart exhibits the most efficient third‚Äêorder optical nonlinearity.
Abstract Chiral hybrid metal halides show great promise for nonlinear optical (NLO) applications like circularly polarized second harmonic generation (SHG). The inherent toxicity of lead is a concern for the widespread adoption of frequently explored lead‚Äêbased chiral hybrid halides. Here, we report the second and third‚Äêorder NLO properties of lead‚Äêfree 0D chiral compounds, (R‚Äê/S‚ÄêMBA)4Bi2I10, and their achiral counterpart, (Rac‚ÄêMBA)4Bi2I10 (MBA: methylbenzylammonium) under excitation wavelength ranging 1360‚Äì1590¬†nm. Chiral (R‚Äê/S‚ÄêMBA)4Bi2I10 exhibits strong SHG along with stronger third harmonic generation (THG). The chiral crystals showed high sensitivity to the handedness of circularly polarized pump light (gSHG ‚àí CD ‚âà 9% at 1510¬†nm). The THG response shows resonance enhancement matching the excitonic absorption. Achiral (Rac‚ÄêMBA)4Bi2I10 exhibits the maximum THG response (œá(3) = 1.05 √ó 10‚Åª¬π‚Å∏¬†m2¬†V‚àí2). Z‚Äêscan measurements with non‚Äêresonant femtosecond pulse excitation at 800¬†nm yield high nonlinear absorption coefficients (Œ≤) and nonlinear refractive index (n2) for all three samples, with (Rac‚ÄêMBA)4Bi2I10 exhibiting the highest values. These hybrid chiral metal halides, with efficient second and third‚Äêorder nonlinearity, and high optical stability, are potential candidates for NLO applications such as Kerr‚Äêbased optical switching, circularly polarized up‚Äêconversion, and communication.

item.title: Multi‚Äêmaterial Volumetric Bioprinting and Plug‚Äêand‚Äêplay Suspension Bath Biofabrication via Bioresin Molecular Weight Tuning and via Multiwavelength Alignment Optics
item.content:encoded:
Multimaterial volumetric and embedded extrusion bioprinting of complex cell‚Äêladen architectures is enabled by unravelling the interplay between molecular weight and degree of functionalization in gelatin‚Äêbased bioresins. Tomographic light‚Äêresponsive support baths for suspended printing can be easily generated from single component materials. Molecular weight tuning produces a library of printable hydrogels matching the viscoleasticity properties of native tissues, influencing cell self‚Äêorganization.
Abstract Volumetric Bioprinting (VBP), enables to rapidly build complex, cell‚Äêladen hydrogel constructs for tissue engineering and regenerative medicine. Light‚Äêbased tomographic manufacturing enables spatial‚Äêselective polymerization of a bioresin, resulting in higher throughput and resolution than what is achieved using traditional techniques. However, methods for multi‚Äêmaterial printing are needed for broad VBP adoption and applicability. Although converging VBP with extrusion bioprinting in support baths offers a novel, promising solution, further knowledge on the engineering of hydrogels as light‚Äêresponsive, volumetrically printable baths is needed. Therefore, this study investigates the tuning of gelatin macromers, in particular leveraging the effect of molecular weight and degree of modification, to overcome these challenges, creating a library of materials for VBP and Embedded extrusion Volumetric Printing (EmVP). Bioresins with tunable printability and mechanical properties are produced, and a novel subset of gelatins and GelMA exhibiting stable shear‚Äêyielding behavior offers a new, single‚Äêcomponent, ready‚Äêto‚Äêuse suspension medium for in‚Äêbath printing, which is stable over multiple hours without needing temperature control. As a proof‚Äêof‚Äêconcept biological application, bioprinted gels are tested with insulin‚Äêproducing pancreatic cell lines for 21 days of culture. Leveraging a multi‚Äêcolor printer, complex multi‚Äêmaterial and multi‚Äêcellular geometries are produced, enhancing the accessibility of volumetric printing for advanced tissue models.

item.title: Simultaneously Tailoring Hydrostability and Photoelectroactivity in Heterocluster Metal‚ÄìOrganic Frameworks for Efficient Photocatalytic Hydrogen Production
item.content:encoded:
The first heterocluster‚Äêbased crystalline MOF photocatalysts integrating copper‚Äêsulfur and copper‚Äêhalide clusters are obtained through the heterocluster assembly engineering and localized microenvironment regulation, demonstrating an unprecedented synergistic enhancement of hydrostability and photoelectroactivity, facilitating the efficient synthesis of green hydrogen at an exceptionally high rate under visible light.
Abstract The simultaneous enhancement of structural stability and photoelectroactivity in metal‚Äêorganic frameworks (MOFs) remains a critical challenge for sustainable photocatalytic hydrogen (H2) production. Herein, an atomically‚Äêprecise heterocluster assembly approach is presented to construct two isostructural 3D MOFs, CuSL‚ÄêCuX (X = Cl, Br), featuring a cds net. CuSL‚ÄêCuXs integrate hexanuclear copper‚Äêsulfur {Cu6S6} cluster and dinuclear copper‚Äêhalogen {Cu2X2} cluster, which not only impart exceptional stability across a broad pH range (1‚Äì14) but also enable wide visible‚Äêlight absorption, tailored redox potentials, and efficient charge‚Äêcarrier dynamics. Notably, halogen substitution markedly boosts photocatalytic activity: CuSL‚ÄêCuBr achieves an efficient H2 evolution rate of 50.28¬†mmol¬†g‚àí1¬†h‚àí1 without noble metals, doubling that of CuSL‚ÄêCuCl (26.99¬†mmol¬†g‚àí1¬†h‚àí1) and surpassing most reported MOF‚Äêbased photocatalysts. Both experimental and theoretical investigations indicate that bromine substitution optimizes electronic structure, refines orbital distribution, and accelerates charge separation, ultimately leading to promoted photocatalytic efficiency. This research provides insights into the structure‚Äêproperty interplay in heterocluster MOFs and establishes a paradigm for designing robust, high‚Äêperformance photocatalysts through precise cluster engineering.

item.title: Tailoring Synergistic Ion Environment for Copper Telluride toward High‚ÄêCapacity and Ultrastable Acidic Multivalent‚ÄêIon Batteries
item.content:encoded:
Cu2‚ÄêxTe electrodes are disclosed in acidic multivalent‚Äêion batteries for the first time to achieve a high capacity of up to 409 mAh g‚àí1 and a long cycling lifespan of 40‚Äâ000 cycles. Composite in situ X‚Äêray diffraction measurements and spectroscopic analyses show that the synergistic copper‚Äêion/proton electrolyte environment ensures stable reversible storage of copper‚Äêions and prevents potential material oxidation.
Abstract Acidic batteries permit a reliable energy supply at low temperatures with low cost and intrinsic safety, yet the development of stable acid‚Äêresistant electrodes with high capacity and a reliable lifespan is still challenging. Herein, nonstoichiometric copper telluride (Cu2‚ÄêxTe) nanosheets are first explored as high‚Äêperformance electrodes for acidic batteries to provide a stable capacity release of 409 mAh g‚àí1 with a record‚Äêbreaking lifespan of 40¬†000 cycles and excellent kinetics, enabling operation at a high current density of 20 A g‚àí1. In contrast to the inherent perception of corrosive destruction of electrode materials by strongly acidic environments, the electrolyte environment enriched with copper ions and hydrogen ions synergistically stabilizes the Cu2‚ÄêxTe electrode and drives reversible multielectron transfer asymmetric deep conversion, which is confirmed by in situ synchrotron X‚Äêray diffraction, X‚Äêray absorption spectroscopy, first‚Äêprincipal calculations, and composite electrochemical characterization. Therefore, Cu2‚ÄêxTe provides an impressive accumulation capacity of over 4764 Ah g‚àí1, exceeding that of most acidic batteries, and works well at ‚àí20¬†¬∞C. High‚Äêperformance Cu2‚ÄêxTe electrodes also promote the establishment of Cu2‚ÄêxTe//Mn2O3 and Cu2‚ÄêxTe//Fe acidic full cells enabling stable operation at room temperature and low temperature, offering promising opportunities for electrode progress in advanced acidic batteries.

item.title: Harnessing Near‚ÄêInfrared Light for Enhanced Solar Hydrogen Production from Escherichia coli Interfaced with Biocompatible Low‚ÄêBandgap Conjugated Polymer Nanosheets
item.content:encoded:
Biocompatible, low‚Äêbandgap conjugated polymer nanosheets are interfaced with non‚Äêphotosynthetic and non‚Äêgenetic engineered Escherichia coli for solar hydrogen production using near‚Äêinfrared light. The rationally designed polymer nanosheets play a crucial role in harnessing the broad solar spectrum and injecting photo‚Äêgenerated electrons into bacteria, thereby enhancing hydrogen production.
Abstract The efficient conversion of solar energy into clean hydrogen fuel presents a promising pathway for sustainable energy production. However, utilizing the full solar spectrum, particularly the near‚Äêinfrared (NIR) region, remains underexplored in photosynthetic biohybrid systems. In this study, biocompatible, low‚Äêbandgap conjugated polymer nanosheets (PyTT‚ÄêtBAL‚ÄêHAB) are developed to integrate with non‚Äêphotosynthetic, non‚Äêgenetically engineered Escherichia coli (E. coli) for enhanced solar‚Äêdriven biological hydrogen production. The PyTT‚ÄêtBAL‚ÄêHAB nanosheets exhibit unique NIR light absorption properties. Integrating these nanosheets with E. coli facilitates efficient electron transfer, resulting in a 1.96‚Äêfold increase in hydrogen production rate under NIR light. Consequently, this photosynthetic biohybrid system achieves a quantum efficiency of 18.36% at 940¬†nm. This study demonstrates the potential of using low‚Äêbandgap conjugated polymer nanosheets as advanced photosensitizers in semi‚Äêartificial photosynthetic systems, offering a robust platform for the effective utilization of the solar spectrum.

item.title: Azepination‚ÄêInduced Frontier Molecular Orbital Delocalization of Multiple Resonance Emitters: Constructing Highly Efficient Narrowband Electroluminescent Materials
item.content:encoded:
A strategy for azepination‚Äêinduced frontier molecular orbital (FMO) delocalization of multiple resonance (MR) emitters is proposed to construct long‚Äêwavelength MR materials. Organic light‚Äêemitting diode based on m‚ÄêPAz‚ÄêBNCz exhibits excellent electroluminescence performances with Commission Internationale de L'Eclairage coordinates of (0.26, 0.70) and a maximum external quantum efficiency of 36.2%.
Abstract Developing diversified construction strategies for high‚Äêcolor‚Äêpurity and efficient multiple resonance thermally activated delayed fluorescence (MR‚ÄêTADF) materials is a major strategic demand to meet the requirements of ultra‚Äêhigh‚Äêdefinition organic light‚Äêemitting diode (OLED) displays, posing a significant challenge to the design and synthesis of emitters at the molecular level. Herein, a strategy is proposed for azepination‚Äêinduced frontier molecular orbital (FMO) delocalization of MR emitters, that is, embedding azepine into the prototype molecule BNCz can effectively improve the œÄ‚Äêconjugation degree and extend the FMO delocalization, thereby constructing a series of long‚Äêwavelength MR‚ÄêTADF materials with narrowband emission. Through an intramolecular Scholl reaction, these target molecules with an azepine‚Äêembedded core are afforded by one‚Äêfold heptagonal cyclization of BNCz core and the phenyl ring attached to (aromatic amine‚Äêsubstituted) aryl precursor. They all exhibit efficient green emission around 520¬†nm and narrow full‚Äêwidths at half‚Äêmaximum (FWHMs) of ‚â§ 37¬†nm in toluene. OLEDs employing these emitters show excellent electroluminescence (EL) performances, among which m‚ÄêPAz‚ÄêBNCz‚Äêbased OLED exhibits the optimal EL performances with a peak of 528¬†nm, a FWHM of 37¬†nm, Commission Internationale de L'Eclairage (CIE) coordinates of (0.26, 0.70), and a maximum external quantum efficiency (EQE) of 36.2%.

item.title: Europium(II) Complex with d‚Äêf Transition: New Emitter for Blue Light‚ÄêEmitting Electrochemical Cells with an External Quantum Efficiency of 19.8%
item.content:encoded:
A lanthanide Eu(II) complex is demonstrated as an emitter in¬†light‚Äêemitting electrochemical cells (LECs) for the first time. The bis[hydrotris(3‚Äêtert‚Äêbutylpyrazolyl)borate]europium(II)¬†complex based LEC achieved a record‚Äêbreaking external quantum efficiency of 19.8% with Commission Internationale de L'Eclairage coordinates of (0.12, 0.18).
Abstract Light‚Äêemitting electrochemical cells (LECs) have good prospects in the solid‚Äêstate lighting field due to their simple single‚Äêlayer structure and low manufacturing cost. However, the lack of high‚Äêefficiency blue LECs limits their development and further application. To solve this problem, many luminescent materials with various mechanisms such as fluorescence, phosphorescence, and thermally‚Äêactivated delayed fluorescence are studied as emitters in LECs. Besides these materials, herein lanthanide europium(II) (Eu(II)) complex with d‚Äêf transition is demonstrated as a new type of emitter for LECs. In detail, a blue emitting Eu(II) complex bis[hydrotris(3‚Äêtert‚Äêbutylpyrazolyl)borate]europium(II) is dispersed into 9‚Äê(3‚Äê(triphenylsilyl)phenyl)‚Äê9H‚Äê3,9‚Ä≤‚Äêbicarbazole host and tetrahexylammonium tetrafluoroborate electrolyte to make a blend film, which attains a high photoluminescence quantum yield of ‚âà100%. The LEC using the blend film as an active layer achieves a blue emission with Commission Internationale de L'Eclairage coordinates of (0.12, 0.18) and a record‚Äêbreaking external quantum efficiency of 19.8%, corresponding to an exciton utilization efficiency of ‚âà100%. This work reveals that Eu(II) complex with d‚Äêf transition is a promising emitter toward high‚Äêperformance blue LECs, which can inspire further research on Eu(II) complex based LECs.

item.title: Correction to ‚ÄúMultifunctional Copper‚ÄêPhenolic Nanopills Achieve Comprehensive Polyamines Depletion to Provoke Enhanced Pyroptosis and Cuproptosis for Cancer Immunotherapy‚Äù
Robust Homogeneous Segmented Power Generator Driven by Sb2Te3‚ÄêBased Thermoelectrics
item.content:encoded:
The Cd‚ÄìS co‚Äêalloying‚Äêinduced microstructural evolution enables high‚Äêperformance Sb2Te3‚Äêbased thermoelectrics. Subsequently, an innovative full‚Äêscale Bi‚ÄìSb‚ÄìTe segmented power generator is fabricated, extending the operational range of conventional Bi2Te3‚Äêbased modules from 500 to 650 K and achieving an exceptional efficiency of 9.3% under a distinct ŒîT = 350 K. Notably, it exhibits remarkable stability after 80‚Äêcycle thermal shock and 160‚Äêh thermal durability, highlighting great potential for low‚Äêgrade waste heat recovery.
Abstract Thermoelectric (TE) technology offers a promising solution for waste heat recovery, particularly in applications involving abundant low‚Äêgrade heat (<650 K). However, for over half a century, TE power generators have predominantly relied on Bi2Te3 alloys with limited efficiencies below 7%. Herein, Cd and S are doped into Sb2Te3 to promote microstructural regulation characterized by dense twin boundaries and dislocations, resulting in a 45% reduction of lattice thermal conductivity at 300 K. Combined with the optimized density‚Äêof‚Äêstates effective mass and expanded band gap, the Cd0.04Sb1.96Te2.94S0.06 sample attains a peak ZT of 1.1 at 650 K and an average ZT of 1.0 from 500 to 650 K, while exhibiting remarkable compressive and bending strengths of 197 and 56¬†MPa. Most importantly, a well‚Äêdesigned, homogeneous segmented TE power generator, constructed entirely from Bi‚ÄìSb‚ÄìTe alloys, achieves a remarkable efficiency of 9.3% under a temperature gradient of 350 K, as certified by third‚Äêparty validation. This work provides new insights into extending the operation temperature of Bi2Te3, demonstrating great potential for low‚Äêgrade waste heat harvest.

item.title: Designing Cellulose Triacetate‚ÄêBased Universal Binder for High‚ÄêVoltage Sodium‚ÄêIon Battery Cathodes with Enhanced Ionic Conductivity and Binding Strength
item.content:encoded:
Cellulose triacetate‚Äêbased binder with broad compatibility, high ionic conductivity, and superior binding strength has been successfully designed and validated through its application in high‚Äêvoltage polyanionic cathodes (Na3V2(PO4)2O2F), layered oxide cathodes (NaNi1/3Fe1/3Mn1/3O2), and tunnel‚Äêtype oxide cathodes (Na0.61[Mn0.27Fe0.34Ti0.39]O2). This work presents a sustainable and effective strategy for achieving high‚Äêperformance sodium‚Äêion batteries.
Abstract Binders play a pivotal role in the performance of sodium‚Äêion battery (SIB) cathodes, but traditional binders often struggle to balance broad compatibility, high ionic conductivity, superior binding strength, and environmental sustainability. In this study, a universal cellulose triacetate (TAC)‚Äêbased binder (TAC‚ÄêMMT) composed of TAC and natural montmorillonite (MMT) is designed to facilitate rapid Na+ transport pathways and establish a robust hydrogen‚Äêbonding network. This innovative TAC‚ÄêMMT binder features a unique chemical structure that achieves high ionic conductivity through a self‚Äêenrichment and fast‚Äêtransport mechanism, while its superior binding strength is attributed to hydrogen‚Äêbonding crosslinks between proton acceptors (C‚ïêO) in TAC and proton donors (‚àíOH) in MMT. More importantly, the outstanding solubility and film‚Äêforming properties of TAC‚ÄêMMT contribute to stable electrode protection and broad compatibility with high‚Äêvoltage SIB cathodes. Benefiting from these advantages, the Na3V2(PO4)2O2F (NVPOF) electrodes with the TAC‚ÄêMMT binder demonstrate exceptional performance, including a high capacity retention of 95.2% over 500 cycles at 5C and a rapid rate response of up to 15C. The versatility of the TAC‚ÄêMMT binder is further confirmed with high‚Äêvoltage NaNi1/3Fe1/3Mn1/3O2 and Na0.61[Mn0.27Fe0.34Ti0.39]O2 cathodes. This study highlights the potential of biomass‚Äêbased binders as a sustainable and effective solution for advancing high‚Äêperformance sodium‚Äêion batteries.

item.title: Multiple Functional Engineering Strategies and Active Site Identification in Ru‚ÄêBased Electrocatalysts for Catalytic Conversion Reactions
item.content:encoded:
This review provides a comprehensive analysis of engineering modification strategies for ruthenium (Ru)‚Äêbased catalysts, highlighting their critical role in optimizing electronic structures and surface properties to enhance electrocatalytic conversion. Furthermore, it emphasizes the integration of multiple engineering strategies aimed at improving catalytic performance, while also addressing key commercialization challenges.
Abstract Electrochemical conversion has been regarded as an ideal technology for achieving clean and sustainable energy, showing significant promise in addressing the increasingly serious energy crisis and environmental pollution. Ru‚Äêcontaining electrocatalysts (RUCE) outperform other precious metals due to elevated intrinsic activity and superior cost‚Äêeffectiveness, developing into a promising candidate for electrochemical conversion reactions. A significant challenge in the field of catalyst discovery lies in its heavy reliance on empirical methods, rather than approaches that are rooted in rational design principles. This review first concentrates on the catalytically active sites and critical factors governing catalytic activity and performance durability. Then, a comprehensive summary of multifunctional modification strategies ranging from nanoscale to atomic scale is explored to control the structure and improve the performance. By unveiling the roles of each component in the modified RUCE at the atomic level, their intrinsic active sites are identified and discussed to establish the structure‚Äêperformance relationship of the catalysts. Finally, the challenges and perspectives of Ru‚Äêbased materials for electrochemical hydrogen, oxygen, and nitrogen conversion reactions are presented to inspire further efforts toward understanding RUCE to meet the ever‚Äêgrowing demand in the future.

item.title: Electrochemical Lattice Engineering of Bismuthene for Selective Glycine Synthesis
item.content:encoded:
A Bi‚Äêbased catalyst is developed via the electrochemical transformation of bismuth‚Äêoxide composites, inducing enhanced lattice strain to optimize catalytic performance. At an applied potential of ‚àí0.76¬†V versus RHE, the catalyst exhibits outstanding efficiency in glycine electrosynthesis, achieving a Faradaic efficiency (FE) of 79.1% and a record‚Äêhigh glycine concentration of 0.17¬†m, significantly outperforming conventional Bi‚Äêbased systems. Moreover, the introduction of glycolaldehyde and hydroxylamine as reactants further elevate the glycine FE to 91.3%, with an impressive production rate of 2433.3¬†¬µmol h‚àí1 under identical conditions.
Abstract Glycine plays a crucial role in various industrial and daily applications. However, traditional synthesis methods are often associated with high toxicity, energy intensity, and inefficiency. This study introduces an efficient and eco‚Äêfriendly method for synthesizing glycine via the reductive coupling of oxalic acid and nitrate using a Bi metal catalyst, enhanced by lattice strain from Bi and oxide composites undergoing electrochemical transformation. At an applied potential of ‚àí0.76¬†V versus the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE), the Bi catalyst achieves an impressive glycine Faradaic efficiency (FE) of 79.1%, yielding a record concentration of 0.17¬†m, substantially higher than conventional Bi‚Äêbased systems. Furthermore, the introduction of glycolaldehyde and hydroxylamine as reactants raise the glycine FE to 91.3% with a production rate of 2433.3¬†¬µmol h‚àí1 under identical conditions. Electrochemical analysis and theoretical calculations demonstrate that lattice expansion notably boosts glycine synthesis by facilitating NH2OH formation and promoting the efficient reduction of oxime intermediates. These results underscore the significance of lattice engineering in enhancing active site performance and accelerating reaction kinetics, offering a sustainable and efficient alternative to traditional glycine synthesis methods.

item.title: Simultaneous Heavy‚ÄêMetal Ion Adsorption and Electricity Generation From Wastewater via ‚ÄúHeavy‚ÄêMetal Removal Batteries‚Äù
item.content:encoded:
A heavy‚Äêmetal removal battery is designed, which displays the capacity of simultaneous heavy‚Äêmetal ion adsorption and electricity generation. In such battery, the heavy‚Äêmetal ion adsorption is driven by the potential difference between adsorption electrodes and metal electrodes. Furthermore, a chemical oxidation strategy is developed to desorb heavy‚Äêmetal ions from adsorption electrodes, achieving the recycling of the electrodes.
Abstract The heavy‚Äêmetal ion in wastewater is a great threat to the health of both humans and ecosystems. The common heavy‚Äêmetal ion removal strategies usually suffer from energy consumption and poor recyclability. Herein, a heavy‚Äêmetal removal battery is designed by constructing a two‚Äêchamber configuration. Such battery displays the capacity of simultaneous heavy‚Äêmetal ion adsorption and electricity output, where heavy‚Äêmetal ion adsorption is driven by the potential difference between adsorption electrodes and metal electrodes, and electricity is generated continuously during the adsorption process. Significantly, various heavy‚Äêmetal ions (e.g., Mn2+, Co2+, Ni2+, Zn2+, Cr3+ and Pb2+ ions) can be removed due to the large lattice spacing of active materials in adsorption electrodes, displaying the universality of adsorbing heavy‚Äêmetal ions from wastewater. In addition, an environmental‚Äêfriendly chemical oxidation strategy is developed to desorb heavy‚Äêmetal ions from adsorption electrodes, which not only produces high‚Äêquality metal salts, but also reduces the toxicity of sludge in the case of secondary pollution. Impressively, these heavy‚Äêmetal removal batteries can be easily scaled up and integrated to extend the heavy‚Äêmetal ion adsorption ability and voltage/current output. This work proves a creative approach for simultaneous heavy‚Äêmetal ion removal and electricity generation from wastewater.

item.title: Near‚ÄêUnity PLQY of Cs‚ÇÉCu‚ÇÇX‚ÇÖ (X = Cl, Br) for High‚ÄêEfficiency White Light‚ÄêEmitting Diodes with Exceptional Color Quality
item.content:encoded:
The TOC illustrates Cs‚ÇÉCu‚ÇÇBr‚ÇÖ, Cs‚ÇÉCu‚ÇÇCl‚ÇÖ, and double perovskite suspensions, the 3D‚Äêprinted ‚ÄúMIZZOU‚Äù text under 325 nm laser excitation, the corresponding emission spectra of the color conversion layer, and the CIE 1976 (u', v') color space of the fabricated white LED.
Abstract Metal halide perovskites and their derivatives have emerged as highly promising materials for next‚Äêgeneration optoelectronic devices, owing to their intrinsic defect tolerance and exceptional electrical and optical properties. Among these, lead‚Äêfree copper(I)‚Äêbased halide perovskite derivatives, Cs‚ÇÉCu‚ÇÇX‚ÇÖ (X = Cl, Br, I) (CHPs), have garnered significant attention as environmentally friendly and stable alternatives to lead‚Äêbased perovskites. In this study, a cost‚Äêeffective and sustainable synthesis route for Cs‚ÇÉCu‚ÇÇCl‚ÇÖ and Cs‚ÇÉCu‚ÇÇBr‚ÇÖ powders is developed, which exhibit strong green (‚âà526¬†nm) and blue (‚âà458¬†nm) emissions, and achieve remarkable photoluminescence quantum yields (PLQYs) of 100% and 92%, respectively. Cs‚ÇÉCu‚ÇÇX‚ÇÖ (X = Cl, Br) powders are incorporated into 3D‚Äêprinted structures, exhibiting excellent transparency and color stability. Furthermore, white LEDs are fabricated by using the green‚Äêemitting Cs‚ÇÉCu‚ÇÇCl‚ÇÖ and blue‚Äêemitting Cs‚ÇÉCu‚ÇÇBr‚ÇÖ and a yellow‚Äêemitting double perovskite (PLQY‚âà 73%), resulting in devices with an exceptionally high color rendering index (CRI) of up to 98 and tunable correlated color temperatures (CCTs) ranging from 3864 to 9677 K, closely mimicking natural white light. Beyond solid‚Äêstate lighting, the superior optical performance and stability of Cs‚ÇÉCu‚ÇÇX‚ÇÖ (X = Cl, Br) powders open new avenues for their application in photovoltaics and other optoelectronic devices.

item.title: Enabling High Performance in a Positive Potential of Nitrate‚Äêto‚ÄêAmmonia Electrocatalysis Over Mesoporous Core@Shell Cu2O/Cu@PdCu Nanozyme
item.content:encoded:
Mesoporous core@shell Cu2O/Cu@PdCu nanozymes are demonstrated as efficient tandem electrocatalyst for highly selective NH3 electrosynthesis from NO3‚àí at fairly positive potentials. Meanwhile, this enzyme‚Äêlike electrocatalyst performs perfectly in the two‚Äêelectrode coupling system for cathode NO3‚àí‚Äêto‚ÄêNH3 and anode ethanol oxidation in a more energy‚Äêefficient manner.
Abstract Electrocatalytic tandem nitrate reduction to ammonia (NO3‚àí‚Äêto‚ÄêNH3) offers a promising pathway for energy and environmental sustainability. Although considerable efforts have been presented to modulate the reaction pathways for enhanced NO3‚àí‚Äêto‚ÄêNH3 electrocatalysis, these advances often require relatively high overpotentials to balance yield rate and selectivity of NH3, resulting in a remarkable energy inefficiency. Inspired by enzyme catalysis in nature, herein a tandem enzyme‚Äêlike electrocatalyst is designed consisting of a core of Cu2O/Cu heterojunction surrounded by mesoporous PdCu shell (Cu2O/Cu@mesoPdCu) that accelerated NO3‚àí‚Äêto‚ÄêNH3 electrocatalysis in positive potentials. Impressively, Cu2O/Cu@mesoPdCu nanozymes hold superior performance for robust NH3 electrosynthesis in a fairly positive potential of 0.10¬†V (versus reversible hydrogen electrode), having Faraday efficiency of 96.2%, yield rate of 13.3¬†mg h‚àí1 mg‚àí1, and half‚Äêcell energy efficiency of 46.0%. Kinetic studies, in situ spectra and density functional theory calculations revealed that Cu2O/Cu core preferentially adsorbed NO3‚àí and further reduced to *NO2, while active hydrogen radicals enriched on PdCu shell promoted multistep hydrodeoxygenation of *NO2 to NH3 within ‚Äúsemi‚Äêclosed‚Äù mesoporous microenvironment, both of which synergistically enabled tandem electrocatalysis in positive potentials. Moreover, this enzyme‚Äêlike electrocatalyst disclosed better NO3‚àí‚Äêto‚ÄêNH3 performance in a more energy‚Äêefficient manner when coupling with more thermodynamically favorable ethanol oxidation reaction.

item.title: Residue‚ÄêFree Fabrication of 2D Materials Using van der Waals Interactions
item.content:encoded:
Residue‚Äêfree 2D materials with exceptional cleanliness and high quality are achieved using van der Waals interaction‚Äêbased fabrication and manipulation techniques, completely free from polymers and solvents. Precise manipulation enables the construction of vdW heterostructures with controlled alignment, expanding the potential of 2D materials for next‚Äêgeneration electronic and optoelectronic devices.
Abstract 2D materials have garnered considerable attention due to their distinctive properties, prompting diverse applications across various domains. Beyond their inherent qualities, the significance of 2D materials extends into the fabrication processes that can lead to the degradation of intrinsic performance through undesirable mechanical defects and surface contaminations. Herein, a novel fabrication technique to achieve residue‚Äêfree 2D materials using van der Waals (vdW) interactions, primarily employing molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) is proposed. Optical and electrical characterizations confirm the absence of residues, mechanical defects, oxidation, and strain, along with a prominent field‚Äêeffect mobility of up to 60 cm2¬†V‚àí1 s‚àí1 and an on/off ratio of ‚âà108. Furthermore, the utilization of residue‚Äêfree material as a stamp enables various manipulations of flakes transferred on substrates in advance, including pick‚Äêup and release, stacking, exfoliation, wiping‚Äêout, flipping, and smoothing‚Äêout processes. Additionally, the manipulation techniques also facilitate the fabrication of vdW heterostructures with precise positioning and the desired stacking order. In this regard, the feasibility of applying this method to hexagonal boron nitride and graphite is demonstrated. It is expected that this method will offer a versatile and effective approach to enhancing the qualities of 2D material‚Äêbased electronic and optoelectronic devices.

item.title: Electric Field‚ÄêInduced Dual‚ÄêGradient Heterojunction Diodes Toward Ultrasensitive Self‚ÄêPowered Ionic Skin
item.content:encoded:
A universal strategy for constructing ultrasensitive self‚Äêpowered sensing materials with dual‚Äêgradient heterojunctions is developed through the induction of anionic and cationic polymer gradient distribution under direct current electric field.
Abstract The hydrogel ionic diode is regarded as a promising self‚Äêpowered sensor, capable of harvesting energy from low‚Äêfrequency stimuli human motions and converting it into electrical signals. However, the sensitivity of the reported conventional bilayer hydrogel ionic diodes are relatively low, due to the single heterojunction interface and high interface resistance, making it challenging to meet the demands of high‚Äêprecision sensing. Here, a universal method for fabricating dual‚Äêgradient hydrogel ionic diodes without bilayer structure through the induction of anionic and cationic polymer gradient distribution via a direct current electric field is developed. Due to the dual‚Äêgradient distribution, numerous heterogeneous microstructures (i.e., microdiodes) with low interface resistance are formed in the bulk phase of hydrogel, and these series‚Äêconnected microdiodes demonstrate a significantly increase in open circuit voltage in response to mechanical pressure. The dual‚Äêgradient hydrogel ionic diode exhibits ultra‚Äêhigh sensitivity (1247.3¬†mV/MPa) and ultralow detection limit (0.8¬†Pa), enabling the smart prosthetic hand to non‚Äêdestructive grasp ultrasoft tofu. This work is expected to pave the way for novel high‚Äêprecision self‚Äêpowered sensors in intelligent wearable electronics.

item.title: Issue Information
The Critical Role of Atomic‚ÄêScale Polarization in Transition Metal Oxides on Vanadium‚ÄêRedox Electrochemistry (Adv. Mater. 13/2025)
item.content:encoded: Atomic‚ÄêScale Polarization In article number 2420510, Walid A. Daoud and colleagues report an atomic‚Äêscale polarization‚Äêfunctionalized Mn3O4‚Äêbased catalyst for vanadium redox flow battery, where the role of vacancy‚Äêinduced local polarization on vanadium redox reactions is investigated. The findings shed light on the fundamental rules governing the utility and evolution of vacancies in transition metal oxide electrocatalysts, thereby moving a step closer toward their deployment in a wide range of sustainable energy storage schemes.

item.title: Hyperspectral Metachip‚ÄêBased 3D Spatial Map for Cancer Cell Screening and Quantification (Adv. Mater. 13/2025)
item.content:encoded: Cancer Cell Detection In article number 2412738, Zihan Zhao, Guangwei Hu, Xumin Ding, and co‚Äêworkers report a method that employs a multiplexed THz metachip with high sensitivity to capture rich spectral signatures of human cancer cells and maps them in a three‚Äêdimensional spatial coordinate. The experimental detection success rate reaches 93.33%, providing a novel path for early cancer screening technology.

item.title: In Situ Formation of Ripplocations in Hybrid Organic‚ÄìInorganic MXenes (Adv. Mater. 13/2025)
item.content:encoded: Hybrid Organic‚ÄìInorganic MXenes This cross‚Äêsectional STEM image captures the wave‚Äêlike rippling observed in an organic‚Äêinorganic hybrid 2D MXene. Here, these ripples, often referred to as Ripplocations, are formed when the organic surface groups are exposed to the electron beam. Ripplocations are a fundamental defect in layered materials and may play a key role in how the material responds to stress and external conditions. More details can be found in article number 2411669 by Francisco Lagunas, Robert F. Klie, and co‚Äêworkers.

item.title: Hydrogen‚ÄêBonded Organic Framework Nanoscintillators for X‚ÄêRay‚ÄêInduced Photodynamic Therapy in Hepatocellular Carcinoma (Adv. Mater. 13/2025)
item.content:encoded: X‚ÄêRay Induced Photodynamic Therapy A novel biocompatible organic phosphorescent HOF nanoscintillator (BPT‚ÄêHOF@PEG) was fabricated to enhance X‚Äêray induced photodynamic therapy (X‚ÄêPDT) for treating unresectable hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). The precise tumor localization ability of stereotactic radiotherapy, along with the efficient X‚Äêray energy absorption and transfer properties of BPT‚ÄêHOF@PEG, provides significant therapeutic potential for HCC treatment, making this phosphorescent HOF‚Äêbased X‚ÄêPDT a promising alternative for patients with unresectable HCC. More details can be found in article number 2417001 by Feng Shen, Huijing Xiang, Yu Chen, Tian Yang, and co‚Äêworkers.

item.title: Magnetointeractive Cr2Te3‚ÄêCoated Liquid Metal Droplets for Flexible Memory Arrays and Wearable Sensors (Adv. Mater. 13/2025)
item.content:encoded: Coated Liquid Metal Droplets In article number 2414519, Yixiong Feng. Jingyu Sun, Xiuju Song, and co‚Äêworkers present a novel strategy for coating liquid metals with 2D magnetic materials. The fabricated cadmium telluride (Cr2Te3)‚Äêcoated liquid metal (CT‚ÄêLM) droplets exhibit controllable deformation and locomotion under magnetic fields, non‚Äêadhesion to surfaces, and cost‚Äêeffective recyclability. Their functionality is demonstrated in magneto‚Äêinteractive memory devices and wearable sensors for dynamic gesture recognition, broadening the potential applications of flexible electronics.

item.title: Pioneering the Future: Principles, Advances, and Challenges in Organic Electrodes for Aqueous Ammonium‚ÄêIon Batteries
item.content:encoded:
Leveraging the numerous advantages of ammonium‚Äêion (NH‚ÇÑ‚Å∫)‚Äîincluding cost‚Äêeffectiveness, low corrosiveness, preferential orientation, and rapid diffusion kinetics‚Äîaqueous NH‚ÇÑ‚Å∫ batteries (AAIBs) have gained significant attention. This review highlights and evaluates the progress of AAIBs utilizing organic electrode materials such as small molecules, conducting polymers, covalent organic frameworks, and organic‚Äêinorganic hybrid materials, with the goal of advancing cutting‚Äêedge aqueous energy storage systems.
Abstract Aqueous ammonium‚Äêion (NH4+) batteries (AAIBs) have recently been considered as attractive alternatives for next‚Äêgeneration large‚Äêscale energy storage systems, on account of their cost‚Äêeffectiveness, nonflammability, less corrosive, small hydrated ionic radius, and rapid NH4+ diffusion kinetics. In addition, the tetrahedral structure of NH4+ exhibits preferential orientation characteristics, resulting in a different electrochemical storage mechanism from spherical charge carriers such as Li+, Na+, and K+. Therefore, unlocking the NH4+‚Äêion storage mechanisms in host electrode materials is pivotal to advancing the design of high‚Äêperformance AAIBs. Organic materials, with their customizable, flexible, and stable molecular structures, along with their ease of recycling and disposal, offer tremendous potential. However, the development of cutting‚Äêedge organic electrode materials specifically for ammonium‚Äêion storage in AAIBs remains an exciting, yet largely untapped, frontier. This review systematically explores the interaction mechanisms between NH4+ ions and organic electrode materials, such as electrostatic interactions including hydrogen bonding. It also highlights the application of diverse organic electrode materials, such as small molecules, conducting polymers, covalent organic frameworks (COFs), and organic‚Äêinorganic hybrids in AAIBs. Lastly, the review addresses the key challenges and future perspectives of organic‚Äêmaterial‚Äêbased AAIBs, aiming to push the boundaries of cutting‚Äêedge aqueous energy storage systems.

item.title: Advances and Outlooks for Carbon Nanotube‚ÄêBased Thermoelectric Materials and Devices
item.content:encoded:
The unique structure of carbon nanotubes (CNTs) offers excellent electrical, mechanical properties, and surface area, enhancing their use in flexible thermoelectric materials. This review highlights recent advances in CNT‚Äêbased thermoelectrics, focusing on doping, composites, stability improvement, and applications in wearable devices, while addressing current challenges and future directions for optimization.
Abstract The unique structure of carbon nanotubes (CNTs) endows them with exceptional electrical and mechanical properties, along with a high surface area, making them highly beneficial for use as flexible, high‚Äêperforming thermoelectric materials. As a result, the application of CNTs in the thermoelectric field has become increasingly widespread. Considering the rapid advancements in this field, this review offers a timely overview of the most recent progress on CNT‚Äêbased thermoelectric materials and devices over the past five years. This review begins by introducing the fundamental concepts and thermoelectric mechanisms of CNT‚Äêbased thermoelectric materials. Then new strategies are explored to enhance their thermoelectric performance, focusing on doping and composites, while emphasizing the importance of CNT stability as a key research area. Additionally, the latest design concepts and expanded application scenarios for flexible and wearable CNTs‚Äêbased thermoelectric devices are summarized. Finally, the current challenges are addressed and future directions for the development of CNT‚Äêbased thermoelectric materials and devices are discussed.

item.title: The Influence of Ionizing Radiation on Quantification for In Situ and Operando Liquid‚ÄêPhase Electron Microscopy
item.content:encoded:
Liquid‚Äêphase transmission electron microscopy enables visualization of nanoscale processes involving liquid media. Yet, it suffers from beam effects, such as radiolysis of the liquid, sample heating, and membrane charging. This review summarizes beam effect fundamentals, describes modeling and assessment, and illustrates handling strategies. The findings are transferable to other ionizing radiation techniques using, for example,¬†Œ≥‚Äê or X‚Äêrays.
Abstract The ionizing radiation harnessed in electron microscopes or synchrotrons enables unique insights into nanoscale dynamics. In liquid‚Äêphase transmission electron microscopy (LP‚ÄêTEM), irradiating a liquid sample with electrons offers access to real space information at an unmatched combination of temporal and spatial resolution. However, employing ionizing radiation for imaging can alter the Gibbs free energy landscape during the experiment. This is mainly due to radiolysis and the corresponding shift in chemical potential; however, experiments can also be affected by irradiation‚Äêinduced charging and heating. In this review, the state of the art in describing beam effects is summarized, theoretical and experimental assessment guidelines are provided, and strategies to obtain quantitative information under such conditions are discussed. While this review showcases these effects on LP‚ÄêTEM, the concepts that are discussed here can also be applied to other types of ionizing radiation used to probe liquid samples, such as synchrotron X‚Äêrays.

item.title: Eliminating Radioresistance With a Magnetic Ion‚ÄêGenerator by Simultaneously Augmenting DNA Damage and Diminishing Immunosuppression
item.content:encoded:
Traditional medicine has encountered certain bottlenecks in dealing with radioresistance. To address this, a ‚Äúthree birds with one stone‚Äù strategy based on the constructed radioresistance model is developed. This innovative magnetic ion‚Äêgenerator can not only release Fe2+ and Mn2+ ions to induce ferroptosis and activate the STING pathway, enhancing DNA damage synergistically with radiotherapy, but it can also modulate the immunosuppressive microenvironment effectively, thereby reversing radioresistance.
Abstract Radiotherapy (RT) hinges on DNA damage‚Äêinduced cancer cell death and the subsequent anti‚Äêtumor immunity. However, the efficacy of RT is curtailed by cell cycle heterogeneity and an immunosuppressive tumor microenvironment, which foster radioresistance. Here an ion generator‚Äêbased RT enhancement strategy is demonstrated in a mouse model of the radioresistant tumor. The ion generator is degraded in the tumor microenvironment, resulting in iron‚Äêtriggered ferroptosis that enhanced immunogenic cell death and a manganese‚Äêactivated stimulator of interferon gene that reversed the immunosuppressive environment. As a result, the proposed strategy promotes dendritic cells maturity, augmentes CD8+ T cell infiltration of tumors, suppresses intratumoral myeloid‚Äêderived suppressor cells, and limits the M2 macrophages polarization, indicating the formation of an immunoreactive microenvironment. Significantly, this approach impedes the growth of not just primary, but also distal metastatic tumors. It is thus believed that the current ion generator provides a robust and enduring countermeasure to radioresistant cancer and its metastasis, with potential implications for enhancing the efficacy of RT in clinically resistant tumors.

item.title: In Situ Formation of Ripplocations in Hybrid Organic‚ÄìInorganic MXenes
item.content:encoded:
Hybrid MXenes (h‚ÄêMXenes) are a family of 2D¬†transition metal carbides with amino surface groups that exhibit interesting optical properties. The sensitivity of the organic material under high‚Äêenergy electron beams complicates conventional TEM analysis. Using cryogenic STEM, we show h‚ÄêMXenes are stable until a critical dose threshold. Beyond that threshold, the in situ generation of ripplocations is observed.
Abstract Inorganic‚Äìorganic hybrid MXenes (h‚ÄêMXenes) are a family of 2D transition metal carbides and nitrides functionalized with alkylimido and alkylamido surface groups. Using cryogenic and room temperature scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) and electron energy‚Äêloss spectroscopy (EELS), it is shown that ripplocations, a form of a fundamental defect in 2D and layered structures, are abundant in this family of materials. Furthermore, detailed studies of electron probe sample interactions, focusing on structural deformations caused by the electron beam are presented. The findings indicate that at cryogenic temperatures (‚âà100¬†K) and below a specific dose threshold, the structure of h‚ÄêMXenes remains largely intact. However, exceeding this threshold leads to electron beam‚Äêinduced deformation through ripplocations. Interestingly, the deformation behavior, required dose, and resultant structure are highly dependent on temperature. At 100¬†K, it is demonstrated that the electron beam can induce ripplocations in situ with a high degree of precision.

item.title: Polyamine‚ÄêDepleting Hydrogen‚ÄêBond Organic Frameworks Unleash Dendritic Cell and T Cell Vigor for Targeted CRISPR/Cas‚ÄêAssisted Cancer Immunotherapy
item.content:encoded:
A microfluidic‚Äêassisted hydrogen‚Äêbond organic framework (HOF) nanoplatforms depletes polyamines in the tumor microenvironment, reversing T‚Äêcell immunosuppression and enhancing dendritic cell activity. By releasing CRISPR‚ÄêCas9 and inducing neoantigen generation via carbonyl stress and mutational burden elevation, this system enables precision cancer immunotherapy through dual‚Äêaction mechanisms targeting both immune vigor and tumor vulnerability.
Abstract Polyamines have tantalized cancer researchers as a potential means to rein in the rampant growth of cancer cells. However, clinical trials in recent decades have disappointed in delivering notable progress. Herein, a microfluidic‚Äêassisted synthetic hydrogen‚Äêbond organic framework (HOF) as a polyamine‚Äêdepleting nanoplatforms designed to unleash the vigor of both dendritic cells (DCs) and T cells for precision cancer immunotherapy is reported. Upon internalization by tumor cells, the loaded plasma amine oxidase (PAO) in HOF efficiently depletes polyamines, remolding the tumor microenvironment and alleviating T‚Äêcell immunosuppression. This process also generates acrolein and H2O2, triggering CRISPR‚Äêassisted neoantigen generation. Specifically, Acrolein induces carbonyl stress, increasing mutational burdens. Simultaneously, HOF leverages the energy from the bis[2,4,5‚Äêtrichloro‚Äê6‚Äê(pentyloxycarbonyl)phenyl] oxalate (CPPO)‚ÄêH2O2 reaction for CRET‚Äêtriggered singlet oxygen production, leading to thioether bond cleavage and release CRISPR‚ÄêCas9. Once released, CRISPR‚ÄêCas9 knocks out the DNA mismatch repair (MMR)‚Äêrelated MLH1 gene, further elevating mutational burdens and generating neoantigens, ideal targets for DCs. This dual‚Äêaction strategy not only corrects T‚Äêcell immunosuppression but also enhances DC efficacy, presenting a powerful approach for tumor immunotherapy.

item.title: Hyperspectral Metachip‚ÄêBased 3D Spatial Map for Cancer Cell Screening and Quantification
item.content:encoded:
A 3D spatial map for human cancer cells is developed using the designed multiplexed THz metachip with superior Q factors and sensitivity. This method for screening and quantifying cancer cells based on such a 3D spatial map has been experimentally validated to achieve high accuracies (93.33%) under several selected cancer cells from different parts of the human body.
Abstract In this paper, compact terahertz (THz) metachips for hyperspectral screening and quantitative evaluation of human cancer cells is reported. This pixelated resonant metachips feature the resonance channel from 1 and 3¬†THz frequency with a record‚Äêhigh quality factor (up to 230). Through the interactions of various cancer cells of different concentrations, high‚Äêdimensional spectral signatures are obtained, which are further transformed into a spatial map for labelling and quantification purposes. The screening of up to 15 cancer cells is experimentally reported, with very high detecting accuracy of 93.33% and with attractive quantitative concentration sensitivity up to 1320¬†kHz¬†cell¬†mL‚àí1. This hyperspectral metachips are low‚Äêcost, highly compact, and label‚Äêfree for fast, high‚Äêthroughput and high‚Äêsensitivity detections and evaluation of human cancer cells. This technology does not require clinical experience, representing an accessible technology for early diagnosis of cancer.

item.title: An Integrated Virtual Screening Platform to Identify Potent Co‚ÄêAssembled Nanodrugs for Cancer Treatment
item.content:encoded:
This work uses ligand‚Äêbased virtual screening¬†(LBVS) and density functional theory (DFT) calculations to construct a high‚Äêthroughput screening platform, which can be used to identify small molecule combinations with potential co‚Äêassembly ability.
Abstract Co‚Äêassembled nanodrugs provide significant advantages in cancer treatment and drug delivery, yet effective screening methods to identify molecular combinations for co‚Äêassembly are lacking. This study presents a screening strategy integrating ligand‚Äêbased virtual screening (LBVS) and density functional theory (DFT) calculations to explore new molecular combinations with co‚Äêassembly capabilities. The accuracy of this screening was validated by synthesizing various co‚Äêassembled nanodrugs under mild conditions. Vinpocetine (Vin) and lenvatinib (Len) are representative co‚Äêassembly combinations that can directly co‚Äêassemble into nanoparticles (NPs) through hydrogen bonding, van der Waals forces, and œÄ‚ÄêœÄ interactions. These NPs were further functionalized with polyethylene glycol (PEG), resulting in PEG‚ÄêL/V NPs that exhibited enhanced stability and biocompatibility. In addition, PEG‚ÄêL/V NPs can respond to acidic conditions and release Vin and Len, working synergistically to induce cell cycle arrest and apoptosis in tumor cells in vitro while also inhibiting xenograft tumor growth in vivo. RNA sequencing (RNA‚Äêseq) analysis revealed that the co‚Äêassembled nanodrugs exhibited mechanisms that are distinct from those of single drugs. This study demonstrates the feasibility of utilizing a computational approach combining LBVS and DFT to identify small molecules with co‚Äêassembly capabilities, leading to innovative anticancer strategies.

item.title: Nonlocal Conduction in a Metawire
item.content:encoded:
