Resulting structural degeneracy and associated soft vibrations sink heat effectively from acoustic phonons, which along with various nanoscale defects, confine the phonon mean free path (MFP) close to the interatomic distance, rendering the thermal transport glassy. However, the material still maintains a high electrical conductivity at ambient condition due to much longer MFP of the charge carriers. A promising output power density of ‚âà0.8¬†W¬†cm‚àí2 for ŒîT ‚âà441 K in double‚Äêleg thermoelectric device demonstrate the potential of this material for mid‚Äêtemperature thermoelectric applications.

item.title: Topology‚ÄêOriented Lymph Node Drainage of Dendritic Polymer‚ÄêTLR Agonist Conjugates to Enhance Vaccine Immunogenicity
item.content:encoded:
To investigate the effects of topological characteristics of polymers on their lymph node (LN) targeting activity and how their molecular weight (MW) influences pharmacokinetics to support LN homing, a series of polymer‚ÄêTLR agonist conjugates (PTACs) are designed. Among the conjugates, the dendritic 6‚Äêarm PTAC with an MW of 60 kDa demonstrated the highest LN drainage, deepest penetration, and prolonged retention. As a result, it induced broad antibody and T cell responses, enhancing vaccine immunogenicity and suppressing tumor growth.
Abstract Strategically targeting lymph nodes (LNs) to orchestrate the initiation and regulation of adaptive immune responses is one of the most pressing challenges in the context of vaccination. Herein, a series of polymer‚ÄêTLR agonist conjugates (PTACs) is developed to investigate the impact of dendritic‚Äêtopological characteristics on their LN targeting activity in vivo, and their molecular weight (MW) on their pharmacokinetics in support of their LN homing. Notably, the dendritic 6‚Äêarm PTAC with a MW of 60¬†kDa (6A‚ÄêPTAC‚Äê60k) rapidly delivered cargo to draining LNs after administration to peripheral tissues. Specifically, this topologic structure ameliorated the targeting behavior within lymphatic vessels and LNs, including an elevated amount of TLR7/8 agonist delivered to the LNs, an improved distribution pattern among barrier cells and immune cells, increased permeability, and prolonged retention. Furthermore, the 6A‚ÄêPTAC‚Äê60k formulation induced broad antibody and T cell responses, enhancing vaccine immunogenicity and suppressing tumor growth. The results revealed that both the topology and MW of polymers are crucial factors for immunoadjuvant distribution and their functional activity in the draining LNs, which, in turn, enhanced the immunogenicity of the vaccine formulation. This study may provide a chemical and structural basis for optimizing the design of immunoadjuvant delivery systems.

item.title: Large‚ÄêScale 2D Perovskite Nanocrystals Photodetector Array via Ultrasonic Spray Synthesis
item.content:encoded:
Red, green, and blue (R/G/B) colored 2D perovskite nanocrystals synthesized via an ultrasonic spray method demonstrate outstanding photo‚Äêdetection performance in 4‚Äêinch photodetector arrays with a 100% operational yield, enabled by a liquid‚Äêbridge‚Äêtransport strategy. This scalable, self‚Äêaligned synthesis provides a practical pathway for high‚Äêperformance, large‚Äêarea perovskite optoelectronic devices and shows promising potential for broader applications in integrated optoelectronic systems.
Abstract 2D perovskite (PVSK) single crystals have received significant attention due to their unique optical and optoelectronic properties. However, current synthesis methods face limitations, particularly in large‚Äêarea fabrication, which remain critical barriers to practical applications. In this study, the synthesis of red/green/purple‚Äêblue‚Äêcolored 2D PVSK nanocrystals over a large area (4‚Äêinch wafer) and the fabrication of high‚Äêperformance photodetector arrays are presented via a facile yet efficient spray‚Äêcoating approach with a liquid‚Äêbridge transport effect. The photodetector array achieves 100% working yield, high photo‚Äêresponsivity (1.5¬†√ó¬†106¬†A¬†W‚àí1) and specific‚Äêdetectivity (1.1 √ó 1016 Jones) with competitive photomapping characteristics. An intelligent vision system for automatic shape recognition is further demonstrated with a recognition rate exceeding 90%. This study provides significant advances in the scalable synthesis of nanoscale 2D PVSK crystals, their integration into large‚Äêarea optoelectronic devices, and their potential use in artificial‚Äêintelligence systems.

item.title: Andrias davidianus Derived Glycosaminoglycans Direct Diabetic Wound Repair by Reprogramming Reparative Macrophage Glucolipid Metabolism
item.content:encoded:
Glycosaminoglycans (GAGs) in the skin mucus of Andrias davidianus and its derived engineered microspheres have been shown to promote angiogenesis and modulate the inflammatory microenvironment by inducing the polarization of reparative macrophages, thus contributing to wound healing. This is an excellent paradigm for harnessing cross‚Äêspecies regenerative capabilities to address impaired wound repair, introducing a novel therapeutic strategy for refractory wounds.
Abstract Harnessing cross‚Äêspecies regenerative cues to direct human regenerative potential is increasingly recognized as an excellent strategy in regenerative medicine, particularly for addressing the challenges of impaired wound healing in aging populations. The skin mucus of Andrias davidianus plays a critical role in self‚Äêprotection and tissue repair, yet the fundamental regenerative factors and mechanisms involved remain elusive. Here, this work presents evidence that glycosaminoglycans (GAGs) derived from the skin secretion of Andrias davidianus (SAGs) serve as potent mediators of angiogenesis and inflammatory remodeling, facilitating efficient healing of diabetic wounds. Mechanistic studies reveal that SAGs promote macrophage polarization toward an anti‚Äêinflammatory and pro‚Äêregenerative phenotype (CD206+/Arg1+) via glucolipid metabolic reprogramming. This process suppresses excessive inflammation and enhances the expression of VEGF and IL‚Äê10 to create a facilitative microenvironment for tissue regeneration. Additionally, this work develops SAGs‚ÄêGelMA composite microspheres that address multiple stages of wound healing, including rapid hemostasis, exudate control, and activation of endogenous regenerative processes. This engineered approach significantly improves the scarless healing of diabetic wounds by facilitating the recruitment and activation of reparative macrophages. The findings offer new insights into the regenerative mechanisms of Andrias davidianus and highlight the potential therapeutic application of SAGs in tissue repair.

item.title: All‚ÄêSolid‚ÄêState Lithium Metal Batteries with Microdomain‚ÄêRegulated Polycationic Solid Electrolytes
item.content:encoded:
Analogic to the design of an anionic framework for inorganic sulfide/oxide solid electrolytes, a copolymeric polycationic electrolyte, P(AT‚ÄêMBA‚Äê6F), that leverages the polycationic backbones with fluorinated microdomain trapping effect is constructed, which enables stable, fast and high‚Äêenergy all‚Äêsolid‚Äêstate LMBs at ambient temperature.
Abstract Solid polymer electrolytes (SPEs) are promising for high‚Äêenergy and high‚Äêsafety solid‚Äêstate lithium metal batteries (LMBs). Here, a polycationic solid electrolyte (PCSE) is described that leverages the inherent high thermal/chemical stability of the polycationic domain and the anion trapping (FMAT) effect of another fluorinated microdomain for stable and fast‚Äêcharging high‚Äêvoltage LMBs. Specifically, while the polycationic imidazolium backbone ensures high segmental flexibility facilitating the Li+ mobility, the fluorinated microdomain effectively traps the bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide anions by strong dipole interactions, imparting localized solvation and restricted mobility of the anions, as well as improved oxidation stability. As a result, the PCSE exhibits a high ionic conductivity of 1.4 mS cm‚àí1, a high Li+ transference number of 0.50, and a wide electrochemical window of ‚àº5.5 V at 25¬†¬∞C. By way of in situ thermal polymerization of the electrolyte within assembled cells, the PCSE enables ultra‚Äêstable cycling of Li|LiNi0.8Co0.1Mn0.1O2 cells with a capacity retention of 98.1% after 500 cycles at 0.2¬†C at ambient temperatures. The work on the molecular design of PCSEs represents a fundamentally unique perspective for the rational design of SPEs with balanced properties that are historically challenging for high‚Äêenergy, long‚Äêlife, ambient‚Äêtemperature solid‚Äêstate LMBs.

item.title: Atomically Engineered Trimetallic Nanoclusters Toward Enhanced Photoluminescence and Photoinitiation Activity
item.content:encoded:
The central doping of Pd/Pt atoms and the surface‚Äêmotif doping of Cd atoms are concurrently achieved in trimetallic MAu18Cd3 (M = Pd/Pt) nanoclusters, which are synthesized via using the M‚Äêdoped Au25 template. This co‚Äêdoping strategy can significantly enhance the photoluminescence intensity and efficiency by affecting radiative relaxation and nonradiative relaxation pathways simultaneously.
Abstract Precise doping is of vital significance for atomic engineering and the establishment of structure‚Äêproperty relationships in nanocluster (NC) chemistry. Herein, two novel trimetallic MAu18Cd3 (M = Pd/Pt) NCs that are derived from M‚Äêdoped Au25 templates of MAu24 are reported, in which the central doping of M atom and the surface‚Äêmotif doping of Cd atoms are concurrently achieved. Compared to the original templates, Cd‚Äêinduced surface engineering enhances the rigidity of the structural framework and enlarges the HOMO‚ÄêLUMO gaps of the MAu18Cd3, significantly improving photoluminescent efficiency by suppressing nonradiative relaxation. The critical role of the central M (Pd/Pt) dopant in photoluminescence, which regulates the rate of radiative decay of excited‚Äêstate electrons, has also been substantiated. More notably, the doped case of PtAu18Cd3 exhibits excellent photoinitiation activity in 3D two‚Äêphoton printing with a high resolution of ‚âà140¬†nm, which may be attributed to the prolonged excited state. Overall, this work provides a generalized routine for the precise synthesis of multi‚Äêmetal NCs with concurrent enhancements in photoluminescence and photoinitiation activity, which is expected to stimulate further research for the design and preparation of multi‚Äêfunctional, multi‚Äêmetal NCs.

item.title: Autonomous, Moisture‚ÄêDriven Flexible Electrogenerative Dressing for Enhanced Wound Healing
item.content:encoded:
An autonomous, moisture‚Äêdriven flexible electrogenerative dressing (AMFED) is developed by integrating a moist‚Äêelectric generator, an antibacterial hydrogel dressing, and concentric molybdenum electrodes. This self‚Äêsustaining dressing provides continuous electrical stimulation and exhibits potent antibacterial activity. In vivo studies demonstrate that AMFED effectively accelerates diabetic wound healing.
Abstract Electrotherapy has shown considerable potential in treating chronic wounds, but conventional approaches relying on bulky external power supplies and mechanical force are limited in their clinical utility. This study introduces an autonomous, moisture‚Äêdriven flexible electrogenerative dressing (AMFED) that overcomes these limitations. The AMFED integrates a moist‚Äêelectric generator (MEG), an antibacterial hydrogel dressing, and concentric molybdenum (Mo) electrodes to provide a self‚Äêsustaining electrical supply and potent antibacterial activity against Staphylococcus aureus and Escherichia coli. The MEG harnesses chemical energy from moisture to produce a stable direct current of 0.61¬†V without external input, delivering this therapeutic electrical stimulation to the wound site through the Mo electrodes. The AMFED facilitates macrophage polarization toward reparative M2 phenotype and regulates inflammatory cytokines. Moreover, in vivo studies suggest that the AMFED group significantly enhances chronic wound healing, with an approximate 41% acceleration compared to the control group. Using a diabetic mouse wound model, the AMFED demonstrates its effectiveness in promoting nerve regulation, epithelial migration, and vasculogenesis. These findings present a novel and efficient platform for accelerating chronic wound healing.

item.title: Multicolor Organic Single‚ÄêCrystal Microcavity Light Emitting Diodes With High Color‚ÄêPurity and High Brightness
item.content:encoded:
Single crystal microcavity organic light‚Äêemitting diodes (SC‚ÄêMC‚ÄêOLEDs) with high color purity (FWHM < 10 nm), high brightness (> 106 cd m‚àí2), high efficiency (EQE‚àº4%), high polarization (> 0.90) and high stability are realized by combining the large size 2D organic single crystals with efficient microcavity effect, unlocking potential for ultra‚Äêhigh‚Äêdefinition displays and AR/VR applications.
Abstract The development of ultra‚Äêhigh‚Äêdefinition (UHD) displays demands organic light‚Äêemitting diodes (OLEDs) with high color purity of all three primary colors for a wide color gamut and high brightness essential for future AR/VR applications. However, the vibronic coupling in organic emitters typically results in broad emissions, with a full width at half maximum (FWHM) exceeding 40‚Äì50¬†nm. Herein, multicolor organic single‚Äêcrystal microcavity light‚Äêemitting diodes (SC‚ÄêMC‚ÄêOLEDs) are demonstrated by embedding ultrathin 2D organic single crystals (2D‚ÄêOSCs) between two silver layers that serve as both electrodes and mirrors. By leveraging the microcavity effect, the resonant output frequencies of SC‚ÄêMC‚ÄêOLEDs can be continuously tuned from 448 to 602¬†nm by adjusting the thickness of 2D‚ÄêOSCs (i.e., the microcavity length), achieving high color purity with a full width at half maximum (FWHM) of <10¬†nm. Furthermore, the Purcell effect in SC‚ÄêMC‚ÄêOLEDs enhances the radiative rate and improves light‚Äêcoupling efficiency, resulting in a maximum external quantum efficiency (EQE) of up to 4% and minimal efficiency roll‚Äêoff. Due to the excellent bipolar transport properties of OSCs, the brightness of SC‚ÄêMC‚ÄêOLEDs surpasses 106 cd m‚àí2, along with a degree of linear polarization exceeding 0.9, unlocking new application opportunities.

item.title: Waveguide Microactuators Self‚ÄêRolled Around an Optical Fiber Taper
item.content:encoded:
A novel self‚Äêrolling integration strategy mounts ultrathin (‚âà2¬†¬µm) poly(N‚Äêisopropylacrylamide)/Au microactuators onto optical fiber tapers, achieving unprecedented bending angles (>800¬∞) and rapid response (‚âà0.55¬†s). This waveguide microactuator enables dynamic capture of fast‚Äêmoving microorganisms and provides a high‚Äêperformance, versatile platform for biomedical applications in confined, unstructured environments.
Abstract Precisely capturing and manipulating microscale objects, such as individual cells and microorganisms, is fundamental to advancements in biomedical research and microrobotics. Photoactuators based on optical fibers serving as flexible, unobstructed waveguides are well‚Äêsuited for these operations, particularly in confined locations where free‚Äêspace illumination is impractical. However, integrating optical fibers with microscale actuators poses significant challenges due to size mismatch, resulting in slow responses inadequate for handling motile micro‚Äêobjects. This study designs microactuators based on hydrogel/Au bilayer heterostructures that self‚Äêroll around a tapered optical fiber. This self‚Äêrolling mechanism enables the use of thin hydrogel layers only a few micrometers thick, which rapidly absorb and release water molecules during a phase transition. The resulting microactuators exhibit low bending stiffness and extremely fast responses, achieving large bending angles exceeding 800¬∞ within 0.55 s. Using this technique, this study successfully captures rapidly swimming Chlamydomonas and Paramecium, and demonstrates programmable non‚Äêreciprocal motion for effective non‚Äêcontact manipulation of yeast cells. This approach provides a versatile platform for microscale manipulations and holds promise for advanced biomedical applications.

item.title: Low‚ÄêVolatility Fused‚ÄêRing Solid Additive Engineering for Synergistically Elongating Exciton Lifetime and Mitigating Trap Density Toward Organic Solar Cells of 20.5% Efficiency
item.content:encoded:
3,6‚Äêdibromothieno[3,2‚Äêb]thiophene (3,6TTBr) is selected as a representative low‚Äêvolatility fused‚Äêring solid additive to elucidate the mechanism of photovoltaic performance. The integrated theoretical and experimental study reveals that 3,6TTBr's rigid, planar molecules interact with the terminal units of L8‚ÄêBO, facilitating spacing for neighboring molecules. To validate the broader applicability of the findings, 1,5‚Äêdibromonaphthalene (1,5‚ÄêBN) is examined, achieving a notable PCE of 20.5%.
Abstract Volatile solid additives (VSAs) with single or fused‚Äêring structures have attracted much attention for enhancing power conversion efficiencies (PCEs) of organic solar cells (OSCs). While the working mechanisms of high‚Äêvolatility single‚Äêring additives have been well studied, the influence of low‚Äêvolatility fused‚Äêring VSAs on molecular aggregations and exciton/carrier dynamics remains still unclear. Herein, 3,6‚Äêdibromothieno[3,2‚Äêb]thiophene (3,6TTBr) is selected as a representative low‚Äêvolatility fused‚Äêring VSA to elucidate its working mechanism. Via the theoretical and experimental joint investigation, it is found that rigid and planar 3,6TTBr molecules adsorb onto the terminal units of L8‚ÄêBO (acceptor), inducing loose space for adjacent molecules. The low‚Äêvolatility 3,6TTBr thus favors the L8‚ÄêBO center‚Äêterminal packing with a larger interfragment distance, which relieves the L8‚ÄêBO over‚Äêaggregation and induces the ordered packing. Consequently, the 3,6TTBr treatment reduces aggregation‚Äêcaused quenching, enhancing the photoluminescence quantum yield and exciton lifetime of L8‚ÄêBO film. The combination of the above properties with the reduced trap density and improved carrier transport in the 3,6TTBr‚Äêtreated devices contributed to PCE of 20.1%. To validate the broad applicability of the findings, 1,5‚Äêdibromonaphthalene (1,5‚ÄêBN), another low‚Äêvolatility fused‚Äêring solid, is explored. The devices with 1,5‚ÄêBN achieved an impressive PCE of 20.5%, verifying the validity of the low‚Äêvolatility fused‚Äêring VSA strategy for boosting OSC performances.

item.title: DNA‚ÄêCapturing Manganese‚ÄêCoordinated Chitosan Microparticles Potentiate Radiotherapy via Activating the cGAS‚ÄêSTING Pathway and Maintaining Tumor‚ÄêInfiltrating CD8+ T‚ÄêCell Stemness
item.content:encoded:
DNA‚Äêcapturing CS‚ÄêMn microparticles are prepared to potentiate radioimmunotherapy. Upon injection into the tumors after X‚Äêray irradiation, they undergo rapid dissociation to release chitosan which assembles with the extracellular DNA fragments released from the dead cancer cells to in situ form CS‚ÄêDNA complexes and synergize with Mn2+ to stimulate DC maturation via activating the cGAS‚ÄêSTING pathway for enhanced CD8+ T‚Äêcell stemness.
Abstract The radiotherapy‚Äêinduced release of DNA fragments can stimulate the cyclic guanosine monophosphate‚Äêadenosine monophosphate synthase‚Äêstimulator of interferon genes (cGAS‚ÄêSTING) pathway to prime antitumor immunity, but this pathway is expected to be less potent because of the inefficient cytosolic delivery of negatively charged DNA fragments. In this study, manganese‚Äêcoordinated chitosan (CS‚ÄêMn) microparticles with selective DNA‚Äêcapturing capacity are concisely prepared via a coordination‚Äêdirected one‚Äêpot synthesis process to potentiate the immunogenicity of radiotherapy. The obtained CS‚ÄêMn microparticles that undergo rapid disassembly under physiological conditions can selectively bind with DNA to form positively charged DNA‚ÄêCS assemblies because of the strong electrostatic interaction between linear chitosan and DNA molecules. They thus enable efficient cytosolic delivery of DNA in the presence of serum to cooperate with Mn2+ to activate the cGAS‚ÄêSTING pathway in dendritic cells. Upon intratumoral injection, the CS‚ÄêMn microparticles markedly enhance the efficacy of radiotherapy against both irradiated and distal tumors in different tumor models via collectively promoting tumor‚Äêinfiltrating CD8+ T‚Äêcell stemness and the activation of innate immunity. The radiosensitization effect of CS‚ÄêMn microparticles can be further augmented by concurrently applying anti‚Äêprogrammed cell death protein 1 (anti‚ÄêPD‚Äê1) immunotherapy. This work highlights an ingenious strategy to prepare Trojan horse‚Äêlike DNA‚Äêcapturing microparticles as cGAS‚ÄêSTING‚Äêactivating radiosensitizers for effective radioimmunotherapy.

item.title: Glucose Metabolism‚ÄêTargeted Poly(amino acid) Nanoformulation of Oxaliplatin(IV)‚ÄêAspirin Prodrug for Enhanced Chemo‚ÄêImmunotherapy
item.content:encoded:
A glucose metabolism‚Äêtargeted nanoformulation (NP/OXA‚ÄêASP2) is designed to inhibit lactate efflux while inducing mitochondrial stress to boost immunogenic cell death, thus synergistically reversing the immunosuppressive tumor microenvironments by decreasing the proportion of immunosuppressive cells (Tregs and MDSCs) and increasing the proportion of cytotoxic T lymphocytes (CTLs), and plays an enhanced efficacy of chemo‚Äêimmunotherapy to colon cancer.
Abstract Inappropriate glucose metabolism in cancer cells is associated with immunosuppressive tumor microenvironments (TMEs). Although glycolysis inhibition enhances T cell‚Äêmediated immune responses, the integrated platforms combining glycolysis inhibition with immunotherapy remain underdeveloped. To address this gap, a glucose metabolism‚Äêtargeted poly(amino acid) nanoformulation of oxaliplatin(IV)‚Äêaspirin prodrug (NP/OXA‚ÄêASP2) is developed to improve chemo‚Äêimmunotherapy by suppressing tumor glycolysis. This poly(amino acid) nanoparticle exhibits selective release, discharging 90.0% of OXA‚ÄêASP2 under reductive conditions within 36 h. Furthermore, over 80% of the prodrug converts to OXA and ASP within 12 h, promoting mitochondrial damage and glycolysis inhibition, which amplifies immunogenic cell death induced by OXA. In addition, suppressing glycolytic flux reduces lactate leakage, mitigating the immunosuppressive TMEs. Together, these mechanisms contribute to stronger chemo‚Äêimmunotherapy efficacy. Compared to the OXA plus ASP formulation, NP/OXA‚ÄêASP2 demonstrates superior performances, reducing lactate levels at the tumor site by 25.4%, increasing the proportion of cytotoxic T lymphocytes by 1.53 times, decreasing the proportion of regulatory T cells by 2.20 times, and improving 1.39‚Äêfold of the tumor inhibition rate. These findings underscore that NP/OXA‚ÄêASP2 is a promising platform for integrating tumor metabolic regulation with immunomodulation and holds significant potential for advancing clinical chemo‚Äêimmunotherapy.

item.title: Record Efficiency of Œ≤‚ÄêPhase PVDF‚ÄêMXene Composites in Thin‚ÄêFilm Dielectric Capacitors
item.content:encoded:
MXenes are delaminated in a green organic solvent to achieve large flake size and polymer compatibility. PVDF composites are produced through non‚Äêsolvent‚Äêinduced phase separation to tune the structure and properties of thin‚Äêfilm dielectric capacitors. MXenes with both mixed and pure chlorine terminations enhance the¬†dielectric properties of PVDF, reaching energy density above 45 J cm‚àí3 and 95% efficiency.
Abstract Polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) is a semicrystalline polymer used in thin‚Äêfilm dielectric capacitors because of its inherently high dielectric constant and low loss tangent. Its dielectric constant can be increased by the formation and alignment of its Œ≤‚Äêphase crystalline structure, which can be facilitated by 2D nanofillers. 2D carbides and nitrides, MXenes, are promising candidates due to their notable dielectric permittivity and ability to increase interfacial polarization. Still, their mixing is challenging due to weak interfacial interactions and poor dispersibility of MXenes in PVDF. This work explores a novel method for delaminating Ti3C2Tx MXene directly into organic solvents while maintaining flake size and quality, as well as the use of a non‚Äêsolvent‚Äêinduced phase separation method for producing both dense and porous PVDF‚ÄêMXene composite films. A deeper understanding of dielectric behavior in these composites is reached by examining MXenes with both mixed and pure chlorine terminations in PVDF matrices. Thin‚Äêfilm capacitors fabricated from these composites display ultrahigh discharge energy density, exceeding 45 J cm‚àí3 with 95% efficiency. The PVDF‚ÄêMXene composites are also processed using a green and sustainable solvent, propylene carbonate.

item.title: Glucose‚ÄêActivated Programmed Hydrogel with Self‚ÄêSwitchable Enzyme‚ÄêLike Activity for Infected Diabetic Wound Self‚ÄêAdaptive Treatment
item.content:encoded:
The self‚Äêswitching enzyme‚Äêlike activity of the hydrogel activated by the hyperglycemia environment induces the opening of the hypoxia‚Äêsensitive microcapsules, regulates the dynamic stability of blood glucose through intelligent insulin delivery. The hydrogel dynamically regulates reactive oxygen species (ROS) through self‚Äêswitching enzyme‚Äêlike activity, produces ROS through peroxidase‚Äêlike activity to achieve antibacterial, and promotes infected diabetic wound healing by converting ROS to release oxygen.
Abstract The defective blood glucose regulation ability of diabetic patients leading to bacterial infection, cellular oxidative stress, and vascular damage results in delayed healing of chronic diabetic wounds. Here, a glucose‚Äêactivated self‚Äêswitching enzyme‚Äêlike activity programmed hydrogel is proposed to provide self‚Äêregulated timely intelligent insulin release affected by blood glucose fluctuations, thereby forming feedback blood glucose management and exerting a full‚Äêstage wound healing. The hydrogel is composed of Au‚îÄMoS2‚îÄphenylboronic acid nanozyme and insulin‚Äêloaded nitroimidazole‚Äêmodified sodium alginate hypoxia‚Äêsensitive microcapsules and penylboronic‚Äêacid‚Äêmodified chitosan. It utilizes glucose as a sacrificial agent to generate antibacterial reactive oxygen species by recognizing the hyperglycemia environment, and releasing insulin for blood glucose regulation for up to 12 h with the help of the enzyme‚Äêlike catalysis‚Äêgenerated hypoxia environment. In a normoglycemia environment, the hydrogel switches the enzyme‚Äêlike activity to supply oxygen, inhibiting further insulin release. The hydrogel achieves ‚âà3 times the wound recovery rate of commercial dressings through blood glucose regulation and improved wound microenvironment. The hydrogel has been proven to significantly improve the healing of chronic diabetic wounds by regulating the body's blood glucose homeostasis and implementing a staged healing treatment plan, providing a powerful solution for diabetic wound care.

item.title: Deep‚ÄêBlue OLEDs with BT. 2020 Blue Gamut, External Quantum Efficiency Approaching 40%
item.content:encoded:
TADF sensitizers targeting deep‚Äêblue emitters are designed by combining the advantages of short‚Äêrange and long‚Äêrange charge‚Äêtransfer excited states. The resulting sensitizers enable high‚Äêperformance deep‚Äêblue OLEDs with BT. 2020 blue gamut together with external quantum efficiency approaching 40%.
Abstract The hyperfluorescence (HF) technology holds great promise for the development of high‚Äêquality organic light‚Äêemitting diodes (OLEDs) for their excellent color purity, high efficiency, and low‚Äêefficiency roll‚Äêoff. Sensitizer plays a crucial role in the performance of HF devices. However, designing sensitizers with simultaneous high photoluminescence quantum yield (PLQY), rapid radiative decay (kr), and fast reverse intersystem crossing rate (kRISC) poses a great challenge, particularly for the thermally activated delayed fluorescence (TADF) sensitizers targeting deep‚Äêblue HF device. Herein, by introducing a boron‚Äêcontaining multi‚Äêresonance‚Äêtype acceptor into the multi‚Äêtert‚Äêbutyl‚Äêcarbazole encapsulated benzene molecular skeleton, two TADF emitters featuring hybridized multi‚Äêchannel charge‚Äêtransfer pathways, including short‚Äêrange multi‚Äêresonance, weakened through‚Äêbond, and compact face‚Äêto‚Äêface through‚Äêspace charge‚Äêtransfer. Benefiting from the rational molecular design, the proof‚Äêof‚Äêconcept sensitizers exhibit simultaneous rapid kr of 5.3 √ó 107 s‚àí1, fast kRISC up to 5.9 √ó 105 s‚àí1, a PQLY of near‚Äêunity, as well as ideal deep‚Äêblue emission in both solution and film. Consequently, the corresponding deep‚Äêblue HF devices not only achieve chromaticity coordinates that fully comply with the latest BT. 2020 standards, but also showcase record‚Äêhigh maximum external quantum efficiencies nearing 40%, along with suppressed efficiency roll‚Äêoff.

item.title: Control Over Metal‚ÄêHalide Reactivity Enables Uniform Growth of InSb Colloidal Quantum Dots for Enhanced SWIR Light Detection
item.content:encoded:
In this work, it is demonstrated that controlling metal halide precursors' reactivity with organic additives during nucleation and growth enables the synthesis of InSb CQDs with narrow size distributions. Alkanethiol resurfacing facilitates efficient ligand exchange and integration into n‚Äêi‚Äêp photodiodes, exhibiting 10¬π2 Jones detectivity, 33% EQE at 1380 nm, and >19 h of operational stability.
Abstract InSb¬†colloidal quantum dots (CQDs) hold promise in short‚Äêwave infrared¬†sensing; however, their synthesis presents ongoing challenges, particularly in achieving precise size control ‚Äì this is the result of poorly controlled reactivity among the precursors. Herein, the use of alkyl‚Äêphosphine and amine‚Äêbased organic additives to control the reactivity of In and Sb precursors during the nucleation and growth of CQDs is developed. This interplay between organic additive and precursors enables the synthesis of InSb CQDs having narrowed size distributions; and bandgaps tunable across the 1.2‚Äì1.5¬†¬µm spectral range; all this leading to peak‚Äêto‚Äêvalley ratios >1.4 in absorption spectra. The CQDs are surface‚Äêterminated with a mixture of oleylamine, halides, and oxide‚Äêlike species, and this hinders ligand exchange reactions and subsequent integration into photodiodes. We therefore resurface the CQDs with alkanethiols, displacing the native ligands via an acid‚Äêbase mechanism, an approach that removes oxide species. Using a layer‚Äêby‚Äêlayer fabrication process, the ligands of the resurfaced InSb CQDs are exchanged with short organic and halide ligands and incorporated films into n‚Äêi‚Äêp photodiode structures. The resultant devices exhibit a detectivity of 10¬π2 Jones, an external quantum efficiency (EQE) of 33% at 1380¬†nm, and T90 operating stability of >19 h under continuous illuminated operation.

item.title: Integrating PtCo Intermetallic with Highly Graphitized Carbon Toward Durable Oxygen Electroreduction in Proton Exchange Membrane Fuel Cells
item.content:encoded:
By virtue of the tailor‚Äêmade Pt electronic configuration and excellently corrosion‚Äêresistant carbon support, the O‚ÄêPtCo@GCoNC integrating PtCo intermetallic with a Pt‚Äêrich shell and highly graphitized carbon exhibits significantly enhanced ORR activity and stability, attaining outstanding performance in H2/air PEMFC, outstripping the United States Department of Energy 2025 target.
Abstract Exploiting robust and high‚Äêefficiency electrocatalysts for sluggish oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) is essential for proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs) toward long‚Äêterm operation for practical applications, yet remains challenging. Herein, the ordered PtCo intermetallic is reported with a Pt‚Äêrich shell loaded on a highly graphitized carbon carrier (O‚ÄêPtCo@GCoNC) prepared by an impregnation annealing strategy. Systematic X‚Äêray spectroscopic, operando electrochemical techniques and theoretical calculations reveal that thanks to the synergistic interaction of the core‚Äìshell PtCo intermetallic structure with a tailor‚Äêmade Pt electronic configuration and highly graphitized carbon, O‚ÄêPtCo@GCoNC exhibits significantly enhanced activity and stability toward ORR. Crucially, O‚ÄêPtCo@GCoNC delivers a much‚Äêenhanced mass activity of 0.83 A mgPt‚àí1 at 0.9 V versus reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) in 0.1 m HClO4, which only drops by 26.5% after 70¬†000 cycles (0.6‚Äì1.0 V vs RHE), and 10.8% after 10¬†000 cycles (1.0‚Äì1.5 V vs RHE), apparently overmatching Pt/C (0.19 A mgPt‚àí1, 73.7%, and 63.1%). Moreover, O‚ÄêPtCo@GCoNC employed as the cathode catalyst in H2/air PEMFC achieves a superb peak power density (1.04 W cm‚àí2 at 2.06 A cm‚àí2), outperforming that of Pt/C (0.86 W cm‚àí2 at 1.79 A cm‚àí2). The cell voltage loss at 0.8 A cm‚àí2 is 28 mV after 30¬†000 cycles, outstripping the United States Department of Energy¬†2025 target.

item.title: Leveraging Optical Anisotropy of the Morpho Butterfly Wing for Quantitative, Stain‚ÄêFree, and Contact‚ÄêFree Assessment of Biological Tissue Microstructures
item.content:encoded:
We leverage the intrinsic optical anisotropy of the Morpho butterfly wing to introduce Morpho‚ÄêEnhanced Polarized Light Microscopy (MorE‚ÄêPoL), a stain‚Äê and contact‚Äêfree imaging methodology that quantitatively assesses the microstructural properties of fibrous biological tissues. We demonstrate the potential of MorE‚ÄêPoL with patient‚Äêderived xenograft breast cancer tissues, where we quantify the density and organization of fibrillar collagen in the tumor microenvironment.
Abstract Changes in the density and organization of fibrous biological tissues often accompany the progression of serious diseases ranging from fibrosis to neurodegenerative diseases, heart disease and cancer. However, challenges in cost, complexity, or precision faced by existing imaging methodologies and materials pose barriers to elucidating the role of tissue microstructure in disease. Here, we leverage the intrinsic optical anisotropy of the Morpho butterfly wing and introduce Morpho‚ÄêEnhanced Polarized Light Microscopy (MorE‚ÄêPoL), a stain‚Äê and contact‚Äêfree imaging platform that enhances and quantifies the birefringent material properties of fibrous biological tissues. We develop a mathematical model, based on Jones calculus, which describes fibrous tissue density and organization. As a representative example, we analyzed collagen‚Äêdense and collagen‚Äêsparse human breast cancer tissue sections and leverage our technique to assess the microstructural properties of distinct regions of interest. We compare our results with conventional Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) staining procedures and second harmonic generation (SHG) microscopy for fibrillar collagen detection. Our findings demonstrate that our MorE‚ÄêPoL technique provides a robust, quantitative, and accessible route toward analyzing biological tissue microstructures, with great potential for application to a broad range of biological materials.

item.title: Stress Release of Single Crystal Arrays Bridged by SAM Interface Toward Highly Mechanically Durable Flexible Perovskite NIR Photodetector
item.content:encoded:
A universal strategy to enhance the performance and mechanical stability of flexible perovskite near‚Äêinfrared (NIR) photodetector arrays is demonstrated through a combination of self‚Äêassembled monolayer (SAM) bridging interface and stress release of nano‚Äêarray structure, presenting the maximum response wavelength of 1050¬†nm, a responsivity of 1.66 A W‚àí1, detectivity of 6.19 √ó 1012 Jones, high fidelity imaging, and extra‚Äêlong environmental stability.
Abstract Perovskite photodetectors with superior optoelectronic properties, lightweight, and compatibility with flexible substrates have attracted much attention in wearable electronics. However, the large bandgap, inherent brittleness, poor environmental stability, and weak interfacial adhesion interaction between perovskites and substrates hinder the application of near‚Äêinfrared (NIR) wearable devices. Herein, a universal strategy to enhance the performance and mechanical stability of flexible perovskite NIR photodetector arrays is demonstrated through a combination of mussel‚Äêinspired self‚Äêassembled monolayer (SAM) bridging interface and precise modulation of the nano‚Äêarray size, which enables to significantly increase interfacial adhesion, crystallinity, crystallographic orientation, and reduce mechanical stresses of perovskite single‚Äêcrystal arrays. Moreover, inserting paddle‚Äêwheel metal‚Äìorganic cluster ligands lead to an unprecedented small bandgap of 1.04¬†eV, enhanced lattice rigidity, and environmental stability for 2D perovskite. The flexible perovskite NIR photodetector arrays with superior mechanical robustness and record NIR performance are revealed with a maximum response wavelength of 1050¬†nm, a responsivity of 1.66 A W‚àí1, detectivity of 6.19 √ó 1012 Jones, high fidelity imaging, and extra‚Äêlong environmental stability. This work pioneers a new insight into the integration of high‚Äêperformance and mechanically durable perovskite flexible wearable devices.

item.title: Tumor‚ÄêTargeted Glutamine Metabolism Blocker Synergizes with TiO2‚ÄêAu Janus Nanoparticles for Enhanced Sono‚ÄêMetabolic Antitumor Therapy
item.content:encoded:
Sono‚Äêmetabolic nano‚Äêcomposites (TiO2‚ÄêAu@DON) produce huge amounts of ROS (type I and type II) under ultrasound irradiation, effectively inducing immunogenic cell death via TiO2‚ÄêAu‚Äêinduced‚ÄêSDT phenomena. The released DON disrupts NADPH and tumor redox homeostasis by reprogramming metabolic pathways while it intensifies the activities of immune cells. This metabolic disruption amplifies SDT‚Äêmediated oxidative stress, offering a precise combination of SDT and immunotherapy.
Abstract Sonodynamic therapy (SDT) is a promising therapeutic modality known for its non‚Äêinvasiveness, temporal‚Äêspatial controllability, and deeper tissue penetration. However, the SDT treatment efficacy is still hampered by the scarcity of ideal sonosensitizers and complex tumor microenvironment (TME). To address these challenges, a sono‚Äêmetabolic nano‚Äêcomposite (TiO2‚ÄêAu@DON) using the metabolic reprogramming prodrugs of 6‚ÄêDiazo‚Äê5‚Äêoxo‚Äêl‚Äênorleucine (DON) grafted on TiO2‚ÄêAu Janus nanoparticles (NPs) is fabricated. The coupling of TiO2 and gold in the TiO2‚ÄêAu@DON effectively prevents the fast recombination of excited electrons and holes under ultrasound irradiation. The result is the generation of higher levels of both type I and II reactive oxygen species (ROS) compared to pure TiO2, which helps overcome the limitations of SDT in the hypoxic TME. Furthermore, the TiO2‚ÄêAu Janus NPs act as nano‚Äêcarriers, delivering DON prodrugs to the tumor site. The released DON can disrupt nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate hydrogen (NADPH) and tumor redox homeostasis by reprogramming the metabolic pathways while it intensifies the activities of immune cells. This metabolic disruption amplifies SDT‚Äêmediated oxidative stress, resulting in the increase of tumor sensitivity to ROS through TiO2‚ÄêAu@DON‚Äêintegrated synergistic effects of SDT and glutamine reprogramming strategies. This increased sensitivity ultimately induces robust immunogenic cell death (ICD), enhancing antitumor therapeutic efficacy and remodeling the tumor's immunosuppressive microenvironment.

item.title: Emerging Materials and Computing Paradigms for Temporal Signal Analysis
item.content:encoded:
Efficient and robust temporal signal analysis is crucial for diverse fields, including medicine, finance, and telecommunications. Traditional techniques struggle with efficiency issues when handling complex temporal signals, primarily due to hardware and architectural limitations. This perspective explores the methods, features, applications, and potential of emerging materials and computing paradigms in temporal signal analysis.
Abstract In the era of relentless data generation and dynamic information streams, the demand for efficient and robust temporal signal analysis has intensified across diverse domains such as healthcare, finance, and telecommunications. This perspective study explores the unfolding landscape of emerging materials and computing paradigms that are reshaping the way temporal signals are analyzed and interpreted. Traditional signal processing techniques often fall short when confronted with the intricacies of time‚Äêvarying data, prompting the exploration of innovative approaches. The rise of emerging materials and devices empowers real‚Äêtime analysis by processing temporal signals in situ, mitigating latency concerns. Through this perspective, the untapped potential of emerging materials and computing paradigms for temporal signal analysis is highlighted, offering valuable insights into both challenges and opportunities. Standing on the cusp of a new era in computing, understanding and harnessing these paradigms is pivotal for unraveling the complexities embedded within the temporal dimensions of data, propelling signal analysis into realms previously deemed¬†inaccessible.

item.title: Ultraviolet Optoelectronic Synapse Based on AlScN/p‚Äêi‚Äên GaN Heterojunction for Advanced Artificial Vision Systems
item.content:encoded:
Researchers have developed a two‚Äêterminal AlScN/p‚Äêi‚Äên GaN heterojunction ferroelectric memristor with ultraviolet photoelectric synapse function, enabling nonvolatile memory and optoelectronic synaptic characteristics. This innovation achieves a high memory on/off ratio and a relatively low synaptic energy consumption, advancing optoelectronics and artificial vision systems with potential applications in on‚Äêchip sensing and computing.
Abstract Ferroelectric materials represent a frontier in semiconductor research, offering the potential for novel optoelectronics. AlScN material is a kind of outstanding ferroelectric semiconductor with strong residual polarization, high Curie temperature, and mainstream semiconductor fabrication compatibility. However, it is challenging to realize multi‚Äêstate optical responders due to their limited light sensitivity. Here, a two‚Äêterminal AlScN/p‚Äêi‚Äên GaN heterojunction ultraviolet optoelectronic synapse is fabricated, overcoming this limitation by leveraging hole capture at the AlScN/p‚ÄêGaN hetero‚Äêinterface for multi‚Äêstate modulation. The novel structure maintains excellent memristor characteristics based on the ferroelectric of AlScN, realizing an on/off ratio of 9.36¬†√ó¬†105. More importantly, the device can mimic synaptic characteristics essential for artificial vision systems, achieving an image recognition accuracy of 93.7% with a weight evolution nonlinearity of 0.26. This approach not only extends the applications of AlScN in optoelectronics but also paves the way for advanced artificial vision systems with image preprocessing and recognition capabilities. The findings provide a step forward in the development of non‚Äêvolatile memories with potential for on‚Äêchip sensing and computing.

item.title: Lignin‚ÄêBased Separators for Lithium‚ÄêIon Batteries via a Dry Fibrillation Method
item.content:encoded:
Can lignin revolutionize lithium‚Äêion battery separators? A single‚Äêlayer lignin‚Äêbased ultrathin separator (as thin as 15¬†¬µm) is fabricated using a dry fibrillation method, enabling exceptional thermal stability, low energy consumption, and full material utilization. Sulfonate functional groups enhance interfacial stability, significantly improving cycling in graphite||NMC811 and Si‚ÄêGr||NMC811 cells. This scalable, sustainable approach paves the way for next‚Äêgeneration functional separators.
Abstract Separators are critical components in lithium‚Äêion batteries (LIBs), preventing internal short circuits, mitigating thermal runaway, and influencing rate capability and cycling performance. However, current polyolefin separators suffer from limitations, such as high thermal shrinkage, relatively poor wettability, and inadequate long‚Äêterm stability, impacting safety and cycle life in critical applications like electric vehicles. Here, a single‚Äêlayer lignin‚Äêbased ultrathin separator (as thin as 15¬†¬µm) with exceptional intrinsic thermal stability and cycling performance is demonstrated. The separator is fabricated using lignosulfonate, a natural polymer derived as a byproduct of chemical pulping and biorefinery processes. By employing a dry fibrillation method, the process achieves low energy consumption and a 100% raw material conversion rate, highlighting its scalability and sustainability. Interfacial studies reveal the improved cycling performance in both graphite||NMC811 and Si‚ÄêGr||NMC811 cells is attributed to the abundant sulfonate functional groups in lignosulfonates, which promote the formation of a sulfur‚Äêrich cathode/solid electrolyte interphases (CEI/SEI) with low resistance in both the cathode and anode. The high thermal stability, manufacturing feasibility, battery performance, and low cost of such lignin‚Äêbased separators offer new inspiration for developing next‚Äêgeneration, single‚Äêlayer functional separators tailored for high‚Äêperformance LIBs.

item.title: Implanted Magnetoelectric Bionic Cartilage Hydrogel
item.content:encoded:
VAFe bionic cartilage hydrogel with a double‚Äênetwork semi‚Äêcrosslinked chain entanglement structure and motion‚Äêdriven magnetoelectric‚Äêcoupled cyclic transformation effect shows the high water content, a porous structure, good mechanical properties, and the electromagnetic effect of the bionic cartilage, which provides a functional compensation and a suitable induced environment for the defective cartilage repair.
Abstract Enhancing defective cartilage repair by creating a bionic cartilage hydrogel supplemented with in situ electromagnetic stimulation, replicating endogenous electromagnetic effects, remains challenging. To achieve this, a unique three‚Äêphase solvent system is designed to prepare a magnetoelectric bionic cartilage hydrogel incorporating piezoelectric poly(3‚Äêhydroxybutyric acid‚Äê3‚Äêhydroxyvaleric acid) (PHBV) and magnetostrictive triiron tetraoxide nanoparticles (Fe3O4 NPs) into sodium alginate (SA) hydrogel to form a dual‚Äênetwork, semi‚Äêcrosslinked chain entanglement structure. The synthesized hydrogel features similar composition, structure, and mechanical properties to natural cartilage. In addition, after the implantation of cartilage, the motion‚Äêdriven magnetoelectric‚Äêcoupled cyclic transformation model is triggered by gentle joint forces, initiating a piezoelectric response that leads to magnetoelectric‚Äêcoupled cyclic transformation. The freely excitable and cyclically enhanced electromagnetic stimulation it can provide, by simulating and amplifying endogenous electromagnetic effects, obtains induced defective cartilage repair efficacy superior to piezoelectric or magnetic stimulation alone.

item.title: Strategic Development of Memristors for Neuromorphic Systems: Low‚ÄêPower and Reconfigurable Operation
item.content:encoded:
This review investigates technological trends in brain‚Äêinspired artificial reconfigurable memristors, as well as individual non‚Äêvolatile and volatile devices, according to their operating principles and fabrication methods. It examines case studies of artificial neural network system implementations based on these devices, providing the latest comprehensive design guidelines from fundamentals to advanced systems.
Abstract The ongoing global energy crisis has heightened the demand for low‚Äêpower electronic devices, driving interest in neuromorphic computing inspired by the parallel processing of human brains and energy efficiency. Reconfigurable memristors, which integrate both volatile and non‚Äêvolatile behaviors within a single unit, offer a powerful solution for in‚Äêmemory computing, addressing the von Neumann bottleneck that limits conventional computing architectures. These versatile devices combine the high density, low power consumption, and adaptability of memristors, positioning them as superior alternatives to traditional complementary metal‚Äêoxide‚Äêsemiconductor (CMOS) technology for emulating brain‚Äêlike functions. Despite their potential, studies on reconfigurable memristors remain sparse and are often limited to specific materials such as Mott insulators without fully addressing their unique reconfigurability. This review specifically focuses on reconfigurable memristors, examining their dual‚Äêmode operation, diverse physical mechanisms, structural designs, material properties, switching behaviors, and neuromorphic applications. It highlights the recent advancements in low‚Äêpower‚Äêconsumption solutions within memristor‚Äêbased neural networks and critically evaluates the challenges in deploying reconfigurable memristors as standalone devices or within artificial neural systems. The review provides in‚Äêdepth technical insights and quantitative benchmarks to guide the future development and implementation of reconfigurable memristors in low‚Äêpower neuromorphic computing.

item.title: Co‚ÄêEnriched High Entropy Oxides for Efficient Continuous Electrochemical Methane Conversion: Catalytic Performance and Sustainability Insights
item.content:encoded:
A Co‚Äêrich high‚Äêentropy oxide (HEO) catalyst enables efficient electrochemical methane‚Äêto‚Äêethanol conversion at room temperature. By leveraging elemental enrichment, the catalyst achieves high selectivity and stability, outperforming conventional systems. Process modeling further highlights its economic viability and significant potential for reducing carbon emissions.
Abstract The electrochemical conversion of methane offers a sustainable alternative to traditional thermochemical syngas pathways; however, the rational design of catalysts that ensure high productivity remains a significant challenge. In this study, a high‚Äêentropy oxide (HEO) catalyst composed of Co, Cr, Fe, Mn, and Ni is explored, with a targeted element enriched, and identify that a Co‚Äêrich HEO demonstrates high efficiency in room‚Äêtemperature electrochemical methane conversion. This analysis of the projected density of states (PDOS) reveals that Co sites in the HEO catalyst possess an optimally positioned p‚Äêband center for methane activation. The Co‚Äêrich HEO catalyst achieves an ethanol production rate of 12315¬†¬µmol/gcat/hr at 1.6 VRHE, with a Faradaic efficiency of 63.5%; a flow cell electrolyzer equipped with this catalyst achieves continuous methane‚Äêto‚Äêethanol conversion at a rate of 26533¬†¬µmol/gcat/hr over 100 h. Process modeling evaluates the economic and environmental implications, demonstrating that a commercially viable process can be realized through economies of scale while significantly reducing CO‚ÇÇ emissions.

item.title: Establishing Nanoscale Circuitry by Designing a Structure with Atomic Short‚Äêrange Order for High‚ÄêRate Energy Storage
item.content:encoded:
A microsized perovskite oxide Ce0.266W0.1Nb0.9O3 is engineered as an anode material for high‚Äêrate, long‚Äêlife Li+ storage, demonstrating impressive performance by maintaining both high areal capacity and high rate capability, even at high mass loadings. This outstanding electrochemical behavior is primarily attributed to the nanoscale circuitry formed by an atomic‚Äêscale short‚Äêrange order structure.
Abstract High‚Äêrate materials necessitate the rapid transportation of both electrons and ions, a requirement that becomes especially challenging at practical mass loadings (>10 mg cm2). To address this challenge, a material is designed with an architecture having atomic‚Äêscale short‚Äêrange order. This design establishes internal nanoscale circuitry at the particle level, which facilitates rapid electronic and ionic transport within micrometer‚Äêsized niobium tungsten oxides. The architecture features alternating cerium‚Äêdepleted and cerium‚Äêenriched regions. The continuous cerium‚Äêenriched regions with enhanced conductivity provide multilane highways for electron mobility by functioning as electron‚Äêconducting wires that significantly boost the overall conductivity. The cerium‚Äêdepleted regions effectively mitigate electrostatic repulsion and promote rapid ion transport through ion‚Äêconducting channels. These structural characteristics provide a continuous network that supports both electrical migration and chemical diffusion to amplify the areal capacity and rate capability even at high mass loadings. These findings not only expand the fundamental understanding of the design of optimal host lattices for advanced energy storage systems but also of the practical application of microsized high‚Äêrate electrode materials.

item.title: Efficient Photoelectrocatalytic Synthesis of Ammonia by Superionic Conductor with Mixed Ion/Electron Conduction
item.content:encoded:
A van der Waals FePS2.66Li0.87 superionic conductor (SIC) with enhanced mixed electronic/ionic conductivity is applied for solar‚Äêdriven nitrate conversion to ammonia. The migration of mobile lithium ions between layers significantly promotes the electronic conductivity of FePS2.66Li0.87 SIC, which achieves a remarkable ammonia synthesis yield (134.18¬†¬µmol cm‚àí2¬†h‚àí1) under low bias voltage.
Abstract Photoelectrochemical (PEC) nitrate reduction shows substantial potential for solar‚Äêto‚Äêammonia (NH3) conversion. However, low electron density and disordered electron conduction of conventional catalysts result in limited performance and low Faraday efficiency. Herein, a FePS2.66Li0.87 superionic conductor (SIC) is developed by introducing lithium ions into van der Waals immobile layered of FePS3 catalyst. This layered crystal framework facilitates high‚Äêconcentration lithium ions confinement and long‚Äêrange diffusion at room temperature, transitioning the conduction mechanism from electronic to mixed ionic/electronic. The typical nanofluidic ion transport leads to a high ionic conductivity of 16.4 mS cm‚àí1 at room temperature and enhanced electronic conductivity of 5 √ó 10‚àí6 S cm‚àí1. Furthermore, mobile lithium ions within interlayers enhance the interaction between the low‚Äêlying 3dyz orbitals of Fe interacting with 2a2 empty antibonding orbitals of NO3‚àí. An excellent PEC ammonia production of 134.18¬†¬µmol cm‚àí2¬†h‚àí1 with 96.95% Faradaic efficiency is achieved, and the corresponding solar‚Äêto‚ÄêNH3 efficiency of 57.13% offers a promising pathway toward sustainable ammonia production.

item.title: Critical Roles of Ultrafast Energy Funnelling and Ultrafast Singlet‚ÄêTriplet Annihilation in Quasi‚Äê2D Perovskite Optical Gain Mechanisms
item.content:encoded:
Ultrafast broadband photoluminescence spectroscopy provides insights into the lasing dynamics, energy transfer, and singlet‚Äêtriplet annihilation in mixed‚Äêlayer quasi‚Äê2D perovskites. Rapid energy funnelling to the sites of amplified spontaneous emission occurs within sub‚Äêpicosecond timescales. However, the accumulation of triplet excitons effectively quenches incoming singlet excitons, creating a bottleneck in the energy cascade and hindering the development of population inversion.
Abstract Quasi‚Äê2D (Q2D) perovskite possess considerable potential for light emission and amplification technologies. Recently, mixed films containing Q2D perovskite grains with varying layer thicknesses have shown great promise as carrier concentrators, effectively mitigating trap‚Äêmediated recombination. In this strategy, photo‚Äêexcitations are rapidly funnelled down an energy gradient to the thickest grains, leading to amplified spontaneous emission (ASE). However, the quantum‚Äêconfined Q2D slabs also stabilize the formation of unwanted triplet excitons, resulting in parasitic quenching of emissive singlet states. Here, a novel ultrafast photoluminescence spectroscopy is used to study photoexcitation dynamics in mixed‚Äêlayer Q2D perovskites. By analysing spectra with high temporal and energy resolution, this is found that sub‚Äêpicosecond energy transfer to ASE sites is accompanied by excitation losses due to triplet formation on grains with small and intermediate thicknesses. Further accumulation of triplets creates a bottleneck in the energy cascade, effectively quenching incoming singlet excitons. This ultrafast annihilation within 200 femtosecond outpaces energy transfer to ASE sites, preventing the build‚Äêup of population inversion. This study highlights the significance of investigating photoexcitation dynamics on ultrafast timescales, encompassing lasing dynamics, energy transfer, and singlet‚Äêtriplet annihilation, to gain crucial insights into the photophysics of the optical gain process in Q2D perovskites.

item.title: Hierarchically Structured Porous Polyamide‚ÄêImide Membrane for Switchable Emulsion Separation
item.content:encoded:
A novel amphiphilic polymer Torlon‚Äêbased membrane with switchable superwettability is developed using a simple one‚Äêstep phase separation method. Its hierarchical porous structure and surface reorganization enable exceptional oil‚Äêwater separation with ultrahigh permeance and efficiency. The membrane exhibits excellent antifouling, self‚Äêcleaning, and durability, offering a scalable solution for advanced oily wastewater treatment and beyond.
Abstract The development of advanced membranes with switchable superwettability has attracted considerable attention for the efficient treatment of oily wastewater. However, challenges persist in designing and fabricating such membranes through straightforward methods. In this study, a novel strategy is presented to design switchable superwettable membranes based on micro/nano‚Äêstructured porous surfaces and surface chemical composition reorganization. A commercial amphiphilic polymer, polyamide‚Äêimide (Torlon), is fabricated into a porous symmetric membrane with a hierarchical surface structure using a one‚Äêstep non‚Äêsolvent‚Äêinduced phase separation method. By leveraging the surface reorganization capability of amphiphilic polymers and the hierarchically porous structure, the resulting membranes demonstrate exceptional superamphiphilicity in air, underwater superoleophobicity, and underoil superhydrophobicity. These properties enable ultrahigh permeance and separation efficiency for oil‚Äêin‚Äêwater, water‚Äêin‚Äêoil, and crude oil/water emulsions through a gravity‚Äêdriven process, eliminating the need for external energy. Furthermore, the membranes exhibit excellent antifouling and self‚Äêcleaning performance, maintaining stable operation over multiple cycles. This work provides an innovative and scalable approach to next‚Äêgeneration switchable superwettable membranes with broad potential applications in oily wastewater treatment and beyond.

item.title: Smart Dust for Chemical Mapping
item.content:encoded:
This review article explores the advancement of smart dust networks for high‚Äêresolution spatial and temporal chemical mapping. Comprising miniature, wireless sensors, and communication devices, smart dust autonomously collects, processes, and transmits data via swarm‚Äêbased communication. With applications in environmental monitoring, healthcare, agriculture, and industry, it emphasizes energy efficiency, sustainability, and large‚Äêscale deployment to revolutionize chemical analysis in complex environments.
Abstract This review article explores the transformative potential of smart dust systems by examining how existing chemical sensing technologies can be adapted and advanced to realize their full capabilities. Smart dust, characterized by submillimeter‚Äêscale autonomous sensing platforms, offers unparalleled opportunities for real‚Äêtime, spatiotemporal chemical mapping across diverse environments. This article introduces the technological advancements underpinning these systems, critically evaluates current limitations, and outlines new avenues for development. Key challenges, including multi‚Äêcompound detection, system control, environmental impact, and cost, are discussed alongside potential solutions. By leveraging innovations in miniaturization, wireless communication, AI‚Äêdriven data analysis, and sustainable materials, this review highlights the promise of smart dust to address critical challenges in environmental monitoring, healthcare, agriculture, and defense sectors. Through this lens, the article provides a strategic roadmap for advancing smart dust from concept to practical application, emphasizing its role in transforming the understanding and management of complex chemical systems.

item.title: A Multifunctional Binder for Current‚ÄêCollector‚ÄêFree Zn Powder Anodes
item.content:encoded:
By introducing abundant polar groups as Zn2+ absorption sites and hydrogen bond arrays, a protein structure‚Äêderived binder for ZP anode and iodine cathode is proposed. This design can regulate the Zn2+ flux, benefit the formation of free‚Äêstanding electrode, inhibit the side reactions, suppress the shuttle effect of polyiodides, and enable the large‚Äêscale potentials.
Abstract Compared with commonly used Zn foil anodes, Zn powder (ZP) anodes offer superior versatility and processability. However, in aqueous electrolytes, dendrite growth and side reactions, such as corrosion and hydrogen evolution, become more severe in ZP anodes than those in Zn foil anodes because of the rough surfaces and high surface areas of ZP, leading to poor reversibility and limitations in high‚Äêloading mass cathodes. In this study, a diisocyanate‚Äêpolytetrahydrofuran‚Äêdihydrazide polymer (DDP) binder is developed, inspired by protein structures. The strong Zn2+ adsorption capability of the binder effectively regulates Zn2+ flux, while its unique hydrogen‚Äêbond arrays facilitate the formation of a free‚Äêstanding ZP anode and inhibit side reactions. The binder exhibits superior mechanical performance, providing ZP electrodes with excellent resistance to various mechanical stresses, including tensile, nanoindentation, scratch, and dynamic bending tests. ZP symmetric cells achieve stable cycling at capacities of 2 and 5 mAh cm‚àí2. In addition, DDP functions as an iodine cathode, effectively mitigating the polyiodide shuttle effect. The fabricated ZP/DDP||I2/DDP full cells demonstrate an excellent rate capability and cycling stability, even under a high‚Äêloading conditions. This study presents a novel approach for preparing stable ZP anodes and iodine cathodes, offering a promising strategy for large‚Äêscale applications.

item.title: 2D Rhodium‚ÄêIsocyanide Frameworks
item.content:encoded:
Rhodium‚Äêcarbon coordination‚Äêbased 2D metal‚Äêorganic frameworks are rationally synthesized and exhibit ultra‚Äênarrow bandgaps (0.10‚Äì0.28¬†eV) and intrinsic charge mobilities up to 560 ¬±¬†46 cm2‚ÄâV‚àí1‚Äâs‚àí1 via time‚Äêresolved terahertz spectroscopy.
Abstract 2D metal‚Äêorganic frameworks (2D MOFs) are emerging organic van der Waals materials with great potential in various applications owing to their structural diversity, and tunable optoelectronic properties. So far, most reported 2D MOFs rely on metal‚Äêheteroatom coordination (e.g., metal‚Äìnitrogen, metal‚Äìoxygen, and metal‚Äìsulfur); synthesis of metal‚Äêcarbon coordination based 2D MOFs remains a formidable challenge. This study reports the rhodium‚Äìcarbon (Rh‚ÄìC) coordination‚Äêbased 2D MOFs, using isocyanide as the ligand and Rh(I) as metal node. The synthesized MOFs show excellent crystallinity with quasi‚Äêsquare lattice networks. These MOFs show ultra‚Äênarrow bandgaps (0.1‚Äì0.28¬†eV) resulting from the interaction between Rh(I) and isocyano groups. Terahertz spectroscopy demonstrates exceptional short‚Äêrange charge mobilities up to 560 ¬±¬†46 cm2‚ÄâV‚àí1‚Äâs‚àí1 in the as‚Äêsynthesized MOFs. Moreover, these MOFs are used as electrocatalysts for nitrogen reduction reaction and show an excellent NH3 yield rate of 56.0 ¬±¬†1.5¬†¬µg h‚àí1 mgcat‚àí1 and a record Faradaic efficiency of 87.1 ¬±¬†1.8%. In situ experiments reveal dual pathways involving Rh(I) during the catalytic process. This work represents a pioneering step toward 2D MOFs based on metal‚Äìcarbon coordination and paves the way for novel reticular materials with ultra‚Äêhigh carrier mobility and for versatile optoelectronic devices.

item.title: Universally Applicable and Ultra‚ÄêLong Life Cyclic Power Generation Induced by Interfacial Ion‚ÄêOscillation
item.content:encoded:
An electric power generating cell is developed based on potential difference driven reversible ion migration, which generates ultra‚Äêlong life electric output over 8‚Äêmonth with a high short‚Äêcircuit of over 40¬†mA and output power density of up to 6¬†W m‚àí2, surpassing the values reported for many other sorts of typical electricity generators.
Abstract Sustainable energy supply without relying on external power sources is one of the bottlenecks in achieving self‚Äêsupportive wearable electronics and Internet‚Äêof‚Äêthings (IoT) systems. Here a new type of universally applicable and ultra‚Äêlong life cyclic power generation is developed induced by interfacial redox reaction‚Äêmediated ion‚Äêoscillation, which can provide cycling electric energy in a self‚Äêcharging manner without extra pre‚Äêcharge. Based on asymmetric manganese dioxide and molybdenum disulfide electrode pairs, the proof‚Äêconcept electric potential difference power generating cell (EPDC) offers ultra‚Äêlong life electric output over 8‚Äêmonth testing period for tens of thousands of cycles. A layer‚Äêstacking EPDC unit supplies a high direct current of more than 40¬†mA and a power density of ‚âà6¬†W m‚àí2. Such recyclable power‚Äêgenerating process mainly relies on reversible ion migration at an asymmetric interface in response to relative variation of electric potentials. The universal applicability of EPDC is validated by a combination of diverse electrode pairs. Large‚Äêscale manufacture of EPDCs is achievable by industry‚Äêcompatible auto‚Äêblade coating technology with on‚Äêdemand power output, providing a long‚Äêacting power supply platform for self‚Äêcharging electronic systems.

item.title: Bottom‚ÄêUp Selective Growth of Ultralong Organic Phosphorescence Nanocrystals with Optimized Crystal Forms for In Vivo Optical Imaging
item.content:encoded:
Ultralong organic phosphorescence (UOP) nanocrystals have attracted great attention in the field of in vivo optical imaging due to their ability to effectively minimize the interference of fluorescence background from biological tissues. In this work, a bottom‚Äêup strategy is proposed for preparing UOP nanocrystals with different crystal forms for in vivo biological imaging.
Abstract Ultralong organic phosphorescence (UOP) materials are valuable for biological imaging to avoid interference from fluorescence background signals because of their delayed emission property. Obtaining nanocrystals with high phosphorescence quantum yield is a critical factor to achieve high‚Äêquality UOP imaging. Herein, a pair of host‚Äìguest UOP doped system with variable crystal forms for the host is constructed. By exploring the relationship between the crystal form of the host and the UOP of the doped system, the importance of host crystal form is revealed to achieve high quantum yield UOP in doped systems. Furthermore, to overcome the low crystallinity and numerous defects faced by traditional bottom‚Äêup strategies for nanocrystal preparation, a strategy is proposed for the selective preparation of nanocrystals with the target crystal form. Through controlling the evaporation rate of the solvent, the ordered growth of crystals can be effectively regulated to obtain nanocrystals with different crystal forms for bioimaging applications.

item.title: Spontaneous Twist of Ferroelectric Smectic Blocks in Polar Fluids
item.content:encoded:
A chiral ground state of ferroelectric smectric is discovered which emerges in an achiral rod mesogen. This is not due to the torque‚Äêdriven effect on the surface. The research confirms that the polar smectric blocks are twisted despite its high elasticity. Such a structure is predominantly generated in molecules with larger dipole moments, smaller dipole angles, and smaller aspect ratios.
Abstract In soft matter, the polar orientational order of molecules can facilitate the coexistence of structural chirality and ferroelectricity. The ferroelectric nematic (NF) state, exhibited by achiral calamitic molecules with large dipole moments, serves as an ideal model for the emergence of spontaneous structural chirality. This chiral ground state arises from a left‚Äê or right‚Äêhanded twist of polarization due to depolarization effects. In contrast, the ferroelectric smectic state, characterized by a polar lamellar structure with lower symmetry, experiences significantly higher energy associated with layer‚Äêtwisting deformations and the formation of domain walls, thus avoiding a continuously twisted layered structure. In this study, two types of achiral molecules (BOE‚ÄêNO2 and DIOLT) are reported that possess different molecular structures but exhibit a NF‚Äìferroelectric smectic phase sequence. It is demonstrated that the chiral ground state of NF is inherited in the ferroelectric smectic phases of BOE‚ÄêNO2, which features larger dipole moments and a steric hindrance moiety, thereby triggering the formation of the twisted polar smectic blocks.

item.title: Molecular Stitching in Polysaccharide Precursor for Fabricating Hard Carbon with Ultra‚ÄêHigh Plateau Capacity of Sodium Storage
item.content:encoded:
This work opens the avenue to molecular‚Äêlevel modulation in organic precursors for developing high‚Äêperformance hard carbon in sodium‚Äêion batteries. The highly cross‚Äêlinked polymeric network in the precursor is constructed by unique molecular stitching strategy. The network evolves into highly twisted graphitic lattices with abundant¬†closed ultramicro‚Äêpores (<0.3 nm), thereby¬†enabling the storage of massive sodium clusters in hard carbon.
Abstract High energy density of sodium‚Äêion batteries (SIBs) requires high low‚Äêvoltage capacity and initial Coulombic efficiency for hard carbon. However, simultaneously achieving both characteristics is a substantial challenge. Herein, a unique molecular stitching strategy is proposed to edit the polymeric structure of common starch for synthesizing cost‚Äêeffective hard carbon (STHC‚ÄêMS). A mild air‚Äêheating treatment toward starch is employed to trigger the esterification reaction between carboxyl and hydroxy groups, which can effectively connect the branched polysaccharide chains thereby constructing a highly cross‚Äêlinked polymeric network. In contrast with the pristine branched‚Äêchain starch, the cross‚Äêlinking structured precursor evolves into highly twisted graphitic lattices creating a large population of closed ultramicro‚Äêpores (<0.3¬†nm) enabling the storage of massive sodium clusters. Resultantly, STHC‚ÄêMS delivers a reversible capacity of 348 mAh g‚àí1 with a remarkable low‚Äêvoltage (below 0.1¬†V) capacity of 294 mAh g‚àí1, which becomes more attractive by combining the high initial Coulombic efficiency of 93.3%. Moreover, STHC‚ÄêMS exhibits outstanding stability of 0.008% decay per cycle over 4800 cycles at 1 A g‚àí1. STHC‚ÄêMS||Na3V2(PO3)4 full cells achieve an energy density of 266¬†Wh kg‚àí1, largely surpassing the commercial hard carbon‚Äêbased counterpart. This work opens the avenue of molecular‚Äêlevel modulation in organic precursors for developing high‚Äêperformance hard carbon in SIBs.

item.title: Resolving Dynamic Behavior of Electrocatalysts via Advances of Operando X‚ÄêRay Absorption Spectroscopies: Potential Artifacts and Practical Guidelines
item.content:encoded:
Resolving dynamically fine structure of electrocatalysts is realized by advanced X‚Äêray spectroscopies. Based on a case study of operando X‚Äêray absorption spectroscopy at various beamlines, potential artifacts generated by X‚Äêray irradiation are validated and it is identified whether the dynamic behaviors are electrochemical reaction related. A practical protocol is proposed for conducting reliable¬†X‚Äêray spectroscopic measurements for accurate spectra interpretation.
Abstract Although numerous techniques are developed to enable real‚Äêtime understanding of dynamic interactions at the solid‚Äìliquid interface during electrochemical reactions, further progress in the development of these methods over the last several decades has faced challenges. With the rapid development of high‚Äêbrilliance synchrotron sources, operando X‚Äêray spectroscopies have become increasingly popular for revealing interfacial features and catalytic mechanisms in electrocatalysis. Nevertheless, the resulting spectra are highly sensitive to factors such as X‚Äêray radiation, reaction environment, and acquisition procedures, all of which may potentially introduce artifacts that are often overlooked, leading to misinterpretations of electrocatalytic behaviors. In this perspective, several emerging hard X‚Äêray spectroscopies used in electrocatalysis research are reviewed, highlighting their electronic transition processes, detection modes, and functional complementarity. Significantly, based on a case study of operando X‚Äêray absorption spectroscopy at various beamlines, potential artifacts generated by X‚Äêray irradiation are systematically investigated through photon‚Äêflux density‚Äê, dose‚Äê, and time‚Äêdependent studies of typical copper electrocatalysts. Accordingly, a practical protocol for conducting reliable X‚Äêray spectroscopic measurements in operando electrocatalytic studies to minimize potential artifacts that can affect the resulting X‚Äêray spectra, thereby ensuring accurate interpretation and a deeper understanding of interfacial interactions and electrocatalytic mechanisms, is established.

item.title: An n‚ÄêDoped Organic Cross‚ÄêLinked Electron Transport Layer with High Electrical Conductivity for High‚ÄêEfficiency Tandem Organic Photovoltaics
item.content:encoded:
An n‚Äêdoped ETL, that is c‚ÄêNDI‚ÄêBr:PEI with high electrical conductivity, strong work function modification ability and good solvent resistance, is developed via a simple in situ cross‚Äêlinking reaction. The tandem OPVs, with the all‚Äêsolution‚Äêprocessed organic/organic ICL (m‚ÄêPEDOT:PSS/c‚ÄêNDI‚ÄêBr:PEI) achieve 20.06% efficiency under solar radiation, and 38.50% efficiency under 808 nm laser. This study provides a new method to design high‚Äêperfoimance ICLs.
Abstract With merits of good solution processability, intrinsic flexibility, etc, organic/organic interconnecting layers (ICLs) are highly desirable for tandem organic photovoltaics (OPVs). Herein, an n‚Äêdoped cross‚Äêlinked organic electron transport layer (ETL), named c‚ÄêNDI‚ÄêBr:PEI is developed, via a simple in situ quaternization reaction between bromopentyl‚Äêsubstituted naphthalene diimide derivative (NDI‚ÄêBr) and polyethylenimine (PEI). Due to strong self‚Äêdoping, c‚ÄêNDI‚ÄêBr:PEI films exhibit a high electrical conductivity (0.06 S¬†cm‚àí1), which is important for efficient hole and electron reombination in ICL of tandem OPVs. In addition, the cross‚Äêlinked ETLs show strong work function modulation ability, and good solvent‚Äêresistance. The above features enable c‚ÄêNDI‚ÄêBr:PEI to function as an efficient ETL not only for single‚Äêjunction OPVs, but also for tandem devices without any metal layer in ICL. Under solar radiation, the single‚Äêjunction device with c‚ÄêNDI‚ÄêBr:PEI as ETL achieves a power conversion efficiency (PCE) of 18.18%, surpassing the ZnO‚Äêbased device (17.09%). The homo‚Äê and hetero‚Äêtandem devices with m‚ÄêPEDOT:PSS:c‚ÄêNDI‚ÄêBr:PEI as ICL exhibit remarkable PCEs of 19.06% and 20.06%, respectively. Under 808¬†nm laser radiation with a photon flux of 57¬†mW cm‚àí2, the homo‚Äêtandem device presents a superior PCE of 38.5%. This study provides a new ETL for constructing all‚Äêsolution‚Äêprocessed organic/organic ICL, which can be integrated in flexible and wearable devices.

item.title: Regulating Interfacial H2O Activity and H2 Bubbles by Core/Shell Nanoarrays for 800 h Stable Alkaline Seawater Electrolysis
item.content:encoded:
To concurrently improve activity and stability for seawater electrolysis under high current densities, the problems of firm adherence and coverage of H2 bubbles with core/shell nanoarrays, addressed which further regulates the interfacial H2O activity to reduce overpotentials, hence highlighting its potential as a sustainable and economically feasible application for large‚Äêscale hydrogen production.
Abstract The catalytic activity and stability under high current densities for hydrogen evolution reactions (HER) are impeded by firm adherence and coverage of H2 bubbles to the catalytic sites. Herein, we systematically synthesize core/shell nanoarrays to engineer bubble transport channels, which further remarkably regulate interfacial H2O activity, and swift H2 bubble generation and release. The self‚Äêsupported catalyst holds uniform ultra‚Äêlow Ru active sites of 0.38¬†wt% and promotes the rapid formation of plentiful small H2 bubbles, which are rapidly released by the upright channels, mitigating the blockage of active sites and avoiding surface damage from bubble movements. As a result, these core/shell nanoarrays achieve ultralow overpotentials of 18 and 24 mV to reach 10 mA cm‚àí2 for HER in 1 M KOH freshwater and seawater, respectively. Additionally, the assembled electrolyzer demonstrates stable durability over 800 hours with a high current density of 2 A cm‚àí2 in 1 M KOH seawater. The techno‚Äêeconomic analysis (TEA) indicates that the unit cost of the hydrogen production system is nearly half of the DOE's (Department of Energy) 2026 target. Our work addresses the stability challenges of HER and highlights its potential as a sustainable and economically feasible solution for large‚Äêscale hydrogen production of seawater.

item.title: Non‚ÄêInvasive Diagnosis of Early Colorectal Cancerization via Amplified Sensing of MicroRNA‚Äê21 in NIR‚ÄêII Window
item.content:encoded:
An amplified sensing strategy is reported in the second near‚Äêinfrared long‚Äêwavelength (NIR‚ÄêII‚ÄêL, 1500‚Äì1900 nm) window for non‚Äêinvasivel in situ visualization of early cancerization biomarker miRNA‚Äê21, providing a promising alternative for early diagnosis of cancerization and a guidance for therapeutic management.
Abstract Accurate, sensitive, and in situ visualization of aberrant expression level of low‚Äêabundant biomolecules is crucial for early colorectal cancer (CRC) detection ahead of tumor morphology change. However, the clinical used colonoscopy and biopsy methods are invasive and lack of sensitivity at early‚Äêstage of cancerization. Here, an amplified sensing strategy is developed in the second near‚Äêinfrared long‚Äêwavelength subregion (NIR‚ÄêII‚ÄêL, 1500‚Äì1900¬†nm) by integrating DNAzyme‚Äêtriggered signal amplification technology and lanthanide‚Äêdye hybrid system. In the early‚Äêstage of CRC, the overexpressed biomarker microRNA‚Äê21 initiates the NIR‚ÄêII‚ÄêL luminescence ratiometric signal amplification of the CRCsensor. The high sensitivity with a limit of detection (LOD) of 1.26 pm allows non‚Äêinvasive visualization of orthotopic colorectal cancerization via rectal administration, which achieves early and accurate in situ diagnosis at 2 weeks ahead of the in vitro histological results.
