Abstract The explicit roles of the hardly avoidable oxygen species on carbon materials in various fields remain contentious due to the limitations of characterization techniques, which lead to a lack of fundamental understanding of carbon surface chemistry. This study delves exhaustively into the comprehension of the features of different oxygen‚Äêmodified carbons through the dynamic evolution of surficial oxygen functional groups. Significant differences of thermal stability and electronic properties among various oxygen species are elucidated via in situ characterizations and theoretical calculations, providing a reliable benchmark for identifying oxygen functional groups on carbon materials. The chemical properties of the carbon materials are simultaneously investigated to show the influence of the oxygen functional groups on carbon structures, redox stability, and scalable metal adsorption. These findings not only consider the common misconception that oxygen species produced under various conditions possess identical properties but also raise awareness of understanding carbon surface chemistry in the atomic level.

item.title: Anti‚ÄêSelf‚ÄêDischarge Capability of Zn‚ÄêHalogen Batteries Through an Entrapment‚ÄêAdsorption‚ÄêCatalysis Strategy Built Upon Separator
item.content:encoded:
The mechanisms of glass fiber (GF) and Zn‚îÄMn atom pairs‚Äêmodified glass fiber separator (named as ZnMn‚ÄêNC/GF) work in zinc‚Äêhalogen batteries. The Mn‚ÄêN4 single‚Äêatom sites are responsible for adsorption, while the Zn‚îÄMn atom pairs are responsible for catalysis. The polyiodide can be rapidly captured and further transformed into I‚Äê before it reaches zinc anodes through this effective ZnMn‚ÄêNC modified layer.
Abstract Aqueous Zn‚Äêhalogen batteries (Zn‚ÄêI2/Br2) suffer from grievous self‚Äêdischarge behavior, resulting in irreversible loss of active cathode material and severe corrosion of zinc anode, which ultimately leads to rapid battery failure. Herein, an entrapment‚Äêadsorption‚Äêcatalysis strategy is reported, leveraging Zn‚îÄMn atom pairs‚Äêmodified glass fiber separator (designated as ZnMn‚ÄêNC/GF), to effectively mitigate the self‚Äêdischarge phenomenon. The in situ Raman and UV experiments, along with theoretical calculations, confirmed the single‚Äêatom Mn sites are responsible for polyiodides adsorption, while Zn‚îÄMn atom pairs facilitated the conversion of reaction intermediates. As a result, the utilization rate of cathode active species is enhanced through this ZnMn‚ÄêNC/GF separator. The fully charged Zn‚ÄêI2 battery assembled with ZnMn‚ÄêNC/GF maintained a Coulombic efficiency (CE) of 90.1% after being left for 120 h, as well as a capacity retention rate of 95.3% after 30000 cycles at a current density of 5 A g‚àí1. Additionally, the Zn‚ÄêBr2 battery designed with ZnMn‚ÄêNC/GF separator can withstand more serious self‚Äêdischarge problems of bromine species, with an average discharge voltage platform of 1.75 V at 0.5 A g‚àí1. The self‚Äêdischarge problem of aqueous Zn‚Äêhalogen batteries is significantly suppressed by this entrapment‚Äêadsorption‚Äêcatalysis strategy, which can serve as a crucial reference for the advancement of high‚Äêperformance aqueous Zn‚Äêhalogen batteries.

item.title: Atomic Layer Deposition Stabilizes Nanocrystals, Enabling Reliably High‚ÄêPerformance Quantum Dot LEDs
item.content:encoded:
Atomic layer deposition (ALD) of Al‚ÇÇO‚ÇÉ on ZnMgO nanocrystals eliminates aging‚Äêinduced performance variability in quantum dot light‚Äêemitting diodes (QD‚ÄêLEDs). This scalable passivation strategy suppresses nanocrystal ripening and passivates surface traps, achieving reproducible 17% external quantum efficiency, a tenfold increase in device operational stability, and consistent performance sustained over 39 weeks.
Abstract Quantum dot light‚Äêemitting diodes (QD‚ÄêLEDs) with stable high efficiencies are crucial for next‚Äêgeneration displays. However, uncontrollable aging, where efficiency initially increases during storage (positive aging) but is entirely lost upon extended aging (negative aging), hinders further device development. It is uncovered that it is chemical changes to nanocrystal (NC)‚Äêbased electron transport layer (ETL) that give rise to positive aging, their drift in structure and morphology leading to transiently improved charge injection balance. Using grazing‚Äêincidence small‚Äêangle X‚Äêray scattering, it is found that ZnMgO NCs undergo size‚Äêfocusing ripening during aging, improving size uniformity and creating a smoother energy landscape. Electron‚Äêonly device measurements reveal a sevenfold reduction in trap states, indicating enhanced surface passivation of ZnMgO. These insights, combined with density functional theory calculations of ZnMgO surface binding, inspire an atomic layer deposition (ALD) strategy with Al‚ÇÇO‚ÇÉ to permanently suppress surface traps and inhibit NC growth, effectively eliminating aging‚Äêinduced efficiency loss. This ALD‚Äêengineered ZnMgO ETL enables reproducible external quantum efficiencies (EQEs) of 17% across 30 batches of LEDs with a T60 of 60 h at an initial luminance of 4500 cd m‚àí2, representing a 1.6‚Äêfold increase in EQE and a tenfold improvement in operating stability compared to control devices.

item.title: An Integrated Modular Vaccination System for Spatiotemporally Separated Perioperative Cancer Immunotherapy
item.content:encoded:
A spatiotemporal segmentation immunotherapy strategy uses modular microneedles to modulate paradoxical postoperative immunization microenvironments. The modular microneedles load a personalized antitumor vaccine and demonstrate broad antitumor activities in postoperative immunotherapy, reducing recurrence and the incidence of perioperative wound complications.
Abstract The perioperative period is crucial for determining postoperative tumor recurrence and metastasis. Various factors in postoperative lesions can diminish the therapeutic effect of conventional chemoradiotherapy, while emerging immunotherapy is restricted. The combination use of inflammatory inhibitors during treatment is also controversial. Here, a modular microneedle prepared from engineered keratin proteins is reported, which spatially and temporally differentiates the microenvironment of immune cell activation required for immunotherapy from that of wound healing. The recombinant keratin‚Äê84‚ÄêT‚Äêbased needle root layer, mainly retained in the epidermis, facilitated dendritic cell recruitment to achieve maximum antigen presentation of loaded vaccines. Meanwhile, the recombinant keratin‚Äê81‚Äê1AŒ±‚Äêbased needle tip layer, located within the dermis, rapidly mitigated inflammatory¬†responses while promoting tissue repair and regeneration. Unlike simply mixing immunotherapy and wound¬†treatment, this spatiotemporal segmentation approach maximized the efficacy of immune therapeutics while promoting wound healing, making it suitable for application throughout the perioperative period.

item.title: Manipulating Aggregation Kinetics toward Efficient All‚ÄêPrinted Organic Solar Cells
item.content:encoded:
The acceptor BTP‚ÄêCy, featuring cyclohexyl side chains, is synthesized to control molecular aggregation state in solution. Compared to molecules containing benzene and undecyl side chains, BTP‚ÄêCy‚Äêbased active layer exhibits suitable solubility and molecular aggregation size, leading to an optimal liquid precursor film length and film morphology. Consequently, all‚Äêprinted 23.6 cm2 BTP‚ÄêCy‚Äêbased modules achieve a power conversion efficiency of 16.2%.
Abstract The power conversion efficiencies (PCEs) of all‚Äêprinted organic solar cells (OSCs) remain inferior to those of spin‚Äêcoated devices, primarily due to morphological variations within the bulk heterojunction processed via diverse coating/printing techniques. Herein, cyclohexyl is introduced as outer side chains to formulate a non‚Äêfullerene acceptor, BTP‚ÄêCy, aimed at modulating the molecular aggregation in solution and subsequent film formation kinetics during printing. Investigations demonstrate that BTP‚ÄêCy molecule with cyclohexyl side chains exhibits enhanced intermolecular œÄ‚ÄêœÄ stacking, optimal solution aggregation size, and favorable phase separation. Consequently, PB3:FTCC‚ÄêBr:BTP‚ÄêCy‚Äêbased OSCs achieve remarkable PCEs of 20.2% and 19.5% via spin‚Äêcoating and blade‚Äêcoating, respectively. Furthermore, a 23.6 cm2 module exhibits a remarkable efficiency of 16.7%. This study offers a fresh perspective on tailoring the film formation kinetics of photoactive materials during printing through molecular design, paving a novel path to enhance the efficiency of all‚Äêprinted OSCs.

item.title: High‚ÄêPerformance Organic Ultralong Room Temperature Phosphorescence Based on Biomass Macrocycle
item.content:encoded:
High‚Äêperformance ultralong biomass room temperature phosphorescence (RTP) doped systems with phosphorescence quantum up to 32.8%, lifetime up to 4.65 s, and multi‚Äêstimulus response through multiple interactions between host biomass macrocycle and guest is reported. The RTP performance of biomass macrocycle doped systems far exceeds biomass systems ever reported and compares favorably with highly effective polymer systems.
Abstract The pursuit of sustainable, high‚Äêperformance organic ultralong room temperature phosphorescence (OURTP) materials with stimulus‚Äêresponsive properties presents a significant and enticing yet formidable challenge. Herein, an efficient strategy to confining boric acid‚Äêbased compounds into biomass macrocycle Œ≥‚Äêcyclodextrin through multiple interactions is developed, enabling the construction of high‚Äêperformance and multicolor OURTP doped systems. The synergistic effects of strong hydrogen bonding, C‚îÄO‚îÄB covalent cross‚Äêlinking, and host‚Äìguest encapsulation significantly suppress non‚Äêradiative transition, culminating in an extraordinary lifetime and excellent phosphorescence quantum yield of 4.65 s and 32.8%, respectively, which are far superior to reported biomass RTP materials. Additionally, merging biomass macrocycle with phosphors contributes to multiple stimulus responses, overcoming the inherent limitations of degradation and recycling of organic RTP compounds, and dynamically modulating RTP signals through multiple‚Äêstimulus responses, achieving the integration of multifunctional dynamic data processing techniques. This work will provide a direction for new environmentally friendly and potentially commercially available stimulus‚Äêresponsive OURTP materials.

item.title: Incompatible Geometry Regulation of Nanowire Assemblies Enabled Light‚ÄêDriven Shape Morphing and Motions
item.content:encoded:
A nanowire assemblies‚Äêinduced geometry engineering method is reported to fabricate a photoresponsive liquid crystal actuator with mechanically incompatible geometry, exhibiting a saddle‚Äêlike appearance. By regulating the off‚Äêaxis director angle and strip width, the configurations of the actuators undergo sharp and periodic transitions among the rings, helicoids, and spirals, enabling the generation of multi‚Äêmodal photo‚Äêdriven locomotion with fast velocities and high controllability.
Abstract Photoresponsive shape‚Äêchanging materials have significant applications in miniaturized smart robotics and biomedicine powered in a remote and wireless manner. Existing light‚Äêfuelled soft materials suffer from limited continuous shape manipulation and constrained mobility and locomotive modes. One promising solution is developing a hierarchical structure design approach to integrate rapid, reversible photoactive molecular alignment and mechanically incompatible geometry in a macroscopic system. Here, a nanowire assemblies‚Äêinduced geometry engineering method is reported for the fabrication of silver nanowire‚Äêincorporated nematic liquid crystalline elastomers with prominent anisotropic structures at multi‚Äêlength scales and incompatible elasticity that show sharp morphological transitions among the rings, helicoids, and spirals with diverse helical configurations. The engineered composite films can realize complex light‚Äêdriven motions including rotating, rolling, and jumping with the controlled directionality and magnitude that are pre‚Äêencoded in their both molecular and macroscopic configurations. Owing to the great controllability of multimodal locomotion, a spiral robot can undertake task‚Äêspecific configuration to climb up complex terrains. The complete regulatory relationship among molecular orientation, shape geometry, and light‚Äêdriven motions is also established. This study may open an avenue for elaborate design and precise fabrication of novel shape‚Äêmorphing materials for future applications in intelligent robotic systems.

item.title: Harnessing Amino Acid Modularity for Programmable Function in Covalent Peptide Assemblies
item.content:encoded:
Covalent peptide assembly integrates the robustness of covalent bonds with the adaptability of dynamic non‚Äêcovalent interactions. Systematic amino acid substitution screening yields programmable peptide frameworks, facilitating the advanced engineering of features such as frustrated growth, hierarchical hollow architectures, affinity enrichment, stimuli‚Äêresponsive behavior, and signal amplification. This approach revolutionizes multicomponent peptide assembly, offering enhanced complexity, versatility, and multifunctional potential.
Abstract Covalent peptide assembly leverages robust covalent bonds and dynamic non‚Äêcovalent interactions to provide enhanced stability and introduce diverse functionalities. Nevertheless, it remains significantly challenging to achieve modular control over the structural diversity and functional complexity while elucidating how specific amino acid sequences contribute to these processes. Here, the systematic encoding of peptide derivative characteristics is demonstrated through amino acid modularity to enable precise control over both the structural diversity and functional complexity in covalent peptide assemblies. By systematically screening single amino acid substitutions in pentapeptides using tyrosine crosslinking, a diverse library of peptide constructs is developed. Each construct is tailored to exhibit distinct properties, including charge repulsion, aggregation‚Äêinduced quenching, disassembly behavior, and redox responsiveness. The strategic manipulation of sequence composition, both in individual assemblies and combinatorial systems, enables programmable control over the structural diversity and functional complexity. This approach yields various module‚Äêspecific functions, including frustrated growth, hierarchical hollow architecture formation, affinity enrichment, stimuli‚Äêresponsive behavior, and fluorescence signal amplification. This work establishes a framework for the design of modular peptide materials with programmable functionalities, advancing the development of next‚Äêgeneration multicomponent peptide assembly technologies characterized by unprecedented complexity and adaptability.

item.title: Unifying Electrochemically‚ÄêDriven Multistep Phase Transformations of Rutile TiO2 to Rocksalt Nanograins for Reversible Li+ and Na+ Storage
item.content:encoded:
This work reveals the insight reason for the Li+ and Na+ storage performance of the rutile phase, which is determined by the electrochemically driven formed rocksalt nanograins. Importantly, the electrochemically in situ formed rocksalt phase has open diffusion channels for rapid Li+ or Na+ (de)intercalations through a solid‚Äêsolution mechanism, which determines the pseudocapacitive, ‚Äúmirror‚Äêlike‚Äù cyclic voltammetry curves and excellent rate capabilities.
Abstract Rutile titanium dioxide (TiO2(R)) lacks octahedral vacancies, which is not suitable for Li+ and Na+ intercalation via reversible two‚Äêphase transformations, but it displays promising electrochemical properties. The origins of these electrochemical performances remain largely unclear. Herein, the Li+ and Na+ storage mechanisms of TiO2(R) with grain sizes ranging from 10 to 100 nm are systematically investigated. Through revealing the electrochemically‚Äêdriven atom rearrangements, nanosize effect and kinetics analysis of TiO2(R) nanograins during repeated cycling with Li+ or Na+, a unified mechanism of electrochemically‚Äêdriven multistep rutile‚Äêto‚Äêrocksalt phase transformations is demonstrated. Importantly, the electrochemically in situ formed rocksalt phase has open diffusion channels for rapid Li+ or Na+ (de)intercalation through a solid‚Äêsolution mechanism, which determines the pseudocapacitive, ‚Äúmirror‚Äêlike‚Äù cyclic voltammetry curves and excellent rate capabilities. Whereas, the nanosize effect determines the different Li+ and Na+ storage capacities because of their distinct reaction depths. Remarkably, the TiO2(R)‚Äê10 nm anode in situ turns into rocksalt nanograins after 30 cycles with Na+, which delivers a reversible capacity of ‚âà200 mAh g‚àí1, high‚Äêrate capability of 97 mAh g‚àí1 at 10 A g‚àí1 and long‚Äêterm cycling stability over 3000 cycles. The findings provide deep insights into the in situ phase evolutions with boosted electrochemical Li+ or Na+ storage performance.

item.title: Colloidal Ink Engineering for Slot‚ÄêDie Processes to Realize Highly Efficient and Robust Perovskite Solar Modules
item.content:encoded:
A strategy is presented for fabricating high‚Äêefficiency, highly stable perovskite solar cells, and minimodules using a slot‚Äêdie process based on colloidal inks. By incorporating the antisolvents toluene and chlorobenzene as modulator solvents, a colloidal ink system is formulated with superior rheological properties compared to conventional precursor inks. This colloidal strategy achieves devices with a maximum efficiency of 21.32% and remarkable long‚Äêterm stability.
Abstract Perovskite solar cells (PSCs) have emerged as a promising alternative to silicon solar cells, but challenges remain in developing perovskite inks and processes suitable for large‚Äêscale production. This study introduces a novel approach using colloidal inks incorporating toluene and chlorobenzene as co‚Äêantisolvents for PSC fabrication via slot‚Äêdie process. It is found that colloidal inks that are strategically engineered can significantly improve the rheological properties of perovskite inks, leading to enhanced wettability and high‚Äêquality film formation. The formation of large colloids such as Œ± cubic perovskite, Œ¥ hexagonal perovskite and transition intermediate phases promotes heterogeneous nucleation and lowers activation energy for crystallization, resulting in superior crystal growth and improved film morphology. Notably, the co‚Äêsolvent enhances the FA‚ÄêPbI3 binding energy and weakens the dimethyl sulfoxide coordination, which is more thermodynamically favorable for perovskite crystallization. This colloidal strategy yields devices with a maximum efficiency of 21.32% and remarkable long‚Äêterm stability, retaining 77% of initial efficiency over 10115 h. The study demonstrates the scalability of this approach, achieving 20.26% efficiency in lab‚Äêscale minimodules and 19.15% in larger convergence minimodules. These findings provide an understanding of the complex relationship between ink composition, rheological properties, film quality, crystallization kinetics, and device performance.

item.title: ‚ÄúPumping‚Äù Trace Cu Impurity out of Zn Foil for Sustainable Aqueous Battery Interface
item.content:encoded:
Copper exists as trace impurity in commercial Zn foil and generally gets ignored in terms of its potential for regulating Zn electrodeposition. Herein, it is demonstrated how trace amount of internal Cu atoms can be readily ‚Äúpumped‚Äù out, in one step, to get concentrated on Zn foil surface and to further suppress dendritic Zn electrodeposition as a sustainable aqueous battery interface.
Abstract Dendritic zinc (Zn) electrodeposition presents a significant obstacle to the large‚Äêscale development of rechargeable zinc‚Äêion batteries. To mitigate this challenge, various interfacial strategies have been employed. However, these approaches often involve the incorporation of foreign materials onto Zn anode surface, resulting in increased material costs and processing complexities, not to mention the compromised interface endurability due to structural and compositional heterogeneity. Realizing that Cu atoms typically exist as trace impurities in commercial Zn, a novel approach is demonstrated that leverages these Cu impurities to create a Cu‚Äêrich surface for effective modulation of Zn electrodeposition. By simply heating commercially available Zn foil with a naturally oxidized surface, not only the internal Cu atoms are thermally activated to become diffusible, their diffusion is also navigated toward the surface via¬†oxygen attraction. The resulting Cu‚Äêrich surface effectively regulates Zn electrodeposition, comparable to conventional interfacial strategies, yet exhibits superior cycling durability. 3D in situ microscopy confirms that this Cu‚Äêrich surface enables dendrite‚Äêfree, compact, and (101)‚Äêoriented Zn electrodeposition, contrasting with the traditional (002)‚Äêoriented dendrite‚Äêsuppression mechanism. By transforming trace Cu impurity within Zn foil into a Cu‚Äêrich surface, this work demonstrates a straightforward, cost‚Äêeffective and efficient method for controlling Zn electrodeposition.

item.title: Myocardia‚ÄêInjected Synergistically Anti‚ÄêApoptotic and Anti‚ÄêInflammatory Poly(amino acid) Hydrogel Relieves Ischemia‚ÄêReperfusion Injury
item.content:encoded:
A bioactive thermo‚Äêsensitive poly(amino acid) hydrogel is demonstrated to release the therapeutic drug FTY720 in a reactive oxygen species‚Äêcontrolled manner and achieves a synergistic effect by inhibiting apoptosis and regulating the reperfusion inflammatory microenvironments, thereby reducing ischemia‚Äêreperfusion injury and promoting tissue repair, demonstrating significant clinical potential for the treatment of ischemia‚Äêreperfusion injury.
Abstract Reperfusion therapy is the most effective treatment for acute myocardial infarction, but its efficacy is frequently limited by ischemia‚Äêreperfusion injury (IRI). While antioxidant and anti‚Äêinflammatory therapies have shown significant potential in alleviating IRI, these strategies have not yielded satisfactory clinical outcomes. For that, a thermo‚Äêsensitive myocardial‚Äêinjectable poly(amino acid) hydrogel of methoxy poly(ethylene glycol)45‚Äêpoly(L‚Äêmethionine20‚Äêco‚ÄêL‚Äêalanine10) (mPEG45‚ÄêP(Met20‚Äêco‚ÄêAla10), PMA) loaded with FTY720 (PMA/FTY720) is developed to address IRI through synergistic anti‚Äêapoptotic and anti‚Äêinflammatory effects. Upon injection into the ischemic myocardium, the PMA aqueous solution undergoes a sol‚Äêto‚Äêgel phase transition and gradually degrades in response to reactive oxygen species (ROS), releasing FTY720 on demand. PMA acts synergistically with FTY720 to inhibit cardiomyocyte apoptosis and modulate pro‚Äêinflammatory M1 macrophage polarization toward anti‚Äêinflammatory M2 macrophages by clearing ROS, thereby mitigating the inflammatory response and promoting vascular regeneration. In a rat IRI model, PMA/FTY720 reduces the apoptotic cell ratio by 81.8%, increases vascular density by 34.0%, and enhances left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) by 12.8%. In a rabbit IRI model, the gel‚Äêbased sustained release of FTY720 enhanced LVEF by an additional 7.2% compared to individual treatment. In summary, the engineered PMA hydrogel effectively alleviates IRI through synergistic anti‚Äêapoptosis and anti‚Äêinflammation actions, offering valuable clinical potential for treating myocardial IRI.

item.title: Photoinduced Cleavage of Respiratory Syncytial Virus by Chiral Vanadium Trioxide Nanoparticles
item.content:encoded:
Strongly chiral V2O3 NPs with optical responsiveness achieve targeted and precise cleavage of the RSV pre‚Äêfusion protein through photoinduction, thereby inhibiting respiratory syncytial virus.
Abstract Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) poses a significant threat to the health of infants, children, and the elderly, and as of now there is a lack of effective therapeutic drugs. To tackle this challenge, chiral vanadium trioxide nanoparticles (V2O3 NPs) with a particle size of 2.56 ¬± 0.34 nm are successfully synthesized, exhibiting a g‚Äêfactor value of 0.048 at 874 nm in terms of circular dichroism. Under 808 nm light irradiation, these chiral V2O3 NPs demonstrated selective cleavage of the RSV pre‚Äêfusion protein (RSV protein), effectively blocking its conformational rearrangement and preventing RSV infection both in vitro and in vivo. Experimental analysis revealed that the chiral V2O3 NPs specifically bind to the functional domain spanning from aspartate200 (D200) to asparagine208 (N208) in the primary sequence of the RSV protein. Notably, L‚ÄêV2O3 NPs exhibited a higher affinity, which is 4.06 times that of D‚ÄêV2O3 NPs and 13.55 times that of DL‚ÄêV2O3 NPs. The precise cutting site is located between amino acid residues leucine204 (L204) and proline205 (P205), attributed to the reactive oxygen species (ROS) generated by photoinduced nanoparticles. In addition, L‚ÄêV2O3 NPs inhibited RSV infection by 99.6% in nasal epithelial cells and 99.2% in Vero cells. In the RSV‚Äêinfected mouse model, intranasal administration of L‚ÄêV‚ÇÇO‚ÇÉ NPs effectively controlled the viral load in the lungs of mice, reducing it by 92.43%. The hematoxylin and eosin staining of mouse organs and serum biochemical indicators are similar to those of the wild‚Äêtype group, indicating the biosafety of L‚ÄêV‚ÇÇO‚ÇÉ NPs. The findings suggest that chiral nanoparticles hold great potential in controlling RSV and provide new directions and ideas for drug development against viruses.

item.title: Molecules to Masterpieces: Bridging Materials Science and the Arts
item.content:encoded:
This article describes the convergence of materials science and art through the creation of self‚Äêassembled block copolymer lamellar thin films with vivid iridescence. These films are applied as coatings on window panels for an architectural installation as well as transformed into porous, structurally colored ceramics. The work demonstrates the potential of nanoscale engineering in artistic and architectural contexts.
Abstract Art and materials innovation have always been intertwined, dating back to the earliest human creations. In modern times, however, the increasing specialization of materials science often restricts artists' access to cutting‚Äêedge materials. Here, the materials science aspects of an art‚Äêscience collaboration between artist Kimsooja and the Wiesner Lab at Cornell University, are detailed. The project involves the development of a custom‚Äêmade iridescent block copolymer coating by means of self‚Äêassembly, originally applied to transparent window panels of a fa√ßade for the ‚âà14¬†m tall art installation: A Needle Woman: Galaxy Is a Memory, Earth is a Souvenir by artist Kimsooja. After several exhibitions in the US and Europe, the installation is now part of the permanent museum collection at Yorkshire Sculpture Park in Wakefield, UK. Full characterization of the solution blade‚Äêcast coatings show shear aligned, standing up lamellar morphologies that behave as volume‚Äêphase gratings with periodicities between 300 and 400¬†nm. Coatings are also applied to foldable (origami) paper and converted into iridescent porous ceramic materials. It is hoped this work inspires and informs communities across materials science, the arts, and architecture.

item.title: A Printed Microscopic Universal Gradient Interface for Super Stretchable Strain‚ÄêInsensitive Bioelectronics
item.content:encoded:
Stretchable bioelectronics conforming to dynamic body surfaces enable high‚Äêfidelity physiological monitoring but often suffer from motion artifacts. All‚Äêprinted strain‚Äêinsensitive bioelectronics are presented using a universal gradient interface (UGI) created via aerosol‚Äêbased multi‚Äêmaterials printing (AMMP). The UGI minimizes local strain changes under 180% stretch, supporting artifact‚Äêfree sensors for health monitoring and advancing wearable and implantable bioelectronics for personalized healthcare.
Abstract Stretchable electronics capable of conforming to nonplanar and dynamic human body surfaces are central for creating implantable and on‚Äêskin devices for high‚Äêfidelity monitoring of diverse physiological signals. While various strategies have been developed to produce stretchable devices, the signals collected from such devices are often highly sensitive to local strain, resulting in inevitable convolution with surface strain‚Äêinduced motion artifacts that are difficult to distinguish from intrinsic physiological signals. Here all‚Äêprinted super stretchable strain‚Äêinsensitive bioelectronics using a unique universal gradient interface (UGI) are reported to bridge the gap between soft biomaterials and stiff electronic materials. Leveraging a versatile aerosol‚Äêbased multi‚Äêmaterials printing¬†technique that allows precise spatial control over the local stiffnesses with submicron resolution, the UGI enables strain‚Äêinsensitive electronic devices with negligible resistivity changes under a 180% uniaxial stretch ratio. Various stretchable devices are directly printed on the UGI for on‚Äêskin health monitoring with high signal quality and near‚Äêperfect immunity to motion artifacts, including semiconductor‚Äêbased photodetectors for sensing blood oxygen saturation levels and metal‚Äêbased temperature sensors. The concept in this work will significantly simplify the fabrication and accelerate the development of a broad range of wearable and implantable bioelectronics for real‚Äêtime health monitoring and personalized therapeutics.

item.title: Continuous‚ÄêWave Pumped Self‚ÄêAssembled Colloidal Topological Lasers
item.content:encoded:
A self‚Äêassembled colloidal topological laser with CW room‚Äêtemperature pumping is presented, featuring extensive wavelength tunability, ultra‚Äêhigh polarization, and good temporal stability. Precise control over a single NPL layer thickness allows excellent performance in semiconductor lasers, advancing solution‚Äêprocessed systems for display technology and modern communication.
Abstract The field of optoelectronic integrated circuits is actively developing reliable and efficient room‚Äêtemperature continuous‚Äêwave (CW) lasers. CW‚Äêpumped lasers combine the economical and simple manufacturing processes of colloidal semiconductor lasers with the efficient and stable output of continuous pumping, enabling them to significantly impact the field of semiconductor lasers. However, development is still severely challenged by limitations such as gain materials and cavity structures. Consequently, as a compromise, most colloidal semiconductor lasers proposed to date have relied on another pulsed laser as the pumping source. In this study, a self‚Äêassembled colloidal topological laser is proposed that benefits from CW pumping at room temperature. By utilizing an interfacial self‚Äêassembly strategy, nanoplatelets (NPLs) are managed to control the collective orientation (face‚Äêdown or edge‚Äêup), achieving controlled polarization of amplified spontaneous emission for the first time. Furthermore, precise control over the thickness of a single NPL layer is demonstrated, which enables the laser system to offer extensive wavelength tunability (over 50¬†nm), ultra‚Äêhigh polarization (over 95%), and good temporal stability. These metrics signify the optimal performance level of colloidal semiconductor lasers, marking a new era in solution processing systems for the optoelectronic integrated circuit field.

item.title: High‚ÄêDensity Accessible Iron Single‚ÄêAtom Catalyst for Durable and Temperature‚ÄêAdaptive Laminated Zinc‚ÄêAir Batteries
item.content:encoded:
F‚ÄêN‚ÄêC catalysts with high density of accessible sites (D‚ÄêFe‚ÄêN/C) is fabricated by a cascade capturing strategy. Systematic structural and electrochemical characterizations demonstrate that the high active site density and site utilization enable D‚ÄêFe‚ÄêN/C showcases excellent ORR performance, which is further verified in laminated zinc‚Äêair batteries with remarkable durability and temperature‚Äêadaptive.
Abstract Designing single‚Äêatom catalysts (SACs) with high density of accessible sites by improving metal loading and sites utilization is a promising strategy to boost the catalytic activity, but remains challenging. Herein, a high site density (SD) iron SAC (D‚ÄêFe‚ÄêN/C) with 11.8 wt.% Fe‚Äêloading is reported. The in situ scanning electrochemical microscopy technique attests that the accessible active SD and site utilization of D‚ÄêFe‚ÄêN/C reach as high as 1.01 √ó 1021 site g‚àí1 and 79.8%, respectively. Therefore, D‚ÄêFe‚ÄêN/C demonstrates superior oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) activity in terms of a half‚Äêwave potential of 0.918 V and turnover frequency of 0.41 e site‚àí1 s‚àí1. The excellent ORR property of D‚ÄêFe‚ÄêN/C is also demonstrated in the liquid zinc‚Äêair batteries (ZABs), which exhibit a high peak power density of 306.1 mW cm‚àí2 and an ultra‚Äêlong cycling stability over 1200 h. Moreover, solid‚Äêstate laminated ZABs prepared by presetting an air flow layer show a high specific capacity of 818.8 mA h g‚àí1, an excellent cycling stability of 520 h, and a wide temperature‚Äêadaptive from ‚àí40 to 60 ¬∞C. This work not only offers possibilities by improving metal‚Äêloading and catalytic site utilization for exploring efficient SACs, but also provides strategies for device structure design toward advanced ZABs.

item.title: Zwitterionic Photosensitizer‚ÄêAssembled Nanocluster Produces Efficient Photogenerated Radicals via Autoionization for Superior Antibacterial Photodynamic Therapy
item.content:encoded:
This study presents a simple self‚Äêassembly strategy to construct Type I photosensitizer nanocluster. Facile intermolecular photoinduced electron transfer within nanocluster forms photosensitizer radical cation and anion via autoionization. These radicals engage in cascade photoredox to generate efficient reactive oxygen species, achieving 97.6% antibacterial efficacy against MRSA that surpasses the efficacy of commercial antibiotic Vancomycin by 8.8‚Äêfold.
Abstract Photodynamic therapy (PDT) holds significant promise for antibacterial treatment, with its potential markedly amplified when using Type I photosensitizers (PSs). However, developing Type I PSs remains a significant challenge due to a lack of reliable design strategy. Herein, a Type I PS nanocluster is developed via self‚Äêassembly of zwitterionic small molecule (C3TH) for superior antibacterial PDT in vivo. Mechanism studies demonstrate that unique cross‚Äêarranged C3TH within nanocluster not only shortens intermolecular distance but also inhibits intermolecular electronic‚Äêvibrational coupling, thus facilitating intermolecular photoinduced electron transfer to form PS radical cation and anion via autoionization reaction. Subsequently, these highly oxidizing or reducing PS radicals engage in cascade photoredox to generate efficient ¬∑OH and O2‚Äæ¬∑. As a result, C3TH nanoclusters achieve a 97.6% antibacterial efficacy against MRSA at an ultralow dose, surpassing the efficacy of the commercial antibiotic Vancomycin by more than 8.8‚Äêfold. These findings deepen the understanding of Type I PDT, providing a novel strategy for developing Type I PSs.

item.title: Ordering‚ÄêStructured Antiferroelectric Composite Ceramics for Energy Storage Applications
item.content:encoded:
Inspired by the layered architecture of natural nacre and with the guidance of phase‚Äêfiled simulations, a strategy of controlling the morphology and ordering of Al2O3 fillers in Pb‚Äêbased AFE composite ceramics is proposed, aiming to improve its breakdown strength. Significantly improved Eb of 570¬†kV cm‚àí1 and ultrahigh Wrec of 13.2 J cm‚àí3 are achieved in composite ceramics with parallel‚Äêaligned Al2O3 plates.
Abstract Dielectric capacitors possessing high power density and ultrashort discharge time are valuable for high‚Äêpower energy storage applications. However, achieving high energy storage density remains challenging due to the limited breakdown strength of dielectric ceramics. In this study, inspired by the layered architecture of natural nacre and with the guidance of phase‚Äêfield simulations, a strategy of constructing a nacre‚Äêlike layered structure is proposed to improve the breakdown strength and energy storage density of the ceramics. This unique structure is formed by controlling the morphology and ordering of high‚Äêvoltage‚Äêresistant fillers in a ceramic matrix. The (Pb0.98La0.02)(Zr0.7Sn0.3)0.995O3‚ÄêAl2O3 antiferroelectric composite ceramics, containing 5vol% parallel‚Äêaligned Al2O3 plates, demonstrate a remarkable enhancement in breakdown strength from 390 to 570¬†kV cm‚àí1. Of particular importance is that an ultrahigh recoverable energy storage density of up to 13.2 J cm‚àí3 is achieved, representing a 50% enhancement compared to the pure ceramic (8.7 J cm‚àí3). The parallel‚Äêaligned Al2O3 plates are strongly bound together with the ceramic matrix, effectively blocking charge migration and controlling the breakdown path, thus greatly enhancing the voltage endurance of the composite ceramics. This work provides an innovative approach to designing high‚Äêperformance composite ceramics for next‚Äêgeneration energy storage applications.

item.title: Orbital Matching Mechanism‚ÄêGuided Synthesis of Cu‚ÄêBased Single Atom Alloys for Acidic CO2 Electroreduction
item.content:encoded:
A simple yet intuitive d‚Äêp orbital matching mechanism is proposed for assessing the atomic dispersion stability of Cu‚Äêbased single atom alloys (SAAs). This theoretical framework offers electronic orbital insights into stability factors and is universally applicable for designing stable SAAs. The designed SAAs are experimentally demonstrated with enhanced mono‚Äêcarbon product selectivity in a prototype reaction‚Äîacidic CO2 electroreduction.
Abstract Recent advancements in alloy catalysis have yield novel materials with tailored functionalities. Among these, Cu‚Äêbased single‚Äêatom alloy (SAA) catalysts have attracted significant attention in catalytic applications for their unique electronic structure and geometric ensemble effects. However, selecting alloying atoms with robust dispersion stability on the Cu substrate is challenging, and has mostly been practiced empirically. The fundamental bottleneck is that the microscopic mechanism that governs the dispersion stability is unclear, and a comprehensive approach for designing Cu‚Äêbased SAA systems with simultaneous dispersion stability and high catalytic activity is still missing. Here, combining theory and experiment, a simple yet intuitive d‚Äêp orbital matching mechanism is discovered for rapid assessment of the atomic dispersion stability of Cu‚Äêbased SAAs, exhibiting its universality and extensibility for screening effective SAAs across binary, ternary and multivariant systems. The catalytic selectivity of the newly designed SAAs is demonstrated in a prototype reaction‚Äêacidic CO2 electroreduction, where all SAAs achieve single‚Äêcarbon product selectivity exceeding 70%, with Sb1Cu reaching a peak CO faradaic efficiency of 99.73 ¬± 2.5% at 200¬†mA cm‚àí2. This work establishes the fundamental design principles for Cu‚Äêbased SAAs with excellent dispersion stability and selectivity, and will boost the development of ultrahigh‚Äêperformance SAAs for advanced applications such as electrocatalysis.

item.title: A High‚ÄêRate and Ultrastable Ammonium Ion‚ÄêAir Battery Enabled by the Synergy of ORR and NH4+ Storage
item.content:encoded:
This study explores the synergistic interplay between oxygen reduction reaction and NH4+ storage, and harnesses the synergy for the successful development of a high‚Äêrate and highly stable ammonium ion air battery (AIAB). The assembled AIAB demonstrates outstanding rate performance (89 mAh g‚àí1 at 15 A g‚àí1), high energy density (78 Wh kg‚àí1 at 9369 W kg‚àí1), and exceptional cycling stability at 10 A g‚àí1.
Abstract Ammonium ion batteries (AIBs) offer cost‚Äêeffectiveness, nontoxicity, and eco‚Äêfriendly attributes in energy storage technology. However, the constrained capacity and poor stability of conventional cathode materials have impeded their widespread adoption. Herein, a synergistic approach is introduced to overcome these challenges, by enhancing the air cathode with NH4+ and simultaneously leveraging atmospheric oxygen as a reservoir for NH4+ storage. Notably, NH4+ significantly enhances the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) performance in neutral environments. Through in situ Raman spectroscopy and quantum density functional theory calculations, it is elucidated how NH4+ can act as a proton donor, replacing H2O in neutral media and reducing energy barriers in the protonation of *O2‚àí and *O, thereby accelerating ORR kinetics. The resulting ammonium ion‚Äêair battery, comprising an air cathode and a polymer (PNP) anode, showcases impressive metrics: high energy density of 78 Wh kg‚àí1 and power density of 9369 W kg‚àí1 at 1 A g‚àí1, an initial capacity of 94.3 mAh g‚àí1 and exceptional cycling stability (70.4% capacity retention after 12¬†500 cycles) at 10 A g‚àí1. This pioneering research highlights the synergistic relationship between ORR and NH4+ storage and opens up new avenues for the design and advancement of innovative, sustainable, and environment‚Äêfriendly AIBs.

item.title: TREM2 scFv‚ÄêEngineering Escherichia coli Displaying Modulation of Macrophages to Boost Cancer Radio‚ÄêImmunotherapy
item.content:encoded:
A novel ionizing radiation‚Äêresponsive delivery system is designed for the precise expression of anti‚ÄêTREM2 single‚Äêchain antibody fragments (scFv) using an engineered probiotic, Escherichia coli Nissle 1917 (EcN), to modulate immunotherapy.
Abstract Preoperative neoadjuvant radio‚Äêchemotherapy is a cornerstone in the treatment of low rectal cancer, yet its effectiveness can be limited by the insensitivity of some patients, profoundly impacting their quality of life. Through preliminary research, it is found that TREM2+ macrophages play a pivotal role in the non‚Äêresponsiveness to immunotherapy. To address this challenge, a novel ionizing radiation‚Äêresponsive delivery system is developed for the precise expression of anti‚ÄêTREM2 single‚Äêchain antibody fragments (scFv) using an engineered probiotic, Escherichia coli Nissle 1917 (EcN), to modulate immunotherapy. The released anti‚ÄêTREM2 scFv can be precisely targeted and delivered to the tumor site via the engineered EcN outer membrane vesicles (OMVs), thereby reversing the immunosuppressive tumor microenvironment and enhancing tumor therapeutic efficiency when used in combination with the Œ±PD‚ÄêL1 immune checkpoint inhibitor. Additionally, these engineered bacteria can be further modified to enhance the intestinal colonization capabilities through oral administration, thereby regulating the gut microbiota and its metabolic byproducts. Consequently, the ionizing radiation‚Äêresponsive drug delivery system based on the engineered bacteria not only introduces a promising new therapeutic option for low rectal cancer but also showcases the potential to finely tune immune responses within the intricate tumor microenvironment, paving the way for innovative strategies in tumor radio‚Äêimmunotherapy.

item.title: In Situ Repair and Reconstruction of Copper Surface Enhanced Its Anti‚ÄêOxidation Properties and Stability for Deep Learning‚ÄêPowered Anti‚ÄêCounterfeiting Labels
item.content:encoded:
In situ repair and surface reconstruction of oxidized copper (Cu) (Cu foil, Cu nanowires, Cu nanoparticles) is achieved by solvothermal reaction. The experimental data and Density functional theory calculations demonstrate that (111) crystal‚Äêplane reconstruction enhances the oxidation resistance of the metal, and the method is equally applicable to the Ag nanomaterials (Ag nanowires, Ag nanocubes), which also exhibits good oxidation resistance.
Abstract The in situ repair of oxidized copper (Cu) surfaces while constructing a superior protective layer is critical for sustainable development and the efficient utilization of metallic materials. Here, a simple solvothermal treatment is presented to repair oxidized Cu surfaces (Cu foils, nanowires, and nanocubes) and reconstruct an antioxidant layer with an ordered (111) crystal‚Äêplane (Cu‚ÄêSC) in situ. Electrochemical measurements reveal that the corrosion rate of Cu‚ÄêSC in 0.1¬†m NaOH is reduced to 1.99 √ó 10‚àí3¬†mm yr‚àí¬π, a fivefold improvement over pristine Cu (1.00 √ó 10‚àí2 mm yr‚àí¬π). Density functional theory calculations confirm that the reconstructed (111) surface reduces oxygen molecule adsorption, significantly hinders oxygen atom diffusion into the bulk and continuous adsorption on surface. Anti‚Äêcounterfeiting labels fabricated from Cu‚ÄêSC nanowires exhibit exceptional durability, retaining reliable authentication accuracy after 144¬†h at 85¬†¬∞C/85% relative humidity and 2000 bending cycles. The enhanced anti‚Äêoxidation properties of Cu‚ÄêSC ensure the stability of its microstructures, which are critical for deep learning‚Äêbased authentication, allowing precise feature extraction and accurate label verification even under extreme conditions. These results highlight the potential of (111) surface reconstruction for enhancing material stability, enabling advanced anti‚Äêcounterfeiting applications, and promoting the sustainable utilization of metallic materials.

item.title: Structural Modulation of Cu‚ÄêMn‚ÄêFe Prussian Blue Analogs for Practical Sodium Ion Cylinder Cells
item.content:encoded:
A cost‚Äêeffective ternary Prussian blue analog is synthesized via structural regulation to achieve the compatibility of high capacity and long lifespan for sodium‚Äêion batteries within a wide temperature range. Mn and Cu synergistically enhances conductivity, operating voltage, and stability, suppressing Jahn‚ÄìTeller distortions. This design enables high‚Äêloading 18650‚Äêtype cells with exceptional electrochemical performance, supporting grid‚Äêscale energy storage.
Abstract High‚Äêperformance, cost‚Äêeffective cathodes are essential for grid‚Äêscale sodium‚Äêion batteries (SIBs). Prussian blue analogs (PBAs) have shown great potential as SIB cathodes, but achieving both high capacity and long lifespan remains challenging. In this study, a series of low‚Äêcost ternary PBAs synthesized through structural regulation is presented to simultaneously achieve high capacity, stable cycling performance, and broad temperature adaptability. Among them, CuHCF‚Äê3 demonstrates a specific capacity of 132.4¬†mAh¬†g‚àí1 with 73.3% capacity retention over 1000 cycles. In‚Äêdepth analyses, using in situ techniques and density functional theory calculations, reveal a highly reversible three‚Äêphase transition (monoclinic ‚Üî cubic ‚Üî tetragonal) in Na1.96Cu0.45Mn0.55[Fe(CN)6]0.91¬∑‚ñ°0.09¬∑2.14H2O (CuHCF‚Äê3), which is driven by synergistic interactions between Mn and Cu. Mn enhances conductivity, increases the operating voltage, and introduces additional redox centers, while Cu mitigates the Jahn‚ÄìTeller distortions associated with Mn and buffers volume changes during cycling. This structural synergy results in excellent temperature stability across a wide temperature range (‚àí20 to 55¬†¬∞C). 18650‚Äêtype cylindrical cells based on CuHCF‚Äê3 with high loading density achieve 73.54% capacity retention over 850 cycles. This study offers valuable insights for designing durable, high‚Äêcapacity electrode materials for SIB energy storage applications.

item.title: Peptide‚ÄêOligonucleotide Nanohybrids Designed for Precise Gene Therapy of Rheumatoid Arthritis
item.content:encoded:
The peptide‚Äêoligonucleotide (PON) nanohybrids can be readily fabricated by the bioorthogonal click reaction between PEG5‚ÄêP7‚ÄêR9‚Äê(G‚ÄêDOPA)4‚ÄêHPGGPQ‚ÄêH8‚ÄêC‚ÄêDBCO and miRNA‚Äê124‚ÄêA5‚Äê(CH2)6‚ÄêAzido, which achieve targeted delivery to the lesion sites, robust penetration through cell membrane, efficient scavenging of intracellular ROS, as well as timely escape from the endolysosomes of macrophages, inhibiting proinflammatory M1 polarization and osteoclast differentiation, eventually attenuating arthritic bone destruction and systemic osteoporosis.
Abstract Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic autoimmune disease characterized by excessive inflammation, pathological bone resorption, and systemic osteoporosis. It lacks effective treatment due to the complex pathogenesis. Gene therapy, especially targeted oligonucleotide (ON) delivery therapy, offers a new prospect for the precise treatment of RA. Nevertheless, the clinical application of ON delivery therapy still faces various challenges such as the rapid enzymolysis by RNAse, the lack of tissue targeting ability, difficulty in cell membrane penetration, and the incapability of endolysosomal escape. To address these issues, a novel kind of engineered peptide and oligonucleotide (PON) nanohybrids are designed and fabricated, which provide various advantages including good biosafety, inflammatory region‚Äêtargeted delivery, cell membrane penetration, reactive oxygen species (ROS) scavenging, and endolysosomal escape. The PON nanohybrids produce promising effects in suppressing inflammatory responses and osteoclastogenesis of macrophages via multiple signaling pathways. In vivo administration of PON nanohybrids not only ameliorates local joint bone destruction and systemic osteoporosis in the pathological state, but also demonstrates good prophylactic effects against the rapid progression of RA disease. In conclusion, the study presents a promising strategy for precise RA treatment and broadens the biomedical applications of gene therapy based on delivery system.

item.title: Revisiting the ‚ÄúStick‚ÄêSlip‚Äù Process via Magnetism‚ÄêCoupled Flexible Sensors with Bioinspired Ridge Architecture
item.content:encoded:
A sandwich‚Äêlike device for stick‚Äêslip perception is developed, featuring a deformable bioinspired ridge layer with capability of lateral deformation and fast recovery. Coupled with magnetized functionality, the morphological transformation is capable to induce periodical electrical pulses which allows to revisit the stick‚Äêslip process when human fingertip scans across a specific surface.
Abstract ‚ÄúStick‚Äêslip‚Äù phenomenon that occurs when human fingertip scans across a specific surface is essential to perceive the interactions between skin and the surface. Understanding the ‚Äústick‚Äêslip‚Äù behavior is important for bionic flexible system in applications from advanced robotics to intelligent tactile sensors. However, it is often overlooked owing to the limitations to mimic the soft skin that can tangentially deform/recover with informative electrical feedback. Here, a sandwich‚Äêtype device with deformable ridge‚Äêlayer is proposed to analyze the characteristic of stick/slip states in ‚Äústick‚Äêslip‚Äù process. Specifically, it is observed that fast recovery of the sensing architecture is caused by dynamic slip phase that generates periodical signals based on principle of induction. The results experimentally show that periods of the electrical pulses are dependent on factors such as inherent properties (e.g., modulus and geometry) and operational parameters (e.g., scanning speed and normal load), which is consistent with the theoretical model. Furthermore, it is found that the transition between ‚Äústick‚Äêslip‚Äù and full slip could qualitatively reflect interfacial properties such as moisture, roughness, and topology. It is expected that the results can strengthen the understanding of ‚Äústick‚Äêslip‚Äù behavior when fingertip interacts with a surface and provide guidance of flexible sensor design to enrich the biomimetic perceptions.

item.title: DNA‚ÄëDirected Assembly of Photonic Nanomaterials for Diagnostic and Therapeutic Applications
item.content:encoded:
DNA‚Äêdirected assembly offers a powerful strategy for constructing structured photonic nanomaterials with precise spatial control. This review provides a comprehensive overview of recent advancements in DNA‚Äêassembled photonic nanomaterials for diagnostics and therapeutics, highlighting key design principles, functionalization strategies, and optical effects that enhance their performance in biomedical applications.
Abstract DNA‚Äêdirected assembly has emerged as a versatile and powerful approach for constructing complex structured materials. By leveraging the programmability of DNA nanotechnology, highly organized photonic systems can be developed to optimize light‚Äêmatter interactions for improved diagnostics and therapeutic outcomes. These systems enable precise spatial arrangement of photonic components, minimizing material usage, and simplifying fabrication processes. DNA nanostructures, such as DNA origami, provide a robust platform for building multifunctional photonic devices with tailored optical properties. This review highlights recent progress in DNA‚Äêdirected assembly of photonic nanomaterials, focusing on their applications in diagnostics and therapeutics. It provides an overview of the latest advancements in the field, discussing the principles of DNA‚Äêdirected assembly, strategies for functionalizing photonic building blocks, innovations in assembly design, and the resulting optical effects that drive these developments. The review also explores how these photonic architectures contribute to diagnostic and therapeutic applications, emphasizing their potential to create efficient and effective photonic systems tailored to specific healthcare needs.

item.title: An Air‚ÄêOperated, High‚ÄêPerformance Fe‚ÄêIon Secondary Battery Using Acidic Electrolyte
item.content:encoded:
The air‚Äêoperated assembly of aqueous Fe‚Äêion batteries is realized by a very unexpected finding when excess acid is introduced into the traditional aqueous FeSO4 electrolyte. A proton/O2 competitive mechanism for the as‚Äêdetected ultra‚Äêlow dissolved O2 and reduced coordinated O2 in the Fe2+ solvated shell is revealed.
Abstract Fe2+ have emerged as the ideal charge carriers to construct aqueous batteries as one of the most competitive candidates for next‚Äêgeneration low‚Äêcost and safe energy storage. Unfortunately, the fast oxidation of Fe2+ into Fe3+ at ambient conditions inevitably requires the assembly process of the cells in an oxygen‚Äêfree glovebox. Up to date, direct air assembly of aqueous Fe‚Äêion battery remains very desirable yet highly challenge. Here oxidation of Fe2+ is found at ambient condition and is completely inhibited in an acidic electrolyte. A proton/O2 competitive mechanism in the acidic electrolyte is revealed with reduced coordinated O2 in the Fe2+ solvated shell for this unexpected finding. Based on this surprise, for the first time, air‚Äêoperated assembly of iron‚Äêion batteries is realized. Meanwhile, it is found that the acidic environment induces the in situ growth of active Œ±‚ÄêFeOOH derivate on the VOPO4¬∑2H2O surface. Strikingly, the acidic electrolyte enables an air‚Äêoperated Fe‚Äêion battery with a high specific capacity of 192 mAh g‚àí1 and ultrastable cycling stability over 1300 cycles at 0.1 A g‚àí1. This work makes a break through on the air‚Äêassembly of Fe‚Äêion battery without oxygen‚Äêfree glovebox. It also reveals previously unknown proton/O2 competitive mechanisms in the Fe2+ solvated shell and cathode surface chemistry for aqueous Fe2+ storage.

item.title: Traversing the Periodic Table through Phase‚ÄêSeparating Nanoreactors
item.content:encoded:
Centimeter‚Äêscale arrays of single nanoparticles, generated through either Dip Pen Nanolithography or Polymer Pen Lithography, allow for the discovery of novel nanomaterials at an unprecedented scale. The development of phase‚Äêseparating hydrophobic nanoreactors bypasses element‚Äêspecific chemistry limitations, enabling the synthesis of polyelemental metal and metal oxide nanoparticle megalibraries from at least 52 metal elements with an almost infinite number of chemical combinations in a single experiment.
Abstract Phase‚Äêseparating nanoreactors, generated through either Dip Pen Nanolithography (DPN)¬†or Polymer Pen Lithography (PPL) and capable of single nanoparticle formation, are compatible with almost every relevant element from the periodic table. This advance overcomes one of the most daunting limitations in high throughput materials discovery, specifically enabling the synthesis of broad swaths of the materials genome. Indeed, the platform is compatible with at least 52 metal elements of interest and almost an infinite number of combinations. In particular, it is discovered that surface‚Äêconfined, attoliter‚Äêvolume reactors made of polystyrene (PS) mixtures can be preloaded with metal salts spanning all but the alkali metals and subsequently transformed into single‚Äê or multi‚Äêcomponent nanoparticles of well‚Äêdefined dimensions. This is done in a three‚Äêstep process, which initially involves the facilitation of precursor precipitation and localization with toluene vapor, followed by plasma treatment to remove the polymer reactor component, and then heating from 400‚Äì900¬†¬∞C, depending upon precursor and desired end‚Äêstate (degree of reduction and crystallinity). These phase‚Äêseparating nanoreactors are used to produce metal and metal oxide nanoparticles, depending upon conditions, in a substrate‚Äêgeneral manner.

item.title: Enhanced Reversibility of Iron Metal Anode with a Solid Electrolyte Interphase in Concentrated Chloride Electrolytes
item.content:encoded:
The low plating‚Äêstripping Coulombic efficiency of the iron metal anode is a major barrier for next‚Äêgeneration Fe‚Äêion batteries. Introducing a high concentration of ZnCl2 to the FeCl2‚Äêbased electrolyte makes the solid‚Äêelectrolyte interphase‚Äêenabling dimethyl carbonate miscible to the electrolyte. The hybrid electrolyte exhibits an average Coulombic efficiency of 98.3% and a more stable cycle life.
Abstract Iron is a promising candidate for a cost‚Äêeffective anode for large‚Äêscale energy storage systems due to its natural abundance and well‚Äêestablished mass production. Recently, Fe‚Äêion batteries (FeIBs) that use ferrous ions as the charge carrier have emerged as a potential storage solution. The electrolytes in FeIBs are necessarily acidic to render the ferrous ions more anodically stable, allowing a wide operation voltage window. However, the iron anode suffers severe hydrogen evolution reaction with a low Coulombic efficiency (CE) in an acidic environment, shortening the battery cycle life. Herein, a hybrid aqueous electrolyte that forms a solid‚Äêelectrolyte interphase (SEI) layer on the Fe anode surface is introduced. The electrolyte mainly comprises FeCl2 and ZnCl2 as cosalts, where the Zn‚ÄêCl anionic complex species of the concentrated ZnCl2 allows dimethyl carbonate (DMC) to be miscible with the aqueous ferrous electrolyte. SEI derived from DMC's decomposition passivates the iron surface, which leads to an average CE of 98.3% and much‚Äêimproved cycling stability. This advancement shows the promise of efficient and durable FeIBs.

item.title: Localized and Controllable Mineral Salts Crystallization Enabled by Dye Modified Gold Nanorods with Enhanced Photothermal Conversion
item.content:encoded:
Hybrid materials with enhanced photostability and photothermal properties are prepared by modifying gold nanorods with tailored organic dyes, where plasmonic thermalization and nonradiative relaxation are effectively combined. Using the materials as a reusable energy converter, localized, and controllable photothermal crystallization of biorelevant mineral salts, including NaCl, CaCO3, BaCO3, and SrCO3, is realized using 638 nm laser light.
Abstract Well‚Äêdesigned nanomaterials with favorable photothermal performance are beneficial for exploring fascinating and prospective applications. Herein the facile and effective way is reported to enhance photothermal properties of gold nanorods (GNRs) through immobilizing tailored organic dyes around GNRs. Benefitting from the combination of plasmonic thermalization and nonradiative relaxation, the modified GNRs exhibit a temperature increase of >100¬†¬∞C under 638¬†nm laser irradiation in film state, which is double of that of the bare GNRs‚Äêdoped film under the same condition. The hybrid film also exhibits superior stability and reusability compared to the film only doped with the dyes. Surface temperature of the hybrid film can be adjusted from 31 to 116¬†¬∞C by tunning either doping materials concentration or light power. Interestingly, the hybrid film serves as a reusable energy converter in confined and controllable photothermal crystallization of mineral salts. NaCl crystals can be arranged into different patterns by moving the laser probe during the crystallization. Microcrystals of CaCO3 (calcite, vaterite, and aragonite), BaCO3, and SrCO3 are successfully obtained. It is believed that the as‚Äêprepared materials as well as the demonstrated photothermal crystallization will contribute to the development of function‚Äêled photothermal materials.

item.title: Manipulating Interfacial Water Via Metallic Pt1Co6 Sites on Self‚ÄêAdaptive Metal Phosphides to Enhance Water Electrolysis
item.content:encoded:
A unique electrocatalyst featuring singly dispersed Pt‚ÄìCo sites in a fully metallic state on nanoporous Co2P, which confers exceptional activity and durability for the hydrogen evolution reaction, enabling high‚Äêperformance anion‚Äêexchange‚Äêmembrane water electrolyser, is reported. Real‚Äêtime monitoring reveals that these sites self‚Äêadaptively distort under operating conditions to form a Pt1Co6 configuration with strongly negative charge, optimizing reactant binding and reorganizing the interfacial water structure.
Abstract Metallizing active sites to control the structural and kinetic dissociation of water at the catalyst‚Äìelectrolyte interface, along with elucidating its mechanism under operating conditions, is a pivotal innovation for the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER). Here, a design of singly dispersed Pt‚ÄìCo sites in a fully metallic state on nanoporous Co2P, tailored for HER, is introduced. An anion‚Äêexchange‚Äêmembrane water electrolyzer equipped with this catalyst can achieve the industrial current densities of 1.0 and 2.0 A cm‚àí2 at 1.71 and 1.85¬†V, respectively. It is revealed that the singly dispersed Pt‚ÄìCo sites undergo self‚Äêadaptive distortion under operating conditions, which form a Pt1Co6 configuration with a strongly negative charge that optimizes reactant binding and reorganizes the interfacial water structure, resulting in an improved concentration of potassium (K+) ions in the closest ion plane. The K+ ions interact cooperatively with H2O (K¬∑H2O), which strengthens the Pt‚ÄìH binding interaction and facilitates the polarization of the H‚îÄOH bond, leading to improved HER activity. This study not only propels the advancement of cathodic catalysts for water electrolysis but also delineates a metallization strategy and an interface design principle, thereby enhancing electrocatalytic reaction rates.

item.title: Oriented Assembly of 2D Metal‚ÄêPyridylporphyrinic Framework to Regulate the Redox Kinetics in Li‚àíS Batteries
item.content:encoded:
By connecting CoTPyP blocks with transition metal nodes, a class of bimetallic 2D MOFs are designed and synthesized. The prepared CoTPyP‚ÄêM MOFs enhanced the utilization of sulfur and smoothed the lithium deposition/stripping process. The central Co sites display strong interactions with sulfur species through Co‚àíS and Li‚àíN bonds, facilitating the cleavage of S‚àíS bond from both ends and promoting their conversion kinetics in Li‚àíS batteries.
Abstract Developing the highly efficient catalysts is a great challenge for accelerating the redox reactions in Li‚àíS batteries. Inspired by the single‚Äêatom catalysts and metalloproteins, it makes full use of the advantages of metal‚Äìorganic frameworks (MOFs) as electrocatalysts. Herein, a series of 2D metal‚Äêbonded metalloporphyrin MOFs are prepared with 5,10,15,20‚Äêtetrakis(4‚Äêpyridyl) cobalt porphyrin (CoTPyP) as building blocks and transition metals (M‚ïêMn, Fe, Co, Ni, and Cu) as nodes, respectively. The crystalline structures of the bimetallic 2D MOFs are confirmed by UV‚Äìvis spectra and X‚Äêray diffraction analyses. According to DFT calculation, the peripheral metal nodes optimize the electronic state of Co in porphyrin core. Especially, CoTPyP‚ÄêMn facilitates the cleavage of S‚àíS bond from both ends and promotes their conversion kinetics through Co‚àíS and Li‚àíN bonds. The Li‚àíS cells with CoTPyP‚ÄêMn show the initial specific capacity of 1339¬†mA h g‚àí1 at 0.2 C. The capacity decay rate is only 0.0442% per cycle after 1000 cycles at 2 C. This work achieves the rational control of the central Co d electron state through the peripheral regulation and enriches the application of MOFs in accelerating the redox kinetics in Li‚àíS batteries.

item.title: Highly Ordered Conductive Metal‚ÄêOrganic Frameworks with Chemically Confined Polyoxometalate Clusters: A Dual‚ÄêFunctional Electrocatalyst for Efficient H2O2 Synthesis and Biomass Valorization
item.content:encoded:
Chemically bonded conductive metal‚Äêorganic framework/polyoxometalate composites are synthesized as a high‚Äêperformance bifunctional electrocatalyst through a conserved ligand replacement strategy. Excellent performances with a H2O2 production rate of 9.51¬†mol¬†gcat‚àí1¬†h‚àí1 and 2, 5‚Äêfurandicarboxylic acid yield of 96.8% are achieved in an integrated electrolysis system of two‚Äêelectron oxygen reduction reaction coupling with 5‚Äêhydroxymethylfurfural oxidation reaction.
Abstract The design of bifunctional and high‚Äêperformance electrocatalysts that can be used as both cathodes and anodes for the two‚Äêelectron oxygen reduction reaction (2e‚àí ORR) and biomass valorization is attracting increasing attention. Herein, a conserved ligand replacement strategy is developed for the synthesis of highly ordered conductive metal‚Äêorganic frameworks (Ni‚ÄêHITP, HITP = 2, 3, 6, 7, 10, 11‚Äêhexaiminotriphenylene) with chemically confined phosphotungstic acid (PW12) nanoclusters in the nanopores. The newly formed Ni‚àíO‚àíW bonds in the resultant Ni‚ÄêHITP/PW12 electrocatalysts modulate the electronic structures of both Ni and W sites, which are favorable for cathodic 2e‚àí ORR to H2O2 production and anodic 5‚Äêhydroxymethylfurfural oxidation reaction (HMFOR) to 2, 5‚Äêfurandicarboxylic acid (FDCA), respectively. In combination with the deliberately retained conductive frameworks and ordered pores, the dual‚Äêfunctional Ni‚ÄêHITP/PW12 composites enable a H2O2 production rate of 9.51¬†mol¬†gcat‚àí1¬†h‚àí1 and an FDCA yield of 96.8% at a current density of 100¬†mA¬†cm‚àí2/cell voltage of 1.38¬†V in an integrated 2e‚àí ORR/HMFOR system, significantly improved than the traditional 2e‚àí ORR/oxygen evolution reaction system. This work has provided new insights into the rational design of advanced electrocatalysts and electrocatalytic systems for the green synthesis of valuable chemicals.

item.title: Twist‚ÄêAngle Controllable Transfer of 2D Materials via Water Vapor Intercalation
item.content:encoded:
This is a quasi‚Äêdry transfer technique assisted by water vapor intercalation (WVI), which can be effectively used to fabricate high‚Äêquality twisted heterostructures, including monolayer/few‚Äêlayer graphene and 2D quasicrystal‚Äêlike heterostructure. It also enables the fabrication of suspended 2DMs and high‚Äêperformance devices. This technique features excellent scalability, advancing fundamental research on 2DMs, and the fabrication of quantum devices with outstanding performance.
Abstract Transfer technique has become an indispensable process in the development of two‚Äêdimensional materials (2DMs) and their heterostructures, as it determines the quality of the interface and the performance of the resulting devices. However, how to flexibly and conveniently fabricate two‚Äêdimensional (2D) twisted heterostructures with high‚Äêquality interfaces has always been a formidable challenge. Here, a quasi‚Äêdry transfer technique assisted by water vapor intercalation (WVI) is developed, which can be flexibly used to fabricate twisted heterostructures. This method leverages a charged hydrophilic surface to facilitate WVI at the interface, enabling the clean and uniform detachment of 2DMs from the substrate. Using this method, the twisted monolayer/few‚Äêlayer graphene and 2D quasicrystal‚Äêlike WS2/MoS2, highlighting the surface/interface cleanness and angle‚Äêcontrolled transfer method is successfully fabricated. Besides, suspended structures of these 2DMs and heterostructures are fabricated, which offers substantial convenience for studying their intrinsic physical properties. Further, a high‚Äêperformance hBN/graphene/hBN superlattice device with the mobility of ‚âà199,000¬†cm2¬†V‚àí1¬†s‚àí1 at room temperature is fabricated. This transfer technique ingeniously combines the advantages of dry transfer and wet transfer. Moreover, it features excellent scalability, providing crucial technical support for future research on the fundamental physical properties of 2DMs and the fabrication of quantum devices with outstanding performance.

item.title: p‚ÄêœÄ Conjugated Covalent Organic Frameworks Expedite Molecular Triplet Excitons for H2O2 Production Coupled with Biomass Upgrading
item.content:encoded:
A fluorinated olefin‚Äêlinked triazine covalent organic framework photocatalyst is developed. The adjacent fluorine atom‚Äêolefinic bond forms p‚ÄìœÄ conjugation and expedites triplet excitons for activating O2 to 1O2 while accelerating charge separation, thus leading to high‚Äêefficiency photocatalytic O2 reduction to H2O2 and 5‚Äêhydroxymethylfurfural photo‚Äêoxidation upgrading.
Abstract High‚Äêefficiency production of triplet states in covalent organic framework photocatalysts is crucial for high‚Äêselectivity oxygen (O2)¬†reduction to hydrogen peroxide (H2O2). Herein, fluorine and partial fluorine atoms are incorporated into an olefin‚Äêlinked triazine covalent organic framework (F‚Äêol‚ÄêCOF and HF‚Äêol‚ÄêCOF), in which the adjacent fluorine (F) atoms‚Äêolefinic bond forms p‚ÄêœÄ conjugation that induces spin‚Äêpolarization under irradiation, thus expediting triplet excitons for activating O2 to singlet oxygen (1O2) and contributing to a high H2O2 selectivity (91%). Additionally, the feasibility of coupling H2O2 production with the valorization of 5‚Äêhydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) is exhibited. The F‚Äêol‚ÄêCOF demonstrates a highly stable H2O2 yield rate of 12558¬†¬µmol g‚àí1 h‚àí1 with the HMF‚Äêto‚Äêfunctionalized furan conversion yield of 95%, much higher than the partially fluorinated COF (HF‚Äêol‚ÄêCOF) and the non‚Äêfluorinated COF (H‚Äêol‚ÄêCOF). Mechanistic studies reveal that F‚Äêincorporation promotes charge separation, intensifies the Lewis acidity of the carbon atoms on the olefinic bond as active sites for O2 adsorption, and provides highly concentrated holes at the triazine unit for HMF oxidation upgrading. This study suggests the attractive potential of rational design of porous‚Äêcrystalline photocatalysts for high‚Äêefficiency photocatalytic O2 reduction to H2O2 and biomass upgrading.

item.title: Preventing Benzoquinone‚ÄêBased Catalyst Aggregation Enables the One‚ÄêStep Synthesis of Highly Conductive Poly(benzodifurandione) without Post‚ÄêReaction Purification
item.content:encoded:
Œ±‚ÄêTocopherylquinone (Œ±‚ÄêTQ), the oxidation product of Œ±‚Äêtocopherol (Œ±‚ÄêTOH), catalyzes the oxidative polymerization of 3,7‚Äêdihydrobenzo[1,2‚Äêb:4,5‚Äêb‚Ä≤]difuran‚Äê2,6‚Äêdione (HBFDO). The saturated aliphatic chiral side chain of Œ±‚ÄêTQ suppresses its crystallization, enabling high‚Äêconductivity polymer ink without needing post‚Äêpolymerization dialysis. This scalable method, tested in a 20 L reactor, yields ready‚Äêto‚Äêuse poly(benzodifurandione) (PBFDO) ink.
Abstract Conductive polymers have become crucial in advancing various electronic applications. While p‚Äêtype materials like poly(3,4‚Äêethylenedioxythiophene):polystyrene sulfonate (PEDOT:PSS) are widely used and produced at scale, the development of high‚Äêperformance n‚Äêtype polymers has lagged due to challenges in synthesis and scalability. In this work, a novel method is introduced to synthesize the highly conductive n‚Äêtype polymer poly(benzodifurandione) (PBFDO) using Œ±‚Äêtocopherylquinone (Œ±‚ÄêTQ) as a catalyst. This approach eliminates the need for post‚Äêreaction dialysis, a major obstacle to large‚Äêscale PBFDO production. By preventing catalyst aggregation, high electrical conductivity (>1320 S cm‚àí1) is achieved, which remains stable in air for over 180 d, significantly simplifying the process. The Œ±‚ÄêTQ‚Äêsynthesized PBFDO also exhibits excellent thermoelectric properties, with a power factor exceeding 100 ¬µW m‚àí1 K‚àí2, placing it among the highest‚Äêperforming n‚Äêtype thermoelectric polymers. Additionally, residual Œ±‚ÄêTQ acts as a plasticizer, reducing the elastic modulus by over tenfold while maintaining high conductivity, making this material suitable for mechanically compliant electronics. Similarly, residual Œ±‚ÄêTQ lowers the thermal conductivity of PBFDO by more than an order of magnitude. The process is scalable, as demonstrated by producing high‚Äêconductivity ink in a 20 L reactor. This work presents an efficient and sustainable approach for large‚Äêscale n‚Äêtype polymer production.

item.title: A 2D/3D Heterostructure Perovskite Solar Cell with a Phase‚ÄêPure and Pristine 2D Layer
item.content:encoded:
A simple solution‚Äêbased method that can achieve pristine (without residual 2D precursors) and phase‚Äêpure 2D/3D perovskite heterostructure without the need for synthesizing a single crystal is developed. Perovskite solar cells with this treatment demonstrate a notable improvement in both power conversion efficiency and long‚Äêterm stability, with negligible hysteresis, compared to the conventional process.
Abstract Interface engineering plays a critical role in advancing the performance of perovskite solar cells. As such, 2D/3D perovskite heterostructures are of particular interest due to their optoelectrical properties and their further potential improvements. However, for conventional solution‚Äêprocessed 2D perovskites grown on an underlying 3D perovskite, the reaction stoichiometry is normally unbalanced with excess precursors. Moreover, the formed 2D perovskite is impure, leading to unfavorable energy band alignment at the interface. Here a simple method is presented that solves both issues simultaneously. The 2D formation reaction is taken first to completion, fully consuming excess PbI2. Then, isopropanol is utilized to remove excess organic ligands, control the 2D perovskite thickness, and obtain a phase‚Äêpure, n = 2, 2D perovskite. The outcome is a pristine (without residual 2D precursors) and phase‚Äêpure 2D perovskite heterostructure with improved surface passivation and charge carrier extraction compared to the conventional solution process. PSCs incorporating this treatment demonstrate a notable improvement in both stability and power conversion efficiency, with negligible hysteresis, compared to the conventional process.

item.title: Organic Photoelectrochemical Multisensory Integration
item.content:encoded:
This work reports an OPECT‚Äêbased chemical MSI with multisensory perception, multimodal synaptic plasticity, and typical MSI features in electrolytes. The advanced MSI device is then used to mimic the associative learning and reflex activities of visual and gustatory stimuli with the associated feedback loops. This work may provide new insight into the development of highly biomimetic MSI in biological fluids for seamless neuro‚Äêrobotic systems.
Abstract Neuromorphic perception capable of multisensory integration (MSI) in electrolytes is important but remains challenging. Here, the aqueous implementation of artificial MSI is reported based on the newly emerged organic photoelectrochemical transistor (OPECT) by representative visual (light)‚Äêgustatory (sour) perception. Under the co‚Äêmodulation of light and H+/OH‚àí, multisensory synaptic plasticity and several typical MSI characteristics are mimicked, including ‚Äúsuper‚Äêadditive response,‚Äù ‚Äúinverse effectiveness effect‚Äù and ‚Äútemporal congruency.‚Äù To demonstrate its potential usage, different types of multisensory associative learning and corresponding reflex activities are further emulated. The chemical MSI system is also utilized to control artificial salivation by a closed loop of real‚Äêtime perception, processing, integration, and actuation to emulate the biological responses toward external stimuli. In contrast to previous solid‚Äêstate operations, this work offers a new strategy for developing neuromorphic MSI in aqueous environments that are analogous to those in biology.

item.title: Giant Non‚ÄêSaturating Exchange Striction in a Noncollinear Antiferromagnet
item.content:encoded:
High‚Äêquality single crystals of the noncollinear antiferromagnet Mn3Sn are synthesized, and a non‚Äêsaturating magnetostriction exceeding 400¬†ppm under 57 T is observed, surpassing the giant magnetostriction materials such as FeGa. The theoretical analyses indicate that this pronounced non‚Äêsaturating magnetostriction stems from an exotic exchange striction mechanism, which facilitates a linear relationship between strain output and applied magnetic field.
Abstract Magnetostriction, discovered by Joule in 1842, refers to the mechanical strain that a material undergoes in the presence of a magnetic field. Conventionally, it originates from the spin‚Äêorbit coupling and has been predominantly explored in ferromagnets. In this work, a giant magnetostriction effect is reported in the high‚Äêquality single crystal of a noncollinear antiferromagnet Mn3Sn. Non‚Äêsaturating magnetostriction exceeding 400¬†ppm is obtained, which is even larger than the saturation values of the well‚Äêknown Fe‚Äêbased giant magnetostriction ferromagnetic materials such as FeGa. Theoretical calculations reveal that the large non‚Äêsaturating magnetostriction results from a sophisticated exchange striction effect of the noncollinear antiferromagnetic spin structure, leading to a nearly linear dependence of the strain output on the applied magnetic field. This work provides an unprecedented strategy to design next‚Äêgeneration magnetoelastic materials with noncollinear compensated spin structures.

item.title: Efficient H2O2 Electrosynthesis in Acidic media via Multiscale Catalyst Optimization
item.content:encoded:
This research introduces an innovative octahedron‚Äêlike cobalt structure embedded in hierarchical porous nanofibers, significantly optimizing hydrogen peroxide production in acidic environments. Achieving 80% faradaic efficiency at 400¬†mA cm‚àí2 and maintaining stable operation over 120 h at 100¬†mA cm‚àí2, this approach provides a scalable and sustainable pathway to enhance industrial hydrogen peroxide generation.
Abstract Electrochemically generating hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) from oxygen offers a more sustainable and cost‚Äêeffective alternative to conventional anthraquinone process. In alkaline conditions, H2O2 is unstable as HO2‚àí, and in neutral electrolytes, alkali cation crossover causes system instability.
