However, the low mechanical strength can compromise their stability under high stress, making the material susceptible to fracture in complex or harsh environments. Achieving a balance between conductivity and mechanical robustness remains a critical challenge. In this study, super‚Äêrobust conductive hydrogels were designed and developed with highly oriented structures and densified networks, by employing techniques such as stretch‚Äêdrying‚Äêinduced directional assembly, salting‚Äêout, and ionic crosslinking. The hydrogels showed remarkable mechanical property (tensile strength: 17.13‚Äì142.1¬†MPa; toughness: 50¬†MJ¬†m‚àí3), high conductivity (30.1 S¬†m‚àí1), and reliable strain sensing performance. Additionally, it applied this hydrogel material to fabricate biomimetic electronic skin device, significantly improving signal quality and device stability. By integrating the device with 1D convolutional neural network algorithm, it further developed a real‚Äêtime material recognition system based on triboelectric and piezoresistive signal collection, achieving a classification accuracy of up to 99.79% across eight materials. This study predicted the potential of the high‚Äêperformance conductive hydrogels for various applications in flexible smart wearables, the Internet of Things, bioelectronics, and bionic robotics.

item.title: Stacked Scintillators Based Multispectral X‚ÄêRay Imaging Featuring Quantum‚ÄêCutting Perovskite Scintillators With 570 nm Absorption‚ÄêEmission Shift
item.content:encoded:
A new design strategy is introduced to eliminate mutual excitation in stacked scintillator detectors by rare earth ions doped quantum‚Äêcutting scintillators with a significant absorption‚Äêemission shift as the top layer. The developed detector features non‚Äêoverlapping optical absorption and RL emission spectra, improving the discrimination of materials with similar densities.
Abstract Traditional energy‚Äêintegration X‚Äêray imaging systems rely on total X‚Äêray intensity for image contrast, ignoring energy‚Äêspecific information. Recently developed multilayer stacked scintillators have enabled multispectral, large‚Äêarea flat‚Äêpanel X‚Äêray imaging (FPXI), enhancing material discrimination capabilities. However, increased layering can lead to¬†mutual excitation, which may affect the accurate discrimination of X‚Äêray energy. This issue is tackled by proposing a novel design strategy utilizing rare earth ions doped quantum‚Äêcutting scintillators as the top layer. These scintillators create new luminescence centers via energy transfer, resulting in a significantly larger absorption‚Äêemission shift, as well as the potential to double the photoluminescence quantum yield (PLQY) and enhance light output. To verify this concept, a three‚Äêlayer stacked scintillator detector is developed using ytterbium ions (Yb3+)‚Äêdoped CsPbCl3 perovskite nanocrystals (PeNCs) as the top layer, which offers a high PLQY of over 100% and a significant absorption‚Äêemission shift of 570¬†nm. This configuration, CsAgCl2 and Cs3Cu2I5 as the middle and bottom layers, respectively, ensures non‚Äêoverlapping optical absorption and radioluminescence (RL) emission spectra. By calculating the optimal thickness for each layer to absorb specific X‚Äêray energies, the detector demonstrates distinct absorption differences across various energy bands, enhancing the identification of materials with similar densities.

item.title: Cycloolefin Copolymers With a Multiply Rigid Structure for Protecting Triplet Exciton From Thermo‚Äê and Moisture‚ÄêQuenching
item.content:encoded:
Cycloolefin copolymers bearing hydroxyl, ester, and adamantanyl side groups are synthesized. Upon dispersing various phosphors into this polymer matrix, the resultant composites exhibit full‚Äêcolor room temperature phosphorescence with lifetimes of 249‚Äì590 ms, showing no obvious luminescence quenching in water, acid, alkalinous, reductive, and oxidative environments.
Abstract Polymeric room temperature phosphorescence (RTP) materials have been well developed and utilized in various fields. However, their fast thermo‚Äê and moisture‚Äêquenching behavior highly limit their applications in certain harsh environments. Therefore, the preparation of materials with thermo‚Äê and moisture‚Äêresistant phosphorescence is greatly attractive. Compared with common water‚Äêsoluble polymers, cycloolefin copolymers (COC) show outstanding hydrophobicity and higher rigidity, even at elevated temperatures, being as a promising candidate to prepare phosphorescence materials with suppressed thermo‚Äê and moisture‚Äêquenching behavior. Herein, a type of COC bearing hydroxyl, ester, and adamantanyl side groups is synthesized. After dispersing various phosphors into this matrix, the resultant composites exhibit full‚Äêcolor RTP with lifetimes of 249‚Äì590 ms. Their luminescence does not show obvious quenching in water, acid, alkalinous, reductive, and oxidative environments. In the presence of both rigid COC matrix and rigid phosphors, the corresponding composite displays high‚Äêtemperature phosphorescence performance. Even at 378 K, the composite can emit phosphorescence with a lifetime of 40‚Äì98 ms. The applications of these COC‚Äêbased composites for imaging, information encryption, and anti‚Äêcounterfeiting are thus explored.

item.title: Stretchable Blue Phase Liquid Crystal Lasers with Optical Stability Based on Small‚ÄêStrain Nonlinear 3D Asymmetric Deformation
item.content:encoded:
A single‚Äêpeak stretchable BPLC laser is fabricated based on partially and fully crosslinked networks due to the slow variation of lattice orientation under small strains. The laser exhibits a tuning range of 44.429¬†nm at 32% strain, providing stable output over a broad‚Äê temperature range with 3D circularly polarized emission under small strains, presenting the potential applications in 3D mechanical perception.
Abstract Blue phase liquid crystal (BPLC) lasers exhibit exceptional optical quality and tunability to external stimuli, holding significant promise for innovative developments in the field of flexible optoelectronics. However, there remain challenges for BPLC elastomer (BPLCE) lasers in maintaining good optical stability during stretching and varying temperature conditions. In this work, a stretchable laser is developed based on a well‚Äêdesigned BPLCE with a combination of partially and fully crosslinked networks, which can output a single‚Äêpeak laser under small deformation (44.429¬†nm lasing shift at 32% strain) and a broad‚Äêtemperature range (from ‚àí20 to 100¬†¬∞C). The superior performance can be attributed to the nonlinear 3D asymmetric deformation exhibited by the BPI lattice during stretching, particularly at low deformation rates below 40% strain, which effectively maintains the stability of the body‚Äêcentered cubic structure (with the maximum strain of this BPLCE up to 220%). Moreover, the BPLCE exhibits excellent thermal stability over a temperature range from ‚àí180 to 70¬†¬∞C with a stopband shift of less than ¬±10¬†nm. As a proof‚Äêof‚Äêconcept, the application of BPLCE laser for morphology sensing and 3D mechanical perception is demonstrated, which paves the way for potential applications of flexible optoelectronics.

item.title: Coaxial Direct Ink Writing of Cholesteric Liquid Crystal Elastomers in 3D Architectures
item.content:encoded:
A low‚Äêviscosity cholesteric liquid crystal (CLC) ink and a silicone ink are prepared for coaxial direct ink writing of 3D strain sensors. The silicone shell supports the CLC core to enable layer‚Äêby‚Äêlayer printing in addition to enhancing the mechanical properties of the core. Monostable and bistable thin‚Äêshell domes are printed to demonstrate the 3D printing capabilities and mechanochromic behaviors.
Abstract Cholesteric liquid crystal elastomers (CLCEs) hold great promise for mechanochromic applications in anti‚Äêcounterfeiting, smart textiles, and soft robotics, thanks to the structural color and elasticity. While CLCEs are printed via direct ink writing (DIW) to fabricate free‚Äêstanding films, complex 3D structures are not fabricated due to the opposing rheological properties necessary for cholesteric alignment and multilayer stacking. Here, 3D CLCE structures are realized by utilizing coaxial DIW to print a CLC ink within a silicone ink. By tailoring the ink compositions, and thus, the rheological properties, the cholesteric phase rapidly forms without an annealing step, while the silicone shell provides encapsulation and support to the CLCE core, allowing for layer‚Äêby‚Äêlayer printing of self‚Äêsupported 3D structures. As a demonstration, free‚Äêstanding bistable thin‚Äêshell domes are printed. Color changes due to compressive and tensile stresses can be witnessed from the top and bottom of the inverted domes, respectively. When the domes are arranged in an array and inverted, they can snap back to their base state by uniaxial stretching, thereby functioning as mechanical sensors with memory. The additive manufacturing platform enables the rapid fabrication of 3D mechanochromic sensors thereby expanding the realm of potential applications for CLCEs.

item.title: Local Structure Distortion in Mn, Zn Doped Cu‚ÇÇV‚ÇÇO‚Çá: Supercapacitor Performance and Emergent Spin‚ÄêPhonon Coupling
item.content:encoded:
Mn/Zn co‚Äêdoping in Œ±‚ÄêCu‚ÇÇV‚ÇÇO‚Çá induces local structure distortions, enhancing supercapacitor performance (Specific capacitance‚Äê1950.95¬†Fg‚Åª¬π; Energy density‚Äê97.54¬†Whkg‚Åª¬π) and cycling stability. Spin‚Äêphonon coupling and superior magnetic properties enable thermo‚Äêmagnetic applications. A prototype device powers LED bulbs, demonstrating real‚Äêworld energy storage potential. This work integrates energy storage and spintronics, offering a transformative approach for advanced multifunctional materials.
Abstract Supercapacitors are rapidly gaining attention as next‚Äêgeneration energy storage devices due to their superior power and energy densities. This study pioneers the investigation of Mn/Zn co‚Äêdoping in Œ±‚ÄêCu‚ÇÇV‚ÇÇO‚Çá (CVO) to enhance its performance as a supercapacitor electrode material. Structural and local Structural properties of Mn/Zn co‚Äêdoped CVO have been investigated through X‚Äêray Diffraction (XRD), Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM), Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM), X‚Äêray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS), and X‚Äêray Absorption Spectroscopy (XAS), revealing significant distortions that enhance supercapacitor performance. The optimized sample demonstrates a remarkable specific capacitance of 1950.95¬†Fg‚àí1, energy density of 97.54¬†Whkg‚àí1, and enhanced capacitive retention, attributed to the unique Cu coordination environment and improved charge transfer kinetics. Temperature‚Äêdependent Raman spectroscopy unveils spin‚Äêphonon coupling (SPC), particularly in VO‚ÇÑ stretching modes, supported by magnetic measurements that shows a reduction in the N√©el temperature and the emergence of zero field‚Äêcooled (ZFC) exchange bias (EB). This work is the first to report the impact of local structure distortion on both supercapacitor performance and SPC in CVO, offering a novel strategy for developing high‚Äêperformance energy storage materials with spintronics potential. In addition, the assembled symmetric optimized supercapacitor shows a high energy density of 93.32¬†Whkg‚àí1 and excellent cycling stability. A prototype device incorporating the optimized CVO successfully powers eight commercial LED bulbs, demonstrating its practical application potential.

item.title: Constructing Anion Solvation Microenvironment Toward Durable High‚ÄêVoltage Sodium‚ÄêBased Batteries
item.content:encoded:
The anion solvation structure is regulated by constructing a high‚Äêsalt concentration microenvironment, which maintains highly oxidation‚Äêresistant contact ion pairs and ion aggregation. The tailored solvation structure assists in the formation of robust electrode‚Äêelectrolyte interphase, restraining the electrolyte oxidation and solvent co‚Äêintercalation at high voltage, which promotes the rate capability and cycling stability of SDIBs over 10¬†000 cycles.
Abstract Sodium‚Äêbased rechargeable batteries are some of the most promising candidates for electric energy storage with abundant sodium reserves, particularly, sodium‚Äêbased dual‚Äêion batteries (SDIBs) perform advantages in high work voltage (‚âà5.0¬†V), high‚Äêpower density, and potentially low cost. However, irreversible electrolyte decomposition and co‚Äêintercalation of solvent molecules at the electrode interface under a high charge state are blocking their development. Herein, a high‚Äêsalt concentration microenvironment is created and proposed by tailoring the solvation structures of charge carriers including both cations and anions, which maintains highly oxidation‚Äêresistant contact ion pairs and ion aggregates and provides a high ion conductivity. The tailored solvation structure makes a great contribution to protecting the graphite cathode from electrolyte oxidation, solvent co‚Äêintercalation, and structural degradation by constructing a robust cathode‚Äêelectrolyte interphase with standout electrochemical stability. Based on this, the SDIBs achieved an excellent high‚Äêvoltage cycling stability with 81% capacity retention after 10¬†000 cycles and the battery showed an improved rate performance with 97.4 mAh g‚àí1 maintained at 100¬†C. It is identified that regulating anion solvation structure is responsible for the stable interface chemistry and enhanced reaction kinetics, which provides deep insight into the compatibility design between the electrolyte and specialized charge storage in electrodes.

item.title: Broadband Near‚ÄêInfrared Fibers Derived from Nanocrystal‚ÄêGlass Composites for Miniature Arrays Light Sources
item.content:encoded:
The design synthesis of highly efficient Cr3+‚Äêdoped broadband near‚Äêinfrared (NIR) nanocrystal‚Äêglass composite (NGC) and the following NGC fiber fabrication for the miniature array light sources is innovated, facilitating the convergence of fluorescence imaging and all‚Äêfiber endoscopy systems.
Abstract Broadband near‚Äêinfrared (NIR) fiber arrays are highly desirable for multiplexed fluorescence endoscopic, however, there is a challenge for the development of miniature light sources with highly efficient broadband NIR emissions. Here the synthesis of a MgAl2O4:Cr3+ nanocrystal‚Äêglass composite (NGC) with an Cr3+‚Äêclusters‚Äêinduced broadband NIR emission possessing is presented and external quantum efficiency of 44% and a full width at half maximum of 297¬†nm, and the NGC fiber is further fabricated through a template solidification strategy, resulting in the construction of an all‚Äêfiber coupling system by fusing them with commercial quartz fiber that achieves an optical coupling efficiency of 95.2%. Furthermore, these NGC fibers are regularly arranged into fiber bundle as an array light source to enhance NIR luminescence and imaging ability, and the fluorescence imaging of 4¬†mm biological tissue penetration is realized, as well as the multiplexed fluorescence imaging, under the irradiation of the NIR fiber bundle. This study provides general and efficient fiber fabrication guidelines toward NIR array light sources, opening the new routes for fluorescence endoscopes.

item.title: Colloidal Quantum‚ÄêDot Heterojunction Imagers for Room‚ÄêTemperature Thermal Imaging
item.content:encoded:
Room‚Äêtemperature operation or high‚Äêoperation temperature (HOT) is essential for mid‚Äêwave infrared (MWIR) optoelectronics devices providing low‚Äêcost and compact systems for numerous applications. A band‚Äêengineered mercury telluride colloidal quantum dot (HgTe CQD) heterojunction with suppressed dark current is developed and demonstrates sensitive thermal imaging above 250¬†K with a resolution of 640¬†√ó¬†512.
Abstract Room‚Äêtemperature operation or high‚Äêoperation temperature (HOT) is essential for mid‚Äêwave infrared (MWIR) optoelectronics devices providing low‚Äêcost and compact systems for numerous applications. Colloidal quantum dots (CQDs) have emerged as a rising candidate to enable photodetectors to operate at HOT or room temperature and develop the next‚Äêgeneration infrared focal plane array (FPA) imagers. Here, band‚Äêengineered heterojunctions are demonstrated to suppress dark current with well‚Äêpassivated mercury telluride (HgTe) CQDs enabling room‚Äêtemperature MWIR imaging by single‚Äêpixel scanning and 640¬†√ó¬†512 FPA sensitive thermal imaging above 250¬†K. As a result, the room‚Äêtemperature detectivity reaches as high as 1.26¬†√ó¬†1010 Jones, and the noise equivalent temperature difference (NETD) is as good as 25¬†mK up to 200¬†K.

item.title: In‚Äêdevice Battery Failure Analysis
item.content:encoded:
This study analyzes the failure of wireless earbud batteries within their intended usage context. By examining degradations from the material to device level, it reveals that failure patterns are linked to device configuration and operating conditions. The interplay of battery materials, structural design, and microenvironmental factors like temperature gradients offer crucial insights for improving battery integration and reliability.
Abstract Lithium‚Äêion batteries are indispensable power sources for a wide range of modern electronic devices. However, battery lifespan remains a critical limitation, directly affecting the sustainability and user experience. Conventional battery failure analysis in controlled lab settings may not capture the complex interactions and environmental factors encountered in real‚Äêworld, in‚Äêdevice operating conditions. This study analyzes the failure of commercial wireless earbud batteries as a model system within their intended usage context. Through multiscale and multimodal characterizations, the degradations from the material level to the device level are correlated, elucidating a failure pattern that is closely tied to the specific device configuration and operating conditions. The findings indicate that the ultimate failure mode is determined by the interplay of battery materials, cell structural design, and the in‚Äêdevice microenvironment, such as temperature gradients and their fluctuations. This holistic, in‚Äêdevice perspective on environmental influences provides critical insights for battery integration design, enhancing the reliability of modern¬†electronics.

item.title: Vertical Memristive Crossbar Array for Multilayer Graph Embedding and Analysis
item.content:encoded:
To address the challenge of embedding multilayer graphs with minimal complexity and information loss, this study introduces a vertical m‚ÄêCBA (vm‚ÄêCBA) capable of directly mapping multilayer relationships. By accurately representing inter‚Äêlayer and intra‚Äêlayer connections in three dimensions, vm‚ÄêCBA outperforms conventional embeddings in link prediction and information scores while requiring fewer operations.
Abstract Graph data structures effectively represent objects and their relationships, enabling the modeling of complex connections in various fields. Recent work demonstrate that metal at diagonal crossbar arrays (m‚ÄêCBA) can effectively represent planar graphs. However, they are unsuitable for representing multilayer graphs having multiple relationships across different layers. Using conventional software, embedding multilayer graphs in high‚Äêdimensional Euclidean spaces introduces significant mathematical complexity and computational burden, often resulting in information loss. This study proposes a unique graph embedding (mapping) method utilizing a fabricated vertical m‚ÄêCBA (vm‚ÄêCBA), where a custom‚Äêbuilt measurement system thoroughly validated its functionality. This structure directly maps multilayer graphs into a 3D vm‚ÄêCBA, accurately representing inter‚Äêlayer and intra‚Äêlayer connections. The practical link prediction and information scores across various real‚Äêworld datasets demonstrated that vm‚ÄêCBA achieved enhanced accuracy compared to conventional embeddings, even with a significantly decreased number of operations.

item.title: Ultrathin Rare‚ÄêEarth Oxyhalides as High‚ÄêŒ∫ van der Waals Layered Dielectrics
item.content:encoded:
A class of ultrathin GdOX with a high dielectric constant and breakdown field strength is synthesized via van der Waals epitaxy. The fabricated MoS2 transistor gated by monocrystalline dielectric exhibits an on/off current ratio exceeding 109 and a near‚ÄêBoltzmann‚Äêlimit SS, indicating their tangible applications in 2D electronics.
Abstract Van der Waals (vdW) dielectrics are extensively employed to enhance the performance of 2D electronic devices. However, current vdW dielectric materials still encounter challenges such as low dielectric constant (Œ∫) and difficulties in synthesizing high‚Äêquality single crystals. 2D rare‚Äêearth oxyhalides (REOXs) with exceptional electrical properties present an opportunity for the exploration of novel high‚ÄêŒ∫ dielectrics. In this study, for the first time, the synthesis of a series of van der Waals layered gadolinium oxyhalides with thicknesses down to monolayer through a space‚Äêconfined vdW epitaxy approach and demonstrating their application as a single‚Äêcrystalline gate dielectric is reported. It exhibits a remarkable relative dielectric constant exceeding 17 and an impressive breakdown field strength of 13.5¬†MV¬†cm‚àí1. The 2D transistors directly gated by the REOXs layer exhibit enhanced electron mobility and a low interface trap density. An ultrahigh on/off current ratio of 109 and a near‚ÄêBoltzmann‚Äêlimit subthreshold swing is achieved. The superior dielectric properties, combined with the universality and scalability of the production method (e.g., millimeter‚Äêscale films are achieved), demonstrate that 2D REOXs can serve as promising gate dielectrics for 2D electronics, thereby expanding the study of high‚ÄêŒ∫ vdW materials and potentially providing new opportunities for the development of low‚Äêpower electronic devices.

item.title: Mechanochemical Synthesis of Type III Porous Liquids from Solid Precursors for the Removal and Conversion of Waste CO2 from CH4
item.content:encoded:
A scalable mechanochemical synthetic approach is reported to fabricate Type III PLs from solid precursors. Owing to the presence of multiple interfacial hydrogen and coordination bonds, these PLs not only maintain porosity and fluidity with high stability, enabling efficient CH4 purification by CO2 removal and sequestration, but also facilitate the catalytic conversion of stored CO2 into valuable products.
Abstract Porous liquids (PLs) have emerged as a promising class of flow porous materials, offering distinctive benefits for sustainable separation processes coupled with catalytic transformations in the chemical industry. Despite their potential, challenges remain in the realms of synthesis complexity, stability, and the strategic engineering of separation and catalytic sites. In this study, a scalable mechanochemical synthetic approach is reported to fabricate Type III PLs from solid precursors with high stability. In these Type III PLs, ZIF‚Äê8 nanocrystals are dispersed in the deep eutectic solvents formed by solid hydrogen‚Äêbond donors and acceptors. Owing to the presence of multiple interfacial hydrogen and coordination bonds, these PLs not only maintain porosity and fluidity with high stability, enabling efficient CH4 purification by CO2 removal and sequestration, but also facilitate the catalytic conversion of stored CO2 into valuable products under ambient conditions. This strategy advances the green production of stable and well‚Äêdispersed PLs, showing the potential of PLs in the sustainable separation and catalysis coupling system in the chemical industry.

item.title: Strain Release via Glass Transition Temperature Regulation for Efficient and Stable Perovskite Solar Cells
item.content:encoded:
A Tg (glass transition temperature) regulation (TR) strategy is developed to effectively release residual strain in the perovskite film through adjusting the ratio of monomeric additives. The resulting film exhibits significantly reduced tensile strain, decreased trap density and superior stability. The optimized perovskite solar cells achieve a high efficiency of 26.15% (certified as 25.59%) and excellent stability.
Abstract Thermally induced tensile strain that remains in perovskite films after annealing is one of the key reasons for diminishing the performance and operational stability of perovskite solar cells (PSCs). Herein, a glass transition temperature (Tg) regulation (TR) strategy is developed by introducing two polymerizable monomers, 2‚Äê(N‚Äê3‚ÄêSulfopropyl‚ÄêN,N‚Äêdimethyl ammonium)ethyl methacrylate (SBMA) and 2‚ÄêHydroxyethyl acrylate (HEA), into the perovskite layer. SBMA and HEA undergo in situ polymerization, which regulates the nucleation and crystal growth of the perovskite film. In addition, adjusting the ratio of SBMA and HEA to lower the Tg of the resulting polymer effectively releases the strain in the perovskite film. The modified film exhibits significantly reduced tensile strain, decreased trap density and improved stability. As a result, the optimized PSCs achieve a champion power conversion efficiency (PCE) of 26.15% (certified as 25.59%). Furthermore, the encapsulated device demonstrates prominent enhanced operation stability, maintaining 90.3% of its initial efficiency after 500¬†h of continuous sunlight exposure.

item.title: Fluid Control of Dip Coating for Efficient Large‚ÄêArea Organic Solar Cells
item.content:encoded:
Dip coating is employed to fabricate large‚Äêarea organic solar cells. By controlling the fluid characteristics, the correlation among Van der Waals forces in precursor film, aggregation state of polymer, and fibrous orientation in active layer is revealed. Consequently, the dip‚Äêcoated 1.0 cm2 rigid and 10.0 cm2 flexible cells exhibit the efficiencies of 17.9% and 13.7%, respectively.
Abstract As a classical low‚Äêcost technique, dip coating has not been used for printable electronics. Here, the study demonstrates large‚Äêarea organic solar cells can be made by dip coating. The correlation is revealed among Van der Waals forces in precursor film, aggregation state of polymer, and fibrous orientation in active layer; the relationship is also expounded between fluid mechanics of the confined liquid in polymer scaffold and the continuity of the acceptor phase. By controlling the fluid characteristics, the ideal nanoscale bicontinuous interpenetrating network forms. As a result, the 1.0 cm2 rigid and 10.0 cm2 flexible cells exhibit efficiencies of 17.9% and 13.7%, respectively. Moreover, the method for predicting the optimal coating speed for the dip coating of given inks is proposed. Overall, this work not only demonstrates the superiority of dip coating for organic solar cell fabrication but also provides guidance for its application in printable electronics.

item.title: Observation of Real‚ÄêTime Spin‚ÄêOrbit Torque Driven Dynamics in Antiferromagnetic Thin Film
item.content:encoded:
Antiferromagnetic dynamics in nanometer‚Äêthick LaFeO‚ÇÉ films is unveiled using time‚Äêresolved Kerr effect, demonstrating ultra‚Äêlow damping and spin‚Äêorbit torque manipulation. This study provides an experimental validation of theoretical predictions, offering new insights into nanoscale spintronic systems. The exceptional material quality enables precise probing of dynamics, bridging the gap between antiferromagnetic materials and practical applications in ultrafast spintronics.
Abstract In the burgeoning field of spintronics, antiferromagnetic materials (AFMs) are attracting significant attention for their potential to enable ultra‚Äêfast, energy‚Äêefficient devices. Thin films of AFMs are particularly promising for practical applications due to their compatibility with spin‚Äêorbit torque (SOT) mechanisms. However, studying these thin films presents challenges, primarily due to the weak signals they produce and the rapid dynamics driven by SOT, that are too fast for conventional electric transport or microwave techniques to capture. The time‚Äêresolved magneto‚Äêoptical Kerr effect (TR‚ÄêMOKE) has been a successful tool for probing antiferromagnetic dynamics in bulk materials, thanks to its sub‚Äêpicosecond (sub‚Äêps) time resolution. Yet, its application to nanometer‚Äêscale thin films has been limited by the difficulty of detecting weak signals in such small volumes. In this study, the first successful observation of antiferromagnetic dynamics are presented in nanometer‚Äêthick orthoferrite films using the pump‚Äêprobe technique to detect TR‚ÄêMOKE signal. This paper report an exceptionally low damping constant of 1.5 √ó 10‚àí4 and confirms the AFM magnonic nature of these dynamics through angular‚Äêdependent measurements. Furthermore, it is observed that electrical currents can potentially modulate these dynamics via SOT. The¬†findings lay the groundwork for developing tunable, energy‚Äêefficient spintronic devices, paving the way for advancements in next‚Äêgeneration spintronic applications.

item.title: Dimensional Regulation of Organic n‚ÄêType Dopants for Highly Efficient Perovskite Solar Cells and Modules
item.content:encoded:
A dimensional regulation strategy of organic dopants is developed to fabricate high‚Äêperformance inverted perovskite solar cells. Selenium has a strong electron‚Äêdonating ability, which can transfer electrons to perovskites. Specially, 2D‚Äêperylene diimide can coat the perovskite crystal to form a lattice cage through their conjugate skeletons, which passivates the trap states, improves the n‚Äêdoping efficiency, and restrains ion migration.
Abstract A strong n‚Äêtype perovskite layer is crucial in achieving high open‚Äêcircuit voltage (VOC) and power conversion efficiency (PCE) in the p‚Äêi‚Äên solar cells, as the weak n‚Äêtype perovskites result in a loss of VOC, and the p‚Äêtype perovskites contain numerous electron traps that cause the severe carrier recombination. Here, three types of perylene diimide (PDI) based small molecule dopants with different dimensions, including 1D‚ÄêPDI, 2D‚ÄêPDI, and 3D‚ÄêPDI are designed, to produce heavier n‚Äêtype perovskites. The PDI‚Äêbased molecules with Selenium atoms have a strong electron‚Äêdonating ability, effectively enlarging the quasi‚ÄêFermi level splitting within the perovskites. Besides, the PDI molecules can coat the surface of the perovskite crystal to form the lattice cage through their conjugate skeletons, which passivates the trap states and improves the n‚Äêdoping efficiency, as well as the stabilities of perovskites and related devices. With the addition of the 2D‚ÄêPDI, the small‚Äêarea solar cells achieved a PCE of 26.06% (25.44% certified) with a high VOC of 1.18¬†V and a remarkable fill factor of 87.23%. Furthermore, the rigid and flexible perovskite solar modules yielded high PCEs of 21.48% and 20.71%, respectively. This dimensional regulation strategy provides useful guidance for effective n‚Äêtype doping and high‚Äêperformance p‚Äêi‚Äên solar cells.

item.title: High Entropy Fine‚ÄêTuning Achieves Fast Li+ Kinetics in High‚ÄêPerformance Co‚ÄêFree High‚ÄêNi Layered Cathodes
item.content:encoded:
This work provides an efficient and versatile high‚Äêentropy doping strategy. The synergistic effect between high‚Äêentropy dopant elements is optimized by compositional fine‚Äêtuning to overcome the kinetic hysteresis and high reactivity problems that have hindered the development of Co‚Äêfree Ni‚Äêrich cathode materials. Excellent long‚Äêcycle stability under fast charging and discharging conditions is achieved.
Abstract Co‚Äêfree high‚ÄêNi layered cathode materials LiNixMeyO2 (Me = Mn, Mg, Al, etc.) are a key part of the next‚Äêgeneration high‚Äêenergy lithium‚Äêion batteries (LIBs) due to their high specific capacity and low cost. However, the hindered Li+ kinetics and the high reactivity of Ni4+ result in poor rate performance and unsatisfied cycling stability. This work designs a promising strategy for designing a high‚Äêperformance high‚Äêentropy doping Co‚Äêfree high‚ÄêNi layered cathode LiNi0.9Mn0.03Mg0.02Ta0.02Mo0.02Na0.01O2 (HE‚ÄêNi90‚Äê1.557) by elemental screening and compositional fine‚Äêtuning. Compositional fine‚Äêtuning optimizes the synergistic relationship between the high‚Äêentropy dopant elements, thereby significantly suppresses the kinetic hysteresis induced by Li+/Ni2+ mixing. The pillar effect significantly enhances the diffusion kinetics of Li+ at the high state of charge (SOC). Meanwhile, the high‚Äêentropy fine‚Äêtuning significantly postpones the H2‚ÄêH3 phase transition and reduces the dissolution of transition metals and the loss of lattice oxygen in the cathodes. Consequently, the diffusion kinetics of Li+ at the atomic and electrode particle scales are significantly enhanced. The HE‚ÄêNi90‚Äê1.557 cathode exhibits an initial capacity of 225.1 mAh g‚àí1 at 0.2 C and a full cell with a high capacity retention of 83.1% after 1500 cycles at 3C. This work provides a promising avenue for commercializing Co‚Äêfree high‚ÄêNi cathodes for next‚Äêgeneration LIBs.

item.title: NIR‚ÄêII Fluorescent Thermophoretic Nanomotors for Superficial Tumor Photothermal Therapy
item.content:encoded:
A spherical core‚Äêshell nanomotor consisting of a polydopamine‚Äêindocyanine green composite shell and a rigid functional core is proposed in this work. This motor can be activated by the NIR‚ÄêI irradiation to perform NIR‚ÄêII imaging‚Äêdirected thermoplastic propulsion in subcutaneous tissue, enabling an efficient peritumoral administration for low‚Äêrisk superficial tumor photothermal therapy.
Abstract Peritumoral subcutaneous injection has been highly envisioned as an efficient yet low‚Äêrisk administration of photothermal agents for superficial tumor photothermal therapy. However, obstructed by complex subcutaneous tissue, the delivery of injected photothermal agents to the specific tumor remains a critical issue. Herein, the study reports a polydopamine (PDA)‚Äêencapsulated spherical core/shell nanomotor with fluorescent indocyanine green (ICG) immobilized on its PDA shell. Upon the first near‚Äêinfrared (NIR‚ÄêI) irradiation, this motor can generate favorable photothermal heat, and meantime, emit a robust ICG fluorescence in the second near‚Äêinfrared window (NIR‚ÄêII). The heat turns the motor into an active photothermal agent able to perform thermophoretic propulsion along the irradiation direction in subcutaneous tissue, while the ICG fluorescence can direct the subcutaneous propulsion of motors toward specific tumor through real‚Äêtime NIR‚ÄêII imaging. These functions endow the motor with the ability of moving to tumor after being injected at peritumoral site, enabling an enhanced photothermal therapy (PTT). The results demonstrated herein suggest an integrated nanorobotic tool for the superficial PTT using peritumoral administration, highlighting an NIR‚ÄêII imaging‚Äêdirected subcutaneous propulsion.

item.title: Synergistically Enhanced Co‚ÄêAdsorption of Reactant and Hydroxyl on Platinum‚ÄêModified Copper Oxide for High‚ÄêPerformance HMF Oxidation
item.content:encoded:
A high‚Äêperformance Pt/CuO@CF catalyst is designed for the electrocatalytic oxidation of biomass‚Äêderived HMF at high concentrations with excellent recyclability. Experimental results and theoretical simulations reveal that Pt modification enhances interfacial active sites, strengthens Pt‚ÄêCuO coupling, induces charge redistribution, and adjusts the d‚Äêband structure. These changes effectively improve the adsorption of reactants and hydroxyl groups, contributing to the highly efficient HMFOR.
Abstract Electrochemical oxidation of biomass‚Äêderived 5‚Äêhydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) provides an environmentally friendly route for producing the sustainable polymer monomer 2,5‚Äêfurandicarboxylic acid (FDCA). Thus, precisely adjusting the synergistic adsorption among key reactive species, such as HMF and OHads, on the carefully designed catalyst surface is essential for achieving satisfactory catalytic performance for HMF oxidation to FDCA as it is closely related to the adsorption strength and configuration of the reaction substrates. This kind of regulation will ultimately facilitate the improvement of HMF oxidation performance. In this work, Pt nanoparticles modified CuO nanowires (denoted as Pt/CuO@CF) are constructed for the selective electrooxidation of HMF to FDCA under alkaline conditions. The well‚Äêdesigned Pt/CuO@CF demonstrates highly impressive catalytic performance across a range of HMF concentrations, ranging from the commonly used concentrations to higher levels typically not explored (10, 25, 50, 75, and 100¬†mm) with high FEFDCA (all above 95%) and outstanding long‚Äêterm stability (15 cycles). In situ experimental characterizations confirm that the designed heterogeneous interface between Pt and CuO enhances the enrichment of HMF and OHads species on the catalyst surface. Theoretical calculations reveal the anchored Pt nanoparticles reduce the adsorption barrier for HMF and OHads, thereby promoting the highly selective oxidation of HMF to FDCA.

item.title: Angstrom Confinement‚ÄêTriggered Adaptive Spin State Transition of CoMn Dual Single Atoms for Efficient Singlet Oxygen Generation
item.content:encoded:
Angstrom‚Äêconfined cobalt (Co) manganese (Mn) CoMn dual single atoms within the carbon nitride interlayer are constructed to efficiently activate peroxymonosulfate for water purification. The angstrom‚Äêconfined strategy leads to the adaptive change of atomic spin state, and reduces the energy barrier for *SO5 formation and *O2 desorption during singlet oxygen generation, enabling a 38.6‚Äêfold increase in singlet oxygen production compared to the surface unconfined one.
Abstract To achieve high selectivity in the transformation from peroxymonosulfate to singlet oxygen, adaptive tuning of atomic spin state as the peroxymonosulfate structure varied is crucial. The angstrom confinement can effectively tune spin state, but developing an adaptive angstrom‚Äêconfined atomic system is challenging. Angstrom‚Äêconfined cobalt (Co) manganese (Mn) dual single atoms within flexible 2D carbon nitride interlayer are constructed to drive adaptive tuning of spin state by changing atomic coordination under angstrom confinement. The in situ characterizations and density functional theory calculations showed that medium‚Äêspin Co in Co‚îÄN4 absorbed electrons after the adsorption of peroxymonosulfate on CoMn dual single‚Äêatom sites and then cleaved O‚îÄH of peroxymonosulfate to facilitate *SO5 generation, while the introduction of *SO5 increased interlayer distance and then cleaved Co‚îÄN and Mn‚îÄN, resulting in the spin state transition from medium to high. Subsequently, the high‚Äêspin Co and Mn in Co‚îÄN2 and Mn‚îÄN2 desorbed the *O2 from *SO5, restoring the initial medium spin state. The adaptive spin state transition enhanced 38.6‚Äêfold singlet oxygen yield compared to the unconfined control. The proposed angstrom‚Äêconfined diatomic strategy is applicable to serial diatomic catalysts, providing an efficient and universal design scheme for singlet oxygen‚Äêmediated selective wastewater treatment technology at the atomic level.

item.title: Stepwise Coordination Engineering of Pt1/Au25 Dual Catalytic Sites with Enhanced Electrochemical Activity and Stability
item.content:encoded:
The challenges of constructing heterogeneous catalysts with high metal loading, precise structures, and stability are overcome by proposing a stepwise targeted coordination engineering strategy. This approach allows for the co‚Äêanchoring of Pt single atoms and Au25(SG)18 nanoclusters on g‚ÄêC3N4 and the resulting dual‚Äêsite catalysts demonstrate remarkable electrochemical reduction capabilities and enhanced stability throughout the catalytic process.
Abstract Dual‚Äêsite catalysts hold significant promise for accelerating complex electrochemical reactions, but a major challenge remains in balancing high loading with precise dual‚Äêsite architecture to achieve optimal activity, stability, and specificity simultaneously. Herein, a strategy of stepwise targeted coordination engineering is introduced to co‚Äêanchor Pt single atoms (Pt1, 1.41¬†wt.%) and Au25(SG)18 nanoclusters (Au25, 18.92 wt.%) with high loadings on graphitic carbon nitride (g‚ÄêC3N4). This approach ensures that Pt1 and Au25 occupy distinct surface sites on the g‚ÄêC3N4 substrate, providing excellent stability and unprecedented electrochemical activity. In the catalysis of As(III), a sensitivity of 8.32 ¬µA ppb‚àí1 is achieved, more than double the previously reported values under neutral conditions. The enhanced detection limit (0.2¬†ppb) is crucial for monitoring water quality and protecting public health from arsenic contamination, a significant environmental and health risk. Furthermore, the formation of Pt‚îÄAs and As‚îÄS bonds facilitates the easier breakage of As‚îÄO bonds, thereby lowering the reaction barrier energy of the rate‚Äêdetermining step and significantly enhancing arsenious acid catalysis efficiency. These results not only offer an intriguing strategy for constructing highly efficient heterogeneous dual‚Äêsite catalysts but also reveal the atomic‚Äêscale catalytic mechanisms that drive enhanced catalytic efficiency.

item.title: ASb3Mn9O19 (A = K or Rb): New Mn‚ÄêBased 2D Magnetoplumbites with Geometric and Magnetic Frustration
item.content:encoded:
The first Mn‚Äêbased magnetoplumbites, ASb3Mn9O19 (A = K or Rb), are discovered, synthesized, and characterized. According to magnetic properties measurements, neutron diffraction, and reverse Monte Carlo refinement, short‚Äêrange magnetic correlations are observed in the new materials. These observations reveal 2D magnetic correlations and magnetic frustration in ASb3Mn9O19, making it a promising platform for inducing exotic quantum states.
Abstract Magnetoplumbites are one of the most broadly studied families of hexagonal ferrites, typically with high magnetic ordering temperatures, making them excellent candidates for permanent magnets. However, magnetic frustration is rarely observed in magnetoplumbites. Herein, the discovery, synthesis, and characterization of the first Mn‚Äêbased magnetoplumbite, as well as the first magnetoplumbite involving pnictogens (Sb), ASb3Mn9O19 (A = K or Rb) are reported. The Mn3+ (S = 2) cations, further confirmed by DC magnetic susceptibility and X‚Äêray photoelectron spectroscopy, construct three geometrically frustrated sublattices, including Kagome, triangular, and puckered honeycomb lattices. Magnetic properties measurements revealed strong antiferromagnetic spin‚Äìspin coupling as well as multiple low‚Äêtemperature magnetic features. Heat capacity data does not show any prominent Œª‚Äêanomaly, suggesting minimal associated magnetic entropy. Moreover, neutron powder diffraction (NPD) implied the absence of long‚Äêrange magnetic ordering in KSb3Mn9O19 down to 3 K. However, several magnetic peaks are observed in RbSb3Mn9O19 at 3 K, corresponding to an incommensurate magnetic structure. Interestingly, strong diffuse scattering is seen in the NPD patterns of both compounds at low angles and is analyzed by reverse Monte Carlo refinements, indicating short‚Äêrange spin ordering related to frustrated magnetism as well as 2D magnetic correlations in ASb3Mn9O19 (A = K or Rb).

item.title: A Bifunctional Lysosome‚ÄêTargeting Chimera Nanoplatform for Tumor‚ÄêSelective Protein Degradation and Enhanced Cancer Immunotherapy
item.content:encoded:
A bifunctional lysosome‚Äêtargeting chimera nanoplatform (NLTC) is synthesized for tumor‚Äêselective protein degradation and enhanced cancer immunotherapy. By rationally controlling surface properties and encapsulating catalase, NLTC can efficiently accumulate at tumor tissues and avoid on‚Äêtarget off‚Äêtumor toxicity, synergistically degrade cancer cell surface programmed death ligand‚Äê1 (PD‚ÄêL1) and relieve immunosuppressive tumor microenvironment for effective cancer immunotherapy.
Abstract Lysosome‚Äêtargeting chimeras (LYTACs) have recently emerged as a promising therapeutic strategy for degrading extracellular and membrane‚Äêassociated pathogenic proteins by hijacking lysosome‚Äêtargeting receptors. However, the antitumor performance of LYTAC is limited by its insufficient tumor accumulation and nonspecific activation. Additionally, the synergistic effects of LYTACs and other therapeutic modalities are crucial. To address these issues, a bifunctional LYTAC nanoplatform (NLTC) is developed for tumor‚Äêselective protein degradation and enhanced cancer immunotherapy. By rationally controlling the surface composition, the NLTC can effectively transport extracellular or membrane proteins into lysosomes for degradation via cation‚Äêindependent mannose 6‚Äêphosphate receptors. With removable surface modification, an NLTC is obtained that efficiently accumulated in tumor tissues and avoided on‚Äêtarget off‚Äêtumor toxicity. Moreover, the synthesis method of NLTC is generally applicable to various enzymes. Thus, catalase (CAT) is encapsulated with NLTC to synergistically degrade cancer cell surface programmed death ligand‚Äê1 (PD‚ÄêL1), relieve the immunosuppressive tumor microenvironment for effective cancer immunotherapy, and significantly inhibit tumor growth, recurrence, and metastasis in B16F10‚Äêbearing mice. This work presents a bifunctional LYTAC nanoplatform that can not only perform tissue‚Äêselective protein degradation but also integrate other therapeutic modalities, providing insights into the design of advanced LYTAC technologies for clinical applications.

item.title: Superstrong Lightweight Aerogel with Supercontinuous Layer by Surface Reaction
item.content:encoded:
A ZrO2‚ÄêSiO2 fiber aerogel with a supercontinuous nanolayer is developed for high‚Äêtemperature thermal insulation. The supercontinuous arrangement of ultra‚Äêfine ZrO2 grains on the aerogel surface enables close connections between grains and fibers, promoting efficient transmission of mechanical and thermal stresses, which contributes to record‚Äêhigh specific strength and remarkable thermal‚Äêinsulating behaviors.
Abstract Breaking the thermal, mechanical and lightweight performance limit of aerogels has pivotal significance on thermal protection, new energy utilization, high‚Äêtemperature catalysis, structural engineering, and physics, but is severely limited by the serious discrete characteristics between grain boundary and nano‚Äêunits interfaces. Herein, a thermodynamically driven surface reaction and confined crystallization process is reported to synthesize a centimeter‚Äêscale supercontinuous ZrO2 nanolayer on ZrO2‚ÄêSiO2 fiber aerogel surface, which significantly improved its thermal and mechanical properties with density almost unchanged (‚âà26 mg¬†cm‚àí3). Systematic structure analysis confirms that the supercontinuous layer achieves a close connection between grains and fibers through Zr‚îÄO‚îÄSi bonds. The as‚Äêprepared aerogel exhibits record‚Äêbreaking specific strength (‚âà84615 N¬†m¬†kg‚àí1, can support up to ‚âà227¬†272 times aerogel mass) and dynamic impact resistance (withstanding impacts up to 500 times aerogel mass and up to 200 cycling stability at 80% strain). Besides, its temperature resistance has also been greatly optimized (400¬†¬∞C enhancement, stability at 1500¬†¬∞C). This work will provide a new perspective for exploring the limits of lightweight, high strength, and thermal properties of solid materials.

item.title: Woven Cement Slurry
item.content:encoded:
A particle‚Äêpolymer coalescence strategy is proposed to build balanced particle cohesion, successfully realizing the bending, knotting, coiling, winding, and interlacing of cement slurry for weaving. Beyond the state‚Äêof‚Äêthe‚Äêart formwork casting, grouting, and 3D‚Äêprinting, this cement weaving technology may invoke the construction technology revolution and new material and structure design.
Abstract Weaving, a pivotal technique in human construction activities since the Neolithic era, remains unattainable in modern concrete construction. Here, a novel particle‚Äêpolymer coalescence strategy is proposed, which involves electrostatic, bridging, coordinating, and hydrogen bonding interactions, to establish balanced particle cohesion, enabling the fabrication of stretchable cement slurry. The bending, knotting, coiling, winding, and interlacing of cement filaments for structural textiles is successfully realized beyond traditional formwork casting, grouting, and 3D‚Äêprinting, and fabricate the first‚Äêever Chinese knot woven with cement. Weaving construction builds a triaxially cross‚Äêpenetrating structure that greatly promotes interlayer strength and toughness by ‚âà208.5% and 676.5% compared to the state‚Äêof‚Äêthe‚Äêart layer‚Äêby‚Äêlayer 3D printed structure. These findings not only make a breakthrough in concrete construction technology but also provide solutions for fabricating multi‚Äêdirectional woven structures with great engineering‚Äêapplication potentials.

item.title: Embedding Carbon Nanotubes in Artificial Cells Enhances Probe Transfer
item.content:encoded:
A liposome‚Äêbased artificial cell is constructed to protect the signal probes and carbon nanotubes are embedded in the artificial cell membranes and employed as artificial channels to enhance intercellular probe transduction and mass transfer. The strategy accelerates cell‚Äêcell signal probe transmission and enables effective sensing of let‚Äê7a and visualizing let‚Äê7a in living colon cancer cells.
Abstract Monitoring intracellular biomarkers is crucial for clinical disease diagnosis. However, the majority of signaling molecules face difficulties in slow transference across the cell membrane to reach intracellular detection sites, limiting their application in clinical settings. This study proposes an artificial cell‚Äêbased signal probe transfer‚Äêenhanced sensing strategy to effectively detect microRNAs (miRNAs) by embedding carbon nanotubes (CNTs) in artificial cell membranes. The liposome‚Äêbased artificial cell is constructed to protect the signal probes such as nucleic acids, metal ions, and fluorescent dyes. CNTs are embedded in artificial cell membranes and employed as artificial channels to enhance intercellular signal probe transduction and mass transfer. Through CNTs‚Äêmediate cell‚Äêcell signal probe transmission, the probes pass through the liposome membrane interface and fuse into target cells, selectively hybridizing with the intracellular target miRNAs, triggering a sensing process and resulting in enhanced fluorescence signal. Furthermore, molecular dynamics simulations are carried out to prove the enhancement of CNTs‚Äêmediated cell‚Äêcell fusion. This strategy demonstrates excellent analytical performance by quantitatively detecting let‚Äê7a miRNA and visualizing it in living colon cancer cells. These findings hold great significance in promoting and accelerating cell‚Äêcell signal probe transmission and enabling effective sensing of intracellular biomarkers for diagnostic purposes.

item.title: Dielectric Regulation in Quasi‚ÄêvdW Europium Oxysulfur Compounds by Compositional Engineering for 2D Electronics
item.content:encoded:
This study presents the first synthesis of 2D hexagonal Eu‚ÇÇSO‚ÇÇ and tetragonal Eu‚ÇÇSO‚ÇÜ with tunable dielectric properties. Eu‚ÇÇSO‚ÇÇ offers high dielectric performance, while Eu‚ÇÇSO‚ÇÜ provides a wider bandgap. Integrated into MoS‚ÇÇ field‚Äêeffect transistors, these materials demonstrate excellent performance, highlighting their potential as multifunctional dielectrics for next‚Äêgeneration low‚Äêpower electronics.
Abstract Advancing next‚Äêgeneration electronics necessitates precise control of dielectric properties in 2D materials. Here, the first synthesis of novel 2D quasi‚Äêvan der Waals (vdW) europium oxysulfur (Eu2SOx) compounds, comprising hexagonal Eu‚ÇÇSO‚ÇÇ and tetragonal Eu‚ÇÇSO‚ÇÜ phases, with composition‚Äêtunable dielectric properties, is presented. Using a homodiffusive‚Äêcontrolled epitaxial growth method, materials are achieved with complementary characteristics: the hexagonal Eu‚ÇÇSO‚ÇÇ phase exhibits a high dielectric constant (‚âà30) paired with a moderate bandgap (‚âà4.56 eV), while the tetragonal Eu‚ÇÇSO‚ÇÜ phase offers a wider bandgap (‚âà5.62 eV) but a lower dielectric constant (‚âà20). The potential of these materials is demonstrated by integrating ultrathin Eu‚ÇÇSO‚ÇÇ nanoplates with molybdenum disulfide (MoS‚ÇÇ) field‚Äêeffect transistors (FETs) via vdW forces. The resulting devices achieve a near‚Äêideal Ion/Ioff ratio (‚âà10‚Å∏), minimal hysteresis (‚âà5.3 mV), a low subthreshold slope (‚âà63.5 mV dec‚Åª¬π), and ultralow leakage current (‚âà10‚Åª¬π‚Å¥ A). These results highlight the capacity of europium oxysulfur compounds to address the trade‚Äêoff between dielectric constant and bandgap, offering tailored solutions for diverse 2D electronic applications. This work underscores the potential of composition engineering to expand the family of rare‚Äêearth oxysulfur compounds for nanoelectronics, paving the way for innovative gate dielectrics in next‚Äêgeneration devices.

item.title: Nonlinear Ion Dynamics Enable Spike Timing Dependent Plasticity of Electrochemical Ionic Synapses
item.content:encoded:
Nonlinear ion dynamics in electrochemical ionic synapses enable spike‚Äêtiming‚Äêdependent plasticity (STDP) with low energy consumption and minimal variability. The approach supports diverse STDP forms and flexible learning rules across timescales from milliseconds to nanoseconds, enabling spiking neural network hardware with high throughput and adaptability while maintaining low energy consumption and high reliability.
Abstract Programmable synaptic devices that can achieve timing‚Äêdependent weight updates are key components to implementing energy‚Äêefficient spiking neural networks (SNNs). Electrochemical ionic synapses (EIS) enable the programming of weight updates with very low energy consumption and low variability. Here, the strongly nonlinear kinetics of EIS, arising from nonlinear dynamics of ions and charge transfer reactions in solids, are leveraged to implement various forms of spike‚Äêtiming‚Äêdependent plasticity (STDP). In particular, protons are used as the working ion. Different forms of the STDP function are deterministically predicted and emulated by a linear superposition of appropriately designed pre‚Äê and post‚Äêsynaptic neuron signals. Heterogeneous STDP is also demonstrated within the array to capture different learning rules in the same system. STDP timescales are controllable, ranging from milliseconds to nanoseconds. The STDP resulting from EIS has lower variability than other hardware STDP implementations, due to the deterministic and uniform insertion of charge in the tunable channel material. The results indicate that the ion and charge transfer dynamics in EIS can enable bio‚Äêplausible synapses for SNN hardware with high energy efficiency, reliability, and throughput.

item.title: Lattice‚ÄêStrain Engineering of High‚ÄêEntropy‚ÄêOxide Nanoparticles: Regulation by Flame Spray Pyrolysis with Ultrafast Quenching
item.content:encoded:
This study introduces a continuous‚Äêflow flame spray pyrolysis method for tuning lattice strain in high‚Äêentropy‚Äêoxide nanoparticles. By varying the cooling rates of quenching, tensile strain increases by 2.75%, enhancing oxygen evolution reaction performance with a 25 mV reduction in overpotential at a current density of 10 mA cm‚àí2. This approach facilitates efficient mass production and precise control of lattice strain.
Abstract The lattice‚Äêstrain engineering of high‚Äêentropy‚Äêoxide nanoparticles (HEO‚ÄêNPs) is considered an effective strategy for achieving outstanding performance in various applications. However, lattice‚Äêstrain engineering independent of the composition variation still confronts significant challenges, with existing modulation techniques difficult to achieve mass production. Herein, a novel continuous‚Äêflow synthesis strategy by flame spray pyrolysis (FSP) is proposed, which air varying flow rates is introduced for fast quenching to alter the cooling rate and control the lattice strain of HEO‚ÄêNPs. Experimental results demonstrate that as the flow rate of air increases from 0 L to 24 L min‚àí1, the cooling rate has increased by more than ten times, and the tensile strain of the HEO‚ÄêNPs increases by 2.75%. Utilizing the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) activity as an indicator, it is observed that the overpotential to achieve a current density of 10¬†mA cm‚àí2 is reduced by 25¬†mV. Importantly, this approach enables the simple and efficient regulation of lattice strain in HEO‚ÄêNPs (110 mg min‚àí1). Thus, this study provides a new approach for both the mass production and regulation of lattice strain in HEO‚ÄêNPs.

item.title: Bioinspired Disordered Aerogel for Omnidirectional Terahertz Response
item.content:encoded:
Mimicking micro‚Äêpores structures from black butterflies, terahertz response behaviors with incidence‚Äêangle‚Äêinsensitive and ultra‚Äêbroadband can be effectively controlled through a disordered pore‚Äêinduced structural orientation mechanism. In this research, the first investigation is presented into the regulation of terahertz response behaviors via optimized pore structure including disorder, pore parameters, and orientation, regarding as resonance sphere and waveguide system.
Abstract The structural disorder of the black butterfly assists in capturing sunlight across a wider spectral and angular range, injecting infinite vitality for omnidirectional and stimuli‚Äêresponsive wave‚Äêabsorbing materials. Here, the disordered micro‚Äêpores responding to terahertz (THz) waves through electromagnetic simulations, and then prepared via ice templating technology are analyzed and optimized. The customized disordered aerogel makes possible perfect terahertz response property with incidence‚Äêangle‚Äêinsensitive and ultra‚Äêbroadband. Ti3C2Tx MXene/carboxymethyl cellulose aerogels realize excellent shielding effectiveness exceeding 70.32¬†dB and reflection loss of more than 43.02¬†dB over the frequency range of 0.3‚Äì1.5 THz. Tailoring the structural orientation of anisotropic aerogels functions as a versatile dynamic modulation approach along terahertz propagation direction. The porous structure with moderate conductivity gradually triggers the resonance effect of the cavity, approximating a resonance sphere (pore) and waveguide system (tube). Ultimately, gradient impedance aerogel is proposed integrating THz‚Äêinfrared stealth, hydrophobicity, and mechanical strength. This inspired biomimetic structural strategy will also enable various terahertz applications such as terahertz imaging, line‚Äêof‚Äêsight telecommunication, information encryption, and space exploration.

item.title: Cation‚ÄêVacancy Engineering in Cobalt Selenide Boosts Electrocatalytic Upcycling of Polyester Thermoplastics at Industrial‚ÄêLevel Current Density
item.content:encoded:
Cation vacancies‚Äêvacancies‚Äêrich cobalt selenide as electrocatalyst to convert polybutylene terephthalate into succinic acid is crafted, which functions well at industrial‚Äêlevel current density (1.5¬†A¬†cm‚àí2 @1.477¬†V vs. RHE). The catalytic mechanism of catalyst and related generality of electrocatalytic upcycling of other polyester thermoplastics are investigated. This work contributes to propel current research frontier of utilization of low‚Äêvalue carbon resources.
Abstract The past decades have witnessed the increasing accumulation of plastics, posing a daunting environmental crisis. Among various solutions, converting plastics into value‚Äêadded products presents a significant endeavor. Here, an electrocatalytic upcycling route that efficiently converts waste poly(butylene terephthalate) plastics into high‚Äêvalue succinic acid with high Faradaic efficiency of 94.0% over cation vacancies‚Äêrich cobalt selenide catalyst is reported, showcasing unprecedented activity (1.477¬†V vs. RHE) to achieve an industrial‚Äêlevel current density of 1.5¬†A¬†cm‚àí2, and featuring a robust operating durability (‚âà170¬†h). In particular, when combining butane‚Äê1,4‚Äêdiol monomer oxidation (BOR) with hydrogen evolution using the cation vacancy‚Äêengineered cobalt selenide as bifunctional catalyst, a relatively low cell voltage of 1.681¬†V is required to reach 400¬†mA¬†cm‚àí2, manifesting an energy‚Äêsaving efficiency of ‚âà15% compared to pure water splitting. The mechanism and reaction pathways of BOR over the vacancies‚Äêrich catalyst are first revealed through theoretical calculations and in‚Äêsitu spectroscopic investigations. The generality of this catalyst is evidenced by its powerful electrocatalytic activity to other polyester thermoplastics such as poly(butylene succinate) and poly(ethylene terephthalate). These electrocatalytic upcycling strategies can be coupled with the reduction of small molecules (e.g., H2O, CO2, and NO3‚àí), shedding light on energy‚Äêsaving production of value‚Äêadded chemicals.

item.title: The Optimized Lipid‚ÄêModified Prodrug for CNV Treatment
item.content:encoded:
The modification of SU5402 (SU)¬†with aliphatic chains containing 20 carbon atoms (SU‚ÄêC20 NPs) exhibits an exceptional ability to penetrate the ocular barrier and ensure prolonged drug retention within the eye. These optimized prodrug nanoparticles show a remarkable therapeutic effect in choroidal neovascularization (CNV), resulting in minimal hyperfluorescent leakage and the smallest CNV lesion thickness.
Abstract Choroidal neovascularization (CNV) is a prevalent cause of vision impairment. The primary treatment for CNV involves intravitreal injections of anti‚Äêvascular endothelial growth factor antibodies. Nevertheless, this approach still faces numerous limitations like poor patient compliance, high therapy expenditure and lack of response in some individuals. Herein, a series of anti‚Äêneovascularization prodrugs, SU5402 (SU), modified with lipids of varying chain lengths (C12, C16, C20, C24, C28) is synthesized (SU‚ÄêC12, SU‚ÄêC16, SU‚ÄêC20, SU‚ÄêC24, SU‚ÄêC28). 1% polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) is used as a stabilizer to create nanoformulations of five prodrugs named SU‚ÄêC12 NPs, SU‚ÄêC16 NPs, SU‚ÄêC20 NPs, SU‚ÄêC24 NPs, SU‚ÄêC28 NPs. Among these, SU‚ÄêC20 NPs significantly prolong the retention of bioactive drug in the eye for up to 70 d. Moreover, SU‚ÄêC20 NPs demonstrate superior tissue permeability via enhanced cellular endocytosis and exocytosis. With its prolonged retention and improved penetration, SU‚ÄêC20 NPs reduce the fluorescence intensity of fundus leakage by 42.5% and the fluorescence area by 51.5% in CNV mice after four weeks, effectively inhibiting the progression of CNV. Altogether, small molecule drug SU is innovatively modified to improve its effectiveness for treating fundus neovascular diseases, proposing an alternative therapy for wet age‚Äêrelated macular degeneration (wAMD).

item.title: Self‚ÄêRegulatory Lean‚ÄêElectrolyte Flow for Building 600¬†Wh Kg‚àí1‚ÄêLevel Rechargeable Lithium Batteries
item.content:encoded:
Intra‚Äêparticle pores play a practical role in cutting down the electrolyte quantity needed during wetting. A high pore‚Äêthroat ratio empowers Li‚Äêrich layered oxides to withstand lean electrolyte conditions at 1.4 g Ah‚àí1 and achieve a specific energy of 600 Wh kg‚àí1 in a pouch cell. This accomplishment charts a course for pore‚Äêbased regulation in high‚Äêenergy storage devices.
Abstract Reducing excess electrolytes offers a promising approach to improve the specific energy of electrochemical energy storage devices. However, using lean electrolytes presents a significant challenge for porous electrode materials due to heterogeneous wetting. The spontaneous wetting of nano‚Äê or meso‚Äêpores within particles, though seldom discussed, adversely affects wetting under lean electrolyte conditions. Herein, this undesired wetting behavior is mitigated by enlarging the pore‚Äêthroat ratio, enabling Li‚Äêrich layered oxide to function effectively at very low electrolyte/capacity (E/C) ratio of 1.4¬†g Ah‚àí1. The resulting pouch cell achieves 606¬†Wh kg‚àí1 and retains 80% capacity (75% energy) after 70 cycles. Through imaging techniques and molecular dynamics simulations, it is demonstrated that the pore‚Äêthroat ratio effectively determines the permeability of electrolyte within particles. By elucidating pore‚Äêrelating mechanisms, this work unveils promising potential of manipulating pore structures in porous electrode materials, an approach that can be applied to improve the specific energy of other devices including semi‚Äêsolid‚Äêstate lithium batteries.

item.title: Ultralight Electrospun Composite Filters with Vertical Ternary Spatial Network for High‚ÄêPerformance PM0.3 Purification
item.content:encoded:
An innovative ultralight electrospun nanofiber composite filter,¬†mass‚Äêproduced via an one‚Äêstep free surface electrospinning technology, is engineered with a vertical ternary spatial network (TSN) structure, featuring elongated internal aperture channels. This advanced TSN filter excels in high‚Äêperformance filtration of ultrafine PM0.3 aerosols,¬†while significantly minimizing material usage. It is designed for recyclability and operates with low energy requirements, ensuring both wearer comfort and environmental sustainability.
Abstract Air pollutants, particularly highly permeable particulate matter (PM), threaten public health and environmental sustainability due to extensive filter media consumption. Existing melt‚Äêblown nonwoven filters struggle with PM0.3 removal, energy consumption, and disposal burdens. Here, an ultralight composite filter with a vertical ternary spatial network (TSN) structure that saves ‚âà98% of raw material usage and reduces fabrication time by 99.4%, while simultaneously achieving high‚Äêefficiency PM0.3 removal (‚â•99.92%), eco‚Äêfriendly regeneration (near‚Äêzero energy consumption), and enhanced wearing comfort (breathability >80¬†mm s‚Åª¬π, infrared transmittance >85%), is reported. The TSN filter consists of a hybrid layer of microspheres (average diameter ‚âà1¬†¬µm)/superfine nanofibers (‚âà20¬†nm) sandwiched between two nanofiber scaffolds (diameter ‚âà400¬†nm and ‚âà100¬†nm). This arrangement offers high porosity (‚âà85%), ultralow areal density (<1¬†g m‚àí2), alow airflow resistance (<90¬†Pa), guaranteeing superb thermal comfort. Notably, utilizing scalable one‚Äêstep free surface electrospinning technology, TSN mats can be mass‚Äêproduced at a rate of 60 meters per hour (width of 1.6 meters), which is critical and verified for various applications including window screens, individual respiratory protectors, and dust collectors. This work provides a viable strategy for designing high‚Äêperformance nanofiber filter media through structural regulation in a scalable, cost‚Äêeffective, and sustainable way.

item.title: Tailoring Buried Interface and Minimizing Energy Loss Enable Efficient Narrow and Wide Bandgap Inverted Perovskite Solar Cells by Aluminum Glycinate Based Organometallic Molecule
item.content:encoded:
Aluminum glycinate‚Äêbased organometallic molecule is used to tailor buried interface and minimize interface‚Äêdriven energy loss, which realizes high efficiencies of 26.74% and 20.71% for 1.55 and 1.785 eV bandgap perovskite solar cells, respectively.
Abstract Rational regulation of Me‚Äê4PACz/perovskite interface has emerged as a significant challenge in the pursuit of highly efficient and stable perovskite solar cells (PSCs). Herein, an organometallic molecule of aluminum glycinate (AG) that contained amine (‚ÄêNH2) and aluminum hydroxyl (Al‚ÄêOH) groups is developed to tailor the buried interface and minimize interface‚Äêdriven energy losses. The Al‚ÄêOH groups selectively bonded with unanchored O‚ïêP‚ÄêOH and bare NiO‚ÄêOH to optimize the surface morphology and energy levels, while the ‚ÄêNH2 group interacted specifically with Pb2+ to retard perovskite crystallization, passivate buried Pb‚Äêrelated defects, and release residual interface stress. These interactions facilitate the interface carrier extraction and reduce interface‚Äêdriven energy losses, thereby realizing a balanced charge carrier transport. Consequently, AG‚Äêmodified narrow bandgap (1.55 eV) PSC demonstrates an efficiency of 26.74% (certified 26.21%) with a fill factor of 86.65%; AG‚Äêmodified wide bandgap (1.785 eV) PSC realizes 20.71% champion efficiency with excellent repeatability. These PSCs maintain 91.37%, 91.92%, and 92.00% of their initial efficiency after aging in air atmosphere, the nitrogen‚Äêfilled atmosphere at 85¬†¬∞C, and continuously tracking at the maximum power‚Äêpoint under one‚Äêsun illumination (100 mW cm‚àí2) for 1200 h, respectively.

item.title: Constructing Pillar‚ÄêLayered Covalent Organic Frameworks via Metal‚ÄìLigand Coordination for Electrochemical CO2 Reduction
item.content:encoded:
3D Pillar‚Äêlayered COFs (PL‚ÄêCOFs) with adjustable interlayer spacing, enhanced crystallinity, and increased porosity are designed and constructed using a pillaring strategy via metal‚Äêligand coordination, which demonstrates significantly improved electrochemical activity and selectivity for CO2‚Äêto‚ÄêCO conversion compared to their 2D layered COF counterparts.
Abstract Growing global concerns over energy security and climate change have intensified efforts to develop sustainable strategies for electrochemical CO2 reduction (eCO2RR). Covalent Organic Frameworks (COFs) have emerged as promising electrocatalysts for eCO2RR due to their tunable structures, high surface areas, and abundance of active sites. However, the performance of 2D COFs is often limited by layer stacking, which restricts active site exposure and reduces selectivity. To overcome these challenges, a new class of COFs known as pillar‚Äêlayered COFs (PL‚ÄêCOFs) is developed featuring adjustable interlayer spacing and a 3D architecture. Characterization using PXRD, TEM, XPS, and EIS confirmed the successful integration of pillar molecules, which leads to increased interlayer spacing, crystallinity, and porosity. These structural advancements result in significantly improved electrochemical activity and selectivity for CO2‚Äêto‚ÄêCO conversion. Density functional theory simulations revealed that enhanced CO2 adsorption and CO desorption contribute to the outstanding performance of PL‚ÄêCOF‚Äê1, which boasts the largest interlayer spacing. This material achieved an impressive Faradaic efficiency of 91.3% and demonstrated a significant current density, outperforming both the original COF‚Äê366‚ÄêCo and PL‚ÄêCOF‚Äê2. These findings highlight the effectiveness of the pillaring strategy in optimizing COF‚Äêbased electrocatalysts, paving the way for next‚Äêgeneration materials for CO2 reduction and sustainable energy conversion.

item.title: Crystal Structural Editing: Novel Biaxial MgTe2O5 Crystal as Zero‚ÄêOrder Waveplates
item.content:encoded:
MgTe2O5 with 0D structure has been successfully selected and grown as a waveplate crystal. The MgTe2O5 crystal shows tiny birefringence of 0.0028 in the range from 0.4 to 5¬†¬µm with a high laser damage threshold of up to 2.7 GW¬†cm‚àí2. This work provides a novel waveplate crystal and excellent waveplate devices.
Abstract Waveplates are important optical components to control the polarization of light. Currently, they are often fabricated from uniaxial crystals, and there is no report about waveplates based on the biaxial crystals. In this work, a novel biaxial crystal MgTe2O5 with a structure constructed by 0D Te2O5 groups is designed and grown as waveplate materials for the first time. The exciting result is that the birefringence in the (001)‚Äêplane is smaller than 0.0028 in the range from 0.4 to 5 ¬µm, which is significantly smaller than that of the current waveplate materials. The polarization modulations of the MgTe2O5 devices working at 532 nm indicate that excellent zero‚Äêorder half and quarter waveplates have been successfully prepared. In addition, achromatic waveplates used in the visible, near‚Äêinfrared, and mid‚Äêinfrared ranges have also been calculated. The MgTe2O5 crystal not only exhibits a high laser damage threshold of up to 2.7 GW¬†cm‚àí2 but also shows a wide transmission range from 0.37 to 6.3 ¬µm. These results provide an excellent waveplate crystal and explore the applications of biaxial crystals.

item.title: Ultrafast Li‚ÄêRich Transport in Composite Solid‚ÄêState Electrolytes
item.content:encoded:
A novel Li‚Äêrich transport mechanism is proposed to achieve ultrafast Li‚Äêion conduction in composite solid‚Äêstate electrolytes. Negatively charged cation defects intensify the concentration enrichment of Li ions on the nanofiller surface, inducing the formation of interconnected Li‚Äêrich transport networks. The composite electrolyte exhibits an unprecedented ionic conductivity of approaching 1¬†√ó¬†10‚Åª3¬†S¬†cm‚Åª1 at room temperature.
Abstract Solid‚Äêstate lithium (Li) metal batteries (SSLMBs) have garnered considerable attention due to their potential for high energy density and intrinsic safety. However, their widespread development has been hindered by the low ionic conductivity of solid‚Äêstate electrolytes. In this contribution, a novel Li‚Äêrich transport mechanism is proposed to achieve ultrafast Li‚Äêion conduction in composite solid‚Äêstate electrolytes. By incorporating cation‚Äêdeficient dielectric nanofillers into polymer matrices, it is found that negatively charged cation defects effectively intensify the adsorption of Li ions, resulting in a high Li‚Äêion concentration enrichment on the surface of fillers. More importantly, these formed Li‚Äêrich layers are interconnected to establish continuous ultrafast Li‚Äêion transport networks. The composite electrolyte exhibited a remarkably low ion transport activation energy (0.17¬†eV) and achieved an unprecedented ionic conductivity of approaching 1¬†√ó¬†10‚Åª3¬†S¬†cm‚Åª1 at room temperature. The Li||LiNi0.8Co0.1Mo0.1O2 full cells demonstrated an extended cycling life of over 200 cycles with a capacity retention of 70.7%. This work provides a fresh insight into improving Li‚Äêion transport by constructing interconnected Li‚Äêrich transport networks, paving the way for the development of high‚Äêperformance SSLMBs.

item.title: Stable and Highly Efficient Near‚ÄêInfrared Emission Achieved in Spinel Blocks
item.content:encoded:
Synopsis: Utilizing a 2D framework matrix, a strategy is presented to balance Cr3‚Å∫‚Äêpair emissions at high doping concentrations while effectively suppressing undesirable quenching, thereby ensuring sustained luminescent efficiency.
Abstract Developing efficient and stable near‚Äêinfrared emitters related to Cr3+‚Äêpairs for advanced optoelectronic devices remains a challenge due to concentration quenching effects and unclear luminescence mechanisms. In this study, Cr3+ ions are incorporated into a matrix structure consisting of ZnAl‚ÇÇO‚ÇÑ spinel units separated by 11.312 √Ö, effectively restricting energy transfer between luminescent centers and alleviating quenching effects. Computational analysis identifies the lattice positions of isolated Cr3+ ions and Cr3+‚Äêpairs at different doping levels, providing insights into their spatial distribution and local structural environments. Photoluminescence measurements reveals a Cr3+‚Äêconcentration‚Äêdependent emission broadening, with a Cr3+‚Äêpair emission band peak at 750¬†nm, while detailed spectral analysis further clarified the energy level structure of Cr3+‚Äêpairs for the first time. Enhanced material performance is achieved through flux‚Äêassisted synthesis, reaching a high external quantum efficiency of 58.3%. Consequently, the assembled pc‚ÄêLEDs exhibit minimal efficiency roll‚Äêoff and achieve¬†a high output of 183¬†mW at 650¬†mA, demonstrating their potential in near‚Äêinfrared light sources and night vision technology application.

item.title: Zinc Single‚ÄêAtom Catalysts Encapsulated in Hierarchical Porous Bio‚ÄêCarbon Synergistically Enhances Fast Iodine Conversion and Efficient Polyiodide Confinement for Zn‚ÄêI2 Batteries
item.content:encoded:
A biomass‚Äêderived carbon integrated with Zn single‚Äêatom catalysts for iodine hosting is designed, integrating the high specific surface area, hierarchical porosity, and nitrogen doping of carbon, along with the excellent chemical confinement and electrocatalytic properties of Zn single atoms. This enabled Zn‚ÄêI2 batteries to achieve a long lifespan of 80¬†000 cycles at 10¬†A¬†g‚àí1 with 93.6% capacity retention.
Abstract Aqueous zinc iodine (Zn‚ÄêI2) batteries have attracted attention due to their low cost, environmental compatibility, and high specific capacity. However, their development is hindered by the severe shuttle effect of polyiodides and the slow redox conversion kinetics of the iodine (I2) cathode. Herein, a long‚Äêlife Zn‚ÄêI2 battery is developed by anchoring iodine within an edible fungus slag‚Äêderived carbon matrix encapsulated with Zn single‚Äêatom catalysts (SAZn@CFS). The high N content and microporous structure of SAZn@CFS provide a strong iodine confinement, while the Zn‚ÄêN4‚ÄêC sites chemical interact with polyiodides effectively mitigating the iodine dissolution and the polyiodide shuttle effect. Additionally, the uniformly distributed SAZn sites significantly enhance the redox conversion efficiency of I‚àí/I3‚àí/I5‚àí/I2, leading to improved capacity. At a high current density of 10¬†A¬†g‚àí1, the designed Zn‚ÄêI2 battery delivers an excellent capacity of 147.2¬†mAh¬†g‚àí1 and a long lifespan of over 80¬†000 cycles with 93.6% capacity retention. Furthermore, the battery exhibits stable operation for 3500 times even at 50¬†¬∞C, demonstrating significant advances in iodine reversible storage. This synergistic strategy optimizes composite structure, offering a practical approach to meet the requirements of high‚Äêperformance Zn‚ÄêI2 batteries.

item.title: Aggregation‚ÄêMediated Photoacoustic/NIR‚ÄêII and Photodynamic Properties of pH‚ÄêReversible Thiopyrylium Agents: A Computational and Experimental Approach
item.content:encoded:
This article presents an innovative approach to developing pH‚Äêresponsive thiopyrylium‚Äêbased NIR‚ÄêII fluorophores with enhanced photoacoustic and photodynamic properties. By precisely modulating molecular aggregation, the study demonstrates significant advances in tumor‚Äêtargeted dual‚Äêmodal imaging and therapy, providing a promising pathway for future cancer diagnosis and treatment.
Abstract Aggregation profoundly influences the photophysical properties of molecules. Here, a new series of thiopyrylium‚Äêbased hemicyanine near‚Äêinfrared II (NIR‚ÄêII) fluorophores is developed by meticulously adjusting their aggregation states. Notably, the star molecule HTPA exhibits a remarkable pH‚Äêresponsive behavior and a significant increase in photoacoustic (PA) intensity when aggregated. Additionally, their behavior and pH reversibility during aggregation formation are systematically investigated, including computational optimization, femtosecond transient absorption spectroscopy, NMR analysis, and single crystal analysis. Finally, an innovative ‚Äúoff‚Äâ‚Äù nanoparticle specifically is designed for effective tumor‚Äêtargeted PA/NIR‚ÄêII dual‚Äêmodal imaging and photodynamic therapy by utilizing a pH‚Äêresponsive polymer. The signal‚Äêto‚Äêbackground ratio (SBR) of PA signals significantly increased to 169 in the region of interest (ROI) in the mouse model when irradiated at 1064¬†nm.
