To circumvent this, a systematic methodology for the direct growth of GaN after the AlN nucleation layer on six‚Äêinch silicon substrates is demonstrated using metal‚Äêorganic vapor phase epitaxy (MOVPE). Crucial growth‚Äêstress modulation to prevent epilayer cracking is achieved even without buffers, and threading dislocation densities comparable to those in buffered structures are realized. The buffer‚Äêless design yields a GaN‚Äêto‚Äêsubstrate thermal resistance of (11 ¬± 4) m2¬†K¬†GW‚àí1, an order of magnitude reduction over conventional GaN‚Äêon‚ÄêSi and one of the lowest on any non‚Äênative substrate. As‚Äêgrown AlGaN/AlN/GaN heterojunctions on this template show a high‚Äêquality 2D electron gas (2DEG) whose room‚Äêtemperature Hall‚Äêeffect mobility exceeds 2000 cm2¬†V‚àí1¬†s‚àí1, rivaling the best‚Äêreported values. As further validation, the low‚Äêtemperature magnetoresistance of this 2DEG shows clear Shubnikov‚Äêde‚ÄêHaas oscillations, a quantum lifetime > 0.180 ps, and tell‚Äêtale signatures of spin‚Äêsplitting. These results could establish a new platform for III‚Äênitrides, potentially enhancing the energy efficiency of power transistors and enabling fundamental investigations into electron dynamics in quasi‚Äê2D wide‚Äêbandgap systems.

item.title: In Situ, Treatment with Guanidinium Chloride Ligand Enables Efficient Blue Quantum Dot Light‚ÄêEmitting Diodes with 23.5% External Quantum Efficiency
item.content:encoded:
Insufficient hole injection, excessive electron injection, and abundant defects on the surface of QDs are limiting the performance of blue QLEDs. An in situ patching strategy with GACl is proposed to simultaneously passivate surface defects and enhance hole injection, with the EQE increasing from 16.3% to 23.5%. The model is proposed to understand the physical mechanism of hole injection and transport.
Abstract The poor efficiency and stability of blue Quantum Dot Light‚ÄêEmitting diodes (QLED) hinders the practical applications of QLEDs full‚Äêcolor displays. Excessive electron injection, insufficient hole injection, and abundant defects on the surface of quantum dots (QD) are the main issues limiting the performance of blue devices. Herein, an in situ treatment with bipolar small molecule polydentate ligand‚Äìguanidine chloride (GACl) is proposed to simultaneously suppress excessive electron injection, patch surface defects of QDs and enhance hole injection. GACl‚Äêtreated blue QLEDs exhibited a remarkable increase in maximal external quantum Efficiency (EQE) from 16.3% to a record 23.5%, accompanied by maximal luminance (36810¬†cd¬†m‚àí2), excellent maximal current efficiency (17.5¬†cd¬†A‚àí1), and enhanced device stability. Combining C‚ÄìV and J‚ÄìV characteristics, a concise physical model of hole injection is also established: Below 3¬†V, hole injection is controlled by the interfacial barrier, primarily through tunneling and thermionic injection; Above 3¬†V, the interfacial barrier is eliminated, and hole injection efficiency is governed by transport within the QD layer. This study showed a clear physical model for understanding the hole injection mechanism in QLEDs, offering valuable design strategies for improving the performance of blue‚ÄêQLEDs.

item.title: Fabricating Lattice‚ÄêConfined Pt Single Atoms With High Electron‚ÄêDeficient State for Alkali Hydrogen Evolution Under Industrial‚ÄêCurrent Density
item.content:encoded:
Lattice‚Äêconfined Pt1/Ni(OH)2 SACs with excellent activity for hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) are constructed by a co‚Äêreduction strategy. Mechanism studies disclose the Pt 3d orbital strongly hybridizes with O 2p and Ni 3d orbitals in Ni(OH)2, thus largely reducing the energy barrier of the rate‚Äêdetermining step during HER. Finally, this facile synthesis approach is extended to fabricate other 9 lattice‚Äêconfined SACs.
Abstract The confining effect is essential to regulate the activity and stability of single‚Äêatom catalysts (SACs), but the universal fabrication of confined SACs is still a great challenge. Here, various lattice‚Äêconfined Pt SACs supported by different carriers are constructed by a universal co‚Äêreduction approach. Notably, Pt single atoms confined in the lattice of Ni(OH)2 (Pt1/Ni(OH)2) with a high electron‚Äêdeficient state exhibit excellent activity for basic hydrogen evolution reaction (HER). Specifically, Pt1/Ni(OH)2 just requires 15¬†mV to get 10¬†mA cm‚àí2 and the mass activity of Pt1/Ni(OH)2 is 15 times of commercial Pt/C. Moreover, Pt1/Ni(OH)2 assembled in an alkaline water electrolyzer shows 1030¬†h durability under the industrial current density of 800¬†mA cm‚àí2. In situ spectroscopy techniques reveal Pt‚îÄH and ‚Äúfree‚Äù OH radical can be directly observed for Pt1/Ni(OH)2, confirming the lattice‚Äêconfined Pt single atoms play a key role during HER. Further density functional theory uncovers the Pt 3d orbital strongly hybridizes with O 2p and Ni 3d orbitals in Ni(OH)2, which quickly optimizes the electronic state of the Pt site, thus largely reducing the energy barrier of the rate‚Äêdetermining step to 0.16¬†eV for HER. Finally, this synthesis method is extended to construct other 9 lattice‚Äêconfined SACs.

item.title: Crystallographic Spin Torque Conductivity Tensor of Epitaxial IrO2 Thin Films for Oxide Spintronics
item.content:encoded:
In this work, all the independent elements of the spin torque conductivity tensor allowed by bulk crystal symmetries are determined for the tetragonal conductor IrO2 epitaxial thin films, via measurements of conventional anti‚Äêdamping torques in the high‚Äêsymmetry (001) and (100) orientations. Rotational transformations of this tensor can predict both the conventional and unconventional torques for IrO2 in the lower‚Äêsymmetry orientations, with good agreement.
Abstract Unconventional spin‚Äêorbit torques arising from electric‚Äêfield‚Äêgenerated spin currents in anisotropic materials have promising potential for spintronic applications, including for perpendicular magnetic switching in high‚Äêdensity memory applications. Here, all the independent elements of the spin torque conductivity tensor allowed by bulk crystal symmetries for the tetragonal conductor IrO2 are determined via measurements of conventional (in‚Äêplane) anti‚Äêdamping torques for IrO2 thin films in the high‚Äêsymmetry (001) and (100) orientations. It is then tested whether rotational transformations of this same tensor can predict both the conventional and unconventional anti‚Äêdamping torques for IrO2 thin films in the lower‚Äêsymmetry (101), (110), and (111) orientations, finding good agreement. The results confirm that spin‚Äêorbit torques from all these orientations are consistent with the bulk symmetries of IrO2, and show how simple measurements of conventional torques from high‚Äêsymmetry orientations of anisotropic thin films can provide an accurate prediction of the unconventional torques from lower‚Äêsymmetry orientations.

item.title: Bioinspired Heterogeneous Surface for Radiative Cooling Enhanced Power‚ÄêFree Moisture Harvesting in Unsaturated Atmosphere
item.content:encoded:
Inspired by the Namib Pachydactylus Rangei, a Power‚ÄêFree Cooling moisture harvester with Luneburg Lens Array is fabricated using Self‚ÄêDeveloped Œº‚ÄêECM process. The synergy between the surface and interface functions endows the PFCMH with Exceptional Passive sub‚ÄêDewpoint Cooling and Efficient Harvesting Performance. Installing every 1 m2 of PFCMH can Yield ‚âà294.5‚Äì490.6¬†kg per year of water and Save ‚âà198.7‚Äì331.0¬†kWh per year of electricity.
Abstract The development of zero‚Äêpower moisture‚Äêharvesting technology in an unsaturated atmosphere is of great significance for coping with global freshwater scarcity. Here, inspired by Pachydactylus rangei's¬†(Namib sand gecko) ability to evade thermal radiation and harvest moisture, a power‚Äêfree cooling moisture harvester (PFCMH) is fabricated using the continuous, industrialized micro‚Äêextrusion compression molding. A Luneburg lens is introduced in the PFCMH for the first time, endowing it with a high reflectivity of ‚âà92.9% in 0.3 to the 2.5¬†¬µm waveband and emissivity of ‚âà98.1% in 8‚Äì13¬†¬µm waveband, which are ‚âà19.2% and ‚âà15.4% higher than those of the unstructured radiative cooler, respectively. Consequently, a temperature reduction of ‚âà6.9 ¬∞C is achieved. In addition, the wettability of PFCMH is well regulated, at a contact angle of ‚âà153¬∞ and a rolling angle of ‚âà42¬∞, enabling its surface to efficiently nucleate and transport water droplets. The synergy between the surface and interface functions endows the PFCMH with exceptional passive sub‚Äêdewpoint cooling and efficient harvesting performance. Importantly, every 1 m2 of PFCMH can yield ‚âà294.5‚Äì490.6¬†kg year‚àí1 of water and save ‚âà198.7‚Äì331.0¬†kWh year‚àí1 of electricity. The PFCMH offers an environmentally, power‚Äêfree, and promising solution to freshwater scarcity.

item.title: Directional Freeze‚ÄêCasting Cryogel Loaded with Quaternized Chitosan Modified Gallium Metal‚ÄìOrganic Frameworks to Capture and Eradicate the Resistant Bacteria for Guided Regeneration in Infected Bone Defects
item.content:encoded:
Antimicrobial resistance and impaired bone regeneration are the great challenges in treating infected bone defects. This work reported a quaternized chitosan (QCS) coated gallium‚Äêbased metal‚Äìorganic frameworks (GaMOF), to capture the Methicillin‚Äêresistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) as a ‚Äúcaptor‚Äù and rejuvenate Methicillin (Me). Then, a radially oriented porous cryogel (Me/QCSGa‚ÄêMOF@Cryogel) is fabricated for combating resistant bacteria and guiding bone regeneration in infected bone defects.
Abstract Antimicrobial resistance and impaired bone regeneration are the great challenges in treating infected bone defects. Its recurrent and resistant nature, high incidence rate, long‚Äêterm hospitalization, and high medical costs have driven the efforts of the scientific community to develop new therapies to improve the situation. Considering the complex microenvironment and persistent mechanisms mediated by resistant bacteria, it is crucial to develop an implant with enhanced osseointegration and sustained and effective infection clearance effects. Here, a positively charged quaternized chitosan (QCS) coated gallium‚Äêbased metal‚Äìorganic framework (GaMOF) is designed, to capture the antibiotic‚Äêresistant bacteria (Methicillin‚Äêresistant Staphylococcus aureus, MRSA) as a ‚Äúcaptor‚Äù, and rejuvenate Methicillin (Me) via disturbing the tricarboxylic acid (TCA) cycle. Then, a radially oriented porous cryogel loaded with the Me and QCSGaMOF is fabricated by the directional freeze‚Äêcasting method. The oriented porous structure has an enhanced osseointegration effect by guiding the ingrowth of osteogenic cells. In vitro and in vivo experiments prove the advantages of as‚Äêprepared Me/QCSGa‚ÄêMOF@Cryogel in combating resistant bacteria and guiding bone regeneration in infected bone defects.

item.title: The First Molecular Ferroelectric Mott Insulator
item.content:encoded:
This article presents the design and characterization of first molecular ferroelectric Mott insulator, (C7H14N)3V12O30. Accompanied by the ferroelectric phase transition, (C7H14N)3V12O30 shows a sharp change in conductivity, implying the metal‚Äìinsulator transition‚Äêlike behavior. This finding opened up new possibilities for the development of strongly correlated electron systems.
Abstract With the discovery of colossal magnetoresistance materials and high‚Äêtemperature superconductors, Mott insulators can potentially undergo a transition from insulating state to metallic state. Here, in molecular ferroelectrics system, a Mott insulator of (C7H14N)3V12O30 has been first synthesized, which is a 2D organic‚Äìinorganic ferroelectric with composition of layered vanadium oxide and quinuclidine ring. Interestingly, accompanied by the ferroelectric phase transition, (C7H14N)3V12O30 changes sharply in conductivity. The occurrence of a Mott transition has been proven by electric transport measurements and theoretical calculations. This research has significantly expanded the applicative horizons of ferroelectric materials, and offering an ideal platform for the investigation of strongly correlated electron systems.

item.title: The Photoinduced Response of Antimony from Femtoseconds to Minutes
item.content:encoded:
The optical properties of antimony make it a promising candidate for photonic memory applications due to the large contrast between crystalline and amorphous solid states. This study resolves the entire switching cycle from crystal to glass and back. It elucidates the structural origin of the optical properties of the final and intermediate transient states, which are relevant for high bandwidth photonic applications.
Abstract As a phase change material (PCM), antimony exhibits a set of desirable properties that make it an interesting candidate for photonic memory applications. These include a large optical contrast between crystalline and amorphous solid states over a wide wavelength range. Switching between the states is possible on nanosecond timescales by applying short heating pulses. The glass state is reached through melting and rapid quenching through a supercooled liquid regime. While initial and final states are easily characterized, little is known about the optical properties on the path to forming a glass. Here we resolve the entire switching cycle of antimony with femtosecond resolution in stroboscopic optical pump‚Äêprobe measurements and combine the experimental results with ab‚Äêinitio molecular dynamics simulations. The glass formation process of antimony is revealed to be a complex multi‚Äêstep process, where the intermediate transient states exhibit distinct optical properties with even larger contrasts than those observed between crystal and glass. The provided quantitative understanding forms the basis for exploitation in high bandwidth photonic¬†applications.

item.title: Synergistic Adhesion and Shape Deformation in Nanowire‚ÄêStructured Liquid Crystal Elastomers
item.content:encoded:
Liquid crystal elastomer films with dense nanowire arrays exhibit synergistic adhesion and shape‚Äêchanging properties. They curl toward the nanowire side under heat or chemical vapors but away from it with liquid droplets. Chemical modifications make them superoleophobic underwater, enabling precise droplet manipulation. This biomimetic design integrates enhanced adhesion with stimuli‚Äêresponsive deformation, with promising applications in soft robotics and adaptive surfaces.
Abstract Nature provides many examples of the benefits of nanoscopic surface structures in areas of adhesion and antifouling. Herein, the design, fabrication, and characterization of liquid crystal elastomer (LCE) films are presented with nanowire surface structures that exhibit tunable stimuli‚Äêresponsive deformations and enhanced adhesion properties. The LCE films are shown to curl toward the side with the nanowires when stimulated by heat or organic solvent vapors. In contrast, when a droplet of the same solvent is placed on the film, it curls away from the nanowire side due to nanowire‚Äêinduced capillary forces that cause unequal swelling. This characteristic curling deformation is shown to be reversible and can be optimized to match curved substrates, maximizing adhesive shear forces. By using chemical modification, the LCE nanowire films can be given underwater superoleophobicity, enabling oil repellency under a range of harsh conditions. This is combined with the nanowire‚Äêinduced frictional asymmetry and the reversible shape deformation to create an underwater droplet mixing robot, capable of performing chemical reactions in aqueous environments. These findings demonstrate the potential of nanowire‚Äêaugmented LCE films for advanced applications in soft robotics, adaptive adhesion, and easy chemical modification, with implications for designing responsive materials that integrate mechanical flexibility with surface functionality.

item.title: Creating Single Atomic Coordination for Hypoxia‚ÄêResistant Pyroptosis Nano‚ÄêInducer to Boost Anti‚ÄêTumor Immunotherapy
item.content:encoded:
Uniform carbon nanodots (HNCDs) that inherit the single atomic Fe‚ÄìN4 center of hemin while creating sp2‚Äêhybridized carbon surroundings were created by a simple solvothermal treatment of hemin. HNCDs synergistically modulated the energy level and electron transfer for converting the type II photodynamic process to type I, thus can significantly induce tumor pyroptosis and evoke strong antitumor immune response even under hypoxic environment.
Abstract General synthesis and mechanical understanding of type I nano‚Äêphotosensitizers are of great importance for hypoxia‚Äêresistant pyroptosis inducers. Herein, a simple solvothermal treatment is developed to convert non‚Äêphotosensitive small molecules (hemin) into uniform carbon nanodots (HNCDs) with strong type I photodynamic activity and red fluorescence emission. These HNCDs inherit the single atomic Fe‚ÄìN4 center of hemin while creating sp2‚Äêhybridized carbon surroundings, which synergistically modulated the energy level and electron transfer for converting the type II photodynamic process to type I. After encapsulating HNCDs with bovine serum albumin (BSA)¬†to facilitate in vivo applications, the resulting BSA nanoparticles (HB) can image tumors and significantly induce the pyroptosis of tumor cells even under an extremely hypoxic environment (2% O2). This evokes a strong antitumor immune response, effectively restraining tumor growth and lung metastasis in triple‚Äênegative breast cancer mice, with good biocompatibility. This work introduces an applicable pyroptosis nano‚Äêinducer to combat hypoxic tumors and highlights the regulation of Fe‚ÄìN4 centers to develop hypoxia‚Äêresistant type I nano‚Äêphotosensitizers for cancer treatment.

item.title: Electric Field‚ÄêInduced Nonreciprocal Directional Dichroism in a Time‚ÄêReversal‚ÄêOdd Antiferromagnet
item.content:encoded:
Electric field‚Äêinduced nonreciprocal directional dichroism (E‚Äêinduced NDD) ascribed to the diagonal electrotoroidic effect is discovered in a time‚Äêreversal‚Äêodd antiferromagnet Co‚ÇÇSiO‚ÇÑ possessing a time‚Äêreversal‚Äêodd scalar quantity, magnetic toroidal monopole. Spatial distribution measurements of E‚Äêinduced NDD reveal domain structures. Magnetic field‚Äêinduced domain inversion mediated by the piezomagnetic effect highlights the rich physics of time‚Äêreversal‚Äêodd antiferromagnets.
Abstract Antiferromagnets with broken time‚Äêreversal (T$\mathcal{T}$) symmetry (T$\mathcal{T}$‚Äêodd antiferromagnets) have gained extensive attention, mainly due to their ferromagnet‚Äêlike behavior despite the absence of net magnetization. However, certain types of T$\mathcal{T}$‚Äêodd antiferromagnets remain inaccessible by the typical ferromagnet‚Äêlike phenomena (e.g., anomalous Hall effect). One such system is characterized by a T$\mathcal{T}$‚Äêodd scalar quantity, the magnetic toroidal monopole. To access the broken T$\mathcal{T}$ symmetry in such a system, a unique nonreciprocal optical phenomenon, electric field‚Äêinduced nonreciprocal directional dichroism (E‚Äêinduced NDD), is employed. Signals of E‚Äêinduced NDD are successfully detected in a T$\mathcal{T}$‚Äêodd antiferromagnet, Co‚ÇÇSiO‚ÇÑ, whose magnetic structure is characterized by the magnetic toroidal monopole. Furthermore, by spatially resolving the E‚Äêinduced NDD, spatial distributions of a pair of domain states related to one another by the T$\mathcal{T}$ operation are visualized. The domain imaging revealed the inversion of the domain pattern by applying a magnetic field, which is explained by trilinear coupling attributed to the piezomagnetic effect. The observation of E‚Äêinduced NDD highlights unique functionalities of T$\mathcal{T}$‚Äêodd antiferromagnets.

item.title: High‚ÄêModulus Homochiral Torsional Oxide Ceramic Artificial Muscles
item.content:encoded:
High‚Äêmodulus homochiral Al2O3 yarn artificial muscles with a different actuation mechanism containing volume expansion and topological structure transformation are fabricated. Under an electric drive, the torsional muscle provides a high actuation stress of 483.5 MPa, a large energy density of 9.8 J¬†g‚àí1, and a high output power of 10.3 W¬†g‚àí1, while maintaining a large stroke of 13.5%.
Abstract Fiber‚Äêbased artificial muscles are soft actuators used to mimic the movement of human muscles. However, using high modulus oxide ceramics to fabricate artificial muscles with high energy and power is a challenge as they are prone to brittle fracture during torsion. Here, a ceramic metallization strategy is reported that solves the problem of low torsion and low ductility of alumina (Al2O3) ceramics by chemical plating a thin copper layer on alumina filaments. These filaments with a high modulus of ‚âà180¬†GPa can be twisted into chiral coiled artificial muscles, exhibiting a unique electric thermal actuation mechanism. This tough and robust alumina artificial muscle can carry objects equivalent to 0.28 million times its weight and provide high actuation stress of up to 483.5¬†MPa. In addition, it exhibits 18 times higher contraction power and 240 times higher energy density than human muscles, as well as a high energy conversion efficiency of up to 7.59%, which far exceeds most reported actuated carbon and polymer artificial muscles. This work has achieved large‚Äêscale manufacturing of high‚Äêmodulus oxide ceramic muscles for the first time.

item.title: Self‚ÄêSustained Biophotocatalytic Nano‚ÄêOrganelle Reactors with Programmable DNA Switches for Combating Tumor Metastasis
item.content:encoded:
To overcome the challenges of limited light penetration and insufficient oxygen supply in PDT for metastatic tumor treatment, a self‚Äêcontained organelle‚Äêmimicking nanoreactor is engineered with DNA switches using cell‚Äêinspired compartmentalization technology. It utilizes endogenous glucose as a biofuel, luminol as a light source, and hemoglobin as an oxygen supplier to achieve self‚Äêilluminating chemiexcited PDT via chemiluminescence resonance energy transfer.
Abstract Metastasis, the leading cause of mortality in cancer patients, presents challenges for conventional photodynamic therapy (PDT) due to its reliance on localized light and oxygen application to tumors. To overcome these limitations, a self‚Äêsustained organelle‚Äêmimicking nanoreactor is developed here with programmable DNA switches that enables bio‚Äêchem‚Äêphotocatalytic cascade‚Äêdriven starvation‚Äêphotodynamic synergistic therapy against tumor metastasis. Emulating the compartmentalization and positional assembly strategies found in living cells, this nano‚Äêorganelle reactor allows quantitative co‚Äêcompartmentalization of multiple functional modules for the designed self‚Äêilluminating chemiexcited PDT system. Within the space‚Äêconfined nanoreactor, biofuel glucose is converted to hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) which enhances luminol‚Äêbased chemiluminescence (CL), consequently driving the generation of photochemical singlet oxygen (1O2) via chemiluminescence resonance energy transfer. Meanwhile, hemoglobin functions as a synchronized oxygen supplier for both glucose oxidation and PDT, while also exhibiting peroxidase‚Äêlike activity to produce hydroxyl radicals (¬∑OH). Crucially, the nanoreactor keeps switching off in normal tissues, with on‚Äêdemand activation in tumors through toehold‚Äêmediated strand displacement. These findings demonstrate that this nanoreactor, which is self‚Äêsufficient in light and oxygen and precise in striking tumors, presents a promising paradigm for managing highly metastatic cancers.

item.title: Flat‚ÄêBand Electronic Bipolarity in a Janus and Kagome van der Waals Semiconductor Nb3TeI7
item.content:encoded:
A Janus and Kagome van der Waals material Nb3TeI7 exhibits strong electronic bipolar states and robust semiconducting properties with the face‚Äêdependent n‚Äêtype and p‚Äêtype field‚Äêeffect transistor behaviors. Strong built‚Äêin out‚Äêof‚Äêplane polarization is attributed to ferroelectric‚Äêlike stacking, amplified by strong electron correlation in the Nb flat bands at the breathing‚ÄêKagome lattice, endowing Nb3TeI7 with a promising material platform for Janus‚Äêmaterial‚Äêbased applications.
Abstract Janus materials, a novel class of materials with two faces of different chemical compositions and electronic polarities, offer significant potential for various applications with catalytic reactions, chemical sensing, and optical or electronic responses. A key aspect for such functionalities is face‚Äêdependent electronic bipolarity, which is usually limited by the chemical distinction of terminated surfaces and has not been exploited in the semiconducting regime. Here, it is showed that a Janus and Kagome van der Waals (vdW) material Nb3TeI7 has ferroelectric‚Äêlike coherent stacking of the Janus layers and hosts strong electronic bipolar states in the semiconducting regime. A large potential difference of ‚àº 0.7¬†eV between the I4 and TeI3 terminated surfaces is observed, despite only one fourth of the I atoms being replaced by Te atoms on one side of the layers. Additionally, robust semiconducting properties with the face‚Äêdependent n‚Äêtype and p‚Äêtype field‚Äêeffect transistor behaviors are demonstrated. These unique properties are attributed to Nb 4d orbital flat bands of the breathing‚ÄêKagome lattice, of which significantly large electron mass makes the semiconducting properties immune to impurity doping, and inherent strong electron correlation enhances asymmetric electron distribution, thereby amplifying a built‚Äêin electric field. These findings highlight that naturally‚Äêgrown Janus and Kagome vdW semiconductors provide a promising material platform for utilizing strong electronic bipolarity in 2D‚Äêmaterial‚Äêbased¬†applications.

item.title: Spin‚ÄêOrbit‚ÄêLocking Vectorial Metasurface Holography
item.content:encoded:
This work presents a general multi‚Äêchannel vectorial holography technique encoded by both the spin and orbital angular momentum using a minimalist, non‚Äêinterleaved, geometry‚Äêphase metasurface. The approach not only substantially enhances the selectivity of the input light, exhibiting spin‚Äêorbit‚Äêlocking behavior, but also expands the multiplexing capacity of the output optical field, opening new avenues for advanced light manipulation.
Abstract Vectorial metasurface holography, allowing for independent control over the amplitude, phase, and polarization distribution of holographic images enabled by metasurfaces, plays a crucial role in the realm of optical display, optical, and quantum communications. However, previous research on vectorial metasurface holography has typically been restricted to single degree of freedom input and single channel output, thereby demonstrating a very limited modulation capacity. This work presents a novel method to achieve multi‚Äêchannel vectorial metasurface holography by harnessing spin‚Äêorbit‚Äêlocking vortex beams. In each channel, the optical vectorial field is encoded with a pair of total angular momentums (TAMs) featuring two orthogonal spin angular momentums (SAMs) independently locked with arbitrary orbital angular momentums (OAMs). The methodology relies on a modified Gerchberg‚ÄêSaxton algorithm, enabling the encoding of various TAM channels within a single phase profile. Consequently, a pure geometry‚Äêphase metasurface with a non‚Äêinterleaved approach can be used to support such multi‚Äêchannel vectorial holography, achieving high selectivity of both SAM and OAM, and offering precise routing and manipulation of complex light channels. The work presents a paradigm shift in the field of holography, offering promising avenues for high‚Äêdensity optical information processing and future photonic device design.

item.title: Ring‚ÄêOpening Polymerization of Surface Ligands Enables Versatile Optical Patterning and Form Factor Flexibility in Quantum Dot Assemblies
item.content:encoded:
Partially ligand‚Äêexchanged InP QDs with lipoic acid can undergo direct optical patterning when exposed to UV light, which induces disulfide ring opening, leading to polymerization and the assembly of the QDs. This approach also allows for the creation of stretchable QD films that can be recycled through reversible polymerization. This study provides a solution for future advanced displays and optoelectronics.
Abstract The evolution of display technologies is rapidly transitioning from traditional screens to advanced augmented reality (AR)/virtual reality (VR) and wearable devices, where quantum dots (QDs) serve as crucial pure‚Äêcolor emitters. While solution processing efficiently forms QD solids, challenges emerge in subsequent stages, such as layer deposition, etching, and solvent immersion. These issues become especially pronounced when developing diverse form factors, necessitating innovative patterning methods that are both reversible and sustainable. Herein, a novel approach utilizing lipoic acid (LA) as a ligand is presented, featuring a carboxylic acid group for QD surface attachment and a reversible disulfide ring structure. Upon i‚Äêline UV exposure, the LA ligand initiates ring‚Äêopening polymerization (ROP), crosslinking the QDs and enhances their solvent resistance. This method enables precise full‚Äêcolor QD patterns with feature sizes as small as 3¬†¬µm and pixel densities exceeding 3788 ppi. Additionally, it supports the fabrication of stretchable QD composites using LA‚Äêderived monomers. The reversible ROP process allows for flexibility, self‚Äêhealing, and QD recovery, promoting sustainability and expanding QD applications for ultra‚Äêfine patterning and on‚Äêsilicon displays.

item.title: Mesoporous Boron‚ÄêDoped Carbon with Curved B4C Active Sites for Highly Efficient H2O2 Electrosynthesis in Neutral Media and Air‚ÄêSupplied Environments
item.content:encoded:
A mesoporous B‚Äêdoped carbon (meso‚ÄêBPC) with highly efficient curved B4C active sites for 2e‚àí oxygen reduction reaction¬†catalyst under a neutral electrolyte is reported. Combining experiments with dentity functional theory¬†calculations, it is revealed that the mesoporous structure and B4C active site on the curved carbon surface significantly improve the oxygen supply and catalytic activity at high current densities and air‚Äêsupplied environments.
Abstract Hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) electrosynthesis via the 2e‚àí oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) is considered as a cost‚Äêeffective and safe alternative to the energy‚Äêintensive anthraquinone process. However, in more practical environments, namely, the use of neutral media and air‚Äêfed cathode environments, slow ORR kinetics and insufficient oxygen supply pose significant challenges to efficient H2O2 production at high current densities. In this work, mesoporous B‚Äêdoped carbons with novel curved B4C active sites, synthesized via a carbon dioxide (CO2) reduction using a pore‚Äêformer agent, to simultaneously achieve excellent 2e‚àí ORR activity and improved mass transfer properties are introduced. Through a combination of experimental analysis and theoretical calculations, it is confirmed that the curved B4C configuration, formed by mesopores in the carbon, demonstrates superior selectivity and activity for 2e‚àí ORR due to its weaker interaction with *OOH intermediates compared to planar B4C in neutral media. Moreover, the mesopores facilitate oxygen supply and suppress the hydrogen evolution reaction, achieving a Faradaic efficiency of 86.2% at 150¬†mA cm‚àí2 under air‚Äêsupplied conditions, along with an impressive O2 utilization efficiency of 93.6%. This approach will provide a route to catalyst design for efficient H2O2 electrosynthesis in a practical environment.

item.title: 1.6‚ÄêInch Transparent Micro‚ÄêDisplay with Pixel Circuit Integrated microLED Chip Array by Misalignment‚ÄêFree Transfer
item.content:encoded:
Herein, this work demonstrates a radical technology that will transforms the current display industry beyond the backplane limits. The pixel circuit integrated micro‚ÄêLED (PIMLED) does not need an active‚Äêmatrix backplane but has an active‚Äêpixel circuit into it. The proposed PIMLED is compatible with intrinsic randomness of fluidic‚Äêbased transfer technology and free from angular misalignment during vertical integration.
Abstract Recent advances in mass transfer technology are expected to bring next‚Äêgeneration micro light‚Äêemitting diodes (¬µLED) displays into reality, although reliable integration of the active‚Äêmatrix backplane with the transferred ¬µLEDs remains as a challenge. Here, the ¬µLED display technology is innovated by demonstrating pixel circuit‚Äêintegrated micro‚ÄêLEDs (PIMLEDs) and integrating them onto a transparent glass substrate. The PIMLED comprises of low‚Äêtemperature poly‚Äêsilicon transistors and GaN ¬µLED. The square‚Äêshaped PIMLED is designed to secure a larger process margin but to reduce misalignment in the subsequent bonding process. Its unique four‚Äêfold rotational symmetric design together with concentric circular pixel electrodes of the substrate makes their massive transfer compatible with intrinsic randomness of fluidic‚Äêbased transfer and free from angular misalignment during wafer bonding. The vertically integrated pixels show similar optical and electrical properties regardless of four possible arrangements. It is demonstrated that a 96 √ó 96 PIMLED display on a transparent glass substrate, which is expected to open a door to novel form‚Äêfactor free and transparent ¬µLED displays.

item.title: Minute‚ÄêLevel Room‚ÄêTemperature Switching and Long Cycle Stability of Thermochromic Inorganic Perovskite Smart Windows
item.content:encoded:
A reversible switching between colored and bleached phases of three colors of inorganic perovskite smart windows is induced using dimethyl sulfoxide vapor at room temperature. Compared with normal houses in field tests, the model houses with three colors of smart windows reached a maximum indoor temperature drop of 2.6, 3.6, and 4.2¬†¬∞C at noon, respectively, showing excellent energy‚Äêsaving potential.
Abstract Perovskite smart windows (PSWs) are widely investigated owing to excellent thermochromic properties, while restricted by poor transition performance and cycle stability. Herein, dimethyl sulfoxide vapor is utilized as an induction reagent for rapid reversible switching at room temperature between the colored and bleached phases. To obtain PSWs with different optical properties and transition performance, red CsPbIBr2, yellow Rb0.5Cs0.5PbIBr2 and brown CsSn0.1Pb0.9IBr2 are prepared through alloying. The perovskites can exhibit reversible switching at 27.4‚Äì34.3¬†¬∞C within 1.9‚Äì5.1¬†min. Even after 100 cycles, they exhibit remarkable stability of luminous transmittance (retention ‚â•97.4%) and transition time (retention ‚â•97.6%). Experimental characterization proves that the reversible switching occurs between colored three‚Äêdimension perovskite phase and bleached zero‚Äêdimension perovskite phase. In the field test (air temperature¬†=¬†21.6‚Äì26.5¬†¬∞C), model houses with PSWs exhibit a maximum indoor temperature drop of 4.2¬†¬∞C. Furthermore, they exhibit considerable temperature modulation ability up to 7.9¬†¬∞C under a solar simulator (temperature of the control model house¬†=¬†60¬†¬∞C). The decrease in the luminous transmittance of the PSWs after 20 days is 2.9%, indicating excellent long‚Äêterm stability. This study offers PSWs with prominent transition performance and long cycle stability.

item.title: Distinct Transmission of Left‚Äê and Right‚ÄêHanded Magnon Modes in Compensated Ferrimagnet/Antiferromagnet Structures
item.content:encoded:
Left‚Äê and right‚Äêhanded magnons, thermally generated in a compensated ferrimagnet Gd3Fe5O12, propagate efficiently through the antiferromagnetic NiO layer. Within NiO, these magnons undergo distinct decay processes, unveiling a chiral selection rule for magnon transmission induced by interfacial spin‚Äêflop coupling. These findings provide new insights for advancing chirality‚Äêbased magnonics.
Abstract The chirality of magnons, exhibiting left‚Äê and right‚Äêhanded polarizations analogous to the counterparts of spin‚Äêup and spin‚Äêdown, has emerged as a promising paradigm for information processing. However, the potential of this paradigm is constrained by the controllable excitation and transmission of chiral magnons. Here, the magnon transmission is explored in the Gd3Fe5O12/NiO/Pt structures. It is demonstrated that both left‚Äê and right‚Äêhanded magnon modes, thermally generated in the compensated ferrimagnet Gd3Fe5O12, can efficiently propagate through the antiferromagnetic NiO layer. Remarkably, these modes undergo distinct decay processes in NiO, manifested by different evolutions of the spin diffusion length with temperature. This behavior can be explained by an exchange model rooted in the spin‚Äêflop magnetic configuration between Gd3Fe5O12 and NiO, which establishes a chiral selection rule for magnon transmission. These findings offer significant fundamental insight into controlling chiral magnons, opening avenues for chirality‚Äêbased magnonics.

item.title: Bifunctional Group Modulation Strategy Enables MR‚ÄêTADF Electroluminescence Toward BT.2020 Green Light Standard
item.content:encoded:
The ‚Äúbifunctional group modulation strategy‚Äù enables precise emission wavelength control while maintaining exceptionally narrow FWHM values. Non‚Äêsensitized pure green OLEDs based on DBNDS‚ÄêTPh exhibited peak EQE of 34.5% and 36.0%, with CIE coordinates of (0.17, 0.76) and (0.19, 0.75) at the doping concentration of 1 and 3 wt.%. This is the first instance of a green OLED in a bottom‚Äêemitting device structure achieving a CIEy value of 0.76.
Abstract Herein, a parallel ‚Äúbifunctional group‚Äù modulation method is proposed to achieve controlled modulation of the emission wavelength and full‚Äêwidth at half‚Äêmaximum (FWHM) values. As a result, three proof‚Äêof‚Äêconcept emitters, namely DBNDS‚ÄêTPh, DBNDS‚ÄêDFPh, and DBNDS‚ÄêCNPh, are designed and synthesized, with the first functional dibenzo[b,d]thiophene unit concurrently reducing the bandgap and elevate their triplet state energy. A second functional group 1,1‚Ä≤:3‚Ä≤,1‚Ä≥‚Äêtriphenyl, and electron acceptors 1,3‚Äêdifluorobenzene and benzonitrile, respectively, to deepen the HOMO and LUMO levels. Accordingly, the CIE coordinates of DBNDS‚ÄêTPh, DBNDS‚ÄêDFPh, and DBNDS‚ÄêCNPh are (0.13, 0.77), (0.14, 0.77), and (0.14, 0.76) respectively, in a dilute toluene solution. This marks the first instance of achieving a CIEy value of 0.77 in dilute toluene solutions. Significantly, the non‚Äêsensitized pure‚Äêgreen OLEDs based on DBNDS‚ÄêTPh and DBNDS‚ÄêDFPh demonstrate peak EQE of 35.0% and 34.5%, with corresponding CIE coordinates of (0.18, 0.75), (0.17, 0.76) at the doping concentration of 1 wt.%, representing the first green OLED with a CIEy value reaching 0.76 in a bottom‚Äêemitting device structure as reported in the literature.

item.title: Protein‚ÄêGuided Biomimetic Calcification Constructing 3D Nitrogen‚ÄêRich Core‚ÄêShell Structures Realizing High‚ÄêPerformance Lithium‚ÄêSulfur Batteries
item.content:encoded:
The crystallization mechanism of the biomimetic calcification method triggers a secondary conformational transition of proteins from Œ±‚Äêhelix to Œ≤‚Äêsheet in solvents. The adoption of the Œ≤‚Äêsheet conformation enhances the affinity for metal ions, thereby intensifying the competitive interaction with organic ligands and expediting crystal formation and encapsulation.
Abstract Biomimetic calcification is a micro‚Äêcrystallization process that mimics the natural biomineralization process, where biomacromolecules regulate the formation of inorganic minerals. In this study, it is presented that a protein‚Äêassisted biomimetic calcification method for the in situ synthesis of nitrogen‚Äêdoped metal‚Äêorganic framework (MOF) materials. A series of unique core‚Äêshell structures are created by utilizing proteins as templates and guiding agents in the nucleation step, creating ideal conditions for shell growth. To further understand the influence of the protein and organic ligand on the morphology of the MOF shell, the competing mechanism toward metal ions is supposed. Through systematic experiments and analyses, a strategy to construct unique precursor structures by controlling calcification nucleation is proposed. After carbonization, protein‚Äêcontaining precursors exhibit exceptional porous characteristics, stability, and high nitrogen content. These attributes make them promising materials as sulfur hosts in lithium‚Äêsulfur batteries (LSB). Electrochemical tests confirm that biomimetic calcification‚Äêassisted 3D carbonaceous structure can effectively immobilize dissolved polysulfides, demonstrating strong adsorption and catalytic capabilities. This discovery not only opens up new avenues for employing biomimetic calcification as a sustainable method for batteries but also enlightens the fields of materials science, catalytic chemistry, and energy storage.

item.title: Multiple Electron Transfers Enable High‚ÄêCapacity Cathode Through Stable Anionic Redox
item.content:encoded:
K2FeSiO4 is synthesized and utilized as a cathode material for potassium‚Äêion batteries. This compound offers advantages including high elemental abundance, low cost, and structural stability. Ultrahigh capacity can be achieved through charge compensation involving Fe cations and O anions during cycling. Additionally, the strong Si‚îÄO bond can effectively immobilize O anions to prevent excessive lattice oxygen loss.
Abstract Single‚Äêelectron transfer, low alkali metal contents, and large‚Äêmolecular masses limit the capacity of cathodes. This study uses a cost‚Äêeffective and light‚Äêmolecular‚Äêmass orthosilicate material, K2FeSiO4, with a high initial potassium content, as a cathode for potassium‚Äêion batteries to enable the transfer of more than one electron. Despite the limited valence change of Fe ions during cycling, K2FeSiO4 can undergo multiple electron transfers via successive oxygen anionic redox reactions to generate a high reversible capacity. Although the formation of O‚ÄíO dimers in K2FeSiO4 occur upon removing large amounts of potassium, the strong binding effect of Si on O mitigates irreversible oxygen release and voltage degradation during cycling. K2FeSiO4 achieves 236 mAh g‚àí1 at 50¬†mA g‚àí1, with an energy density of 520¬†Wh kg‚àí1, which can be comparable with commercial LiFePO4 materials. Moreover, it also exhibits 1400 stable cycles under high‚Äêcurrent conditions. These findings enhance the potential commercialization prospects for potassium‚Äêion batteries.

item.title: Sargassum Nanocellulose‚ÄêBased Fully Ingestible Supercapacitor
item.content:encoded:
Using food‚Äêsafe sargassum nanocellulose as the binder framework, combined with food‚Äêgrade additives, a highly biocompatible fully ingestible supercapacitor is successfully employed. This design introduces high mechanical strength and fast ion transport behavior of the nanofiber, achieving a disposable power supply and electrical stimulation antibacterial in vivo, which provides a promising alternative power source for novel medical electronic devices.
Abstract Small high‚Äêperformance energy modules have significant practical value in the biomedical field, such as painless diagnosis, alleviation of gastrointestinal discomfort, and electrical stimulation therapy. However, due to performance limitations and safety concerns, it is a formidable challenge to design a small, emerging ingestible power supply. Here, a fully ingestible supercapacitor (FISC) constructed of sargassum cellulose nanofiber is presented. FISCs exhibit an electrode areal capacitance of 2.29 F cm‚àí2 and a high energy density of 307 ¬µWh cm‚àí2. Furthermore, over 90% of the antibacterial activity against Escherichia coli is achieved during the self‚Äêdischarge process. Therefore, following insertion into an enteric capsule, this device can enable a disposable power supply and electrostimulation for bacteriostasis in the intestine after being swallowed by a human, which offers new possibilities for scientific and simple therapy.

item.title: Efficient and Scalable Direct Regeneration of Spent Layered Cathode Materials via Advanced Oxidation
item.content:encoded:
A novel advanced oxidation strategy leverages the inherent catalytic activity of spent layered cathode materials, facilitating the decomposition of H2O2 to generate ‚Ä¢OH and ‚Ä¢O2‚àí free radicals, which promote oxidation reactions with the surface of the spent cathode. It effectively elevates the Ni valence state, modifies the surface microstructure, and eliminates fluorine‚Äêcontaining interface impurities, thereby promoting the solid‚Äêstate regeneration process.
Abstract Among direct recycling methods for spent lithium‚Äêion batteries, solid‚Äêstate regeneration is the route with minimal bottlenecks for industrial application and is highly compatible with the current industrial cathode materials production processes. However, surface structure degradation and interfacial impurities of spent cathodes significantly hinder Li+ replenishment during restoration. Herein, we propose a unique advanced oxidation strategy that leverages the inherent catalytic activity of spent layered cathode materials to address these challenges. This strategy decomposes H2O2 to generate ‚Ä¢OH and ‚Ä¢O2‚àí free radicals, facilitating oxidation reactions with the surface of the spent cathode. As a result, this approach effectively elevates the Ni valence state, modifies the surface microstructure, and eliminates fluorine‚Äêcontaining interface impurities, thereby promoting the solid‚Äêstate regeneration process. The regenerated LiNi0.83Co0.12Mn0.05O2 cathodes demonstrate a specific capacity of 206¬†mAh¬†g‚àí1 at 0.1 C, comparable to commercially available cathodes. Meanwhile, this advanced oxidation strategy proves adaptable and scalable for treating industrial dismantled LiNi0.5Co0.2Mn0.3O2 black mass. A 3.1¬†Ah pouch cell assembled with the regenerated LiNi0.5Co0.2Mn0.3O2 exhibits impressive capacity retention of 74% after 500 cycles. Additionally, a techno‚Äêeconomic analysis reveals that this strategy possesses low energy consumption, minimal environmental footprint, and high economic viability, suggesting its suitability for the battery recycling industry.

item.title: Synergistic Control of Ferroelectric and Optical Properties in Molecular Ferroelectric for Multiplexing Nonvolatile Memory
item.content:encoded:
This work focuses on the synergistic control between ferroelectric polarization (FP) and optical properties in the molecular ferroelectric material, TMCM‚ÄêMnCl3. It demonstrates that FP can modulate the photoluminescence (PL) emission, while optical writing can trigger FP reversal. This enables a seamless transition between electric‚Äêwriting optical‚Äêreading and optical‚Äêwriting electrical‚Äêreading modes, hinting at the viability of implementing multiplexing and multistate memory in ferroelectric fields.
Abstract Utilizing the correlation among diverse physical properties to facilitate multiplexing and multistate memory is anticipated to emerge as an efficient strategy to enhance memory capacity, achieve device miniaturization, and ensure information security. As an important functional material, ferroelectrics have long been considered as a potential candidate in multistate memory devices. Furthermore, the integration of optical response offers an alternative path to realizing multiplexing features, further enhancing the versatility and efficiency of these devices. However, combining ferroelectricity and optical activity is always challenging because ferroelectricity is very sensitive to the crystal structure. In this study, on the correlation between ferroelectric polarization (FP) and optical properties in molecular ferroelectric material, trimethylchloromethyl ammonium trichloromanganese (TMCM‚ÄêMnCl3) is reported. This research demonstrated that the FP can modulate the photoluminescence (PL) emission, while optical illumination can trigger FP reversal. Based on these, both electric‚Äêwriting optical‚Äêreading (EWOR) and optical‚Äêwriting electrical‚Äêreading (OWER) modes have been conclusively established, and the seamless transition between these two modes can be achieved by adjusting the excitation light intensity. These findings reveal an intriguing physical interconnection and imply the viability of implementing multiplexing and multistate memory functionalities in systems based on ferroelectrics.

item.title: Anti‚ÄêScattering Perovskite Scintillator Arrays for High‚ÄêResolution Computed Tomography Imaging
item.content:encoded:
An anti‚Äêscattering CsPbBr3 scintillator array embedded within a polyurethane acrylate matrix for CT imaging significantly suppresses light scattering and enhances the light collection efficiency by nearly two times compared to the monolithic film. The scintillator array provides a high spatial‚Äêresolution 3D reconstructed tooth image at a low X‚Äêray dosage in CT imaging.
Abstract Computed tomography (CT) imaging has emerge as an effective medical diagnostic technique due to its rapid and 3D imaging capabilities, often employing indirect imaging methods through scintillator materials. Arraying scintillators that can confine light scattering to enable high‚Äêresolution CT imaging remains an area of ongoing exploration for emerging perovskite scintillators. Here an anti‚Äêscattering cesium lead bromide (CsPbBr3) scintillator array embedded within a polyurethane acrylate matrix for CT imaging using a cost‚Äêeffective solution‚Äêprocessed method is reported. Due to the large refractive index contrast between the scintillator and matrix, photon propagation can be well confined within the CsPbBr3 scintillator array to significantly suppress the light scattering and enhance the light collection efficiency by nearly two times compared to the monolithic film. Furthermore, the scintillator array exhibits low‚Äêdosage and high‚Äêresolution CT imaging capability by reconstructing a 3D tooth image with a good spatial resolution of 20.1 lp cm‚àí1 at a low effective dose of 0.22 mSv. This work highlights that the CsPbBr3 scintillator array is a highly promising candidate for CT imaging.

item.title: 2D Nanochannel Interlayer Realizing High‚ÄêPerformance Lithium‚ÄìSulfur Batteries
item.content:encoded:
2D porous silica nanosheets (PSN)/MXene nanochannel interlayer with selective cation transport characteristics facilitates lithium ion rapid transport while rejects translocation of polysulfides, and the raised p‚Äêband center of the surface O on PSN helps enhance polysulfide conversion kinetics. This work well addresses polysulfide shuttling and dendritic lithium growth, opening up new avenues for expanding application of nanofluidics in electrochemical energy storage and conversion.
Abstract Commercialization of lithium‚Äìsulfur (Li‚ÄìS) batteries is largely limited by polysulfide shuttling and sluggish kinetics. Herein, 2D nanochannel interlayer composed of alternatively‚Äêstacked porous silica nanosheets (PSN) and Ti3C2Tx‚ÄêMXene are developed. The 2D nanochannels with selective cation transport characteristics facilitate lithium ion rapid transport, while reject the translocation of polysulfide anions across the separator. The hydroxylated MXene shifts the p‚Äêband center of the surface O on PSN closer to the Fermi level, leading to strong absorptive/catalytic effect for polysulfides and thus fast polysulfide transformation kinetics. Together with the ion/electron bi‚Äêconduction function of PSN/MXene, the Li‚ÄìS batteries deliver high initial capacity of 1443 mAh g‚àí1 at 0.1 C, low‚Äêcapacity decay rate of 0.049% per cycle over 800 cycles at 2 C, and excellent rate capability. At a high sulfur loading of 5.2¬†mg cm‚àí2, the cells present higher areal specific capacity than commercial lithium ion batteries. The pouch cells with lean electrolyte (E/S = 3.9¬†¬µL mg‚àí1) yield a capacity of 2‚ÄêAh at 100¬†mA, high energy density and excellent cycling stability. This contribution opens up new avenues for expanding application of 2D nanofluidics in electrochemical energy storage and conversion.

item.title: Piezoelectric Vitamin‚ÄêBased Self‚ÄêAssemblies for Energy Generation
item.content:encoded:
This work systematically explores piezoelectric response of vitamin‚Äêbased self‚Äêassemblies for power generation. Vitamin molecules can self‚Äêassemble into different supramolecular structures exhibiting tunable predicted piezoelectric coefficients. Vitamin B7 D‚Äêbiotin (D‚ÄêBIO) self‚Äêassemblies with high piezoelectricity are fabricated into piezoelectric devices for human motion monitoring and energy harvesting. These findings will facilitate the exploration and development of biomolecule‚Äêbased piezoelectric materials.
Abstract Structural diversity of biomolecules leads to various supramolecular organizations and asymmetric architectures of self‚Äêassemblies with significant piezoelectric response. However, the piezoelectricity of biomolecular self‚Äêassemblies has not been fully explored and the relationship between supramolecular structures and piezoelectricity remains poorly understood, which hinders the development of piezoelectric biomaterials. Herein, for the first time, the piezoelectricity of vitamin‚Äêbased self‚Äêassemblies for power generation is systematically explored. X‚Äêray diffraction studies revealed that vitamin molecules can self‚Äêassemble into different supramolecular structures, which exhibited tunable piezoelectric coefficients ranging from 3.8 to 42.8 pC¬†N‚àí1 by density functional theory (DFT) calculations. Notably, vitamin B7 D‚Äêbiotin (D‚ÄêBIO) self‚Äêassemblies exhibited superior piezoelectricity due to low crystal symmetry and high polarization of supramolecular arrangements. The D‚ÄêBIO assemblies‚Äêbased piezoelectric nanogenerator (PENG) produced output voltages of ‚âà0.8 V under a mechanical force of 47 N, showing high mechanical durability after 5400 pressing‚Äêreleasing cycles and high stability of at least three months. The PENG‚Äêbased wearable sensor successfully detected bending motions of human limbs. Furthermore, the PENG‚Äêbased insole converted biomechanical energy into stable electrical energy upon foot movement, illuminating 12 light‚Äêemitting diodes (LEDs). This work fills knowledge gaps in piezoelectricity of vitamin‚Äêbased self‚Äêassemblies, providing paradigms for realizing high‚Äêperformance piezoelectric biomaterials through supramolecular engineering.

item.title: Shear‚ÄêMediated Stabilization of Spin Spiral Order in Multiferroic NiI2
item.content:encoded:
The magneto‚Äêstructural phases of 2D multiferroic NiI2 are studied using resonant magnetic X‚Äêray scattering and X‚Äêray diffraction. A change of magnetic symmetry from incommensurate collinear to helical spin‚Äêspiral at a structural transition involving a significant interlayer shear is observed. These results highlight the role for interlayer magnetic exchange for driving the magnetic ground state and associated spin‚Äêinduced ferroelectricity in NiI2.
Abstract Type‚ÄêII multiferroicity from non‚Äêcollinear spin order is recently explored in the van der Waals material NiI2. Despite the importance for improper ferroelectricity, the microscopic mechanism of the helimagnetic order remains poorly understood. Here, the magneto‚Äêstructural phases of NiI2 are investigated using resonant magnetic X‚Äêray scattering (RXS) and X‚Äêray diffraction. Two competing magnetic phases are identified. Below 60 K, an incommensurate magnetic reflection (q¬†‚âà¬†[0.143,0,1.49] reciprocal lattice units) is observed which exhibits finite circular dichroism in RXS, signaling the inversion symmetry‚Äêbreaking helimagnetic ground state. At elevated temperature, in the non‚Äêpolar phase (60 K¬†<¬†T¬†<¬†75 K), a distinct q¬†‚âà¬†[0.087,0.087,1.5] magnetic order is observed, attributed to a collinear incommensurate (CI) state. The first‚Äêorder CI‚Äêhelix transition is concomitant with a structural transition characterized by a significant interlayer shear, which drives the helimagnetic ground state as evidenced by a mean‚Äêfield Heisenberg model including interlayer exchange and its coupling to the structural distortion. These findings identify interlayer magneto‚Äêstructural coupling as the key driver behind multiferroicity in NiI2.

item.title: Fluorine Doping‚ÄêAssisted Reconstruction of Isolated Cu Sites for CO2 Electroreduction Toward Multicarbon Products
item.content:encoded:
Fluorine (F) doping is an efficient strategy to facilitate the in situ aggregation of Cu single atoms and stabilize Cu+ species. Consequently, the F‚Äêdoped Cu single‚Äêatom catalyst exhibits outstanding performance in CO2 electroreduction toward multicarbon products, achieving ultrahigh Cu utilization. This is attributed to the formation of abundant Cu nanocrystals with a high ratio of stable Cu+ species.
Abstract The electrocatalytic synthesis of multicarbon compounds from CO2 is a promising method for storing renewable electricity and addressing global CO2 issues. Single‚Äêatom catalysts are promising candidates for CO2 reduction, but producing high‚Äêvalue multicarbon (C2+) products using a single‚Äêatom structure remains a significant challenge. In this study, a fluorine doping strategy is proposed to facilitate the reconstruction of isolated Cu atoms, promoting multicarbon generation. The in situ formed Cu nanocrystals contain a substantial amount of stable Cu+ species, demonstrating remarkable activity for CO2‚àíto‚Äêmulticarbon conversion. Notably, they achieve the highest Cu utilization, with a C2+ partial current density of ‚àí2.01 A mgper Cu‚àí1and a C2+ formation rate of 7.03¬†mmol h‚àí1 mgper Cu‚àí1at ‚âà‚àí1¬†V versus RHE. In situ Raman spectroscopy and density functional theory calculations confirm the crucial role of fluorine atoms in structural evolution and electrolysis.

item.title: Machine Learning‚ÄêAssisted High‚ÄêThroughput Screening of Nanozymes for Ulcerative Colitis
item.content:encoded:
A data‚Äêdriven design strategy is developed for UC therapeutic nanozymes. The optimal CT‚Äêimageable oral UC therapeutic nanozyme SrDy2O4 is successfully discovered and the high‚Äêdimensional structure‚Äêactivity relationships between the material database and nanozyme UC therapeutics are further elucidated by machine learning model interpretation in combination with the SISSO method.
Abstract Ulcerative colitis (UC) is a chronic gastrointestinal inflammatory disorder with rising prevalence. Due to the recurrent and difficult‚Äêto‚Äêtreat nature of UC symptoms, current pharmacological treatments fail to meet patients' expectations. This study presents a machine learning‚Äêassisted high‚Äêthroughput screening strategy to expedite the discovery of efficient nanozymes for UC treatment. Therapeutic requirements, including antioxidant property, acid stability, and zeta potential, are quantified and predicted by using a machine learning model. Non‚Äêquantifiable attributes, including intestinal barrier repair efficacy and biosafety, are assessed via high‚Äêthroughput screening. Feature significance analysis, sure independence screening, and sparsifying operator symbolic regression reveal the high‚Äêdimensional structure‚Äêactivity relationships between material features and therapeutic needs. SrDy2O4 with high stability, low toxicity, targeting ability, and reactive oxygen species (ROS) scavenging capability is identified, which reduces ROS production, lowers cytochrome C levels in cytoplasm, and inhibits apoptosis in intestinal epithelial cells by stabilizing the mitochondrial membrane potential. Mice treated with SrDy2O4 show improvements in colon length and body weight compared with dextran sodium sulfate salt‚Äêtreated model group. Transcriptomic and 16S rRNA sequencing analyses show that SrDy2O4 boosts beneficial gut bacteria, and decreases pathogenic bacteria, thereby effectively restoring gut microbiota balance. Moreover, SrDy2O4 offers the advantage of X‚Äêray imaging without side effects.

item.title: Stabilizing Layered Oxide Cathodes Based on Universal Surface Residual Alkali Conversion Chemistry for Rechargeable Secondary Batteries
item.content:encoded:
This work presents a universal surface residual alkali conversion strategy based on NH4F treatment and ring‚Äêopening polymerization of tetrahydrofuran. The approach transforms residual alkali into a stable polymer coating which can enhance interfacial stability, suppress lattice oxygen release and reduce side reactions, providing a promising solution to overcome residual alkali and interfacial instability issues for layered oxide cathodes in practical application.
Abstract Layered transition metal oxides (LTMOs) are attractive cathode candidates for rechargeable secondary batteries because of their high theoretical capacity. Unfortunately, LTMOs suffer from severe capacity attenuation, voltage decay, and sluggish kinetics, resulting from irreversible lattice oxygen evolution and unstable cathode‚Äêelectrolyte interface. Besides, LTMOs accumulate surface residual alkali species, like hydroxides and carbonates, during synthesis, limiting their practical application. Herein, a universal strategy is suggested to in situ convert surface residual alkali into a stable polymer coating layer for LTMOs, thus turning wastes into treasure. The formation process of polymer coating involves NH4F treatment to consume residual alkali, then utilizing generated fluorides to induce the ring‚Äêopening polymerization of tetrahydrofuran. Implementing this strategy to Li‚Äêrich Mn‚Äêbased cathode materials (LRM) results in a notable reduction in voltage hysteresis, along with enhanced kinetics and cycling stability in lithium‚Äêion batteries. With this layer of encapsulation, surface lattice oxygen release and layered‚Äêto‚Äêspinel phase transition of LRM are significantly alleviated with minimal mechanical degradation and surface parasitic reactions. Such strategy can also be applied to air‚Äêsensitive sodium‚Äêrich LTMOs in sodium‚Äêion batteries,¬†which showcases superior universality. This work might provide a promising solution to overcome residual alkali and interfacial instability issues for LTMOs in practical application.

item.title: Enhanced Photocatalytic Efficiency Through Oxygen Vacancy‚ÄêDriven Molecular Epitaxial Growth of Metal‚ÄìOrganic Frameworks on BiVO4
item.content:encoded:
This article introduces an innovative method, achieving molecular‚Äêlevel epitaxial growth of metal‚Äìorganic frameworks (MOF) on BiVO4 photoanodes by precisely controlling the concentration of surface oxygen vacancies. The seamless interface of BiVO4/MOF optimizes electron transfer and reduces recombination losses, elevating the overall efficiency of the PEC water oxidation.
Abstract Efficient charge separation at the semiconductor/cocatalyst interface is crucial for high‚Äêperformance photoelectrodes, as it directly influences the availability of surface charges for solar water oxidation. However, establishing strong molecular‚Äêlevel connections between these interfaces to achieve superior interfacial quality presents significant challenges. This study introduces an innovative electrochemical etching method that generates a high concentration of oxygen vacancy sites on BiVO4 surfaces (Ov‚ÄêBiVO4), enabling interactions with the oxygen‚Äêrich ligands of MIL‚Äê101. This reduces the formation energy and promotes conformal growth on BiVO4. The Ov‚ÄêBiVO4/MIL‚Äê101 composite exhibits an ideal semiconductor/cocatalyst interface, achieving an impressive photocurrent density of 5.91 mA cm‚àí2 at 1.23 VRHE, along with excellent stability. This high‚Äêperforming photoanode enables an unbiased tandem device with an Ov‚ÄêBiVO4/MIL‚Äê101‚ÄêSi solar cell system, achieving a solar‚Äêto‚Äêhydrogen efficiency of 4.33%. The molecular‚Äêlevel integration mitigates surface states and enhances the internal electric field, facilitating the migration of photogenerated holes into the MIL‚Äê101 overlayer. This process activates highly efficient Fe catalytic sites, which effectively adsorb water molecules, lowering the energy barrier for water oxidation and improving interfacial kinetics. Further studies confirm the broad applicability of oxygen vacancy‚Äêinduced molecular epitaxial growth in various MOFs, offering valuable insights into defect engineering for optimizing interfaces and enhancing photocatalytic activity.

item.title: Boosting Thermoelectric Performance of Semicrystalline Conducting Polymers by Simply Adding Nucleating Agent
item.content:encoded:
Simply adding a nucleating agent N,N‚Ä≤‚Äê(1,4‚Äêphenyl)diisonicotinamide (PDA)¬†to poly(2,5‚Äêbis(3‚Äêalkylthiophen‚Äê2‚Äêyl)thieno[3,2‚Äêb]thiophene (PBTTT‚ÄêC14) precisely tunes its crystallization and maximizes structural order. The improved molecular packing reduces disorder and elevates charge mobility. With optimized doping, this polymer achieves remarkable electrical conductivity (up to 1968¬†S¬†cm‚Åª¬π) and a power factor ‚âà176¬†¬µW¬†m‚àí1¬†K‚àí2, expanding possibilities for high‚Äêperformance thermoelectrics.
Abstract Controlling the microstructure of semiconducting polymers is critical for optimizing thermoelectric performance, yet remains challenging, requiring complex processing techniques like alignment. In this study, a straightforward strategy is introduced to enhance the thermoelectric properties of semi‚Äêcrystalline polymer films by incorporating minimal amounts of nucleating agents, a method widely used in traditional polymer industries. By blending less than 1 wt% of N,N‚Ä≤‚Äê(1,4‚Äêphenyl)diisonicotinamide (PDA) into poly(2,5‚Äêbis(3‚Äêalkylthiophen‚Äê2‚Äêyl)thieno[3,2‚Äêb]thiophene) (PBTTT‚ÄêC14), controlled modulation of crystallization behavior is achieved, resulting in reduced structural disorder and enhanced charge carrier mobility. Systematic investigations reveal that an optimal PDA loading of 0.9 wt% increases the crystallization degree by 45% compared to pristine PBTTT‚ÄêC14 films. Under these optimized conditions, the PDA‚Äêmodified PBTTT‚ÄêC14 films exhibit a maximum electrical conductivity of 1,894¬†S¬†cm‚àí1 and a maximum power factor of 176¬†¬µW¬†m‚àí1¬†K‚àí2, showing improvements of 96% and 433%, respectively, over doped pristine PBTTT‚ÄêC14 films. These gains are attributed to the synergistic effects of polymer chain extension and reduced grain boundary resistance, which collectively enhance charge transport efficiency. Additionally, ion exchange doping is found to maintain a high charge carrier concentration while preserving the crystallinity introduced by PDA, paving the way for advanced thermoelectric materials and next‚Äêgeneration polymer‚Äêbased electronics.

item.title: A Robust, Biodegradable, and Fire‚ÄêRetardant Cellulose Nanofibers‚ÄêBased Structural Material Fabricated from Natural Sargassum
item.content:encoded:
Cellulose nanofiber and alginate from natural sargassum are used to prepare a fire‚Äêretardant structural material through a hydrogel layer‚Äêby‚Äêlayer method. This bio‚Äêbased material has excellent mechanical properties, thermal stability, and fire retardancy. This work greatly improves the utilization of seaweed residues and natural polymers, provides a bio‚Äêbased fire‚Äêretardant strategy, and has important potential in the future development of high‚Äêperformance fiber‚Äêbased materials.
Abstract With increasing concern about the environmental pollution of petrochemical plastics, people are constantly exploring environmentally friendly and sustainable alternative materials. Compared with petrochemical materials, cellulose has overwhelming superiority in terms of mechanical properties, thermal properties, cost, and biodegradability. However, the flammability of cellulose hinders its practical application to a certain extent, so improving the fire‚Äêretardant properties of cellulose nanofiber‚Äêbased materials has become a research focus. Here, cellulose nanofiber and alginate are extracted from abundant natural sargassum as high‚Äêstrength nanoscale building blocks, and then a sargassum cellulose fire‚Äêretardant structural material is prepared through a bottom‚Äêup hydrogel layer‚Äêby‚Äêlayer method. The structural materials obtained incorporate excellent mechanical properties (‚âà297 MPa), thermal stability (‚âà200¬†¬∞C), low thermal expansion coefficient (‚âà7.17 √ó 10‚àí6 K‚àí1), and fire‚Äêretardant properties. This work largely improves the utilization of seaweed residue and natural polymers, providing a bio‚Äêbased fire‚Äêretardant strategy, and has a wide range of development prospects in the field of fiber‚Äêbased high‚Äêperformance structural materials in the future.

item.title: Phase‚ÄêEngineered Bi‚ÄêRuO2 Single‚ÄêAtom Alloy Oxide Boosting Oxygen Evolution Electrocatalysis in Proton Exchange Membrane Water Electrolyzer
item.content:encoded:
A unique Bi‚ÄêRuO2 single‚Äêatom alloy oxide is rational designed and achieved by phase engineering of the hexagonal close‚Äêpacked RuBi single‚Äêatom alloy, to boost oxygen evolution electrocatalysis. The incorporation of Bi1 improves the activity by electronic density optimization and the stability by hindering surface Ru demetallation, enabling a practical proton exchange membrane water electrolyzer (PEMWE) that needs only 1.59 V to reach 1.0 A cm‚àí2.
Abstract Engineering nanomaterials at single‚Äêatomic sites can enable unprecedented catalytic properties for broad applications, yet it remains challenging to do so on RuO2‚Äêbased electrocatalysts for proton exchange membrane water electrolyzer (PEMWE). Herein, the rational design and construction of Bi‚ÄêRuO2 single‚Äêatom alloy oxide (SAAO) are presented to boost acidic oxygen evolution reaction (OER), via phase engineering a novel hexagonal close packed (hcp) RuBi single‚Äêatom alloy. This Bi‚ÄêRuO2 SAAO electrocatalyst exhibits a low overpotential of 192¬†mV and superb stability over 650¬†h at 10¬†mA cm‚àí2, enabling a practical PEMWE that needs only 1.59¬†V to reach 1.0 A cm‚àí2 under industrial conditions. Operando differential electrochemical mass spectroscopy analysis, coupled with density functional theory studies, confirmed the adsorbate‚Äêevolving mechanism on Bi‚ÄêRuO2 SAAO and that the incorporation of Bi1 improves the activity by electronic density optimization and the stability by hindering surface Ru demetallation. This work not only introduces a new strategy to fabricate high‚Äêperformance electrocatalysts at atomic‚Äêlevel, but also demonstrates their potential use in industrial electrolyzers.

item.title: A Wenzel Interfaces Design for Homogeneous Solute Distribution Obtains Efficient and Stable Perovskite Solar Cells
item.content:encoded:
A Wenzel model is successfully constructed at the interface to achieve a super‚Äêhydrophilic substrate, greatly alleviating the coffee‚Äêring effect during the large‚Äêarea perovskite film printing process. The highly hydrophilic nature of the interface, along with its unique microstructure, greatly facilitates the efficient and rapid deposition of perovskite colloidal particles during the printing process.
Abstract The coffee‚Äêring effect, caused by uneven deposition of colloidal particles in perovskite precursor solutions, leads to poor uniformity in perovskite films prepared through large‚Äêarea printing. In this work, the surface of SnO2 is roughened to construct a Wenzel model, successfully achieving a super‚Äêhydrophilic interface. This modification significantly accelerates the spreading of the perovskite precursor solution, reducing the response delay time of perovskite colloidal particles during the printing process. Additionally, the micro‚Äêspherical depression structure on the SnO2 surface effectively inhibits the migration of colloidal particles toward the edges of liquid film, trapping perovskite colloidal particles at the buried interfaces and improving film uniformity. Due to the synergistic effect of super‚Äêhydrophilicity and micro‚Äêrough structure on the surface of SnO2, leading to a substantial improvement in the quality of perovskite crystals. Therefore, the efficiency of printing prepared flexible devices (0.101 cm2) reached 25.42% (certified 25.12%). Moreover, the efficiency of rigid and flexible large‚Äêscale perovskite solar modules (PSMs) based on meniscus‚Äêcoating manufacture reached 21.34% and 16.99% (100 cm2), respectively, and demonstrated superior environmental stability by maintaining an initial efficiency of 91% after being stored in atmospheric conditions for 2000 h, offering practical guidance for fabricating high‚Äêperformance and stable large‚Äêscale perovskite solar cells (PSCs).

item.title: Microglial‚ÄêBiomimetic Memantine‚ÄêLoaded Polydopamine Nanomedicines for Alleviating Depression
item.content:encoded:
A microglial‚Äêbiomimetic memantine‚Äêloaded polydopamine nanomedicine, PDA‚ÄêMem@M, that achieves blood‚Äêbrain barrier penetration and brain inflammation site targeting for rapid and precise treatment of depression is designed. PDA‚ÄêMem@M effectively alleviate depression‚Äêlike behaviors. This synergistic strategy, with satisfactory biosafety and strong anti‚Äêinflammatory and synaptic plasticity restoration effects, is conducive to advances in depression therapy.
Abstract Depression is a common psychiatric disorder, and monoamine‚Äêbased antidepressants as first‚Äêline therapy remain ineffective in some patients. The synergistic modulation of neuroinflammation and neuroplasticity could be a major strategy for treating depression. In this study, an inflammation‚Äêtargeted microglial biomimetic system, PDA‚ÄêMem@M, is reported for treating depression. Microglial membrane‚Äêcoated nanoparticles penetrate the blood‚Äêbrain barrier and facilitate microglial targeting. Subsequently, owing to the excellent free radical‚Äêscavenging capacity, PDA‚ÄêMem@M attenuate¬†the brain inflammatory microenvironment. After on‚Äêdemand release from the nanoparticles, memantine increases¬†the expression of brain‚Äêderived neurotrophic factors and reverses¬†the loss of synaptic dendritic spines. Further, in vivo studies demonstrate that PDA‚ÄêMem@M effectively alleviate¬†depression‚Äêlike behaviors to a greater extent than memantine or polydopamine nanoparticles (PDA) monotherapy. This synergistic strategy, with satisfactory biosafety and strong anti‚Äêinflammatory and synaptic plasticity restoration effects, is conducive to advances in depression therapy.

item.title: Phytic Acid‚ÄêInduced Gradient Hydrogels for Highly Sensitive and Broad Range Pressure Sensing
item.content:encoded:
Distinct interactions between phytic acid and various polymers are discovered first and leveraged to construct a gradient ionic hydrogel‚Äêbased pressure sensor, which offers excellent sensitivity, wide sensing range, and superior low‚Äêpressure detection performance. The gradient ionic hydrogel‚Äêbased sensor recognizes subtle pressures from acoustic waves and airflow, moderate pressures due to speaking and finger pressing, and high magnitudes of plantar pressures.
Abstract Ionic conductive hydrogels have emerged as an excellent option for constructing dielectric layers of interfacial iontronic sensors. Among these, gradient ionic hydrogels, due to the intrinsic gradient elastic modulus, can achieve a wide range of pressure responses. However, the fabrication of gradient hydrogels with optimal mechanical and sensing properties remains a challenge. In this study, it is discovered first that phytic acid (PA) interacts in remarkably distinct manners (i.e., plasticizing effects and phase separation) with different polymers (i.e., polyacrylamide and polyacrylic acid). This distinctive PA‚Äêpolymer interacting mechanism is innovatively utilized to construct a modulus gradient ionic hydrogel through a simple precursor solution infiltration approach. The gradient hydrogel‚Äêbased flexible pressure sensor not only achieves a high sensitivity (9.00¬†kPa‚àí1, <15¬†kPa) and a broad sensing range (from ‚âà3.7¬†Pa to 1.2¬†MPa) simultaneously, but also exhibits superior low pressure sensing performance. It successfully recognizes the subtle pressure due to acoustic waves and airflow, as well as the moderate pressure due to speaking and finger pressing and the high magnitude of plantar pressure. In addition, the gradient hydrogel demonstrates remarkable antibacterial properties and biocompatibility. This functional hydrogel with excellent sensing performance and bioactivity exhibits exceptional potential for wearable sensing applications.

item.title: All Light Controlled Five State Logic Gates on a Ferroelectric Ceramic Chip
item.content:encoded:
A novel planar three‚Äêelectrode structure is constructed on the Ti3+ self‚Äêdoping 0.5Ba(Zr0.2TI0.8)O3‚Äê0.5(Ba0.7Ca0.3)TiO3 (BZT‚ÄêBCT) ceramic surface that has an obvious photovoltaic and pyroelectric response. Through a specific polarization method, the device shows a region‚Äêdependent photoelectric response. Based on this, five basic optoelectronic logic gates are achieved on a single ferroelectric ceramic chip.
Abstract Differentiating photoelectric response in a single material with a simple approach is desirable for all‚Äêin‚Äêone optoelectronic logical devices. In ferroelectric materials, significantly distinct photoelectric features should be observed if they are in diverse polarization states, unveiling a possible pathway to realize multifunctional optoelectronic logic gates through ferroelectric polarization design. In this study, the Ti3+ self‚Äêdoping strategy is first applied to 0.5Ba(Zr0.2Ti0.8)O3‚Äê0.5(Ba0.7Ca0.3)TiO3 ferroelectric ceramics (BZT‚ÄêBCT‚ÄêxT) through co‚Äêfiring metallic Ti powders and BZT‚ÄêBCT powders to enhance photoelectric output. Subsequently, on the BZT‚ÄêBCT‚Äê3T ceramic surface that has optimal photoelectric properties, three individual regions are separated and heterogeneously polarized by using a novel planar three‚Äêelectrodes structure. Intriguing illumination region‚Äêdependent photocurrent directions are demonstrated in this as‚Äêfabricated device. Based on this, five basic optoelectronic logic gates are integrated into single ferroelectric ceramic via fully light‚Äêcontrolled methods, including ‚ÄúAND‚Äù, ‚ÄúOR‚Äù, ‚ÄúNOT‚Äù, ‚ÄúNAND‚Äù and ‚ÄúNOR‚Äù. These gates can be readily switched by simply altering the output electrodes or light intensity of 405¬†nm LED modulating light. This work not only puts forward an innovative strategy for designing ferroelectric optoelectronic logic gates, but also provides feasibility for more ferroelectric materials to be applied in logical devices.

item.title: Supramolecular Organic Nanofiller: A New Reinforcement Strategy for Dynamic Covalent Polymer Networks Toward Upcycling of Carbon Fiber Composites
item.content:encoded:
A new reinforcement strategy for DCPN involving the in situ formation of supramolecular organic nanofillers via asynchronous polymerization is proposed. The reinforcement and recyclability of the supramolecular organic nanofillers on DCPN considerably exceed those of traditional methods. This reinforcement strategy is versatile and can be successfully applied for the upcycling of high‚Äêperformance CF composites.
Abstract Dynamic covalent polymer networks (DCPN) provide an important solution to the challenging recyclability of thermoset elastomers.
