However, dynamic bonds exhibit relatively weak bond energies, considerably decreasing the mechanical properties of DCPN. Herein, a novel reinforcement strategy for DCPN involving the in situ formation of supramolecular organic nanofillers through asynchronous polymerization is proposed. Owing to the difference in the reactivity of the isocyanate groups and the gradual deblocking of aldimine, asynchronous cross‚Äêlinking of hexamethylene diisocyanate and isocyanate‚Äêterminated prepolymer containing dynamic oxime‚Äìurethane bonds with the deblocked tris(2‚Äêaminoethyl)amine facilitates the transition from the molecular interpenetration of chains into immiscible polymerization. This results in thermodynamic incompatibility between the hyperbranched clusters and long chains, inducing a spontaneous formation of supramolecular organic nanofillers. Compared to traditional reinforcement strategies, supramolecular organic nanofillers considerably improve the mechanical properties of DCPN. Furthermore, the supramolecular interactions between hyperbranched clusters and dynamic oxime‚Äìurethane bonds enable the network with excellent recyclability. The unique reinforcement and recyclability of the prepared DCPN allow their combination with carbon fibers (CF) to form CF composites with outstanding properties for personal‚Äêprotection applications, achieving CF composite upcycling. This study offers a novel strategy on the reinforcement of DCPN and the upcycling of high‚Äêperformance CF composites.

item.title: A Tribo/Piezoelectric Nanogenerator Based on Bio‚ÄêMOFs for Energy Harvesting and Antibacterial Wearable Device
item.content:encoded:
Based on two kinds of biomolecule‚ÄêMOFs, we construct a self‚Äêpowered multi‚Äêfunctional wearable device by combining Zn‚ÄêCar_MOF and patterned PDMS to achieve various environmental energy collection (water droplets, ocean energy, and e‚Äêbike driving) and human gait detection, when Thy loaded Cu‚ÄêHHTP_MOF combined with wearable fibers are cooperated with Zn‚ÄêCar_TPHG, achieving electrocatalytic ROS generation and drug releasing synergistic sterilization.
Abstract New types of metal‚Äìorganic framework (MOF) materials have great potential in solving the current global dilemma on energy, environment, and medical care. Herein, based on two kinds of biomolecule‚ÄêMOFs (Bio‚ÄêMOFs) with favorable biocompatibility and degradation‚Äêreconstruction characteristics, we have established a self‚Äêpowered muti‚Äêfunctional device to achieve an efficient and broad‚Äêspectrum environmental energy collection and biomedical applications. Combining Zn(II) and carnosine‚Äêbased Zn‚ÄêCar_MOF possessing a high piezoelectric response (d33 = 11.17 pm V‚àí1) with patterned polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) film, a tribo‚Äêpiezoelectric hybrid nanogenerator (TPHG) is constructed with a synergy output of triboelectric and piezoelectric effects. The Zn‚ÄêCar_TPHG demonstrates a high output performance (131¬†V at 100¬†kPa) and a wide range of pressure response (1¬†Pa‚Äì100¬†kPa), possessing applications in environmental energy collection and biomedical sensors. To expand the application of the wearable device, a conductive hexagonal prism MOF (Cu3(2,3,6,7,10,11‚Äêhexahydroxytriphenylene)2 (Cu‚ÄêHHTP)) is synthesized and employed to load thymol (Thy). Cooperating with Zn‚ÄêCar_TPHG, the resulting Cu‚ÄêHHTP/Thy can achieve an efficient self‚Äêpowered ROS (singlet oxygen (1O2) and hydroxyl radical (¬∑OH)) generation and drug synergistic broad‚Äêspectrum sterilization effect (efficiency ‚â• 98%). In a word, the flexible wearable device based on the muti‚Äêfunctional Bio‚ÄêMOFs is sustainable and environmentally friendly, possessing wide application potential in fields of environmental energy collection, biosensors, and self‚Äêpowered antibacterial.

item.title: Ultrafast Preparation of High‚ÄêEntropy NASICON Cathode Enables Stabilized Multielectron Redox and Wide‚ÄêTemperature (‚àí50‚Äì60¬†¬∞C) Workability in Sodium‚ÄêIon Batteries
item.content:encoded:
The high‚Äêentropy Na3.45V0.4Fe0.4Ti0.4Mn0.45Cr0.35(PO4)3 cathode material prepared by ultrafast high temperature shock inhibits the possibility of phase separation and achieves the reversible and stable multielectron transfer, fabulous cycling stability and excellent wide‚Äêtemperature range operation from ‚àí50 to 60¬†¬∞C. The ultrafast sintering strategy provides a broad platform for the development of polyanionic materials for long‚Äêlifespan and all‚Äêclimate sodium‚Äêion batteries.
Abstract Avoiding severe structural distortion, irreversible phase transition, and realizing the stabilized multielectron redox are vital for promoting the development of high‚Äêperformance NASICON‚Äêtype cathode materials for sodium‚Äêion batteries (SIBs). Herein, a high‚Äêentropy Na3.45V0.4Fe0.4Ti0.4Mn0.45Cr0.35(PO4)3 (HE‚ÄêNa3.45TMP) cathode material is prepared by ultrafast high‚Äêtemperature shock, which inhibits the possibility of phase separation and achieves reversible and stable multielectron transfer of 2.4/2.8 e‚àí at voltage range of 2.0‚Äì4.45/1.5‚Äì4.45 V versus Na+/Na (the capacity of 137.2/162.0 mAh g‚àí1). The galvanostatic charge/discharge and in‚Äêsitu X‚Äêray diffraction tests indicate the sequential redox reactions and approximate solid solution phase transition behavior of HE‚ÄêNa3.45TMP. Density functional theory calculations analyze the migration pathways and energy barriers, further confirming the superior reaction kinetics of HE‚ÄêNa3.45TMP. Accordingly, the HE‚ÄêNa3.45TMP exhibits outstanding wide temperature applicability and can operate stably in the temperature range of ‚àí50‚Äì60¬†¬∞C, accompanied by a capacity retention of 92.8% after 400 cycles at ‚àí40¬†¬∞C and a capacity of 73.7 mAh g‚àí1 even at ‚àí50¬†¬∞C. The assembled hard carbon//HE‚ÄêNa3.45TMP full‚Äêcell offers an energy density of ‚âà301 Wh kg‚àí1 based on total cathode and anode active mass, verifying the application feasibility of HE‚ÄêNa3.45TMP. This work provides an innovative and ultrafast pathway to rationally fabricate high‚Äêperformance cathodes for SIBs.

item.title: Nano‚ÄêMetal‚ÄìOrganic Frameworks Isolated in Mesoporous Structures
item.content:encoded:
This work reports a general methodology for in situ synthesis of eight nanoMOFs which are exclusively located inside the internal mesochannels. This is the first report of the complete impregnation and even dispersion of nanoscale MOFs within the interior channels of mesoporous carbons, which can regulate Zn2+ plating electrochemistry toward stable aqueous Zn batteries.
Abstract As an alternative to bulk counterparts, metal‚Äìorganic framework (MOF) nanoparticles isolated within conductive mesoporous carbon matrices are of increasing interest for electrochemical applications. Although promising, a ‚Äúclean‚Äù carbon surface is generally associated with poor compatibility and weak interactions with metal/ligand precursors, which leads to the growth of MOFs with inhomogeneous particle sizes on outer pore walls. Here, a general methodology for in situ synthesis of eight nanoMOF composites within mesochannels with high dispersity and stability are reported. Mesoporous polydopamine (mesoPDA)‚ÄêF127 nanospheres with unique surface chemistry, e.g., nanoconfined spaces, catechol functional groups, pyrrolic N doping, and hydrophilic PEO blocks, are found to be a suitable molecular platform. Sliced cross‚Äêsectional TEM, HAADF‚ÄêSTEM, and corresponding EDS elemental mapping, as well as nitrogen adsorption characterizations, are utilized to visualize the in situ growth process of ZIF‚Äê8 nanoparticles. These careful analyses provides direct evidence that the highly dispersed ZIF‚Äê8 is exclusively located inside the internal mesochannels. After moderate carbonization of the mesoPDA‚ÄêF127/ZIF‚Äê8 nanocomposites, a prototype for a mesoporous carbon‚Äêisolated ZIF‚Äê8 nanostructure is achieved, which can regulate Zn2+ plating electrochemistry toward stable aqueous Zn batteries. This is the first report of the complete impregnation and even dispersion of nanoscale MOFs within the interior channels of mesoporous carbons.

item.title: Maximizing Output Energy via Suppressing Charge Loss and Increasing Load Voltage in Charge Extraction Process
item.content:encoded:
A new charge loss and a voltage loss model are proposed and a historical record output energy density of 5.03 J m‚àí2 is achieved by the effective collection of interface tribo‚Äêcharges and the increase in load voltage during the charge extraction process.
Abstract The effective collection of interfacial tribo‚Äêcharges and an increase in load voltage are two essential factors that improve the output energy of triboelectric nanogenerators. However, some tribo‚Äêcharges are hardly collected through one or multiple integrated side electrodes based on corona discharge, and their load voltages are limited by air breakdown in adjacent electrodes. In this study, a dynamic quasi‚Äêdipole potential distribution model is proposed to systematically reveal the mechanisms of interfacial tribo‚Äêcharge loss. Based on this model, an optimization route is designed to reduce the interfacial charge loss stepwise, achieving a 15‚Äêfold improvement in charge collection from the tribo‚Äêinterface.¬†A potential difference enhancement strategy is used for the first time to increase the air breakdown threshold between the inner electrodes and increase the output voltage under a large load. By effective increase in charge collection efficiency and load voltage, a historical record output energy density of 5.03 J m‚àí2 is obtained. This study refined and optimized the interfacial charge loss mechanisms and provided advanced guidance for efficiently extracting energy during the triboelectrification process.

item.title: 3D‚ÄêPorous Electrocatalyst with Tip‚ÄêEnhanced Electric Field Effect Enables High‚ÄêPerformance Proton Exchange Membrane Water Electrolyzer
item.content:encoded:
An efficiently reactant‚Äêenriched and mass traffic system is developed through integrating high‚Äêcurvature Pt nanocones with a 3D porous TiAl framework. The 3D multiple interconnected channels in TiAl boosts the mass transport rate, while the high curvature of Pt nanocones induces an ultrahigh local electric field, thereby accelerating the transfer of H3O+ during HER.
Abstract Hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), as one of the most advanced methods for the green production of hydrogen, is greatly impeded by inefficient mass transfer. Here we present an efficiently reactant enriched and mass traffic system by integrating high‚Äêcurvature Pt nanocones with 3D porous TiAl framework to enhance mass transfer rate. Theoretical simulations, in situ Raman spectroscopy and potential‚Äêdependent Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy results disclose that the strong local electric field induced by high‚Äêcurvature Pt can greatly promote the H3O+ supply rate during HER, resulting in ‚àº1.6 times higher H3O+ concentration around the Pt nanocone than that in electrolyte. X‚Äêray computed tomography and molecular dynamic simulation demonstrate the diffusion coefficient of H3O+ in 3D TiAl framework surpasses that in commercial carbon support by more than 16.7 times. Consequently, Pt/TiAl‚Äênanocone exhibits a high mass activity of 17.2 mA cm‚àí2Pt at an overpotential of 100 mV with an ultrahigh TOF value of 42.9 atom‚àí1 s‚àí1. In a proton exchange membrane water electrolyzer, the Pt/TiAl‚Äênanocone cathode achieves an industrial‚Äêscale current density of 1.0 A cm‚àí2 with a cell voltage of 1.88 V at 60 ¬∞C and can operate stably for at least 800 h with a sluggish voltage decay rate of 137 ¬µV h‚àí1.

item.title: Local Polarization Piezoelectric Electric Field Promoted Water Dissociation for Hydroxyl Radical Generation under Ambient Humidity Condition
item.content:encoded:
The generated local polarization piezoelectric field (LPPEF) can be significantly enhanced through ball milling piezoelectric Pb2B5O9Cl (PBOC) by adsorbing trace amounts of water under ambient humidity conditions. Under this circumstance, the energy barrier for water dissociation can be largely lowered, thus facilitating the breaking of H‚ÄìO‚ÄìH bonds and the generation of hydroxyl radicals.
Abstract Combining piezocatalysts with mechanical ball milling for dissociating water to generate hydroxyl radicals (¬∑OH) offers unprecedented opportunities for energy conversion and environmental remediation. However, the in‚Äêdepth insights into the relationship between water and local polarization piezoelectric electric field (LPPEF) are currently lacking, in particularly, the ¬∑OH formation mechanism in ball milling driven piezocatalyst system is not systematically elucidated. To this end, the present work constructs a ball milling driven piezoelectric solid/liquid interface between piezoelectric Pb2B5O9Cl (PBOC) and different contents of water to investigate LPPEF initiated catalytic reaction. Results show that PBOC exhibits an excellent Tetrabromobisphenol A (TBBPA) degradation efficiency with a 68.94 and 12.43 times faster rate constant than traditional SiO2 and BaTiO3, respectively. Under ambient humidity condition, the lower energy barrier of water dissociation (0.23¬†eV) endows ¬∑OH generation more energetically favorable than under the water‚Äêoversaturated condition (0.66¬†eV), and trace water magnifies the polarizability of [BO3] and [BO4] units in PBOC to initiate an enhanced LPPEF, thus it enhances the trapping of lone pairs electrons in trace adsorbed water by holes to contribute a higher yield of ¬∑OH. This study constructs a highly correlated field‚Äêinitiated electron transfer system that provides opportunities for promoting the performance of piezocatalytic materials.

item.title: Plasmonic Single‚ÄêMolecule Affinity Detection at 10‚àí20 Molar
item.content:encoded:
Surface‚Äêplasmon‚Äêresonance (SPR) typically detects in the nanomolar range. A pH‚Äêconditioning of a physisorbed biolayer, hosting trillions of capturing antibodies or probes enables SPR to detect a single protein or DNA‚Äêstrand in 0.1 mL of plasma. The pH‚Äêconditioning transition the biolayer in a metastable state where a single affinity‚Äêbiding event can trigger an amplification mechanism involving a broad self‚Äêpropagating electrostatic rearrangement
Abstract DNA can be readily amplified through replication, enabling the detection of a single‚Äêtarget copy. A comparable performance for proteins in immunoassays has yet to be fully assessed. Surface‚Äêplasmon‚Äêresonance (SPR) serves as a probe capable of performing assays at concentrations typically around 10‚Åª‚Åπ molar. In this study, plasmonic single‚Äêmolecule assays for both proteins and DNA are demonstrated, achieving limits‚Äêof‚Äêdetections (LODs) as low as 10‚Åª2‚Å∞ molar (1¬†¬±¬†1 molecule in 0.1¬†mL), even in human serum, in 1 h. This represents an improvement in typical SPR LODs by eleven orders‚Äêof‚Äêmagnitude. The single‚Äêmolecule SPR assay is achieved with a millimeter‚Äêwide surface functionalized with a physisorbed biolayer comprising trillions of recognition‚Äêelements (antibodies or protein‚Äìprobe complexes) which undergo an acidic or alkaline pH‚Äêconditioning. Potentiometric and surface‚Äêprobing imaging experiments reveal the phenomenon underlying this extraordinary performance enhancement. The data suggest an unexplored amplification process within the biomaterial, where pH‚Äêconditioning, driving the biolayer in a metastable state, induces a self‚Äêpropagating aggregation of partially misfolded proteins, following single‚Äêaffinity binding. This process triggers an electrostatic rearrangement, resulting in the displacement of a charge equivalent to 1.5e per 102 recognition elements. Such findings open new opportunities for reliable SPR‚Äêbased biosensing at the physical detection limits, with promising applications in point‚Äêof‚Äêcare plasmonic systems.

item.title: Bioinspired Electrostatic Capture‚Äêand‚ÄêRelease System for Precise Microdroplet Manipulation
item.content:encoded:
This work introduces an innovative electrostatic capture‚Äêand‚Äêrelease manipulator enabling precise microdroplet emission and transportation. Utilizing electrostatic forces and dielectric pinning, it achieves controlled, contamination‚Äêfree manipulation of nanoscale droplets. The study explores its application in diverse fields, including microfluidics, chemical reactions, and material fabrication, offering a sustainable and highly accurate platform for droplet‚Äêbased technologies.
Abstract The application of physical fields is crucial for droplet generation and manipulation, underpinning technologies like printing, microfluidic biochips, drug delivery, and flexible sensors. Despite advancements, precise micro/nanoscale droplet generation and accurate microfluidic reactions remain challenging. Inspired by the liquid ejection mechanisms in microscopic organisms, an electrostatic manipulator for the precise capture, emission, and transport of microdroplets is proposed. This approach enables the controlled and periodic emission of nanoscale daughter droplets from microscale parent droplets, achieved through dielectric pinning on surfaces and electrostatic field‚Äêdriven forces. Results show precise nanoscale droplet release on inert polymer surfaces, enabling directional, contamination‚Äêfree liquid manipulation. Moreover, leveraging surface treatment techniques and robust electrostatic force‚Äêdriven transportation, a versatile strategy for droplet generation and manipulation, spanning from microfluidic devices to chemical reaction operations. The novel droplet manipulation phenomena and control strategies can advance the fields of electrostatic‚Äêbased microfluidics, materials fabrication, and beyond.

item.title: Tailored Colloidal Shapes in Precursor Solutions for Efficient Blade‚ÄêCoated Perovskite Solar Modules
item.content:encoded:
Ellipsoidal colloids are tailored in the perovskite precursor solution by incorporating perovskite colloids and polymer additives. Due to the anisotropic driven force from the fluidic flow in the meniscus, perovskite film demonstrates more oriented packing during the blade‚Äêcoating process. The regulated PSCs and PSMs achieve PCE of 24.31% and 21.67% (21.37% certified), respectively, for aperture areas of 0.09 and 13.94¬†cm2.
Abstract Metal halide perovskite solar cells (PSCs) have emerged as one of the most promising candidates for next‚Äêgeneration photovoltaic technologies. However, perovskite films deposited by blade‚Äêcoating usually exhibit inferior film morphology compared to those fabricated by spin‚Äêcoating, which hinders the power conversion efficiency (PCE) and stability of the scalable perovskite solar modules (PSMs). Herein, ellipsoidal colloids are tailored in the perovskite precursor solution by incorporating perovskite colloids and polymer additives. Compared to unregulated spherical colloids, the ellipsoidal colloids demonstrate more oriented packing during the blade‚Äêcoating process, which is due to the anisotropic driven force from the fluidic flow in the meniscus. As a result of the improved film morphology, the regulated PSCs and PSMs achieve superior PCE of 24.31% and 21.67% (21.37% certified), respectively, for aperture areas of 0.09 and 13.94 cm2, and 89% initial PCE after 600¬†h continuous operation.

item.title: Spin State Modulation with Oxygen Vacancy Orientates C/N Intermediates for Urea Electrosynthesis of Ultrahigh Efficiency
item.content:encoded:
Tailored transformation of high‚Äêspin Ni2+ (t2g6eg2) into low‚Äêspin Ni3+ (t2g6eg1) by introducing oxygen vacancies (Ov) can enhance reduction/adsorption of NO3‚Äí‚Üí*NO and subsequent protonation to generate *NH2 intermediate, which in situ acts as a localized proton donor to promote *CO2‚Üí*COOH on adjacent Ce3+‚ÄìO site for generating *CO intermediate, following by cross‚Äêcoupling of the reduced C‚Äê/N‚Äêintermediates to achieve efficient urea electrosynthesis.
Abstract The co‚Äêelectrolysis of CO2 and NO3‚àí to synthesize urea has become an effective pathway to alternate the conventional Bosch‚ÄêMeiser process, while the complexity of C‚Äê/N‚Äêcontaining intermediates for C‚àíN coupling results in the urea electrosynthesis of unsatisfactory efficiency. In this work, an electronic spin state modulation maneuver with oxygen vacancies (Ov) is unveiled to effectively meliorate the oriented generation of key intermediates *NH2 and *CO for C‚àíN coupling, furnishing urea in ultrahigh yield of 2175.47¬†¬µg mg‚àí1¬†h‚àí1 and Faraday efficiency of 70.1%. Mechanistic studies expound that Ov can induce the conversion of the high‚Äêspin state Ni2+ (t2g6eg2) of Ni@CeO2‚àíx to the low‚Äêspin state Ni3+ (t2g6eg1), which markedly enhances the hybridization degree of the Ni 3d and the N 2p orbitals of *NO, facilitating the selective formation of *NH2. Notably, the in situ generated *NH2 intermediates can serve as a localized proton donor to promote the electroreduction of CO2 on the adjacent site Ce3+‚àíO to exclusively afford *CO, followed by C‚àíN coupling of each other to efficiently synthesize urea. The strategy of tailored switching of the active site spin state provides a reliable reference to rectify the electronic structure of electrocatalysts for directional CO2 valorization.

item.title: Engineering EVs‚ÄêMediated mRNA Delivery Regulates Microglia Function and Alleviates Depressive‚ÄêLike Behaviors
item.content:encoded:
The dual delivery system employing extracellular vesicles to mediate the co‚Äêdelivery of mRNA and nanozymes exhibits synergistic effects on endoplasmic reticulum stress, mitochondrial injury, and their functional crosstalk. This system is capable of regulating microglia function from many aspects, including inhibiting NF‚ÄêŒ∫B signaling pathway, inhibiting microglia overactivation, and promoting microglia M2 polarization, and ultimately ameliorates depressive behaviors.
Abstract The development of new non‚Äêneurotransmitter drugs is an important supplement to the clinical treatment of major depressive disorder. The latest development of mRNA therapy provides the possibility for the treatment of some major diseases. The endoplasmic reticulum (ER) and mitochondria constitute a highly interconnected set of fundamental organelles within cells. The interconnection between them forms specific microdomains that play pivotal roles in calcium signaling, mitochondrial dynamics, inflammation, and autophagy. Perturbations in ER‚Äêmitochondrial connections may contribute to the progression of neurological disorders and other diseases. Herein, an extracellular vesicles‚Äêbased delivery system, grounded in mRNA gene therapy and integrated with nanomedicine technology is devised. This system is engineered to traverse the blood‚Äìbrain barrier and specifically target the central nervous system (CNS), facilitating the simultaneous delivery of mRNA drugs and metallic nanozymes into the brain. This dual‚Äêpronged approach, targeting ER and mitochondrial crosstalk, inhibits microglial overactivation, promotes M2 polarization of microglia, and suppresses the NF‚ÄêŒ∫B signaling pathway. Consequently, it significantly alleviates Lipopolysaccharides‚Äêinduced neuroinflammatory responses and ameliorates anxiety‚Äê and depression‚Äêlike behaviors. This study demonstrates a novel antidepressant therapeutic strategy and establishes a new paradigm for mRNA gene therapy in CNS diseases.

item.title: Electrocatalytic Biomass Oxidation via Acid‚ÄêInduced In Situ Surface Reconstruction of Multivalent State Coexistence in Metal Foams
item.content:encoded:
Electrochemical biomass conversion offers a sustainable alternative to conventional chemical processes. This study introduces a novel acid‚Äêinduced in situ surface reconstruction strategy on metal foams, enabling efficient biomass transformation. The approach is versatile, adaptable across metals and acids, and provides a scalable platform for green chemistry, demonstrating significant potential for advancing resource recycling and sustainable industrial applications.
Abstract Electrocatalytic biomass conversion offers a sustainable route for producing organic chemicals, with electrode design being critical to determining reaction rate and selectivity. Herein, a prediction‚Äêsynthesis‚Äêvalidation approach is developed to obtain electrodes for precise biomass conversion, where the coexistence of multiple metal valence states leads to excellent electrocatalytic performance due to the activated redox cycle. This promising integrated foam electrode is developed via acid‚Äêinduced surface reconstruction to in situ generate highly active metal (oxy)hydroxide or oxide (MOxHy or MOx) species¬†on inert foam electrodes, facilitating the electrooxidation of 5‚Äêhydroxymethylfurfural (5‚ÄêHMF) to 2,5‚Äêfurandicarboxylic acid (FDCA). Taking nickel foam electrode as an example, the resulting NiOxHy/Ni catalyst, featuring the coexistence of multivalent states of Ni, exhibits remarkable activity and stability with a FDCA yields over 95% and a Faradaic efficiency of 99%. In situ Raman spectroscopy and theoretical analysis reveal an Ni(OH)2/NiOOH‚Äêmediated indirect pathway, with the chemical oxidation of 5‚ÄêHMF as the rate‚Äêlimiting step. Furthermore, this in situ surface reconstruction approach can be extended to various metal foams (Fe, Cu, FeNi, and NiMo), offering a mild, scalable, and cost‚Äêeffective method for preparing potent foam catalysts. This approach promotes a circular economy by enabling more efficient biomass conversion processes, providing a versatile and impactful tool in the field of sustainable catalysis.

item.title: Bioinspired Smart Triboelectric Soft Pneumatic Actuator‚ÄêEnabled Hand Rehabilitation Robot
item.content:encoded:
An innovative, lobster tail‚Äêinspired triboelectric soft pneumatic actuator (TENG‚ÄêSPA) is introduced, featuring self‚Äêpowered sensing capabilities. Leveraging these features, a smart TENG‚ÄêSPA‚Äêenabled hand rehabilitation robot is developed, showing great promise in replacing the traditional assessment method‚Äîwhich relies on clinicians for manual stretching, subjective resistance evaluation, and experience‚Äêbased scoring‚Äîthereby driving the transformation from traditional rehabilitation medicine to modern digital rehabilitation medicine.
Abstract Quantitative assessment for post‚Äêstroke spasticity remains a significant challenge due to the encountered variable resistance during passive stretching, which can lead to the widely used modified Ashworth scale (MAS) for spasticity assessment depending heavily on rehabilitation physicians. To address these challenges, a high‚Äêforce‚Äêoutput triboelectric soft pneumatic actuator¬†(TENG‚ÄêSPA) inspired by a lobster tail is developed. The bioinspired TENG‚ÄêSPA can generate approximately 20 N at 0.1¬†MPa, providing sufficient stretching force for spastic fingers. The anti‚Äêinterference, durability, and electrical output characteristics of the TENG‚ÄêSPA under varying conditions‚Äîsuch as different air pressures, bending frequencies, and simulated spastic finger stretching‚Äîare explored, demonstrating TENG‚ÄêSPA's ability to sense resistance during the stretching process. Furthermore, a TENG‚ÄêSPA‚Äêenabled hand rehabilitation robot system integrated with the convolutional neural network (CNN) is further developed, which is tested in a clinical trial involving 15 stroke patients. The results have demonstrated that a classification accuracy for the levels of finger spasticity reaches 93.3% and the MAS scores predicted by the CNN regression model exhibit a strong linear relationship with the actual MAS (R2 = 0.8451, p <¬†0.01). This study presents promising potential applications in digital rehabilitation medicine, human‚Äìmachine interaction, biomedicine, and related fields.

item.title: Engineering Highly Aligned and Densely Populated Cardiac Muscle Bundles via Fibrin Remodeling in 3D‚ÄêPrinted Anisotropic Microfibrous Lattices
item.content:encoded:
This study presents the development of 3D‚Äêprinted anisotropic InterPore microfibrous lattices for engineering aligned and densely populated cardiac muscle bundles. By promoting cardiomyocyte alignment and facilitating cell‚Äêmediated remodeling in these lattices, the approach improves high‚Äêdensity tissue organization, enhances electrophysiological function, and supports the maturation of cardiac tissues.
Abstract Replicating the structural and functional features of native myocardium, particularly its high‚Äêdensity cellular alignment and efficient electrical connectivity, is essential for engineering functional cardiac tissues. Here, novel electrohydrodynamically printed InterPore microfibrous lattices with anisotropic architectures are introduced to promote high‚Äêdensity cellular alignment and enhanced tissue interconnectivity. The interconnected pores in the microfibrous lattice enable dynamic, cell‚Äêmediated remodeling of fibrous hydrogels, resulting in continuous, mechanically stable tissue bundles. Compared to lattices with isolated pores, the engineered aligned cardiac tissues from neonatal rat cardiomyocytes exhibit improved electrophysiological properties and synchronous contractions. Using a multiseeding strategy, an equivalent cell seeding density of 8 √ó 107 cells¬†mL‚àí1, facilitating the formation of multicellular, vascularized cardiac structures with maintained tissue viability and integrity, is achieved. As a demonstration, human‚Äêinduced pluripotent stem cell‚Äêderived cardiac tissues are engineered with progressive maturation and functional integration over time. These findings underscore the potential of InterPore microfibrous lattices for applications in cardiac tissue engineering, drug discovery, and therapeutic development.

item.title: Dynamic Reconstruction of Fluid Interface Manipulated by Fluid Balancing Agent for Scalable Efficient Perovskite Solar Cells
item.content:encoded:
Methanol (MeOH) is introduced as a fluid balance agent to regulate Marangoni convection, thereby mitigating disordered colloidal particle motion. As a result, record power conversion efficiencies of 24.45% and 20.32% are achieved for small‚Äêarea FAPbI3 devices (0.07¬†cm2) and large‚Äêarea modules (21¬†cm2), respectively.
Abstract Laboratory‚Äêscale spin‚Äêcoating techniques are widely employed for fabricating small‚Äêsize, high‚Äêefficiency perovskite solar cells. However, achieving large‚Äêarea, high‚Äêuniformity perovskite films and thus high‚Äêefficiency solar cell devices remain challenging due to the complex fluid dynamics and drying behaviors of perovskite precursor solutions during large‚Äêarea fabrication processes. In this work, a high‚Äêquality, pinhole‚Äêfree, large‚Äêarea FAPbI3 perovskite film is successfully obtained via scalable blade‚Äêcoating technology, assisted by a novel bidirectional Marangoni convection strategy. By incorporating methanol (MeOH) as a fluid balance agent, the direction of Marangoni convection is effectively regulated, mitigating the disordered motion of colloidal precursor particles during the printing process. As a result, champion power conversion efficiencies (PCEs) of 24.45% and 20.32% are achieved for small‚Äêarea FAPbI3 devices (0.07¬†cm2) and large‚Äêarea modules (21¬†cm2), respectively. Notably, under steady illumination, the device reached a stabilized PCE of 24.28%. Furthermore, the unencapsulated device exhibited remarkable operational stability, retaining 92.03% of its initial PCE after 1800¬†h under ambient conditions (35¬†¬±¬†5% relative humidity, 30¬†¬∞C). To demonstrate the universality of this strategy, a blue perovskite light‚Äêemitting diode is fabricated, showing an external quantum efficiency (EQE) of 14.78% and an electroluminescence wavelength (EL) of 494¬†nm. This work provides a significant technique for advancing solution‚Äêprocessed, industrial‚Äêscale production of high‚Äêquality and stable perovskite films and solar cells.

item.title: Sole‚ÄêSolvent High‚ÄêEntropy Electrolyte Realizes Wide‚ÄêTemperature and High‚ÄêVoltage Practical Anode‚ÄêFree Sodium Pouch Cells
item.content:encoded:
A sole‚Äêsolvent high‚Äêentropy electrolyte is capable of forming stable anion‚Äêderived electrode‚Äìelectrolyte interphases, extending the temperature extremes of the battery. Consequently, high‚Äêvoltage anode‚Äêfree sodium batteries with cycling ability in a wide temperature range (‚àí20‚Äì60¬†¬∞C) are realized. Furthermore, Ah‚Äêlevel pouch cell delivers a leadingly high energy density (209 Wh kg‚àí1) and a high capacity retention (83.1%) after 100 cycles at 25¬†¬∞C.
Abstract Anode‚Äêfree sodium batteries (AFSBs) hold great promise for high‚Äêdensity energy storage. However, high‚Äêvoltage AFSBs, especially those can stably cycle at a wide temperature range are challenging due to the poor electrolyte compatibility toward both the cathode and anode. Herein, high‚Äêvoltage AFSBs with cycling ability in a wide temperature range (‚àí20‚Äì60¬†¬∞C) are realized for the first time via a sole‚Äêsolvent high‚Äêentropy electrolyte based on the diethylene glycol dibutyl ether solvent (D2) and NaPF6 salt. The sole‚Äêsolvent high‚Äêentropy electrolyte with unique solvent‚Äêions effect of strong anion interaction and weak cation solvation enables entropy‚Äêdriven electrolyte salt disassociation and high‚Äêconcentration contact ion pairs, thus simultaneously forming stable anion‚Äêderived electrode‚Äìelectrolyte interphases on cathode and anode. Moreover, the wide liquid range of D2 further extends the temperature extremes of the battery. Consequently, ampere‚Äêhour (Ah)‚Äêlevel anode‚Äêfree sodium pouch cells with cyclability in a wide temperature range of ‚àí20‚Äì60¬†¬∞C are realized. Impressively, the pouch cell achieves a leadingly high cell‚Äêlevel energy density of 209¬†Wh kg‚àí1 and a high capacity retention of 83.1% after 100 cycles at 25¬†¬∞C. This work provides inspirations for designing advanced electrolytes for practical AFSBs.

item.title: U‚ÄêShaped Dimeric Acceptors for Balancing Efficiency and Stability in Organic Solar Cells
item.content:encoded:
U‚Äêshaped dimeric acceptors, 5‚ÄêIDT and 6‚ÄêIDT, are introduced into the binary OSCs as a third component. The efficiencies of 6‚ÄêIDT‚Äì and 5‚ÄêIDT‚Äêtreated OSCs are significantly improved to 19.32% and 19.96%, respectively. Moreover, the smaller molecular length of 5‚ÄêIDT can well stabilize the phase‚Äêseparated morphology of the active layer, thereby significantly improving the thermal stability.
Abstract Despite significant improvements in power conversion efficiencies (PCEs) of organic solar cells (OSCs), achieving excellent stability remains a great challenge to their commercial feasibility. Here, U‚Äêshaped dimeric acceptors (5‚ÄêIDT and 6‚ÄêIDT) with different molecular lengths are introduced into the binary OSCs as a third component, respectively. The introduction of the third component effectively reduces the energetic disorder and non‚Äêradiative voltage losses and improves the exciton dissociation and charge transport of the devices. Consequently, the PCEs of the 6‚ÄêIDT‚Äê and 5‚ÄêIDT‚Äêtreated OSCs are significantly improved to 19.32% and 19.96%, respectively, which is the highest PCE for oligomeric acceptors‚Äêbased ternary OSCs to date. Meanwhile, the thermal stability of the treated devices is dramatically improved, with the initial efficiency retention of the 6‚ÄêIDT‚Äê and 5‚ÄêIDT‚Äêtreated devices increasing from 18% to 32% and 75%, respectively, after 1000¬†h of thermal stress. This is mainly attributed to the ability of the smaller molecular length of 5‚ÄêIDT to stabilize the phase‚Äêseparated morphology of the polymeric donor and small molecular acceptor, rather than the high glass transition temperature and low diffusion coefficient.

item.title: Supramolecular Scale Hydrophilicity Regulation Enabling Efficient Dewatering and Assembly of Nanocellulose into Dense and Strong Bulk Materials as Sustainable Plastic Substitutes
item.content:encoded:
The dewatering difficulty of nanocellulose dispersion has long been a major challenge hindering its practical utilization. Here, through a supramolecular scale hydrophilicity regulation, the water retention value is substantially decreased and efficient dewatering of cellulose nanofibers (CNF) dispersion is realized, enabling the fabrication of highly dense, strong, fire‚Äêretardant, and moldable CNF bulk materials as sustainable plastic substitutes.
Abstract Cellulose nanofibers (CNFs) are ideal building blocks for creating lightweight and strong bulk structural materials due to their unique supramolecular structure and exceptional mechanical properties within the crystalline regions. However, assembling CNFs into dense bulk structural materials with customizable shape and functionalities remains a great challenge, hindering their practical applications. Here, the dewatering issue of aqueous CNF dispersions is addressed by regulating supramolecular scale hydrophilicity using lactic acid, combined with hot‚Äêpress molding. This approach enables the fabrication of transparent CNF bulk structural materials with a density of up to 1.426¬†g cm‚àí3. The mechanical properties, including isotropic in‚Äêplane tensile strength (75.5 ¬± 4.5¬†MPa), flexural strength (198 ¬± 20¬†MPa), and hardness (‚âà300¬†MPa), surpass most engineering plastics. Moreover, unlike conventional CNF based materials, the CNF bulk structural materials exhibit remarkable water stability and flame retardancy. These unique advantages open a new avenue to bottom‚Äêup assembly of CNFs into high‚Äêperformance multifunctional eco‚Äêfriendly structural materials, dedicating to substitution of plastics and easing the consumption of petrochemical resources.

item.title: Overcoming Energy‚ÄêScaling Barriers: Efficient Ammonia Electrosynthesis on High‚ÄêEntropy Alloy Catalysts
item.content:encoded:
A multi‚Äêelemental synergy strategy for regulating the local electronic structure is applied to create a broad adsorption energy landscape in high‚Äêentropy alloy catalysts. This approach enables optimal adsorption and desorption of various intermediates in the multi‚Äêstep NO3‚àí‚Äêto‚ÄêNH3 conversion, effectively overcoming energy‚Äêscaling limitations for efficient NH3 electrosynthesis.
Abstract Electrochemically converting nitrate (NO3‚àí) to value‚Äêadded ammonia (NH3) is a complex process involving an eight‚Äêelectron transfer and numerous intermediates, presenting a significant challenge for optimization. A multi‚Äêelemental synergy strategy to regulate the local electronic structure at the atomic level is proposed, creating a broad adsorption energy landscape in high‚Äêentropy alloy (HEA) catalysts. This approach enables optimal adsorption and desorption of various intermediates, effectively overcoming energy‚Äêscaling limitations for efficient NH3 electrosynthesis. The HEA catalyst achieved a high Faradaic efficiency of 94.5¬†¬±¬†4.3% and a yield rate of 10.2¬†¬±¬†0.5¬†mg h‚àí1 mgcat‚àí1. It also demonstrated remarkable stability over 250 h in an integrated three‚Äêchamber device, coupling electrocatalysis with an ammonia recovery unit for continuous NH3 collection. This work elucidates the catalytic mechanisms of multi‚Äêfunctional HEA systems and offers new perspectives for optimizing multi‚Äêstep reactions by circumventing adsorption‚Äêenergy scaling limitations.

item.title: Development of Marine‚ÄêDegradable Poly(Ester Amide)s with Strong, Up‚ÄêScalable, and Up‚ÄêCyclable Performance
item.content:encoded:
A novel method for fabricating poly(ester amide)s combines the benefits of biodegradable polyesters and strong polyamides. These materials, made from upcycled monomers, form films, and yarns with a tensile strength of 109 MPa, tenacity of 5.0 g de‚àí1, and withstand ironing temperatures. They achieve 92% marine biodegradability in 12 months and have a low environmental impact.
Abstract Biodegradable polyesters provide an attractive alternative to non‚Äêdegradable plastics but often encounter a tradeoff between biodegradability and mechanical properties because esters are rotational and lack hydrogen bonds. Conversely, natural polyamides, i.e., silk exhibit excellent mechanical strength because amides are non‚Äêrotational and form hydrogen bonds. Unlike esters, the nitrogen in amides can enhance microbial biodegradation. However, protein engineering exhibits limited productivity, and artificial polyamides, i.e., nylon remain non‚Äêdegradable due to their hydrophobic nature. Herein, a method is proposed for developing poly(ester amide)s (PEA)s, a polyester and polyamide hybrid, to address prevailing production challenges. These materials are synthesized from upcycled monomers in a 10 L reactor and converted into films and yarns. They achieve a tensile strength of 109 MPa and tenacity of 5.0 g de‚àí1, while withstanding ironing temperatures. They achieve a remarkable 92% marine biodegradability in 12 months, which is rarely attained by current bioplastics, and exhibit low environmental impact in terms of greenhouse gas emissions. While biodegradable polyesters have remained within the performance range of commodity plastics, PEAs fall into the high‚Äêperformance category, potentially reaching markets that existing biodegradable plastics have not, such as fishing lines and clothing.

item.title: Surface Modification of 3D Biomimetic Shark Denticle Structures for Drag Reduction
item.content:encoded:
Biomimetic shark denticles with alternating superhydrophobic and superhydrophilic regions are fabricated through 3D printing. Superhydrophobic and partially superhydrophobic denticles exhibit superior drag reduction performance compared to superhydrophilic ones by minimizing vortex formation, presenting a novel approach to the biomimetic design of shark denticles for optimal drag reduction.
Abstract Shark skin features superhydrophilic and riblet‚Äêtextured denticles that provide drag reduction, antifouling, and mechanical protection. The artificial riblet structures exhibit drag reduction capabilities in turbulent flow. However, the effects of the surface wettability of shark denticles and the cavity region underneath the denticle crown on drag reduction remain insufficiently explored. Here, 3D printing is utilized to fabricate realistic staggered and overlapped denticle arrays, modified to achieve superhydrophilic, superhydrophobic, and hybrid configurations, including external riblets hydrophilic/internal cavities hydrophobic (ELIB), and vice versa (EBIL). Denticles of varying heights are also fabricated. The results indicate that superhydrophobic, ELIB, and EBIL denticles outperform superhydrophilic ones in reducing drag, achieving a peak drag reduction rate of ‚âà20%. Notably, shorter denticles further improve drag reduction. Reduced vortex formation within the underneath cavity correlates with improved drag reduction. These vortices can function similarly to rolling bearings while facilitating momentum exchange and increasing skin friction drag. Superhydrophobic or partially superhydrophobic denticles (ELIBD/EBILD) mitigate this effect. This study suggests that sharks may secrete mucus on specific sections of their denticles to further reduce vorticity and drag, offering novel insights into the biomimetic design of shark denticles for optimized drag reduction.

item.title: Boosting Amino Acid Synthesis with WOx Sub‚ÄêNanoclusters
item.content:encoded:
By adjusting the size of tungsten oxide cluster through carbon defects, sub‚Äênanoclusters are applied to electrocatalytic C‚îÄN coupling for amino acid synthesis. Unlike nanoclusters, sub‚Äênanoclusters facilitate potential tuning to optimize hydroxylamine yield, enabling the production of diverse amino acids with Œ±‚Äêketo acids. This study offers an innovative perspective for catalyst design in high‚Äêvalue electrosynthesis.
Abstract The conversion of nitrate‚Äêrich wastewater and biomass‚Äêderived blocks into high‚Äêvalue products using renewably generated electricity is a promising approach to modulate the artificial carbon and nitrogen cycle. Here, a new synthetic strategy of WOx sub‚Äênanoclusters is reported and supported on carbon materials as novel efficient electrocatalysts for nitrate reduction and its coupling with Œ±‚Äêketo acids. In acidic solutions, the NH3‚ÄêNH2OH selectivity can also optimized by adjusting the potential, with the total FE exceeding 80% over a wide potential range. After introducing Œ±‚Äêketo acids, the WOx/D‚ÄêCB electrode achieves remarkable activity and selectivity toward C2‚ÄêC6 amino acids. For glycine and alanine, impressive FEs of 49.34% and 38.22% based on transitional metal oxides can be obtained, surpassing those of WOx nanoclusters with larger size. In situ analysis and mechanistic studies reveal the critical role of WOx sub‚Äênanoclusters in reducing the energy barriers of key steps in alanine synthesis. This work opens up new insights into the rational design of cluster catalysts to promote electrochemical amino acid synthesis.

item.title: Hydration Induces Dehydration: Creating Negative Swelling Gel by a Paradox
item.content:encoded:
Negative swelling of hydrogel is achieved via a paradoxical hydration‚Äêinduced‚Äêdehydration pathway. Chemically crosslinked polymer network generates considerable hydrostatic pressure upon swelling, which forces transformable polymers to self‚Äêassemble and collapse. The as‚Äêfabricated gels can lose 35% weight underwater and exhibit water‚Äêstrengthened mechanical properties, enhanced structural responsiveness, underwater repair ability, resistance to deformation, and swelling turn‚Äêoff effect, which significantly broadened potential applications.
Abstract Swelling positively in water is a common behavior of hydrogels, which, however, can lead to reduced mechanical performance and stability. Enabling negative swelling represents a promising way to address those issues but is extremely challenging to realize. Here, real negative swelling hydrogels are successfully prepared for the first time through a unique molecular architecture. Specifically designed interpenetrating transformable‚Äêrigid polymer network undergoes self‚Äêassembly and collapses upon hydration, which in turn dehydrates itself. This paradoxical hydration‚Äêinduced‚Äêdehydration process brings about revolutionary outcomes. Gels can now lose up to 35% weight underwater and exhibit water‚Äêstrengthened mechanical properties, enhanced structural responsiveness, underwater repair ability, resistance to deformation, and swelling turn‚Äêoff effect. Those unique properties allow future material development and applications to be carried out in much broader dimensions.

item.title: An Overview of Flame‚ÄêRetardant Materials for Triboelectric Nanogenerators and Future Applications
item.content:encoded:
This review provides a comprehensive understanding of the role of flame‚Äêretardant materials in enhancing the safety and performance of TENG devices, addressing critical challenges in their design and application. It paves the way for researchers and engineers seeking to develop safer, more reliable energy‚Äêharvesting technologies.
Abstract Triboelectric nanogenerators (TENGs) have gained significant attention for ability to convert mechanical energy into electrical energy. As the applications of TENG devices expand, their safety and reliability becomes priority, particularly where there is risk of fire or spontaneous combustion. Flame‚Äêretardant materials can be employed to address these safety concerns without compromising the performance and efficiency of TENGs. The primary focus of this review is on flame‚Äêretardant materials, including polymers, biomaterials, liquid polymers, aerogels, and carbon‚Äêbased materials. The fundamental properties of these materials for TENG applications are elucidated. The characteristics of each material type are described, along with their potential to boost the safety and performance of TENGs. The importance of flame retardancy in advancing TENG technology can be projected from its usage in wearable electronics, self‚Äêpowered sensors, and smart textiles. Current challenges such as material compatibility, fabrication complexity, and environmental concerns are addressed, along with proposed strategies for overcoming them. This review underscores the significance of flame‚Äêretardant materials in strengthening the functionality and safety of TENG devices, paving the way for their widespread adoption across various industries.

item.title: Negative‚ÄêValent Platinum Stabilized by Pt‚îÄNi Electron Bridges on Oxygen‚ÄêDeficient NiFe‚ÄêLDH for Enhanced Electrocatalytic Hydrogen Evolution
item.content:encoded:
Atomically dispersed Pt anchored in oxygen‚Äêdeficient NiFe‚ÄêLDH via Pt‚îÄNi bonds reduces Pt's valence state, enhancing hydrogen evolution reaction performance. Oxygen vacancies facilitate electron transfer, while elevated Ni valence boosts hydrophilicity and lowers hydrolysis barriers. The catalyst achieves ultra‚Äêlow overpotentials and significantly higher mass activity compared to Pt/C, showcasing a novel coordination design strategy.
Abstract The unique hydrogen adsorption characteristics of negatively charged platinum play a crucial role in enhancing the electrocatalytic hydrogen evolution reaction. However, atomically dispersed Pt atoms are typically anchored to the support through non‚Äêmetallic atom bonds, resulting in a high oxidation state. Here, atomically dispersed Pt atoms are anchored in oxygen‚Äêdeficient NiFe‚ÄêLDH. Electron transfer between Pt and NiFe‚ÄêLDH occurs primarily through Pt‚îÄNi bonds rather than the conventional Pt‚îÄO bonds. Oxygen vacancies in the NiFe‚ÄêLDH promote additional electron transfer from Ni to Pt, thereby reducing the valence state of Pt and enhancing hydrogen adsorption. Meanwhile, the elevated valence state of Ni increases the catalyst's hydrophilicity and reduces the energy barrier for hydrolysis dissociation. This catalyst demonstrates remarkably low overpotentials of 4 and 9¬†mV at 10¬†mA cm‚àí2 in 1¬†m KOH and 1¬†m KPi, respectively. Additionally, its mass activity is 51.5 and 23.7 times higher that of Pt/C, respectively. This study presents a novel strategy for enhancing electrocatalytic performance through the rational design of coordination environments and electronic structures in supported metal catalysts.

item.title: Lean‚ÄêWater Hydrogel with Multipolar Sites for Flexible and High‚ÄêPerformance Aqueous Aluminum Ion Batteries
item.content:encoded:
Herein, a novel inorganic/organic hybrid hydrogel electrolyte is prepared via in situ sol‚Äêgel polymerization. A high ion conductivity is achieved even under a lean‚Äêwater condition. Abundant polar functional groupstend to form hydrogen bonds with water molecules, thereby reducing the hydrogen evolution reaction. This hydrogel electrolyte exhibits excellent performance in both symmetrical Al batteries and full batteries.
Abstract Rechargeable aqueous aluminum ion batteries (AAIBs) offer a promising avenue for achieving safe, high‚Äêenergy, and low‚Äêcost large‚Äêscale energy storage applications. However, the practical development of AAIBs is hindered by competitive reduction reactions in the aqueous solution, which lead to insufficient aluminum (Al) deposition and a severe hydrogen evolution reaction (HRE). In this work, an inorganic/organic hybrid hydrogel with a stable silicon‚Äêbased network and multiple polar sites is successfully fabricated via an in situ sol‚Äêgel polymerization method. The preferential formation of hydrogen bonds between the polar functional groups and water molecules effectively reduces the thermodynamic reactivity of water. Furthermore, X‚Äêray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and time of flight secondary ion mass spectrometry (TOF‚ÄêSIMS) analyses confirm the formation of a stable, inorganic‚Äêrich solid electrolyte interface (SEI) layer, which kinetically suppresses undesirable side reactions. This hydrogel electrolyte exhibits a high ionic conductivity of 2.9 √ó 10‚àí3 S cm‚àí1 at 25¬†¬∞C, even under lean‚Äêwater conditions. As a result, Al|hydrogel|potassium nickel hexacyanoferrate (KNHCF) full cells demonstrate excellent cycling performance, delivering a high initial discharge capacity of 74.9 mAh g‚àí1 at 100 mA g‚àí1 and achieving an outstanding capacity retention of 90.0% after 200 cycles. Additionally, pouch cells exhibit stable open‚Äêcircuit voltage under various mechanical abuse conditions.

item.title: Critical Ingredients Revitalize Magnesium‚ÄêMetal Batteries: Rationality and Challenges
item.content:encoded:
Critical ingredients can revitalize magnesium‚Äêmetal anode in conventional electrolytes. Mechanistic insights, with an emphasis on Mg‚Äêion solvation structure regulation, interfacial evolution, solvent ionization, and weak interfacial passivation, have been especially underscored in terms of the close relationship between electrolyte chemistries and weakly‚Äêpassivated interphase properties.
Abstract Multivalent‚Äêmetal batteries hold tremendous promise in solving safety and sustainability problems encountered by common lithium‚Äêion batteries, but the lack of ideal electrolyte solutions restricts their large‚Äêscale adoption. Tuning electrolyte structures with functional ingredients, especially amines/methoxy‚Äêbased amines and phosphates, can revitalize multivalent‚Äêmetal anodes and high‚Äêvoltage cathodes in conventional electrolytes, unlocking their full potential. However, a rational and clear understanding of the implications of these ingredients, notwithstanding critically important to commercially available electrolyte design, has not been widely accepted. This concise perspective aims to provide timely analysis and discussion on ingredients‚Äô functionalities of solvation shell speciation, interphase evolution, and consequently metal plating/stripping kinetics acceleration. In addition to prevailing coordination interactions, fresh understandings of intermolecular ionization/association and unique interphase formation are underscored by the close relationship between electrolyte chemistries and weakly passivated interphase properties. The existing understandings and proposed outlooks are expected to promote the next breakthroughs for rechargeable multivalent‚Äêmetal batteries.

item.title: Modulation of Near‚ÄêInfrared Afterglow Luminescence in Inorganic Nanomaterials for Biological Applications
item.content:encoded:
Near‚Äêinfrared afterglow luminescent inorganic nanomaterials (NIR‚ÄêALINs) are fascinating due to their optical property of continuing to emit near‚Äêinfrared luminescence after excitation ceases. This review highlights recent progress in the rational design, modulation strategies and biological applications of NIR‚ÄêALINs. The challenges and opportunities in this field are discussed with the aim of stimulating further developments in biological applications using NIR‚ÄêALINs.
Abstract Near‚Äêinfrared afterglow luminescent inorganic nanomaterials (NIR‚ÄêALINs) possess the unique property of continuing to emit near‚Äêinfrared (NIR) luminescence after excitation ceases. They demonstrate excellent photostability, deep tissue penetration, and high imaging signal‚Äêto‚Äênoise ratio (SNR). Additionally, NIR‚ÄêALINs can be re‚Äêexcited in vivo using visible (Vis), NIR light or X‚Äêrays, which avoids the need for continuous in situ excitation, thus eliminating autofluorescence of biological tissues and reducing the tediousness of multiple injections. These features make NIR‚ÄêALINs particularly attractive for biological applications. In recent years, a series of NIR‚ÄêALINs with prolonged afterglow time and enhanced luminescence intensity have been discovered. However, the development of NIR‚ÄêALINs still faces significant challenges, as their NIR afterglow performance is usually insufficient to satisfy practical biological applications. There is still a lack of systematic analysis of the strategies for the regulation of NIR afterglow luminescence in inorganic nanomaterials. This review highlights the rational design and modulation strategies of NIR‚ÄêALINs, focusing on host substrate selection, trap engineering modulation and surface modification. Moreover, the biological applications of NIR‚ÄêALINs in bioimaging, bio‚Äêdetection and disease therapy are summarized. Finally, the present challenges and perspectives in biological applications, such as insufficient afterglow properties and unclear biosafety, are also discussed.

item.title: Skin‚ÄêInspired and Self‚ÄêRegulated Hydrophobic Hydrogel for Diabetic Wound Therapy
item.content:encoded:
A skin‚Äêmimetic smart hydrophobic hydrogel is developed for efficient diabetic wound therapy. Thehydrophobic segments form dense ‚Äúepidermis‚Äù, ensuring prolonged drug diffusion, long‚Äêterm water retention, and high water content. Meanwhile, the responsive segments generate glucose‚Äêlabile ‚Äúsweat pores‚Äù, facilitating on‚Äêdemand drug release to remodel the hostile wound microenvironment.
Abstract Diabetic wounds are refractory and recurrent diseases that necessitate the development of multifunctional dressings. Inspired by the structure and function of the skin, we herein delicately design a novel swollen hydrophobic hydrogel (QL@MAB) composed of hydrophobic methyl acrylate (MA) and (3‚Äêacrylamidophenyl)boronic acid (AAPBA) network and co‚Äêloaded with antioxidant quercetin (Q) and antibiotic levofloxacin (L) for efficient diabetic wound therapy. The hydrophobic MA segments undergo phase separation to form a dense ‚Äúepidermis‚Äù, ensuring prolonged drug diffusion, long‚Äêterm water retention, and high water content. Meanwhile, the AAPBA segments generate glucose‚Äêlabile ‚Äúsweat pores‚Äù via borate ester bonds with the polyphenol drug Q. Upon encountering the hyperglycemic wound microenvironment, the ‚Äúsweat pores‚Äù are dilated due to the cleavage of the borate ester bonds and exposure of the diffusion channel, facilitating drug release for accelerated wound healing. In the infected diabetic rats, QL@MAB achieves rapid wound debridement and re‚Äêepithelization while promoting angiogenesis, hair follicle regeneration, and extracellular matrix remodeling. Taken together, this study not only represents a multipronged dressing for effective interventions of diabetic wounds but also contributes to the rational design of smart hydrogels tailored for biomedical applications.

item.title: Achieving Zero Leakage, Ultralong Lifespan, and Intrinsic Opening Sensing in Microvalves Through Structural Superlubrication and Triboelectric Nanogenerator Technologies
item.content:encoded:
Zero leakage, ultralong lifespan, and intrinsic opening sensing are achieved in microvalves, making it feasible to develop high‚Äêperformance fluid operation chips and integrated drive‚Äêcontrol systems, which promote the miniaturization, integration, and flexibility of pneumatic flexible robots and human‚Äêmachine interaction devices.
Abstract Valves are critical components in advanced fluid control systems (AFCS) and play a vital role in applications such as soft robotics and medical devices. Traditional mechanical valves often suffer from issues such as leakage and wear, which compromise the efficiency and precision of air‚Äêdriven systems. Here, a superlubricity microvalve (SLMV) is developed with characteristics of zero leakage, ultralong lifespan, and self‚Äêsensing capabilities. The SLMV demonstrates zero helium leakage at pressures exceeding 0.9¬†MPa, and remains defect‚Äêfree after one million collision tests and 5000 reciprocating sliding friction tests. Additionally, the valve features self‚Äêpowered sensing that can detect its own open status, and thus enhances the self‚Äêfeedback control. AFCS equipped with SLMVs may significantly improve the flexibility and functionality of pneumatic robots, facilitating the development of implantable drug delivery devices that are more durable, compact, safe, and reliable.

item.title: Machine‚ÄêLearning‚ÄêEnhanced Trial‚Äêand‚ÄêError for Efficient Optimization of Rubber Composites
item.content:encoded:
This study introduces a novel workflow termed machine‚Äêlearning (ML)‚Äêenhanced trial‚Äêand‚Äêerror approach, for efficient optimization of rubber composites. This approach integrates orthogonal experimental design with symbolic regression to proficiently extract empirical principles. This integrated approach not only preserves the features of conventional trial‚Äêand‚Äêerror methodologies but also substantially enhances their efficiency and effectiveness.
Abstract The traditional trial‚Äêand‚Äêerror approach, although effective, is inefficient for optimizing rubber composites. The latest developments in machine learning (ML)‚Äêassisted methodologies are also not suitable for predicting and optimizing rubber composite properties. This is due to the dependency of the properties on processing conditions, which prevents the alignment of data collected from different sources. In this work, a novel workflow called the ML‚Äêenhanced trial‚Äêand‚Äêerror approach is proposed. This approach integrates orthogonal experimental design with symbolic regression (SR) to effectively extract empirical principles. This combination enables the optimization process to retain the characteristics of the traditional trial‚Äêand‚Äêerror approach while significantly improving efficiency and capability. Using rubber composites as the model system, the ML‚Äêenhanced trial‚Äêand‚Äêerror approach effectively extracts empirical principles encapsulated by high‚Äêfrequency terms in the SR‚Äêderived mathematical formulas, offering clear guidance for material property optimization. An online platform has been developed that allows for no‚Äêcode usage of the proposed methodology, designed to seamlessly integrate into the existing experimental optimization process.

item.title: Synchronizing Multicolor Changes and Shape Deformation Into Structurally Homogeneous Hydrogels via a Single Photochromophore
item.content:encoded:
A spiropyran‚Äêderived photochromphore that exhibits a concurrent molecular alteration in fluorescence and charge upon irradiation is reported, which simultaneously enables both photochromic and photodeformable capability upon covalent incorporation into a structurally homogenous hydrogel. The engineered hydrogel system demonstrates synchronized multicolor changes (from red to green) and shape deformation (from positive to negative phototropism) under a single stimulus of light illumination.
Abstract The design of synthetic hydrogels that can mimic their biological counterparts in the simultaneous production of multicolor change and shape transformation in response to environmental stimuli is of great importance toward intelligent camouflage, encryption, and actuation. Previous efforts have focused primarily on developing heterogeneous hydrogels that highly rely on respective mechanisms to achieve color and shape changes separately, and synergistically synchronizing such two variations into structurally homogenous hydrogels via a single chromophore has been challenging. Here, the molecular design of a structurally homogenous hydrogel simultaneously exhibiting synchronized multicolor change and shape deformation triggered by a single stimulus of light is reported. The synchronization mechanism originates from a coupled alteration upon irradiation in the fluorescence emission and charge states of a spiropyran photochromophore covalently incorporated into the hydrogel network, thus leading to macroscale color change and shape variation in the hydrogel, respectively. Following this principle, both positive and negative phototropic deformation are obtained concomitantly with synchronized but flexibly tunable multicolor changes upon light illumination and demonstrated the ingenious application of biomimetic actuation, encryption, and camouflage by the rational combination of these two systems. This work represents an innovative molecular design strategy for developing bioinspired materials with synchronized functions via a single compound.

item.title: Recent Advances in Scalable, High‚ÄêMass Loaded Electrodes for Grid‚ÄêScale Energy Storage
item.content:encoded:
Increased reliance on renewable energy requires enhanced grid‚Äêscale energy storage. The subject of this review, the high mass loading of electrodes, is critical for determining manufacturing costs. Several of the reviewed fabrication techniques surpass the mass loading of conventional electrodes and achieve values above 100¬†mg¬†cm‚àí2. These results represent an important step towards meeting future demands for grid storage.
Abstract The increasing electrification of daily life as well as the intermittent characteristic of renewable energy sources require viable solutions for grid‚Äêscale energy storage. Critical considerations for grid storage applications are electrode mass loading and electrode thickness as these features govern battery pack energy density, an important factor in determining manufacturing costs. For this reason, there is increased interest in finding new ways of creating electrodes with high mass loading. In this review, various high‚Äêmass loading fabrication approaches are considered for positive electrode materials used in batteries. The benchmark used for high mass loading is above 20¬†mg¬†cm‚àí2, which is higher than the practical limit of conventional tape‚Äêcast electrodes. Several different electrode approaches are described including templating, laser patterning, direct ink writing, and electrodeposition. A variety of materials are covered with the most prominent being LiFe(PO4) (LFP), LiCoO2(LCO), and MnO2. In research to date, scalable electrochemical performance has been achieved with mass loadings over 100¬†mg¬†cm‚àí2. Areal capacities as high as 14.7¬†mAh¬†cm‚àí2 at 1.82¬†mA¬†cm‚àí2 have been achieved in non‚Äêaqueous electrolytes and 9.8¬†mAh¬†cm‚àí2 at 10¬†mA¬†cm‚àí2 in aqueous electrolytes. These results establish that the mass loading of electrodes can be scaled up without compromising their electrochemical properties.

item.title: MAPbBr3 Quantum Dots Encapsulated Within Lanthanide‚ÄêMOFs for Time‚ÄêResolved Multicolor Dynamic Anticounterfeiting
item.content:encoded:
Multicolor dynamic anticounterfeiting are achieved by utilizing the quantum‚Äêconfinement effect of MAPbBr3 QDs within the MOFs. This unique anticounterfeiting tag enables high PL intensity and visible recognition to the naked eye and allows for multiple authentications in both time and space dimensions. These results provide valuable insights for designing high‚Äêsecurity, high‚Äêintensity multicolor dynamic anticounterfeiting tags.
Abstract Multicolor dynamic optical materials exhibit significant potential in the realms of anticounterfeiting and information encryption, benefitting from their capacity for generating unpredictable optical information that changes over time. Herein, a novel approach is presented utilizing quantum‚Äêconfinement effect of MAPbBr3 quantum dots (QDs) embedded within lanthanide‚Äêmetal organic frameworks (Ln‚ÄêMOFs) for time‚Äêresolved multicolor dynamic anticounterfeiting applications. The dimensions of MAPbBr3 QDs undergo temporal variations during in situ growth, resulting in dynamic alterations in luminescent color due to the quantum‚Äêconfinement effect. Furthermore, the emission colors of MAPbBr3@Eu‚ÄêMOFs can be modulated by varying UV excitation wavelengths, thereby conferring a spatially distinguishable anticounterfeiting dimension. The time‚Äêresolved unpredictability of these dynamic color changes coupled with sustained luminescent intensity and multi‚Äêdimensional anticounterfeiting, render them suitable system for advanced graphical coding. These findings pave the way for the advancement of intelligent multicolor dynamic optical anticounterfeiting.

item.title: Anomalous Nonlinear Magnetoconductivity in van der Waals Magnet CrSBr
item.content:encoded:
Anomalous nonlinear magnetoconductivity (NLMC) is demonstrated by manipulating internal magnetic orders in van der Waals magnet CrSBr interfaced by hBN layer. The anomalous NLMC presents multiple resistance states governed by both magnetization vector and N√©el vector utilizing the metamagnetic transition of CrSBr. This anomalous NLMC of the engineered CrSBr system promises efficient electrical readout of multiple magnetic information.
Abstract Nonlinear magnetoconductivity (NLMC) is a nonreciprocal transport response arising in non‚Äêcentrosymmetric materials. However, this ordinary NLMC signal vanishes at zero magnetic field, limiting its potential for applications. Here, the observation of an anomalous NLMC controlled by internal order parameters such as the magnetization or N√©el vectors is reported. This response is achieved by breaking both inversion and time‚Äêreversal symmetry in artificial van der Waals heterostructures based on the magnetic CrSBr and insulating hBN. The nonreciprocal signal can be tuned between two different states in ferromagnetic monolayer CrSBr and among four different states in antiferromagnetic bilayer CrSBr, thanks to its metamagnetic transition. Remarkably, this output signal in the ferromagnetic (antiferromagnetic) state of CrSBr is three (one) orders of magnitude higher than those previously measured. A conductivity scaling analysis reveals the Berry connection polarizability as the origin of the anomalous NLMC. The results pave the way for high‚Äêfrequency rectifiers with magnetically switchable output polarity as well as for an efficient electrical readout of the magnetic state of antiferromagnetic materials.

item.title: Morphogenic Growth 3D Printing
item.content:encoded:
I additive manufacturing process exploits the spatial propagation of a polymerization reaction front to produce 3D polymer parts 10√ó faster and 1000√ó more energy efficient ¬†than the fastest stereolithography. In contrast with existing 3D printing, this morphogenic process is inspired by biological ‚Äúgrowth and form‚Äù due to the self‚Äêdirected propagation of the reaction.
Abstract Inspired by nature's morphogenesis, a new 3D printing process ‚Äìgrowth printing (GP)‚Äì takes advantage of a self‚Äêpropagating curing front to produce 3D polymeric parts following a growth‚Äêlike development plan. The propagation of the curing front is driven by the exothermic polymerization of dicyclopentadiene (DCPD), which transforms the liquid resin into a stiff polymer as it propagates at 1 mm s‚àí1. GP is triggered when a heated initiator contacts the uncured liquid resin in an open container. The initiator nucleates the frontal polymerization reaction and the isotropic radial propagation of the growth front. Simultaneously, the initiator is moved up across the free surface of the resin, pulling the cured object out of the uncured resin. The motion trajectory of the initiator with respect to the free resin surface controls the growth morphology of the 3D part. An inverse design algorithm is developed to produce 3D parts by modeling the reaction‚Äêdiffusion‚Äêdriven solidification process. This process has substantial energy savings and high printing¬†speeds.

item.title: Mobile Oxygen Capture Enhances Photothermal Stability of Perovskite Solar Cells Under ISOS Protocols
item.content:encoded:
The SnO2/ZnSb2O6‚Äêx double electron transport layer promotes a highly ordered arrangement of the perovskite lattice, improving film quality and suppressing non‚Äêradiative recombination, which in turn enhances carrier transport and overall device performance. Under photothermal conditions, ZnSb2O6‚Äêx effectively captures oxygen atoms at the SnO2 interface, preventing ion migration and thereby enhancing the photothermal operational stability of PSCs.
Abstract Stability testing protocols from the International Summit on Organic and Hybrid Solar Cell Stability (ISOS) are essential for standardizing studies on the photothermally operational stability of perovskite solar cells (PSCs). Under photothermal conditions, the migration of oxygen from SnO2 layer induces cationic dehydrogenation at the A‚Äêsite of the perovskite, accelerating degradation to PbI2. This leads to the formation of photoinduced I2 and Pb0 defects, significantly compromising long‚Äêterm stability. In this study, ordonezite (ZnSb2O6‚Äêx) as a multifunctional electron transport layer (ETL) that captures migrating oxygen atoms at the SnO2/perovskite interface is introduced, effectively preventing degradation of the buried interface. Additionally, the lattice match between ZnSb2O6‚Äêx and perovskite facilitates well‚Äêordered perovskite film growth. As a result, PSCs featuring ZnSb2O6‚Äêx ETLs achieved a high power conversion efficiency of 25.02% and retained 90.62% of their initial performance after 1000¬†h under the ISOS‚ÄêD‚Äê2 protocol. Furthermore, devices demonstrated remarkable thermal stability, maintaining 83.69% of their original performance after 800¬†h of maximum power point tracking at 85¬†¬∞C, meeting the stringent ISOS‚ÄêL‚Äê2 protocol requirements.

item.title: Programmable Non‚ÄêVolatile Photonic Analog‚Äêto‚ÄêDigital Converter Based on Back‚ÄêEnd‚Äêof‚ÄêLine Compatible Phase‚ÄêChange Materials
item.content:encoded:
This work introduces a programmable photonic analog‚Äêto‚Äêdigital converter (ADC), leveraging phase‚Äêchange materials (PCMs) and foundry‚Äêbased silicon photonics. 2‚Äê and 4‚Äêbit ADCs with zero quantization energy are achieved by the programmable and non‚Äêvolatile nature of PCMs. The photonic ADC can reach a resolution of 8‚Äêbit with 65‚Äêstate PCMs. An all‚Äêoptical analog‚Äêto‚Äêdigital conversion is successfully demonstrated, marking a significant advancement in efficient high‚Äêspeed photonic processing.
Abstract High‚Äêperformance signal processing and telecommunication systems absolutely necessitate analog‚Äêto‚Äêdigital converters (ADCs) that offer extensive bandwidth, exceptional precision, and minimal power consumption, in order to efficiently convert real‚Äêworld analog signals into digital signals. While current electronic ADCs are constrained by limitations such as low bandwidth, high jitter noise, susceptibility to electromagnetic interference, and excessive energy consumption, photonic ADCs¬†present¬†promising solutions to overcome these challenges. Here, a programmable photonic ADC is developed by integrating phase‚Äêchange materials (PCMs) with silicon photonics fabricated using foundry processes. Thanks to the programmability and non‚Äêvolatile nature of PCMs, 2‚Äê and 4‚Äêbit photonic ADCs are demonstrated on a single chip, achieving zero energy consumption during the quantization. Through the experimental demonstration of 65‚Äêstate PCMs, photonic ADCs can attain a resolution of 8‚Äêbit, marking a significant milestone as the highest resolution reported to date for ADCs leveraging optical technologies. As a proof of concept, an all‚Äêoptical analog‚Äêto‚Äêdigital conversion system is demonstrated by integrating 2‚Äêbit photonic ADCs with optical sampling using a mode‚Äêlocked laser (MLL). This system achieves¬†the¬†conversion of a 321¬†MHz radio frequency (RF) signal at a sampling rate of 40 MS¬†s‚àí1. The programmable, energy‚Äêefficient, and high‚Äêspeed photonic ADCs represent a significant advancement in the evolution of signal processing systems.

item.title: Terahertz Spin‚Äêto‚ÄêCharge Conversion in Strontium Iridate‚ÄêBased Magnetic Heterostructures
item.content:encoded:
This work presents a novel system for next‚Äêgeneration spintronic THz emitting sources based on 5d oxides that operate at room temperature. By interfacing a SrIrO3 epitaxial film with ultra‚Äêthin ferromagnetic materials and using femtosecond spin injection THz emission spectroscopy, this system confirms the generation of electromagnetic waves at the THz frequency.
Abstract Oxide interfaces have enormous potential for future electronics with many applications, such as large spin Hall conductance, phase transitions, topological states, and superconductivity. However, previous investigations have predominantly focused on gigahertz frequencies; whilst the possibilities to fabricate devices operational at terahertz frequencies are demonstrated. A model solution is proposed employing 5d rare‚Äêearth, strontium iridate (SrIrO3) heterostructure with cobalt (Co) ultrathin layers. Femtosecond lasers are used to photoexcite the spins in Co, which super diffuse into the SrIrO3 layer to produce an ultrafast inverse spin Hall effect in sub‚Äêpicosecond timescales. The devices exploit the external magnetic field and laser fluence to control the spin polarization from the Co layer and demonstrate a tailored spin Hall effect. These results thus pave paths for next‚Äêgeneration ultrafast oxide electronics offering possibilities for room temperature‚Äêbased devices.

item.title: Multifunctional Terahertz Biodetection Enabled by Resonant Metasurfaces
item.content:encoded:
Testing diverse biomolecules and observing their dynamic interaction in complex biological systems in a label‚Äêfree manner is critically important for THz absorption spectroscopy. A compact and multifunctional THz plasmonic biosensing platform by leveraging multiple interfering resonances from quasi‚Äêbound states in the continuum designed to noninvasively and in situ track the temporal evolution of molecules in multiple analyte systems is proposed.
Abstract Testing diverse biomolecules and observing their dynamic interaction in complex biological systems in a label‚Äêfree manner is critically important for terahertz (THz) absorption spectroscopy. However, traditionally employed micro/nanophotonic techniques suffer from a narrow operating resonance and strong absorption band interference from polar solutions preventing seriously reliable, on‚Äêdemand biosensor integration. Here, a multifunctional THz plasmonic biosensing platform by leveraging multiple interfering resonances from quasi‚Äêbound states in the continuum designed to noninvasively and in situ track the temporal evolution of molecules in multiple analyte systems, is proposed. In contrast to conventional microphotonic sensors, this platform demonstrates substantially broadband performance and reduced footprints, allowing for simultaneous detection of diverse molecular vibrant at multiple spectral points through robust near‚Äêfield interactions. Furthermore, this sensor enables real‚Äêtime analysis of amino acid absorption as water evaporates despite its strong overlapping absorption bands in the THz range. By utilizing the real‚Äêtime format of the reflectance method to acquire a comprehensive spectro‚Äêtemporal data collection, this approach supports developing a deep neural network to discriminate and predict the composition and proportion of multiple mixtures, obviating the need for frequency scanning or microfluidic devices. This approach offers innovative viewpoints for exploring biological processes and provides valuable tools for biological analysis.

item.title: Simultaneous AoLP and DoLP Detection in a Bias‚ÄêSwitchable PdSe2/MoS2/PdSe2 Heterojunction for Polarization Discrimination
item.content:encoded:
A PdSe2/MoS2/PdSe2 vdWH heterostructure polarized photodetector is introduced, which possesses the capability to simultaneously measure both the linear polarization angle and the degree of polarization. This device demonstrates bias‚Äêswitchable polarization detection over a wide spectral range, and exhibits a bipolar photoresponse even at zero bias. Taking advantage of these unique properties, the photodetector has been successfully applied in imaging scenarios and has also been simulated for use in dual coding communication.
